Verumtamen oportet ut fiat illud post euacuationem cum phlebotomia.	However it is necessary that it be done after evacuation with bloodletting.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fluxu sanguins ex arteria in uulnere.	¶ On the manner of cauterizing for a flow of blood from an artery into a wound.
Caput LVIII.	Chapter 58.
Multotiens accidit fluxus sanguinis ex arteria, quae incisa est apud uulnus, quod accidit extrinsecus, aut apud incisionem apostematis, aut cauterium membri, et similia eis: et fit difficile abscindere eum.	A bleeding occurs from an artery which has been cut at the wound, which happens externally, or at the opening of a boil, or the burning of a limb with a cautery, and similar things: and it becomes difficult to sever him.
Cum ergo accidit alicui illud, tunc propera cum manu tua ad orificium arteriae, et pone super ipsum digitum tuum indicem: et stringe eum multum, donec obsessus sit sanguis sub digito tuo, et non egrediatur ex eo aliquid.	So when this happens to someone, then hasten with your hand to the opening of the artery and place your index finger on top of it: and squeeze it a lot until blood is pressed under your finger and nothing comes out from it.
Deinde pone in ignem cauteria oliuaria parua, et magna numero plura: et suffla super ea, donec fiant ignita ualde.	Then place small and large oil-based cauteries in the fire, many in number: and blow on them until they become very hot.
Deinde accipe ex eis unum, aut paruum, aut magnum, secundum uulnus et locum, in quo disrupta est arteria, et depone cauterium super ipsam uenam, post quam tu remoues digitum tuum festinanter: et tene cauterium, donec abscindatur sanguis.	Then take one, small or large, according to the wound and place where the artery has been disrupted, and place the cautery on the vein; after which you quickly remove your finger: and hold the cautery until the bleeding stops.
Quod si expellatur cum eleuas digitum ab orificio arteriae, et extinguis cauterium, tunc accipe cauterium aliud festinanter, ex cauteriis quae in igne sunt praeparata.	But if it is expelled when you lift your finger from the opening of the artery and extinguish the cautery, then take another cautery quickly from those that are prepared by the fire.
Non ergo cesses facere illud cum uno post aliud, donec abscindatur sanguis.	So do not cease to do that with one after the other, until the bleeding stops.
Et caue, ne comburas neruum qui est illic, et accidat super infirmum malicia alia.	And beware, lest you burn the nerve which is there, and another evil occur on the sick person.
Et scias, quod quando ex arteria fluit sanguis, tunc non est possibile abscindere ipsum: praecipue quaudo arteria est magna, nisi cum uno quatuor modorum.	And know that when blood flows from an artery, then it is not possible to stop the bleeding: especially since the artery is large, unless with one of four methods.
Aut cum cauterio, sicut diximus.	Or with a cautery, as we said.
Aut cum extractione, quando non est extracta.	Or by removal, when it has not been removed.
Nam quando extrahitur, contrahuntur extremitates eius, et abscinditur sanguis.	For when it is extracted, its ends contract and the bleeding stops.
Aut ligetur cum filo ligatione forti.	Or it will be tied with a strong binding thread.
Aut ponantur super ipsum medicinae de proprietate, quarum est abscindere sanguinem, et stringatur cum puluinari constrictione decenti.	Or medicines of their own property to stop the blood are placed on it and a compress with a binding constriction is applied.
Qui autem administrat abscisionem eius cum ligamento, et strictura cum panno, aut positione rerum comburentium, et similium, non confert ei penitus, nisi raro.	Whoever administers his incision with a suture, and stitches with cloth or the arrangement of things pressing upon one another, and similar things, does not benefit him at all, unless rarely.
Si autem accidat alicui illud, et non sit ei praesens medicus, neque medicina: tunc incipiat cum positione digiti indicis super orificium uenae ipsius, sicut narrauimus, et constrictione eius ualde, donec obsessus sit sanguis a superiori parte uulneris, et super arteriam.	If however it happens to someone that neither a doctor nor medicine is present: then let him begin with the positioning of the index finger on top of the opening of his vein, as we have mentioned, and constriction thereof very strongly, until the blood from the upper part of the wound becomes stuck and above the artery.
Et digitus non remoueatur, desuper ipsum cum aqua frigida uehementis frigoris semper, donec congeletur sanguis, et ingrossetur, et abscindatur.	And let the finger not be moved, on top of it with cold water from a very icy place always, until the blood congeals and thickens, and is cut.
Et interim consideret in eo, quid indiget ex cauterio, aut ex medicina.	And meanwhile let him consider in himself what he needs from cautery or medicine.
¶ Partis Primae Finis.	End of the First Part.
Liber Chirurgici Albucasis Pars II.	The Book of Surgery by Albucasis, Part II.
¶ De Incisione, Perforatione, et Phlebotomia in uulneribus, et his similibus.	On the incision, perforation, and bloodletting in wounds, and similar things.
Iam Diximus in Capitulo Primo, omnem aegritudinem in qua conueniens est cum igne cauterium et medicina comburente, et occasiones eius, ipsius caussas, et instrumenta eius, et formas cauteriorum.	We have already said in the First Chapter, that every affliction in which a burning cautery and a medicine are suitable to be applied together, and its occasions, its causes, and its instruments, and its forms of cauteries.
Et posui illic capitula a uertice usque ad pedem.	And I have placed there the chapters from the top to the foot.
Et ego procedam in hoc capitulo illa eadem uia: ut alleuietur super quaerentem quaesitum eius.	And I shall proceed in this chapter by the same way, so that relief may be given to him who is seeking it, and his inquiry may be fulfilled.
Et antequam incipiam illud, oportet ut addiscatis o filii, quod in hoc capitulo est ex terrore illud quod est in capitulo primo de cauterizatione.	And before I begin it, my sons, it is necessary that you learn what in this chapter is from fear of the same as in the first chapter about cautery.
Et propter illud oportet, ut sit cautela in eo uehementior, quoniam in operatione quae est in hoc capitulo, multotiens cadit euacuatio cum sanguine, cum quo stat uita apud apertionem uenae, aut incisionem super apostema, aut apertionem exiturae, aut curationem uulneris, aut extractionem sagittae, aut incisionem super lapidem, et illis similia: ex quibus omnibus associatur tremor, et timor, et cadit in pluribus eorum mors.	And because of this it is necessary that there be caution in it more severe, since in the operation which is in this chapter, evacuation often occurs with blood, with which life stands at the opening of a vein, or an incision on an aposteme, or the opening of an exit wound, or the treatment of a wound, or the extraction of an arrow, or an incision over a stone, and similar things: from all of which a tremor and fear arise, and death occurs in many of them.
Et ego moneo uos, ne cadat super uos illud in quo est haesitatio, nam quandoque cadunt ad uos in hac arte modi hominum cum modis infirmitatum.	And I warn you, that it may not fall upon you this thing of doubt, for sometimes falls upon you in this art the manners of men with manners of infirmities.
Ex eis enim est qui irascitur cum aegritudine sua, et est leuis apud eum mors: propter uehementiam eius quod inuenit ex infirmitate sua et longitudine eius maliciei.	For from them is he who is angry with his sickness, and death is light to him: because of the vehemence of that which he finds from his infirmity and the length of his malice.
Et cum aegritudine est ex timore quod significat mortem.	And when sickness is from fear that signifies death.
Et ex eis est, qui dat tibicensum suum, et ditat te cum eo, sperans sanitatem, et aegritudo eius est perniciosa.	And from them is he who gives his physician and enriches you with him, hoping for health, and his sickness is deadly.
Non ergo oportet ut consentiatis ei qui uenit ad uos ex eis, cuius modus est talis.	Therefore it is not fitting that you should agree to him who comes to you of this sort, whose manner is such.
Et sit cautela uestra uehementior, quam cupiditas et uestra rapacitas.	And let your caution be more vehement than your greed and your avarice.
Et non praesumatis super aliquid ex illo, nisi post scientiam certam, quae uerificat apud uos illud ad quod peruenit successio laudabilis.	And do not presume over anything from him, unless after certain knowledge which verifies to you that thing to which comes a praiseworthy outcome.
Et utimini in curatione omnium infirmorum uestrorum, prognosticatione et indicatione de eo ad quod conuenienter sit salus.	And take care in the treatment of all your sick patients, with prognosis and indication of that to which it is fitting for them to be saved.
In illo namque est uobis adiutorium super acquisitionem famae et gloriae, et memoriae et laudis.	For in this indeed is aid to you towards the acquisition of reputation and glory, and memory and praise.
Inspiret uobis Deus o filii, intellectum suum, et non auferat uobis directionem et inspirationem: quoniam illud est in manu eius.	May God inspire you, O sons, with his understanding, and not take away from you direction and inspiration: for it is in his hand.
Et ego quidem ordinaui hoc Capitulum distinguendo per capitula, secundum quod praecessit in capitulo Cauterii, a ceruice usque ad pedes: ut alleuietur uobis quaesitum quod uultis ex eo, et quo indigetis.	And I myself have arranged this Chapter distinguishing by chapters, according to what preceded in the chapter on Cauterization, from head to feet: so that it may be alleviated for you the thing which you seek from it and wherein you are in need.
¶ De curatione Aquae quae aggregatur in capitibus puerorum.	About the cure of water that is accumulated in the heads of boys.
Caput I.	Chapter I.
Scias, quod haec infirmitas multotiens accidit pueris apud partum: aut quando stringit obstetrix caput pueri absque leuitate.	Know that this illness often happens to boys at birth: or when the midwife constricts the boy's head without gentleness.
Et quandeque accidit etiam ex caussa occulta quae non scitur.	And whenever it happens even from a hidden cause which is not known.
Et ego quidem non uidi hanc aegritudinem in aliis quam in pueris: et ad omnem quem ex eis uidi properauit mors: propter illud ergo uisum est mihi dimittere operationem in ea.	And I myself have not seen this affliction in any others except in children, and death has hastened for all whom I saw. Therefore it seemed to me to abandon the treatment of it.
Et ego quidem uidi ex eis puerum, cuius caput impletum erat aqua, et caput magnificabatur in omni die, donec non poterat sedere super seipsum, propter magnitudinem capitis sui: et humiditas augmentata fuit, donec mortuus est.	And I myself have seen a boy whose head was full of water, and his head swelled every day until he could not sit up on account of the magnitude of his head. And the moisture increased until he died.
Et haec quidem humiditas, aut aggregatur inter cutem et os: aut aggregatur sub osse super sifac.	And this moisture indeed either accumulates between the skin and bone, or it accumulates under the bone above the ear.
Et operatio in illo, si est humiditas inter cutem et os, et apostema est paruum, tunc oportet ut findas in medio capitis fissura una in latitudine: et sit longitudo fissurae quasi duo nodi, donec currat humiditas.	And the operation on him, if there is moisture between the skin and bone and an abscess is small, then you must make a cut in the middle of the head with one incision from side to side: and let the length of the incision be as long as two knots, until the moisture runs.
Et haec est forma spatumilis.	And this is the shape of a spatula.
Si ergo humiditas est magis augmentata, et apostema est maius, tunc pone eas duas fissuras, secundum formam hanc.	If therefore the moisture is more increased and the abscess is greater, then make two incisions like these.
Et si humiditas est sub osse, et signum eius est, quod uides commissuras capitis apertas ab omni parte: et aqua deprimitur quando comprimis eam manu tua ad interiora, et non occultatur tibi illud: tunc oportet ut findas in medio capitis tribus fissuris, secundum hunc modum.	And if the moisture is under the bone, and its sign is that you see the folds of the head open on all sides, and the water presses down when you press it with your hand to the inside, and it does not conceal itself from you: then you must make three incisions in the middle of the head, in this manner.
Et post incisionem extrahe humiditatem totam.	And after making the incision draw out all the moisture.
Deinde stringe fissuras cum pannis et puluillis.	Then tie the incisions with bandages and lint.
Deinde embroca illud desuper cum uino et oleo usque ad diem quintum.	Then bind it over with wine and oil from above until the fifth day.
Deinde solue ligamentum, et cura uulnus cum tentis, et unguentis.	Then untie the bandage and care for the wound with threads and ointments.
Et non dimittas stringere caput cum aequalitate.	And do not neglect to bind the head with ligatures.
Et ciba infirmum omni cibo sicco paucae humiditatis, usquequo confortetur membrum, et sanetur.	And feed the weak person with all dry food of little moisture until the limb is comforted and healed.
Et modus alius incisionis est, ut consideres ubi apparet magnitudo apostematis, et collectio aquae.	And another method of making an incision is, that you consider where it appears in what magnitude the swelling is, and the collection of water.
Quoniam quandoque est in occipitio plus, aut in sincipite, aut in dextra, aut in sinistra.	Because sometimes it is more on the back of the head, or on the forehead, or on the right side, or on the left.
Ascende ergo cum incisione ubi apparet tibi apostema et impletio aquae: et scinde illud secundum quod tibi possibile est.	So ascend with an incision to where you see the swelling and collection of water, and cut it as far as is possible for you.
Et obserua, ne incidas arteriam, et accidat fluxus sanguinis, et moriatur infirmus ex illo fluxu cum euacuatione humiditatis.	And observe so that you do not cut the artery and a flow of blood occurs, and the patient dies from that hemorrhage with the evacuation of moisture.
¶ De incisione Arteriarum quae sunt post aures.	Concerning the incision of arteries which are behind the ears.
Caput II.	Chapter II.
Quando accidunt alicui catarri ad oculos, aut ad pectus, et antiquatur illud, et non confert curatio medicinarum: tunc magis ultima curatio est in illo, incisio harum duarum arteriarum.	When there occurs a swelling to the eyes or to the chest, and it is inflamed, and medical treatment does not bring relief: then the last treatment for this is an incision of these two arteries.
Oportet ergo quando uis incidere eas, ut radat infirmus caput suum.	You must therefore when you wish to cut them, so that the sick person may scratch his head.
Deinde frica locum cum panno aspero, ut appareant arteriae.	Then rub the place with a rough cloth, so that the arteries may appear.
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum, cum quolibet panno suo.	Then the sick person should bind his neck with any of his cloths.
Deinde considera, ubi pulset uena.	Then look where you may feel the pulse in the vein.
Et loca utriusque sunt loca quae sunt post aures depressa: et raro occultatur, nisi in quibusdam hominibus.	And those places of both are the places that are behind the ears depressed: and they are rarely hidden, except in some people.
Deinde signa cum encaustro super utraque: et incide utramque cum spatumili utrimque acuro, incisione perueniente ad os: et fiat illud per latitudinem capitis.	Then mark with wax on both, and cut both with a spatula from both sides carefully, the incision arriving at the mouth, and let it be that way by the width of the head.
Et si uis, intromitte spatumile sub arteria, et incide eam ad superiora cum incisione.	And if you wish, insert the spatula under the artery, and cut it upwards with the incision.
Et sit longitudo incisionis quasi duo digiti iuncti.	And let the length of the incision be as two joined fingers.
Nam quando inciditur uena, egreditur sanguis egressione pulsatili, qui salit ad interiora saltu frequenti.	For when the vein is cut, blood issues forth with a pulse-like emission, which leaps within frequently.
Si autem arteria non apparet sensui, tunc oportet ut mensures ab aure quantitatem spacii trium digitorum.	If however the artery does not appear to sense, then it is necessary that measurements be taken from the ear of the space of three fingers.
Deinde signa cum encaustro, et finde usque ad os.	Then mark with encaustic and search until the mouth.
Et illud quod oportet emittere ex sanguine, est VI uncia et fortasse emittis ex eo plus, aut minus.	And what needs to be let out of blood is six inches, and perhaps you let out more or less from it.
Totum illud secundum quantitatem quae apparet tibi ex uirute infirmi et repletione arteriae eius.	The whole thing according to the quantity that appears to you from the weakness of the patient and the filling of his artery.
Deinde considera ad uulnus.	Then consider towards the wound.
Tunc si remanet ad os ex sifac aliquid, tunc incide illud, ut non accidat apostema calidum: tunc stringe uulnus cum liciniis ex panno lini.	Then if something remains at the bone from seepage, then cut it so that a warm gangrene may not occur; then tie the wound with ligatures of linen cloth.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then care for him with an ointment until he heals.
¶ De extractione arteriarum, quae sunt in timporibus.	Concerning the extraction of arteries which are in wounds.
Caput III.	Chapter III.
Quando accidit homini hemicranea antiqua, aut catarri acuti propter humiditates acrimoniales, et caliditate in lacertis timporum, aut soda antiqua, uehemens, et similia illis: et medicatur cum modis curationis medicinae, et non confert illud: tunc experti sumus in his aegritudinibus extractionem arteriarum ex timporibus, aut cauterizationem earum, sicut narrauimus.	When an old hemicrania or acute catarrah occurs in man on account of acidic humidities and heat in the arteries of wounds, or old soda which is gentle and similar to these: and it is treated with the modes of medical cure, and no benefit is conferred by this: then we are experienced in these afflictions that extraction of the artery from the wound, or cauterization of them, as we have narrated.
Et modus operationis in extractione earum, est, ut radat infirmus pilos qui sunt in timporibus, et intendat ad arteriam apparentem in timpore.	And the method of the operation in their extraction is that the patient must shave the hairs which are in the wound, and extend to the artery appearing in the wound.
Ipsa namque ostenditur tibi ex pulsu suo, et raro occultatur nisi in paucis hominibus, aut uehementia frigoris.	For it itself is shown to you from its pulse, and it rarely conceals itself unless in a few men or in great coldness.
Quod si occultatur tibi, tunc stringat infirmus caput suum cum quolibet panno suo: deinde frica locum cum panno aspero.	If it conceals itself from you, then the patient should tie his head with any of his cloths; afterwards scrub the place with a rough cloth.
Aut uapora locum cum aqua calida, donec appareat tibi apparitione manifesta.	Or warm the place with hot water until it appears to you in clear appearance.
Deinde accipe spatumile, quod paulo ante formaui.	Then take a spatula which I formed a little while ago.
Deinde excoria cum eo cutem cum facilitate, donec peruenias ad arteriam.	Then peel off with him the skin with ease until you reach the artery.
Deinde proiice in eam uncinum, et extrahe eam ad superiora, donec extrahas eam ex cute, et facias eam euadere ex tunicis quae sunt sub ea ab omni parte.	Then insert a probe into it and draw it upwards until you extract it from the skin and make it escape from all the tunics that are under it.
Si autem arteria est subtilis: tunc inuolue eam cum extremitate uncini.	But if however the artery is thin, then wrap it around with the extremity of the probe.
Deinde incide ex ea partem secundum quantitatem qua elongentur extremitates eius, et contrahantur, et non accidat fluxus sanguinis.	Then cut out from it a part according to the size in which its extremities stretch and contract, so that there may not be a flow of blood.
Nam si non inciditur, et si non abscinditur, non ascendit sanguis penitus.	For if it is not cut and if it is not severed, the blood does not rise up completely.
Deinde euacua ex sanguine ana VI unci, usque ad .III.	Then drain out six ounces of blood up to three.
Quod si arteria est magna: tunc oportet ut liges eam in duobus locis ex filo duplo, forti, ex serico: aut ex chordis alhohod, ut non properet ad ipsam putrefactio ante consolidationem uulneris, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	Which if the artery is great, then it is necessary that you bind it in two places with thread double, strong, from silk: or from cord of hippopotamus, so that the putrefaction does not rush to it before the consolidation of the wound, and a flow of blood occurs.
Deinde incide superfluitatem, quae est inter duo ligamenta.	Then cut away the superfluity which is between the two ligatures.
Fac illud in illa hora, aut post horam aliam.	Do that at that hour, or after another hour.
Et si uis, cauteriza eam cauterio usque ad os, cum cauterio cultellari: donec incidantur extremitates eius, et stabit loco eiusdem operis.	And if you wish, cauterize it with a cautery up to the bone, with a knife-like cautery, until its extremities are cut and remain in place as is the same work.
Et est melius opus, nisi si infirmus habet febrem, autest calefactae complexionis.	And it is better work, unless the sick person has a fever or a warm complexion.
Quoniam cauterium est ex eis, quae iuuant ad finiendas humiditates.	Because the cautery is from things that help to dry up humors.
Ergo est melius iuuamentum.	So it is a better treatment.
Et oportet post extractionem arteriarum, ut impleatur locus cotto antiquo: et ponantur super ipsum puluilli decenter facti.	And it is necessary after the removal of arteries, that the place be filled with old catgut and well-made poultices be put on top.
Et post solutionem curetur cum medicinis siccis, quae faciunt nasci carnem, et cum liciniis, donec sanetur.	And after the suppuration it should be treated with dry medicines that make flesh to grow and with liniments until it heals.
Quod si interim dum operaris accidit fluxus sanguinis ex arteria, tunc propera ad abscindendum eum cum cauterio, aut ut impleas locum cum zegi: et stringe manum tuam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	Which if in the meantime while you are operating a flow of blood occurs from the artery, then hasten to cut it off with a cautery, or that you fill the place with zege and bind your hand until the blood is cut off.
Quod si nihil ex illis est tibi praesens, tunc pone super locum digitum tuum, donec congeletur sanguis.	If there is nothing among these remedies present for you, then place on top of the place of your finger until the blood coagulates.
Et embroca locum cum aqua uehementis frigoris, donec quiescat acuitas, et stringatur secundum quod oportet.	And bind up the place with water of very cold heat, until the sharpness ceases and becomes tightened as it should.
Et ex eo quod est leuius et facilius extractione arteriae, est, ut cauterizes uenam cum hoc cauterio habente duos cultellos: sitque acuitas duorum cultellorum similis almagdatem.	And from that which is lighter and easier in the extraction of the artery, this is, that you cauterize the vein with a cautery having two knives: and let the sharpness of the two knives be similar to that of an emerald.
Verumtamen sunt multo minoris acuitatis, quam duo cultelli.	However they are much less in sharpness than two knives.
Quoniam si sunt acutae, sicut duo cultelli, properat utrisque frigus: et non incidunt carnem cum uelocitate.	Because if they are sharp, like two knives, the cold rushes to both quickly: and they do not cut the flesh with speed.
Cum ergo in eis est aliquantulum grossitudinis, tenetur in eis calor ignis, et abscinditur caro uelociter: cum hoc ergo opus est melius omni opere, et leuius, et facilius.	Therefore since there is a little thickness in them, heat of fire remains in them and the flesh is cut quickly with this therefore it is better than any work, and easier, and more readily done.
Et sit spacium quod est inter duos cultellos quantitas grossitudinis digiti, postquam tu signas duo loca cum encaustro: et depone utrosque ignitos ualde, donec perueniant ad os, et incidant uenam in duobus locis: ut elongetur quod est inter extremitates eius.	And let the space that is between the two knives be the thickness of a finger, after you mark two places with encaustic, and lay them both burning very hot until they reach the bone, and cut the vein in two places: so that what is between its extremities is lengthened.
Nam non consolidantur cum hoc cauterio penitus.	For they are not completely closed with this cautery.
Et haec est forma cauterii.	And this is the shape of the cautery.
¶ De cura cursus lachrymarum acutarum assiduarum ab oculis.	Concerning the care for a constant flow of sharp tears from the eyes.
Caput IIII.	Chapter IV.
Quando sunt lachrymae assiduae, et est cursus earum ex uenis, quae sunt super craneum capitis exterius: et non confert in eis aliquid curationis medicinae cum medicinis, et uides faciem infirmi iam rubere, et sentit in fronte sua deambulationem, sicut est deambulatio formicarum: et oculi eius sunt extenuati, humidi, ita quod iam corrosi sunt pili eorum cum corrosione: et calefactae sunt palpebrae eius ex acuitate lachrymarum: tunc antiqui indiguerunt in curatione earum hac operatione, et denominauerunt eam curationem, cum Ense.	When there is a constant flow of tears and the course of them comes from the veins that are over the outer part of the head: and no care of medical cure comes to them with medicines, and you see the face of the infirm person already red, and they feel on their forehead a wandering, as if it were the walking of ants: and their eyes are emaciated, moist, so that the hairs around them have been eaten away by corrosion: and their eyelids are heated from the sharpness of the tears: then the ancients needed in curing them this operation, and they called it the cure with a needle.
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo radere pilos qui sunt in fronte sua.	And you should order the patient to shave the hairs that are on his face.
Deinde incide in fronte tres fissuras aequedistantes secundum longitudinem frontis: et sit longitudo fissurae quasi duo digiti, et fissura una sit aequedistans longitudini nasi in medio frontis, et secunda secundum longitudinem parumper a motu lacertorum, et tertia a parte altera: et caue ab incisione arteriarum quae sunt in duobus lateribus: et elonga manum tuam a continuatione duarum mandibularum, et sit spacium omnis incisionis quantitas trium digitorum coniunctorum: et sit tibi frustum spongiae praeparatum, aut panni siccati multi, cum quibus exsicces sanguinem.	Then you should cut three incisions on the face equally spaced according to the length of the face: and the length of each incision should be almost two fingers long, and one incision should be equally distant from the middle of the nose in the center of the forehead, and the second incision should be according to the length a little above the movement of the arm, and the third equally distant on the other side: and beware of cutting the arteries which are on both sides. And stretch out your hand along the continuation of the two jaws, and let the space of all the incisions be the length of three joined fingers. And have a piece of sponge prepared for you, or many dry cloths with which to stanch blood.
Deinde intromitte spatumile duarum acutarum extremitatum, cuius mox sequens est forma.	Then insert the spatula of the two sharp-edged ends, whose form will soon follow.
Ab incisione quae est a parte timporis, usque ad incisionem secundam: et excoria cum eo totam cutem, quae est inter duas incisiones, cum sifac, quod est super os.	From the incision that is on the side of the eyebrow, as far as the second incision: and scrape off with it all the skin that is between the two incisions, along with the Siffak, which is above the eye.
Deinde fac illud etiam ab incisione media usque ad incisionem secundam.	Then do this also from the middle incision as far as the second incision.
Deinde extrahe hoc spatumile, et intromitte in incisionem primam iterum instrumentum aliud, quod nominatur cultellare acutum, ab una parte lene, non acutum ab altera parte.	Then pull out this spatula and insert into the first incision again another instrument which is called a sharp knife, from one side smooth, not sharp on the other side.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its shape.
Et pone latus eius acutum uersus carnem annexam cum cute, et latus eius lene uersus os: et impelle ipsum, donec perueniat ad fissuram mediam: et abscinde cum eo omnia uasa, quae descendunt a capite ad oculos: praeter quod continuetur incisio usque ad illud quod apparet de cute.	And place the sharp edge of it against the attached flesh along with the skin, and the smooth side against the bone: and push it until it reaches the middle incision: and cut off with it all the veins that go from the head to the eyes: except that the incision continue up to what appears on the skin.
Deinde fac illud in fissura media usque ad fissuram aliam.	Then do this in the middle incision as far as the other incision.
Et postquam currit ex sanguine quantitas aequalis, exprime loca ex frustis sanguinis coagulati.	And when an equal quantity of blood has flowed out, press out the places from clots of congealed blood.
Deinde pone in omnem fissuram licinium ex cotto ueteri, et pone super eos puluillos imbibitos in uino, et oleo, aut aceto.	Then place linen from old clay on every split and put over them poultices soaked in wine, oil or vinegar.
Et uide ut non accidat apostema calidum.	And be careful that no hot abscess may occur.
Et in die tertia solue ligamentum, et administra infusionem multam cum aqua tepida.	And on the third day dissolve the ligament and administer a strong infusion with warm water.
Deinde cura illud ex unguento basilicon, et reliquis quibus curantur uulnera: usquequo sanetur.	Then treat it with balsam ointment and other things by which wounds are healed; until it heals.
¶ De cura lachrymarum acutarum et catarrorum ad oculos ex interioribus capitis.	On the cure of sharp tears and catarrhs to the eyes from internal parts of the head.
Caput V.	Chapter 5.
Quando accidunt alicui catarri acuti, acres, assidui: et uides oculos eius extenuatos, paruos, et iam debilitatus est aspectus eorum: et palpebrae ulceratae, et cadunt pili ex eis, et in profundo capitis est dolor acutus, laedens, et sternutatio consequens: tunc sume ex istis accidentibus, quod illae materiae, et catarri non ueniunt, nisi ex uenis multis.	When sharp, acute, constant catarrhs occur to someone, and you see that their eyes are emaciated, small, and already weakened in appearance: and the eyelids are ulcerated, and hairs fall from them, and there is a sharp, piercing pain in the inner part of the head, causing sneezing: then take note of these accidents, that those materials and catarrhs do not come, unless from many veins.
Et melior curatio in eis est haec.	And their better cure is this.
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo radere frontem suam.	And it is, to have the patient shave his forehead.
Deinde incide in eam fissuram unam in medio frontis, aut alterius parumper per latitudinem, et incipe cum fissura a timpore sinistro ad timpus dextrum: et sit incisio usque ad os: et elonga manum tuam a lacertis timporum, qui mouentur apud masticationem: donec quando detegitur os: et exsiccabis totum sanguinem cum spongia.	Then make an incision in it, one wound in the middle of the forehead, or another a little to the side, and start with the left side to the right: and let the incision be up to the bone: and extend your hand from the elbows of the temples which move at mastication: until when the bone is uncovered: and dry out all the blood with a sponge.
Tunc separa inter duo labia fissurae cum cotto ueteri, aut cum liciniis ex lino.	Then separate between the two lips of the wound with old clay or with linens from linen.
Deinde stringe desuper cum puluillis: et imbibe puluillos cum uino et oleo, ut non accidat apostema calidum.	Then bind it on top with poultices and soak the poultices with wine and oil, so that no hot abscess may occur.
Et quando soluis illud, et uides quod apostema calidum iam imminuitur: tunc oportet ut frices os, donec incipiat in eo nasci caro.	And when you dissolve it and see that the hot abscess is already decreasing: then it is necessary to rub the bone until flesh begins to grow there.
Deinde cura ipsum cum regimine exiccatiuo quod facit nasci carnem: sicut si accipias ex farina tritici partes duas, et ex colophonia quatuor partes: et praepares ex eis emplastrum, et administretur ad natiuitatem carnis in istis uulneribus.	Then the treatment of this with a regimen of excitation that makes flesh grow: as if you take two parts from wheat flour and four parts from colophony, and prepare from them an ointment, and it is administered at the birth of flesh in these wounds.
¶ De cura eius quod cadit in Aurem.	Regarding its cure which falls into the ear.
Caput VI.	Chapter 6.
Omne Quod in Aurem cadit, est una quatuor specierum: aut lapis mineralis, aut simile lapidi, sicut ferrum, et uitrum: aut est ex planta, sicut est cicer, et fabae: aut est res fluxibilis, sicut aqua, et acetum, et eis similia: aut aliquod animal.	All that falls into the ear is one of four kinds: either a mineral stone, or similar to a stone, as iron and glass; or it is from a plant, such as chickpeas and beans; or it is a flowing thing, as water and vinegar and things like them; or some animal.
Quando ergo cadit in aurem lapis, aut genus lapidis ex eis quae non adduntur, neque crescunt in aure, expone Aurem soli: si ergo uides lapidem, tunc distilla in Aurem aliquid ex oleo uiolato, aut sisamino.	When therefore a stone falls into the ear, or a kind of stone from among those that do not add or grow within the ear, expose the ear to the sun: if then you see the stone, then distill something from violet oil, or siseum [sesame] into the ear.
Deinde administra extractionem eius, et fac sternutare cum condisi, et opila nares apud aduentum sternutationis, postquam tu ponis in circumitu auris frusta ex pannis, aut lana, et extendis aurem ad superiora.	Then administer an extraction of it [the stone] and make him sneeze with a condiment, and stop up his nostrils near the arrival of sneezing, after you have placed fragments of cloths or wool around the ear, and stretched out the ear upwards.
Multotiens enim egreditur cum hac cura.	For often it exits with this cure.
Si autem non egreditur, tunc administra extractionem eius cum Gesti, id est, Pizigarolis subtilibus: cuius forma est haec.	But if it does not exit, then administer an extraction of it with gesti, that is, fine pomegranate rinds; its form is this.
Si ergo egreditur cum gesti, est bonum.	And so if it exits with the gesti, it is good.
Et si non, tunc administra extractionem eius cum uncino caeco subtili paucae duplicationis.	And if not, then administer an extraction of it with a thin blind thread of fine silk.
Si ergo non egreditur per illud, tunc fac cannulam ex aere, et intromitte extremitatem cannulae in foramen auris multum, et opila quod est in circumitu cannulae cum caera mollificata cum oleo, ut non sit uento uia nisi cannulae: deinde extrahe cum uento tuo attractione forti.	And if it does not exit through that [gesti or thread], then make a tube of air and insert the end of the tube into the ear opening very much, and stop up what is around the tube with softened wax with oil, so that there is no passage for wind except the tube: then draw it out with your own breath, using strong suction.
Multotiens enim egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus.	Therefore it frequently comes out with him as we have said.
Si autem non egreditur hoc modo: tunc accipe ex helkalimbat, aut ex uisco, id est, gluten praeparato, cum quo capiuntur aues, rem modicam: et pone ipsum in extremitate radii postquam tu inuoluis super eam cotum decenter positum: deinde intromitte ipsum in foramen auris cum facilitate, postquam tu exiccas aurem ab humiditate.	But if it does not come out this way then take from the bird lime or from vetch, that is a prepared gluten with which birds are caught, a small amount: and place it at the end of the beam after you have wrapped over it a cloth placed decently: then insert it into the ear canal with ease, after you have dried the ear of moisture.
Si ergo non egreditur cum omnibus quae narrauimus, tunc propera ad scindendum, antequam accidat apostema calidum, aut spasmus.	Therefore if it does not come out with all that we have said, then hasten to cut into it, before a warm abscess or spasms occur.
Et modus fissurae est, ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis in cephalica: et extrahe ei ex sanguine secundum mensuram uirtutis eius.	And the manner of making an incision is, that as a barbers cut the hair on the head first, and draw from it according to its strength.
Deinde fac sedere infirmum inter manus tuas, et conuerte aurem eius ad superiora, et finde fissuram paruam in radice auris apud adipem eius in loco depresso ipsi: et sit fissura lunaris figurae, donec peruenias ad lapidem: deinde aufer eum cum eo, quod est tibi possibile ex instrumentis.	Then have the patient sit between your hands, and turn his ear upwards, and make a small incision in the root of the ear near the fat there in a depressed place itself, in the shape of a crescent moon, until you come to the bone: then remove it with that which is possible from instruments.
Deinde sue fissuram ab hora tua cum uelocitate, et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	Then close the incision with your hand quickly and take care of it until it heals.
Quod si res cadens in aurem est ex uno granorum, quae crescunt, et inflantur: tunc administra extractionem eius.	But if there is a thing falling into the ear from one grain which grows and swells: then administer its removal.
Si autem non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc accipe spatumile tenue, subtile, secundum hanc formam.	But if it does not obey you to come out, then take a thin, subtle spatula according to this shape.
Et administra cum eo abscisionem illius speciei ex granis, quae cadunt in aurem, et non facias illud, quando tu cogitas, quod illud granum iam humectatum est per uaporem auris, donec ponis ipsum frusta multa: deinde extrahe ea cum uncinis, aut cum gesti subtili, aut cum suctione, sicut diximus, nam extractio eius alleuiatur.	And administer with it the removal of that kind of thing from grains which fall into the ear, and do not do this when you think that grain is already moistened by the vapor of the ear, until you put in many tweezers: then draw them out with a hook or with a subtle forceps or by suction, as we said, for the removal of it is eased.
In aqua autem quae ingreditur in aurem, oportet ut utatur infirmus sternutatione cum condisi in primis: et iam impleuit aurem suam cum aliquanto cotto ueteri: et est iacens super illam aurem, in qua est aqua.	But the water which enters into the ear ought to be used by the patient with sneezing after it has been seasoned first, and already filled his ear with a somewhat hot old wine: and he is lying on top of that ear in which is the water.
Si ergo egreditur per illud, est bonum.	If therefore it comes out through that one, it is good.
Et si non: tunc accipe lapides multos, secundum longitudinem digiti, tenues, lenes, et calefac eos cum igne parumper, et intromittat infirmus ex eis unum in foramen auris suae: et saliat super pedem suum unum ex illa parte, et percutiat cum lapide alio super lapidem qui est in aure.	And if not: then take many stones, as long as a finger, thin, soft, and heat them with fire for a little while, and the sick person should insert one of them into his ear hole, and let him urinate over his foot from that side, and strike with another stone on top of the one in his ear.
Non ergo cesset facere illud cum lapide et lapide, donec egrediatur tota aqua.	Therefore he should not stop doing that with stones and stones until all the water comes out.
Et iam egreditur aqua ita, ut accipias ex parpyro, aut ex iunco unum, et intromittas extremitatem eius unam in aurem: et accendas extremitatem alteram cum igne, donec comburatur plurimum eius.	And now water comes out so that you take from a papyrus or a reed one, and insert the end of it into his ear, and burn the other end with fire until much of it is burned.
Deinde itera iuncum alium, et fac illud multotiens, donec egrediatur tota aqua: et extrahe ipsam cum cannula secundum quod praemissum est in lapide.	Then repeat the reed again and do that many times until all the water comes out, and then draw it out with a pipe as was mentioned in the stone.
In extractione autem animalis intrantis in eam, si est parui corporis, ut pulex, et ei simile, cura ipsum sicut dixi in diuisione.	But in the extraction of the living creature entering into it, if it is small in body, such as a louse, and like to it, take care of it just as I said in the division.
Sed si est corporis magni, quod appareat sensui: tunc administra extractionem eius cum gesti, et uncinis: et res eius est facilior omnibus, quae tenentur in aure.	But if it is of a large body that appears to the senses: then administer its extraction with forceps and tweezers: and its removal is easier for all that are held in the ear.
In extractione autem uermis generati in aure, quando curas eum cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et in tractatu distilationum, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut aspicias aurem in sole.	But in the extraction of the worm generated in the ear, when you cure it with that which we said in the division, and in the treatment of distillations, and your care does not help: then it is necessary to look at the ear in the sun.
Si ergo apparet illic aliquid ex uermibus, tunc extrahe illud cum gesti, aut cum uncinis subtilibus.	If therefore something appears there from worms, then draw that out with forceps or with very fine tweezers.
Si autem non apparet illic aliquid, tunc accipe cannulam, cuius haec est forma, stricta inferius, ampla superius: et intromitte extremitatem subtilem in aurem secundum quantitatem quod tolerat eam infirmus: deinde suge cum ea suctione forti.	But if nothing appears there, then take a pipe, of which this is the shape, tight below, wide above: and insert the fine end into the ear according to what the sick person can tolerate: then suck with it strong suction.
Fac illud multotiens, donec egrediantur omnes uermes.	Do that many times, until all worms come out.
Si autem non obediunt tibi ad exitum, tunc opila circumitum cannulae cum caera, sicut dixi in lapide.	If they do not obey you to come out, then a small tube with honey, as I said on stone.
Quod si non egrediuntur cum eo quod diximus: tunc administra distillationes quas iam experti sunt antiqui in interfectione uermium: et inuenies illud in tractatu distillationum.	And if they do not come out with what we said, then administer the distillations which ancient ones have experienced in the removal of worms: and you will find it in the treatise on distillations.
Et sit effusio tua qua effundis olea et medicinas in aurem cum hoc instrumento, cuius forma depicta est hic.	And let your discharge be that which you pour oil and medicines into the ear with this instrument, whose form is depicted here.
Sicut uides fac ipsum ex argento, aut aere, inferius strictum, in quo sit foramen paruum, amplum superius.	As you see, make it from silver or bronze, lower part tightened, with a small hole at the bottom, wider above.
Sit ergo ut impellens quod est in concauitate cannulae, sit ex aere decenter factum.	Let it be so that by pushing what is in the concavity of the tube, it comes out from well-made bronze.
Et si uis, accipe radium, et inuolue in extremitate eius cottum inuolutione decenti: deinde proiice oleum, aut succum, aut quod uis ex istis medicinis in cannulam: et ipsa sit in aure: deinde intromitte radium cum cotto desuper, et exprime ipsum manu tua compressione temperata, donec impellatur oleum in concauitate auditus, et sentiat ipsum infirmus interius: et illud quod infunditur in aurem, sit iam calefactum cum igne parumper: et caue ne sit res quae distillatur in eam frigida ualde: medicinae enim non tolerant illud.	And if you wish, take a reed and wrap in it cotton in a decent wrapping: then pour oil or juice or what you will from those medicines into the tube: and it itself be in the ear: then insert the reed with the cotton on top, and press out by hand with temperate compression until oil flows into the concavity of hearing, and feels it inside the sick person: and that which is poured into the ear, be already warmed up a little with fire: and beware lest what is distilled into it is very cold: for medicines do not tolerate that.
¶ De cura opilationis accidentis Auri.	Concerning the care of the occurrence of goldsmith's burn.
Caput VII.	Chapter VII.
Quandoque egrediuntur quidam infantes ex uentribus matrum suarum non perforati.	And sometimes babies come out through their mothers' wombs unruptured.
Et iam accidit etiam quibusdam hominibus opilatio in meatu Auris a uulnere, aut carne nata in ea.	And it also happens to some people that an obstruction occurs in the ear canal from a wound or a boil in it.
Et haec opilatio quandoque fit in profundo foraminis Auris, quam non consequitur uisus: et quandoque accidit ad exteriora foraminis parum, et consequitur eam uisus.	And this obstruction sometimes occurs in the deep part of the ear canal which cannot be seen, and sometimes it happens to the outer part of the ear canal which can be seen.
Illa ergo quae accidit in profundo Auris, et quam non comprehendit aspectus, est in pluribus dispositionibus difficilis sanationis.	Those things that occur deep within the ear, and which the sight does not comprehend, are often difficult to heal.
Et in illa quam consequitur uisus, oportet ut ponas Aurem infirmi in sole, et aspicias in ea: tunc si uides opilationem apparentem, aperi eam cum spatumili subtili, cuius forma est haec quae sequitur, sit extremitas eius in qua sit quaedam latitudo parua, cuius quaedam pars sit acuta: et reliquum spatumile sit duarum laterum lenium: ut non laedat aurem.	And as for that which results from the sight, it is necessary to place the ear of the infirm person in the sun and look at it. Then if you see a visible blockage, open it with a small thin spatula whose shape is this: its extremity should have a small depth, where there is an acute part, and the rest of the spatule should be two smooth sides so that they do not harm the ear.
Si ergo opilatio est a carne nata in meatu auris: tunc tene eam cum uncino subtili, et incide eam cum facilitate uehementi, donec auferatur tota caro.	Therefore if the blockage is from flesh grown in the ear passage: then take hold of it with a small hook and cut it out with violent facility, until all the flesh is removed.
Quod si opilatio est in profundo auris: tunc accipe radium subtilem, lenem, et calefac ipsum cum igne parumper: deinde mitte ipsum in meatum auris.	And if the blockage is deep within the ear: then take a small thin pointed probe and warm it with fire for a little while. Then insert it into the ear passage.
Si ergo senseris opilationem cum eo, quod inuenit infirmus cum grauitate auditus, conare apertionem eius cum facilitate: et caue, ne uulneres neruos auris.	And if you feel the blockage with it, as the infirm person feels a heaviness of hearing, try to open it with facility: and beware lest you wound the nerves of the ear.
Deinde pone in aurem licinium secundum quantitatem amplitudinis foraminis, quod inuoluisti in unguento aegyptio: fac illud aliquot diebus, donec sis securus de consolidatione uulneris.	Then place a lint in the ear according to the size of the opening that you enveloped with Egyptian ointment. Do this for several days, until you are sure of the wound's consolidation.
Aut accipe licinium, et infunde ipsum in aqua rosata, et pulueriza super ipsum zegi tritum, et utere ipso.	Or take lint and immerse it in rose water, and powder saffron over it, and use it.
Quod si uides aurem iam apostemari: tunc oportet ut extrahas licinium, et permittas ipsum cum licinio alio, quod inuolues in caeroto quod sit factum cum oleo rosato, donec sedetur apostema calidum: deinde cura ipsum usquequo sanetur.	And if you see the ear already to be inflamed: then it is necessary for you to remove the lint and permit it with another cloth which you will wrap in cerate that has been made with rose oil, until the swelling cools down. Then care for it until it heals.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis: tunc submerge spongiam, aut pannos in aqua frigida, et pone super eam aurem: et utere reliqua curatione, quae abscindit fluxum sanguinis praedicta in tractatu distillationum.	And if a bleeding occurs: then submerge a sponge or cloths in cold water and place them over it: and use the remaining cure which stops the flow of blood as described in the treatment of bleedings.
¶ De cura Altheli palpebrarum.	Concerning the care of the eyelids' corners.
Caput VIII.	Chapter Eight.
Isti Althelil qui accidunt in Palpebris oculi, quandoque sunt humidi, et sunt sicci.	These swellings that occur on the eyelids of the eye are sometimes moist and sometimes dry.
Oportet ergo ut teneas eos cum tenaliis: aut cum uncino, et incidas eos cum spatumili a radicibus suis.	Therefore it is necessary to tie them with thread or with a needle, and to cut them off from their roots.
Deinde pone super loca zegi tritum.	Then place powdered vinegar on the places.
Si autem ex eis fluat sanguis, tunc cauteriza eos cum cauterio lenticulari subtili.	But if there is bleeding from them, then cauterize them with a delicate lentil-shaped cautery.
Et cauterizare eos, est melius post incisionem.	And it is better to cauterize them after an incision.
Multotiens enim redeunt quando remanet ex radicibus suis aliquid.	For they often recur when something remains from their roots.
Et quando cauterizantur cum igne, comburuntur illae radices, et non redeunt.	And when they are cauterized with fire, the roots burn and do not recur.
¶ De cura Grandinum palpebrarum oculi.	Concerning the care of the cataracts of the eyelids of the eye.
Caput IX.	Chapter Nine.
Multotiens accidit in palpebris aliquid quod assimilatur Crandini in fortitudine sua, et sua duricie, et propter illud nominatur Grando: et est aggregatio humiditatis grossae in palpebra superiore, et palpebra inferiore.	Often something occurs in the eyelids which is similar in strength and hardness to a cataract, and on account of this it is called a Grandium: and it is a thick gathering of moisture in the upper eyelid and the lower one.
Operatio ergo in eis est, ut consideres tunc, si est Grando procedens in eo, quod apparet de palpebra, et mouentur ad omnem partem, et res eius est facilis.	Therefore the operation in them is to see then if it is a Grandium proceeding from it which appears on the eyelid and moves in every direction, and its nature is easy.
Finde ergo super eam fissura per latitudinem.	Then therefore find an incision over it by breadth.
Deinde excoria eam ab omni parte cum facilitate, donec euadat.	Then peel it off from every part with ease until it comes out.
Deinde suspende eam cum uncino, et abscinde ipsam.	Then hang it with a needle and cut it off.
Si autem non praeparatur tibi abscisio eius, nisi postquam tu penetras palpebram cum incisione parumper, tunc nocet infirmo illud in aliquo.	But if its removal is not prepared for you, unless after you have made an incision into the eyelid a little bit, then it will harm the sick person somehow.
Quod si fissura est magna: tunc aggrega ipsam cum sutura: et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	Which if the incision is great, then sew it up with suture and take care of it until it heals.
Et si est parua, non superueniet tibi malum ex ea.	And if it is small, no harm will come to you from it.
Vnguentum enim restaurat ipsam, et incarnat eam.	The ointment restores it and makes it flesh again.
Et si grando est decliuis ad interiora auris uersus superficiem intrinsecam, tunc inuersa palpebram, et suspende grandinem cum uncino: praeter quod indigeas incisione, et preme eam ab omni parte.	And if the stone is leaning towards the inner ear, towards the internal surface, then turn back the eyelid and hang the stone with a hook; besides which you will need an incision and press it from every side.
Quod si elongatur palpebra per incisionem, non nocet illud in aliquo.	But if the eyelid is stretched by the incision, it will not harm it in any way.
Deinde ablue oculum post incisionem grandinis, cum aqua salsa: et cura locum cum eo quod incarnat, donec sanetur infirmus.	Then wash the eye with salt water after the stone has been cut out, and take care of the place with that which makes it flesh again, until the sick person is healed.
¶ De cura Axirnath palpebrarum.	Concerning the treatment for a swelling of the eyelids.
Caput X.	Chapter 10.
Axirnath est adeps qui generatur in tunicis palpebrae superioris: et plurimum quidem accidit illud pueris: et ipsum grauat oculos eorum, et accidunt eis catarri in matutinis, et non possunt intueri lumen solis, propterea, quod lachrymae properant ad eos, et propter illud uides eos discumbere super facies suas semper, et super eas dormiunt, et sunt palpebrae eorum sub superciliis humidae, quas iam cooperuit inflatio: et eminentia quidem Axirnath apparens est oculo, et quando tu premis locum cum digitis tuis, sentis Axirnath inter eos.	Axirnath is a fatty swelling that arises in the folds of the upper eyelid, and it most commonly occurs in children: and it burdens their eyes, and cataracts occur in them at morning time, and they are unable to look upon the light of the sun, therefore because tears flow towards them, and on this account you see them reclining on their faces always, and sleeping on them, and their eyelids are moist under their eyebrows which have already been overlaid by swelling: and indeed the prominence of Axirnath appears to the eye, and when you press the place with your fingers you feel Axirnath between them.
Et modus operationis eius est, ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	And the manner of operating on it is, that the sick person should lay their head in your lap.
Deinde accipe pannum lini, et praepara in eo licinia, et fac ex illo licinio circulum secundum quantitatem quod continet Axirnath ab omni parte.	Then take a linen cloth and prepare in it lint, and make from this lint a circle according to the size that contains the Axirnath all around.
Deinde pone eum super eam, et preme cum digitis tuis ab omni parte, ut aggregetur Axirnath in medio circuli.	Then place him on it and press with your fingers all around so that the Axirnath is gathered together in the middle of the circle.
Deinde finde in medio illius humiditatis cum spatumili incidente fissuras per latitudinem, et non sit fissura maior illa quae fit in phlebotomia in profundo.	Then prick into the center of that moisture with a splinter, making incisions through its breadth, and let it not be an incision deeper than is done by bloodletting.
Aut oportet ut findas cutem totam, donec peruenias ad Axirnath in pluribus enim dispositionibus procedit Axirnath ex fissura secundum formam frusti pinguedinis albae.	You should find the skin to be intact, until you reach Azarnath; for indeed it proceeds from a fissure according to the shape of white fatty tissue.
Extrahe ergo eam cum panno, quem infiltrasti inter digitos tuos ad exteriora: et tu reuoluis manum tuam ad dextram et sinistram, donec dispergatur: et caue, ne addas in fissura, ut non peruenias cum spatumili ad oculum, et laedas eum.	Therefore draw it out with a cloth which you have infiltrated between your fingers on the outside; and turn your hand to the right and left until it disperses: and beware that you do not add anything in the fissure, lest you reach the white part of the eye and harm it.
Si autem non appareat tibi Axirnath in principio fissurae, tu addas in fissura parum cum facilitate, donec procedat Axirnath.	But if however Azarnath does not appear to you at the beginning of the fissure, then you should add a little into the fissure with ease until it proceeds.
Deinde extrahe eam, sicut diximus.	Then draw it out, as we have said.
Deinde submerge pannos in aceto et aqua, et pone eos super locum, et stringe eum cum puluillis.	Then soak the cloths in vinegar and water, and place them on the place, and bind it with bandages.
Et ex hominibus sunt qui terunt salem, et ponunt ipsum in concauitate fissurae, ut liquefiat quod remansit ex illa humiditate.	And there are men who rub salt and place it in the concavity of the fissure, so that what remains of moisture may dissolve.
Deinde cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	Then care for it, until it heals.
Si autem accidat in loco apostema calidum, tune cura ipsum cum emplastris sedatiuis, donec sanetur.	But if a hot abscess should occur in the place, then cure it with soothing plasters until it heals.
¶ De modis Ataxmir oculi, id est, cum palpebra mollificatur oculi, unde fit ut rugetur sicut non debet.	Concerning the ways of Azarnath of the eye, that is, when the eyelid becomes soft, the eye becomes inflamed as it should not.
Caput XI.	Chapter XI.
Quando nascuntur in palpebris oculi pili additi praeter cursum sub pilis naturalibus, et antiquantur: tunc ipsi nocent oculo, et faciunt accidere modos aegritudinum, sicut lachrymas assiduas, et mollificationem palpebrarum, et albuginem, donec fit illud caussa destructionis oculi.	When hair sprouts out between the eyelashes, in addition to the natural ones, and become old: then they harm the eye and cause various sufferings, as constant tears, softening of the eyelids, and a growth, until it comes to be the cause of destruction of the eye.
Et Ataxmir quidem oculi curatur secundum quatuor modos.	And indeed Azarnath of the eye is cured according to four methods.
Aut per cauterium cum igne.	Either by cauterization with fire.
Aut cum medicina acuta, secundum quod praemissum est in capitulo cauterii.	Or with sharp medicine, according to what is set forth in the chapter on cauterization.
Aut curatur Ataxmir per incisionem et suturam.	This is healed with an incision and stitching.
Aut per cannas, secundum quod ego dicam.	Or by canals, according to what I say.
Oportet ut ponas caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	It is necessary that you place the head of the sick person on your shoulder.
Deinde conuerte palpebram oculi manu tua sinistra.	Then turn the eyelid of the eye with your left hand.
Si ergo conuertitur, bonum est.	Therefore if it turns, it is well.
Et si non: intromitte acum in eam, in qua sit filum ab inferiori parte palpebrae, et fac penetrare acum cum filo desuper, et sit illud prope pilos ipsos, id est, prope marginem palpebrae, in quo nascuntur pili: et trahe filum ad superiora cum palpebra, et conuerte eam cum radio.	And if not, introduce the needle into it where there is a thread from the lower part of the eyelid, and make the needle pass through with the thread on top, and let it be near the hair itself, that is, near the edge of the eyelid where the hairs are born: and pull the thread to the upper parts with the eyelid, and turn it with a stick.
Deinde finde in interiori parte palpebrae sub pilis additis cum spatumili incidente a lachrymali maiore usque ad lachrymale minus.	Then find in the inner part of the eyelid under the hairs with the spatula running from the larger tear duct to the smaller one.
Deinde extrahe filum, et pone sub palpebra puluillum paruum ex cotto, aut panno: deinde signa super palpebram cum encaustro, quod sit sicut figura folii myrti.	Then pull out the thread and place a small dust of ashes, or cloth, under the eyelid; then mark above the eyelid with wax, so that it be like the figure of a myrtle leaf.
Verumtamen oportet, ut fit figura secundum quantitatem et eleuationem palpebrae: quoniam iam diuersificatur illud in hominibus.	However, it is necessary that the figure be made according to the size and elevation of the eyelid, since it varies greatly among men.
Ex eis enim est, qui indiget ut incidatur ex palpebra quantitas magna, secundum quantitatem quae mollificatur a palpebra.	For some of them are those who need that a great quantity be cut from the eyelid, according to the quantity which is softened by the eyelid.
Deinde cum spatumili finde super duas lineas quas signasti, et incipe a lachrymali maiore usque ad lachrymale minus, et sit fissura una prope pilos naturales, sicut est grossitudo radii.	Then with the spatula find above two lines which you marked, and start from the larger tear duct to the smaller one, and let there be a fissure one near the natural hairs, just as is the thickness of the stick.
Deinde intromitte uncinum in uno duorum angulorum cutis.	Then insert the needle into one of the two angles of the skin.
Deinde excoria ipsam totam.	Then peel it off entirely.
Deinde aggrega cum sutura duo labia, cum acu et filo lana subtili: et absterge sanguinem, et fac adhaerere quod superfluit ex filis super duo supercilia, cum quibusdam rebus inuiscantibus, si uis facere illud: et si non, non cures.	Then gather the two eyelids together with a stitch of needle and fine linen thread; and wipe away the blood, and make what overflows from the threads above the eyebrows adhere with some cauterizing things, if you wish to do so: and if not, don't bother.
Deinde dimitte suturam et fila usque ad tres dies, aut quatuor: postea cura illud.	Then let loose the suture and threads until three days, or four: then care for that.
Et si uis, dimitte uulnus absque sutura, et cura ipsum cum eo, quod exsiccat et constringit.	And if you wish, let the wound go without a suture, and care for it with that which dries and tightens.
Nam palpebra eleuatur apud sigillationem uulneris et aggregationem eius: sed futura est melior.	For the eyelid is raised by the sealing of the wound and its gathering together: but the future one will be better.
Hunc modum curandi Ataxmir docuerunt antiqui.	This method of treatment the ancient Ataksir taught.
Verumtamen in eo est sollicitudo super infirmum, et est ex bona operatione, et non est in eo timor.	However, there is concern for the weak one, and it is from good surgery, and there is no fear in it.
Et modus alius est in Ataxmir etiam: et est, ut signes super palpebram figuram, quae sit sicut figura folii myrti, sicut narrauimus.	And another method is in Ataksir also: and it is, to make signs on the eyelid a figure, which is like the figure of a myrtle leaf, as we have narrated.
Deinde eleua palpebram cum tribus uncinis separatis, aut aggregatis, secundum formam hanc quae sequitur, deinde incide quod superfluit cum forficibus paruis, secundum hanc formam, cum aequalitate incisionis.	Then raise the eyelid with three separate or joined hooks, according to this shape which follows, then cut off what is superfluous with small scissors, according to this shape, with equal cutting.
Si autem non est tibi possibile tenere uncinum, et non aequatur illud: tunc accipe acum in qua sit filum, et intromitte ipsum in medio figurae: et intromitte filum aliud prope lachrymale maius, et filum secundum prope lachrymale minus: et aggrega inter digitos tuos fila cum aequalitate.	But if it is not possible for you to hold the hook and it does not come out even: then take a needle with thread on it, and insert it in the middle of the shape: and insert another thread near the larger tear channel, and the second thread near the smaller tear channel: and gather together between your fingers the threads with equality.
Deinde eleua manum tuam eleuatione aequali: et eleua cutem super quam est signatum cotum, sicut narrauimus.	Then raise your hand with equal elevation: and raise the skin above which is marked out, as we have narrated.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then gather together the two lips of the wound with a suture: and care for it, until it heals.
Si uero accidat apostema apud incisionem tuam, aut fissuram tuam: seda illud apostema cum caeroto, et his similibus, ex unguentis sedantibus.	If, however, a suppurative formation occurs at your incision, or your cut: bind that suppurative formation with cerate and those similar things, from soothing ointments.
Et quandoque accidit palpebrae etiam, ut conuertantur pili eius.	And sometimes it happens to the eyelid also, that its hairs turn.
Oportet ergo ut utaris in ea quod diximus in incisione: sed sutura utrisque magis est artificialis.	Therefore you must use in it what we said concerning a cut: but to sew both of them is more artificial.
¶ De cura Ataxmir cum cannis.	On the care of an elephant wound with a thorn.
ET Est, ut conuertas palpebram, et scindas fissuram quae est deintus, secundum quod narraui.	It is so, that you will turn back the eyelid and cut open the split that is inside, as I have told.
Deinde arte fac duas cannas, aut duo ligna subtilia: quarum longitudo sit secundum longitudinem palpebrae, et latitudo earum sit minor latitudine spatumilis: et tu iam incidisti in extremitatibus utriusque ab utrisque partibus ubi tenes fila.	Then make two thin sticks or canes by art, the length of which is according to the length of the eyelid and their width less than half that of a reed: and you have now cut them at both ends on both sides where you hold the threads.
Deinde aggrega utramque cum subtilitate super illud quod superfluit ex palpebra oculi, et stringe duas cannas ab utrisque partibus strictura forti, et dimitte eam diebus aliquot.	Then bring both sticks together with subtlety over the excess from the eyelid of the eye and tie the two canes tightly on both sides with a strong knot, and leave it for some days.
Cutis enim stricta morietur, et denigrabitur, et putrefiet, donec cadet per se.	For the bound skin will die, become blackened, and rot until it falls of its own accord.
Si ergo tardatur, tunc incide eam cum forficibus.	If therefore it is delayed, then cut it with scissors.
Deinde cura eam, donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it heals.
Cum ergo consolidatur, eleuatur palpebra: et non pungunt pili.	When therefore it becomes firm, the eyelid is raised and the hairs do not prick.
Et haec est forma duarum cannarum, quas facies secundum hanc figuram, et quantitatem in longitudinem et latitudinem.	And this is the form of the two canes which you will make according to this shape and quantity in length and width.
¶ De eleuatione pilorum pungentium in oculo cum acu.	On the elevation of pricking hairs in the eye with a needle.
Caput XII.	Chapter Twelve.
Operatio in illo est, ut accipias acum subtilem, et intromittas in eam filum ex serico subtile, lene.	The operation is this: you will take a thin needle and insert into it a fine thread of soft linen.
Deinde aggreges extremitates eius, et nodes utramque nodo subtili ualde: et sit longitudo filorum palmus unus.	Then bring together the ends of it and tie both with a very small knot, and let the length of the threads be one finger.
Deinde compone in Alinxotati filum aliud subtile sub eo in breui, et noda extremitates eius si uis.	Then compose another fine thread under it in shortness, and tie its ends if you wish.
Deinde ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo, et sit prope solem ut declaretur operatio: quoniam est operatio subtilis, uel minuta.	Then let the sick person put his head in your arm and be near the sun so that the operation may be declared; because it is a subtle or minute operation.
Deinde intromitte acum cum alinxotati in radicem palpebrae, et fac eam penetrare in palpebram festinanter, donec extrahas eam desuper pilum naturalem.	Then insert the needle with the Alinxotati under the root of the eyelid and make it penetrate into the eyelid quickly until you draw out from above a natural hair.
Deinde trahe pilum usque supra alinxotati: et intromitte in alinxotati illum pilum: si est unus, aut duo, aut tres, non plures.	Then pull out the arrow until it is above the level of the body. And insert that arrow into the body. If there be one, or two, or three, not more.
Deinde trahe manum tuam cum eo, donec egrediatur pilus cum alinxotati in palpebra cum pilo naturali.	Then pull your hand along with it until the arrow comes out through the body into the eyelid together with its own natural thread.
Si autem trahatur alinxotati, et non egrediatur pilus cum ea: trahes alinxotati ad inferiora, cum filo quod tu composuisti in ea, donec egrediatur alinxotati ex foramine superiori, et uideas eam uisione oculi: tunc enim trahes alinxotati, et filum: et extrahe utraque, et claude oculum: et dimitte ipsum clausum duobus diebus, aut tribus, donec adhaereat pilus loco suo, et nascatur super ipsum caro.	But if the thread is pulled out and the arrow does not come out with it, pull the thread downwards along with the string that you made in it, until the thread comes out through the upper hole and you see it with the sight of the eye. Then pull the thread and the string and take both out, and close the eye and let it remain closed for two or three days, until the thread adheres to its place and new flesh grows over it.
Quod si pilus est breuis, tunc aut associa ei pilum longum ex pilis naturalibus, et eleuatur cum eo: aut dimitte ipsum, donec elongetur post spacium, et tunc eleua ipsum.	And if the thread is short, then either join a long one to it from the natural hairs and lift them up together; or let it be until it lengthens over time, and then lift it up.
¶ De cura Alxatrati quae accidit in palpebra superiori.	About the care of Alxa'tratus which occurs on the upper eyelid.
Caput XIII.	Chapter 13.
Quando accidit oculo haec Alxatrati, nominatur Leporina.	When this Alxa'tratus happens to the eye, it is called Leporina.
Et haec Alxatrati est aut naturalis, aut accidentalis.	And this Alxa'tratus is either natural or accidental.
Accidentalis ergo fit ex consolidatione uulneris, aut sectionis, aut cauterii, et similium illis.	The accidental therefore comes from the closure of a wound, or incision, or cautery, and similar things to these.
Et modus operationis in ea est, ut tu findas illam consolidationem, et ut separes labia eius, et ponas in eo quod est inter ea licinium ex lino, et liges eam, donec sanetur.	And the mode of operation for it is that you should find the closure itself, and separate its lids, and place a linen thread between them, and tie it until it heals.
Et non oportet, ut utaris in curatione eius rebus quae exiccant et constringunt: nam si tu facis illud, redit Alxatrati deterior quam fuit: imo utere in ea rebus quae mollificant, sicut foenumgraecum: et embroca cum aqua, in qua cocta sit althea, semen lini: et unguento dyaquilon, quod liquefactum sit cum aliquo ex oleis: et inuolue cum eo licinium, et cura cum eo.	And you should not use things that dry out and constrict for its treatment, because if you do it will make the Alxatrati worse than it was. But rather use things that soften, such as opium: and mix with water in which althea seeds have been cooked: and a diachylon ointment that has been liquefied with some oil: and wrap it around with the linen, and treat it with this.
Et thesaurus curationis tuae est, ut coneris omni ingenio, ut non consolidetur, secundum formam quae fuit in primis.	And the treasure of your cure is that you strive with all effort, so that it may not harden, according to its original shape.
Et haec quidem operatio quam diximus, non est nisi quaedam rectificatio Alxatrati, ut non redeat forma loci secundum quod fuit omnino.	And indeed this operation which we said is nothing but a certain correction of the Alxatras [?], so that the shape of the place does not return entirely as it was.
¶ De cura Alxatrati quae fit in palpebra inferiori, et est rugatio uel contractio sursum ad dextrum et sinistrum.	On the care for Alxatras which occurs in the lower eyelid, and it is a wrinkling or contraction upwards to the right and left.
Caput XIIII.	Chapter XIII.
Haec Alxatrati quae fit inferius, est quae uere nominatur Alxatrati.	This Alxatras which occurs below is truly called Alxatras.
Et est naturalis, et est accidentalis.	And it is natural and accidental.
Et accidentalis fit ex uulnere, aut fissura, aut cauterio, et illis similibus.	And the accidental one occurs from a wound, or incision, or cautery, and similar things.
Et uia operationis in ea est, ut accipias acum, in qua sit filum duplum, et tingas eam in carnem, et facias eam penetrare a lachrymali sinistro usque ad lachrymale dextrum, donec perueniat filum in duabus extremitatibus carnis.	And the way of operating in it is, to take an awl, in which there is a double thread, and dye it in flesh, and make it penetrate from the left tear duct to the right tear duct, until the thread reaches both ends of the flesh.
Deinde extende carnem ad superiora cum acu, et incide eam cum spatumili lato.	Then stretch the skin upwards with the awl and cut it with a wide spatulum.
Si ergo redit figura palpebrae secundum quod oportet, est bonum.	If then the shape of the eyelid returns as is fitting, it is good.
Et si non, accipe radium, et pone ipsum in fissuram, et conuerte cum eo palpebram: et finde duas fissuras in latere interiore palpebrae, et sint extremitates duarum fissurarum ex duobus angulis incisionis, donec concurrant et fiat ex eis angulus: donec quando aggregantur fiat figura earum haec figura, et est litera lauda graeca.	And if not, take a needle and place it in the incision, and convert with it the eyelid: and make two cuts on the inner side of the eyelid, and let the ends of the two cuts be from both angles of the incision, until they come together and form an angle: until when they are gathered it will be their figure, and it is the Greek letter lambda.
Deinde aufer illam carnem per quantitatem, quod est latus eius acutum inferius, ab eo quod sequitur palpebram.	Then remove that flesh to the extent of its sharp lower side, from what follows the eyelid.
Deinde aggrega partes separatas: sue eam cum filo lanae.	Then gather the separated parts: or sew them with a thread of wool.
Deinde cura eas cum eo quod diximus, de medicinis mollificantibus, et liciniis, donec sanentur.	Then treat them with those things which we said, about softening medicines, and liniments, until they are healed.
Et si Alxatrati accidat ex fissura, et sutura, aut cauterio: tunc oportet ut findas fissura plana sub pilis palpebrarum, etiam secundum quod praecessit.	And if an eyelash has fallen out due to a cut, and stitching, or cautery: then it is necessary that you seek out the flat cut under the eyelid skin, even according to what happened before.
Deinde separa inter duo labia cum licinio, secundum quod diximus.	Then separate between two lids with a lint or linen cloth, as we have said.
Et summa sermonis de cura Alxatrati, quando est desuper, aut inferius, est, ut currat in ea operatio, secundum quod praeparatur ex forma Alxatrati.	And the conclusion of the speech about the cure of Alxatrai, when it is above or below, is that the operation should be done according to the form of Alxatrai.
Ipsa namque est multarum diuersitatum in forma: et artifex prudens praeparat ingenium cum quocunque modo est possibile ei, donec redire faciat figuram ad formam naturalem, aut prope eam, et ipsemet infirmus, secundum quod conuenit ei ex operatione et instrumentis in plurimis dispositionibus.	For indeed it has many differences in form and a wise craftsman prepares the tool with whatever means is possible to him until he makes the figure return to its natural form or close to it, and the infirm person himself, as becomes him from the operation and instruments in various dispositions.
¶ De adhaerentia palpebrae oculi cum coniunctiua, aut cornea.	About the sticking together of the eyelid with the conjunctiva, or cornea.
Caput XV.	Chapter 15.
Quandoque accidit haec consolidatio multis hominibus, ita ut consolidetur palpebra superior cum albedine oculi, et prohibeat ipsum ab operationibus suis naturalibus.	Sometimes this consolidation happens to many people in such a way that the upper eyelid sticks together with the white of the eye and prevents it from performing its own natural operations.
Oportet ergo quod intromittas extremitatem radii sub palpebra, et eleues eam sursum: aut extendas eam cum uncino: deinde incide adhaerentiam cum spatumili subtili, quod non sit cum acuitate incisionis spatumilium, imo sit obtusum parumper: ut non inquietetur infirmus apud operationem, et remoueatur spatumile, et laedat oculum cum acuitate sua: et sit incisio tua quasi tu excories illam adhaerentiam cum facilitate, donec quando redit palpebra secundum formam suam naturalem, et sanetur adhaerentia tota.	Therefore it is necessary that you insert the tip of a rod under the eyelid and raise it upwards, or extend it with a hook: then cut the adhesion with a thin spatula, which should not be sharp but slightly dull, so as not to disturb the patient during the operation and remove the spatula and hurt the eye with its sharpness. And let your incision be like you scrape off that adhesion easily, until when the eyelid returns according to its natural form and the whole adhesion is healed.
Funde tunc in oculum aquam salsam, cum aqua ablue ipsum: aut distilla in ipsum ex sief facto, ex ziniar dissoluto cum aqua.	Then pour salt water into the eye with fresh water or distill a drop into it from a flask made from something dissolved in vinegar.
Deinde separa inter palpebram et oculum cum licinio lini: et pone super oculum lanam infusam cum albugine oui: et post diem tertium utere sief, et cum solidatiuis, donec sanetur.	Then separate between the eyelid and eye with a lint or linen cloth, and place over the eye a woolen poultice soaked in egg white, and after three days use a flask and ointments until it is healed.
¶ De incisione ungulae et eminentiae carnis lachrymarum.	On cutting the nail and the elevation of a cutaneous excrescence of tears.
Caput XVI.	Chapter XVI.
Scias, quod ungula est secundum duos modos.	Know that the nail is in two ways.
Aut est neruosa: et est similis sifac duro, subtili.	Or it is fleshy, and is similar to skin, hard and thin.
Aut est non neruosa, similis humiditati congelatae albae: quae quando tangit cam ferrum, aut conaris capere eam cum uncino, abscinditur, et non figitur in ea uncinus.	Or it is not fleshy, similar to frozen moisture; which when touched with an iron file, or you attempt to take hold of it with a nail, it breaks off and the nail does not stick to it.
Et utraeque species non incipiunt, nisi a lachrymali maiore, usquequo uadit paulatim, donec cooperit uisum, et prohibet lumen, et motum oculi.	And both kinds do not begin to grow, unless from the larger tear of the eye; until it gradually covers the sight, and prevents light, and motion of the eye.
Et modus operandi in incisione eius est: ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	And the manner of procedure in cutting it is: that the sick man places his head on your shoulder.
Deinde aperi oculos eius, et eleua palpebram manu tua.	Then open his eyes, and lift up his eyelid with your hand.
