Take alum, and hyssop, and origanum, and rue, and saffron, and chamomile, and abrotanum, and similar things to them from herbs: and gather all these together, or some of them in a pot, and they are drowned with vinegar, and they boil: and the pot is plastered with clay decently: and there is a hole in the middle of the pot, over which an instrument with a concave shape will be composed according to this manner.
Fiat ex argento, aut aere: et intromittatur extremitas, in qua est granatum, in os infirmi, donec ascendat uapor ad uuulam super cannulam, donec obscuretur uuula multum.	It should be made of silver, or bronze: and the extremity, in which is the powder, will be inserted into the mouth of the sick person, until the vapor ascends to the vein above the tube, until the vein is very obscured.
Deinde itera super ipsam multotiens, donec arescat.	Then repeat over it many times, until it dries up.
Et caue, ne facias hanc curationem in principio aduentus apostematis.	And beware, lest you do this treatment at the beginning of an ulcer's arrival.
Plaerumque enim addit in apostemate: et non oportet ut facias illud nisi apud declinationem apostematis eius calidi.	For many wounds it adds a poultice in suppurating abscesses: and thou oughtest not to do that except at the decline of the fever of the abscess.
Si autem non est praesens tibi hoc instrumentum, tunc accipe cannam, et compone in extremitate eius corticem oui: ut non comburatur os infirmi: quoniam cortex oui prohibet uaporem comburere os: et haec est ex bona curatione cum salute.	But if this instrument is not present to you, then take a stick of wood and compose it at the end with the rind of an egg, so that the tooth of the infirm one does not burn: for the rind of an egg prevents the vapor from burning the tooth: and this is from good healing with health.
¶ De extractione spinarum, et ossium de gula.	Concerning the removal of splinters, and bones from the throat.
Caput XXXVIII.	Chapter 38.
Multotiens adhaeret in gutture os, aut spina piscis, aut aliud.	Often something adheres to the throat, a bone or a fishbone, or some other thing.
Oportet ergo ut extrahas quod ex eis est apparens super quod cadit uisus, postquam premis linguam cum instrumento apud solem, et declaratur tibi quod est in gutture.	Therefore you should remove that which is appearing on what falls under sight, after you have pressed the tongue with an instrument in the sun, and it has been declared to you that it is in the throat.
Et quod non apparet tibi et occultatur in gutture, oportet ut facias uomere infirmum antequam digeratur cibus in stomacho.	And what does not appear to you and is hidden in the throat, it behoves that you should make the patient vomit before food has been digested in the stomach.
Fortasse enim egredietur res annexa per uomitum.	For perhaps indeed something attached will come out through vomiting.
Aut deglutiat infirmus frustum napi, aut radicem lactucae, aut deglutiat buccellam panis sicci: aut accipiat frustum spongiae marinae siccae lenis: et liga ipsum in filo, deinde deglutiat ipsum.	Or the infirm one swallows a piece of dried turnip, or the root of lettuce, or swallows a dry crumb of bread; or takes a piece of dry sea sponge and binds it up with a thread, then swallows it.
Cum ergo peruenit ad locum ubi sunt spinae, aut os, et extrahitur, tunc egreditur.	When therefore it reaches the place where are the splinters or bone, and is drawn out, then it comes out.
Si ergo non egreditur cum eo quod diximus: tunc utere instrumento ex plumbo secundum hanc formam.	If therefore it does not come out with what we said, then use an instrument of lead according to this shape.
Sit grossius quam Radius parumper, et in extremitate eius sit curuitas, quam intromittat in guttur suum cum facilitate: et ipse habeat caput suum eleuatum sursum.	Let it be thicker than a radius a little, and at the end of it let there be a curvature, that you may insert it into his throat with ease; and let itself have its head elevated upwards.
Et caueat a tactu suae epiglotis, ut non accidat ei tussis, et impellat cum eo os, aut spinam, aut intromittat ipsum medicus manu sua.	And beware of touching his epiglottis, lest coughing happen to him; and push with it the bone or splinter, or insert it himself with his hand.
Verum quod infirmus intromittat, hoc est melius: propter scientiam suam de loco rei annexae: et impellat inferius, aut trahat manum suam cum instrumento sursum, totum illud secundum quantitatem quae praeparatur ei, donec egrediatur.	It is true that an infirm person should intervene, that is to say, it is better: because of their knowledge about the place of the thing attached; and they push downward or draw their hand upward with a tool, all of this according to the quantity which has been prepared for them, until it emerges.
¶ De extractione Sanguisugae.	On the removal of the leech.
Caput XXXIX.	Chapter Thirty-Nine.
Quando medicatur sanguisuga cum eo quod dixi in diuisione ex curatione cum medicinis, et non confert, tunc considera in gutture infirmi coram sole, siue apud solem postquam premis linguam eius cum instrumento quod narraui tibi.	When the leech is being treated with what I said in the section on treatment with medications, and it does not adhere, then consider in the throat of the infirm person before the sun, or after the sun when you have pressed his tongue with the instrument which I told you about.
Si ergo cadit uisus tuus super sanguisugam, extrahe eam cum uncino paruo, aut cum gesti subtilibus decenter.	If therefore your gaze falls upon the leech, take it out with a small hook or with delicate fingers.
Quod si non est possibile cum eis: tunc accipe cannulam concauam, et intromitte eam in guttur infirmi usque prope guttur: deinde intromitte in concauitatem cannulae ferrum ignitum cum igne.	And if it is not possible with them [delicate fingers or hook], then take a concave tube and insert it into the throat of the infirm person until near the throat; then insert a glowing iron rod into the concavity of the tube.
Fac illud multotiens: et abstineat infirmus ab aqua tota die.	Do that many times, and let the infirm person abstain from water all day.
Deinde accipiat uitreatam plenam aqua frigida, et aperiat os eius in ea: et colluat os suum cum ea, et non deglutiat ex ea aliquid: et moueat aquam una hora post aliam cum manu sua.	Then let him take a vessel full of cold water, and open his mouth in it; and let him wash his mouth with it, and not swallow anything from it; and let him move the water one hour after another with his own hand.
Sanguisuga enim ilico cum sentit aquam cadit.	For the leech immediately falls when it feels the water.
Si autem non egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus, tunc suffumiga infirmum cum cimicibus, aut cum asa cum instrumento quod narraui in suffumigatione uuulae.	But if it does not come out with what we said, then fumigate the infirm person with cumin or with asafoetida with the instrument which I told you about for the fumigation of a uvula.
Fac illud multotiens, quoniam ipsa cadet.	Do that many times, because it itself will fall.
Et modus operationis in suffumigatione est, ut accipias ollam, in qua sint prunae uiuae cum igne: et olla sit cooperta cum coopertorio, in cuius medio sit foramen: et componatur in illo foramine extremitas instrumenti.	And the mode of operation in fumigation is, that you take a pot in which are fresh prunes with fire; and the pot shall be covered with a cover, in whose middle there is an opening; and arrange the end of the instrument in that opening.
Deinde proiice suffumigationem, et ponat infirmus os suum in extremitate cannulae, et claudat os suum, ut non egrediatur suffumigatio, donec scias quod suffumigatio iam peruenit ad sanguisugam.	Then let him place a smoke there, and the patient put his mouth at the end of the tube, and close his mouth so that the smoke does not escape, until you know that the smoke has reached the bloodsucker.
Nam sanguisuga statim cadet.	For the leech will immediately fall.
Quod si non cadit, tunc itera suffumigationem multotiens.	And if it does not fall, then repeat the smoke many times.
Et toleret infirmus sitim, et comedat salsa, et allia, et non bibat aquam.	And let the patient be thirsty, and eat salt, and onions, and not drink water.
Necesse est ergo ut egrediatur cum hoc regimine.	It is therefore necessary that he come out with this regimen.
Et haec est forma instrumenti cum quo extrahitur sanguisuga ex gutture, quando cadit super ipsam uisus.	And this is the shape of the instrument with which the leech is drawn from the throat when it falls on it in sight.
Est simile forcipibus, sicut uides: nisi quia est ei haee curuitas quae intromittitur ad guttur.	It resembles forceps, as you see: except that it has this curvature which is introduced into the throat.
Et extremitas eius similis ori auis quae nominatur ciconia, in quo est asperitas limae: quando comprehendit aliquid, non dimittit ipsum omnino.	And its extremity resembles the beak of a bird which is called a stork, in which there is the roughness of a nail: when it has grasped something, it does not let it go altogether.
¶ De apertione Apostematum, et eorum sectione, et cura in genere.	Of the opening of apostumes, and their cutting, and care for them generally.
Caput XL.	Chapter 40.
Apostematum species sunt multae, multorum modorum, secundum quod uenit rememoratio eorum, scilicet unius, et unius in hoc libro: et sunt diuersae in perforatione eorum, et sectione ipsorum ex duobus modis.	The species of apostumes are many, of various kinds, according to the memory of them, that is, one and one which is mentioned in this book: and they differ in their perforation and cutting in two ways.
Quorum unus est ex specie apostematis in seipso, et eo quod comprehendit ex humiditatibus.	One of them is a type of aposteme that forms within itself, and because it gathers from moistures.
Et modus secundus est propter loca, in quibus accidit ex corpore.	And the second way is because of the places in which it occurs on the body.
Quoniam apostema accidens in capite, est aliud ab apostemate accidente in ano: et apostema accidens in loco carnoso, est aliud ab apostemate accidente in iuncturis: et unicuique eorum est iudicium suum ex operatione.	For an aposteme that occurs on the head is one thing from an aposteme that occurs in the anus: and an aposteme that occurs in a fleshy place is another from an aposteme that occurs at a joint: and each of them has its own judgment from experience.
Et ex apostematibus sunt quae non oportet ut perforentur, nisi post maturationem saniei in eis, et complementum eius: et ex eis sunt, quae oportet ut perforentur, dum sunt cruda, et non maturantur secundum complementum.	And from apostemes are those which should not be perforated unless after the maturation of health in them and its completion: and from these are those which should be perforated while they are raw, and do not mature according to their completion.
Sicut apostemata quae sunt propinqua iuncturis.	As for boils which are situated near joints.
Quoniam apostema quando accidit prope iuncturam, et prolongatur esse eius, donec putrefit quod est in circumitu eius fortasse corrumpuntur ligamenta, aut nerui illius iuncturae: quare est caussa propior contractionis illius membri.	For since a boil which occurs near a joint and prolongs itself until what is surrounding it putrefies may possibly corrupt the tendons or nerves of that joint; wherefore there is a more probable cause of its adjacent member's contraction.
Aut est apostema apud membrum principale: quoniam si tu tardas perforationem eius, donec maturetur, nocebit uel illi, uel per illud membro principali.	Or it is a boil on the main member itself; for if you delay making an incision until it matures, it will harm either that one or the adjacent main member.
Aut est prope anum, perfora ergo ipsum immaturum: et non oportet, ut perfores, apostema crudum, non completae digestionis, nisi quod est prope anum, ut non putrefiat profundum, et longetur ad interiora ani, et fiat fistula, aut fiat in termino eius quod non sanatur.	Or it is near the anus, therefore make an incision on it unripe: and you should not cut into a fresh boil, not yet completed in digestion, except that which is near the anus, so that it does not putrefy deeply and extend to the inner parts of the anus, and form a fistula, or remain at its end and not heal.
Oportet ut scias horam perforationis apostematis, quod maturatum est secundum complementum: et est apud sedationem doloris, recessionem febris, et diminutionem rubedinis, et pulsationis, et acuitatem capitis apostematis: et reliqua signa.	You should know the hour of making an incision on a boil that has matured according to its completion; and it is at the station of relief from pain, abatement of fever, diminution of redness and pulsation, and sharpness of the head of the boil: and the other signs.
Et oportet, ut facias eandem perforationem in inferiori loco apostematis, et uehementioris eminentiae: et sit perforatio uadens in longitudine corporis, si apostemata sunt in partibus manuum et pedum, et locis lacertorum, et chordarum, et neruorum, et arteriarum, et ad ultimum in omnibus locis aequalibus, quibus non est reflexio.	And you should make the same incision in the lower part of the boil and more prominent elevation; and let the incision be going along in length through the body, if the boils are on parts of the hands and feet, and places of arms, tendons, nerves, arteries, and at last in all equal locations where there is no reflection.
In illis autem quae reflectuntur, uade cum perforatione secundum illud membrum.	But in those which are reflected, make the incision along with it according to that member.
Quando uero apostema est in locis carnosis: tunc melius est ut dimittas perforationem eius, donec confirmetur eius digestio, sicut diximus secundum complementum.	And when the boil is on fleshy places; then it is better to leave its incision until its digestion is confirmed, as we said according to completion.
Quoniam si tu perforas ipsum ante illud, prolongatur cursus uirus ex eo, et est multae sordis et sordiciei, et fortasse indurantur labia eius, et profunditas eius.	For if you make an incision on it before that, the course of the virus is prolonged from it, and there are many filth and foulness, and perhaps its lips become hardened and its depth becomes greater.
Et quaedam apostemata perforantur secundum latitudinem corporis apud necessitatem: aut secundum illud quo indiget membrum.	And certain boils are pierced according to the breadth of the body in necessity; or according to what a limb needs.
Et oportet, ut administres in apostematibus paruis perforationem paruam, et in apostematibus magnis perforationem amplam: aut sectiones multas per similitudinem magnitudinis apostematis.	And it is necessary to administer a small piercing in small boils and a wide piercing in large boils; or many cuttings according to the likeness of the size of the boil.
Et sunt ex apostematibus, in quibus oportet ut concauetur cutis: et incidatur quando iam facta est sicut pannus, et facta est in termino, quod iam mortua est: sicut illud quod accidit in multis, ut dubelet, et bubonibus.	And there are boils from which it is necessary to cauterize the skin and cut when already it has become like a cloth and has turned at the end that is already dead such as those that occur in many cases, as an ulcus or a bubo.
Et ex eis sunt quae secantur sectione habente tres angulos.	And from them are those which are cut with a cutting having three angles.
Et ex eis est, ex quo inciditur sicut figura folii myrti.	And from them is that from which it is cut like the figure of a myrtle leaf.
Sicut apostema inguinum.	Like an inguinal boil.
Et ex eis sunt in quibus administratur sectio rotunda, et sectio lunaris: et similes eis ex sectionibus.	And from them are those in which a round cut and a crescent cut are administered: and similar to these from cuts.
Illud uero cui non est caput, sicut sunt apostemata lenia superficialia, oportet ut perfores ipsum perforatione superficiali, uel plana tantum.	Indeed that which does not have a head, such as soft and superficial boils, it is necessary to pierce it with a shallow piercing, or only a flat one.
Et oportet, quando apostema est grossum, et iam collegit saniem multam, et perforas ipsum, ut non properes et extrahas pus totum in illa hora: imo extrahe ex ipso partem eius.	And it is necessary when the boil is large and has already gathered much matter to pierce it so that the pus does not form and you extract the whole pus at once; or take a part of it from it.
Deinde opila apostema usque ad diem alium.	Then cover the boil with an ointment until another day.
Deinde extrahe quiddam ex pus iterum.	Then extract something again from the pus again.
Fac illud multotiens secundum gradationem, donec egrediatur: praecipue si infirmus est debilis uirtutis, aut mulier praegnans, aut puer paruus, aur senex decrepitus: spiritus enim animalis ab animali multotiens resoluitur cum egressione saniei: et fortasse moritur infirmus, et tu non percipis.	Do this many times according to the order, until it comes out: especially if the patient is weak in strength, or a pregnant woman, or a young child, or an elderly decrepit person: for the spirit of life often dissolves from one animal with the egress of pus, and perhaps the sick person will die, and you won't notice.
Caue ergo hoc capitulum cautela magna.	Therefore beware this chapter with great caution.
Et post perforationem tuam, qua ista perforas apostemata, oportet ut abstergas uulnus: et considera.	And after your piercing, by which you pierce boils, it is necessary to clean the wound and observe.
Si ergo est uulnus apostematis paruum, aut est sectio plana, tunc administra licinia ex lino, aut coto antiquo.	If therefore there is a wound of a small boil, or it is a flat cut, then administer linseed from flax, or old wine.
Et si est apostema magnum, et fissurae perforationis multae sunt, oportet tunc ut intromittas in omnem fissuram licinium, donec perueniant adinuicem.	And if it is a large boil, and there are many perforations of the fissure, then you must introduce linseed into all the fissures, until they come together.
Et si in apostemate abscidisti partem cutis, aut in circumitu concauasti eam: tunc oportet ut impleas eam coto ueteri, aut sicut quando texitur pannus, aut raditur lanugine lini absque humiditate: et stringe ipsum usque ad tertium diem.	And if in the boil you have cut off a part of the skin, or hollowed it out around it: then you must fill it with old wine, or as when cloth is sewn, or wool is shorn from flax without moisture: and bind it until the third day.
Deinde proiice ipsum, et cura illud cum eo quod oportet ex unguento, donec sanetur.	Then throw it out, and take care of it with that which is necessary from an ointment, until it heals.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis in hora tuae operationis, tunc administra aquam frigidam, et acetum, postquam imbibitur in eis pannus: et ponis ipsum super locum fluxus sanguinis multotiens.	But if there occurs a flowing of blood at the time of your operation, then administer cold water and vinegar, after a cloth has been soaked in them: and place it repeatedly over the place of the flowing of blood.
Si autem perseuerat fluxus sanguinis, tunc oportet ut administres regimen, et curationem, et pulueres, quae narraui in locis multis huius nostri libri, et ex diuisione.	But if the flowing of blood persists, then you must administer a dressing, and care, and powders, which I have narrated in many places of this our book, and from division.
Si autem est in tempore hyemis, et locus apostematis est multorum neruorum: tunc oportet ut infundas puluillos cum uino, et oleo calidis: et ponas eos super loca.	But if it is at the time of winter, and the place of the boil is of many nerves: then you must pour in powders with wine and hot oil: and place them over the places.
Et si fuerit in aestate, et loca sunt carnosa: tunc oportet ut ponas puluillos imbibitos in aqua, et oleo, aut eum uino et oleo, et totum illud frigidum.	And if it is in summer, and the places are fleshy: then you must place powders soaked in water and oil, or them in wine and oil, and all that is cold.
Donec quando erit dies tertius, sicut diximus, tunc oportet ut soluas apostema, et abstergas ipsum, et administres in curatione eius quod ei conuenit, donec sanetur.	Until when the third day comes, as we said, then it is necessary that you dissolve the boil, and wash it away, and administer to its cure what is fitting for it, until it heals.
Hoc est ergo quod necessarium est ex cognitione curationis apostematum uniuersaliter.	This then is what is necessary from the knowledge of the cure of boils universally.
Secundum semitam uero distinctionis, iam dixi de omni apostemate, qualiter est uia ad curationem eius capitulatim singulariter.	According to the method of distinction, I have already spoken about every abscess, how there is a way to its cure chapter by chapter individually.
¶ De sectione apostematum quae accidunt in cute capitis.	On the cutting of abscesses which occur on the skin of the head.
Caput XLI.	Chapter 41.
Accidunt in cute capitis apostemata parua, et sunt ex speciebus Nodorum, quos continent tunicae, quae sunt eis sacci: quasi ipsa sint hausolati gallinae.	Small abscesses occur on the skin of the head, and they are similar in appearance to boils, which are enclosed by pouches, that is, the skins, which contain them, like eggs hatched by a hen.
Et ipsorum species sunt multae.	And their kinds are many.
Ex eis sunt pingues: et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditatem similem limo: et ex eis quae continent humiditatem similem frisatis et pultibus: et eis similibus, et ex eis sunt, quae sunt lapidea dura.	Among them are those that are fatty; and among them are those which contain moisture similar to mud: and among them are those which contain moisture similar to porridge and puddings: and similar to them, and among them are those which are hard and stony.
Et in sectione omnium, et ipsorum extractione non est timor, dum apud ipsorum sectionem non facit contrarietatem arteria.	And in the cutting of all of them, and their extraction there is no fear, as long as at their cutting does not conflict with an artery.
Et operatio in sectione eorum est, ut experiaris ea cum instrumento, cuius forma uenit post haec, quod nominatur Intromissum, donec scias quid contineat.	And the operation on cutting them is, that you experiment with them by means of an instrument, whose shape will be described afterwards, which is called Intromissum, until you know what it contains.
Nam si est illud quod continet humiditas, tunc seca ipsum sectione secundum longitudinem sectione superficiali: secundum hanc formam.	For if it is that which contains moisture, then cut it out with a superficial incision following its length, in this shape.
Et incipe cum sectione ex linea b. ad lineam, g. Cum ergo euacuatur humiditas, tunc excoria kistin quae continet illam humiditatem, et non dimittas ex ea aliquid penitus.	And begin with an incision from the line b to the line g. And when the moisture has been evacuated, then scrape out the cyst which contains that moisture, and let nothing be left in it.
Multotiens enim redit, si remanet ex ea aliquid.	For indeed many times it returns if anything remains in it.
Deinde submerge cotum in unguento aegyptio, si est praesens: et si non, in aqua et sale: et imple cum eo uulnus, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	Then immerse the poultice in Egyptian ointment, if it is available: and if not, in water and salt: and fill the wound with it, and leave it until another day.
Ipsum enim corrodet quod remansit ex kisti.	For indeed it will rot what remained from the cyst.
Deinde itera super ipsum cotum cum aegyptio secundo, et tertio, et si indiges illo, donec confidas quia non remanserit ex kisti aliquid, tunc enim cura uulnus cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then repeat the poultice on top of it with Egyptian ointment a second time, and a third time, and if you need to use more, do so until you are confident that nothing remains from the cyst. For then indeed you can cure the wound with ointment, until it is healed.
Quod si apostema continet nodum pinguem: tunc seca ipsum secundum hanc formam, sectione habente formam crucis: et proiice uncinos inter duolabia sectionis, et excoria ipsum ab omni parte: et conare uirtutem tuam in extractione tunicae quae continet ipsum.	If the apostema contains a thick knot: then cut it according to this form, with an incision in the shape of a cross: and throw into the incision some salt between the two blades of the incision, and scrape off from all parts: and try your power in extracting the skin that contains it.
Si autem contrarietatem facit tibi arteria, tunc fac illud quod narrabo tibi post.	But if a vein makes difficulty for you, then do what I shall tell you afterwards.
Et similiter fac in apostemate, si est lapideum, ex sectione, et curatione eadem, secundum quod diximus.	And similarly act in an apostema, if it is stony, from the incision and its cure is the same, according to what we said.
Et sectio super apostema lapideum est facilior: quoniam est pauci sanguinis et humiditatis.	And the cut over a stony apostema is easier: because there is little blood and moisture.
Et quandoque sunt quaedam horum apostematum quae sunt in capite in quibusdam hominibus, cum quibus penitus non est humiditas.	And sometimes among these apostemata are some found on the head of certain people, in which there is no moisture at all.
Quod est: quia ego secui super apostema in capite mulieris uetulae, et inueni apostema sicut lapis solidus et durus, asper, albus, qui non poterat frangi: et si percuteretur cum eo aliquis proiiciendo, uulnerat ipsum.	For I cut over an apostema on the head of an old woman and found the apostema to be like a solid and hard stone, rough, white, which could not be broken: and if anyone struck it with something throwing, he would hurt himself.
In aliis uero apostematibus accidentibus in capite, praeter haec scilicet apostemata quae accidunt in capitibus puerorum, et apud radices aurium, sectio eorum omnium sit sectio superficialis.	But on other accidental apostemata occurring on the head, apart from these indeed which occur on the heads of children and near the roots of the ears, their cutting is a superficial cut.
Vel pone perforationem eorum semper ab inferiori parte eorum, ut alleuietur cursus saniei ad inferiora.	Or make a perforation in them always from the lower part of them, so that the flow of pus may be eased to the lower parts.
Deinde cura ea cum eo quod conuenit eis ex curatione.	Then cure those with what is suitable for them among the cures.
¶ De sectione Strophularum in collo.	About cutting Officiale sores on the neck.
Caput XLII.	Chapter 42.
Multotiens acccidunt ista apostemata in collo, et sub assellis, et inguinibus: et quandoque accidunt in reliquo corpore.	These apostemata often occur on the neck and under the armpits and thighs: and sometimes they occur in the rest of the body.
Et super illa quae ex eis accidunt in collo, sunt unum, et multa: et generantur ab inuicem: et omnis Strophula ex eis est intra tunicam propriam ei, sicut est in nodis et apostematibus capitis, sicut narrauimus.	And on those that occur on the neck, there is one and many of them, and they are generated from one another: and every Officiale sore out of them is within its own skin, just as it is in knots and head apostemata, as we have described.
Et species harum Strophularum sunt multae.	And the shapes of these strophulae are many.
Et ex eis enim sunt lapideae: et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditates: et ex eis sunt malignae, quae non obediunt curationi.	And from them there are lithic, and from them those which contain humidity, and from them the malignant ones, which do not obey cure.
In illa ergo quam ex eis uides bonae dispositionis in tactu, cuius manifestum est propinquum colori cutis, et mouetur ad omnem partem, et non est annexa cum neruis colli, neque cum guidegi, neque cum arteria, neque est profunda: oportet ut seces eam sectione superficiali a superiori parte ad inferiorem partem corporis ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. et excoria eam ab omni parte: et extende duo labia cutis cum uncino, aut cum uncinis multis, si indiges illo, sicut diximus in apostematibus capitis, et extrahe eam paulatim.	Therefore, that one which you see of good disposition by touch, whose manifest color is like the skin's, and it moves to every part, and is not joined with the nerves of the neck, nor with the jugular vein, nor with the artery, nor is it deep: it must be cut off from the upper to the lower part of the body along line b. to line g., and scrape it completely: and extend two folds of skin with a hook or with many hooks if you need it, just as we said in head apostemats, and pull it out gradually.
Et est super cautelam, ut non incidatur uena, aut neruus.	And beware lest you cut the vein, or the nerve.
Et sit spatumile non acutum ualde: ut non addat tibi manum tuam cum incisione, aut inquietet infirmum, et incidas quod non est necesse.	And let the spatula be not sharp at all: lest you cause yourself with the cut, or trouble the patient, and cut what is not necessary.
Si autem incidis uenam, aut arteriam, aut prohibet te ab operatione, tunc pone in uulnus zegi tritum, aut quosdam pulueres qui abscindunt sanguinem, et stringe uulnus, et dimitte ipsum, donec quiescat acuitas apostematis, et mollificetur uulnus: uel incipit et uult putrefieri.	But if you cut the vein, or artery, and it prevents you from operating, then put some ground zegi, or certain powders that stop blood, into the wound, and bind the wound, and leave it until the sharpness of the apostemat ceases, and the wound softens: or rather let it begin to putrefy.
Nam sanguis abscinditur tuncia Redi ergo ad operationem tuam, donec compleas.	For blood is stopped by a cloth Therefore return to your operation until you complete it.
Deinde inquire digito tuo indice, si remansit aliquid ex Strophulis aliis paruis: ergo incide eas, et munda eas.	Then inquire with your index finger if anything remains of the other small strophulae: therefore cut them and clean them.
Quod si est in radice Strophulae uena magna: tunc oportet ut non incidas illam Strophulam ex radice sua: imo oportet ut liges eam cum filo duplato forti, et dimittas eam donec cadat per se absque nocumento.	And if there is a large vein at the root of the strophulae: then it must be that you do not cut that strophula from its root: nay, but rather tie it with a doubled strong thread, and leave it until it falls on its own without harm.
Deinde imple uulnus coto ueteri, quod iam submersisti in unguento aegyptio.	Then fill the wound with a piece of old cord, which you have already immersed in Egyptian ointment.
Deinde cura ipsum.	Then take care of it.
Si inciditur Strophula tota, tunc oportet ut aggreges labia duo uulneris: et suas ipsum statim, postquam uides quia prorsus non remansit superfluitas.	If a swelling develops around the wound, then it is necessary to close together the two lips of the wound; and sew it up immediately, as soon as you see that there is no excess remaining.
Si autem uides quod remansit superfluitas propter magnitudinem Strophulae, tunc oportet ut intendas ad incidendam radicem eius, et extrahendam eam: et administra suturam quam diximus.	But if you see that there is excess remaining because of the size of the swelling, then it is necessary to apply yourself to cutting out the root of it, and pulling it out; and to administer a suture such as we said.
Et quae ex Strophulis continet humiditates, perfora illam perforatione superficiali: ut appareat tibi locus maturitatis eius: et pone perforationem ab eo quod sequitur inferius corporis, sicut diximus.	And what contains humidity among the swellings, pierce it with a superficial puncture; so that you may see the place of its maturity; and place the puncture below from what follows in the lower part of the body, as we said.
Deinde administra post perforationem licinia cum unguento, et similia eis, ut corrodat quod remansit ex corruptione, donec quando uides uulnus iam mundatum esse: tunc cura ipsum cum unguento generatiuo carnis, donec sanetur.	Then apply linseed with ointment to it after the puncture, and similar things to them, so that what remains from corruption may rot away; until when you see that the wound is now clean; then take care of it with a unguent born of flesh generation, until it heals.
¶ De sectione Epiglotis ab apostemate intra guttur accidente.	About the cutting off of the epiglottis from an abscess occurring inside the throat.
Caput XLIII.	Chapter 43.
Dixerunt antiqui hanc sectionem in Epigloti, et non uidi aliquem in terra nostra, qui eam fecerit: et haec est scriptura sermonis eorum.	The ancients said this cutting into the epiglottis and I have not seen anyone on our earth who has done it; and this is the writing of their speech.
In habentibus autem synanchiam, oportet ut deuitetur sectio Epiglotis: cum non fiat iuuamentum per illud: propterea, quod omnes uenae et pulmo sunt infirmi.	But in those having dyspnea, it is necessary to avoid cutting into the epiglottis: because there will be no benefit through it; on account of which all the veins and lung are weak.
In illis uero qui habent apostema calidum in ore, aut gutture, aut duabus amigdalis, quando non est aegritudo in cannali, oportet uti sectione Epiglotis, ad fugiendum ex perditione quae fit ex praefocatione.	But in those who have a hot abscess in the mouth, or throat, or both tonsils, when there is no suffering in the canal, it is necessary to make an incision into the epiglottis, in order to flee from the destruction that comes from suffocation.
Oportet ergo quando uolumus illud, ut secemus Epiglotim sub tribus circulis Epiglotis, aut quatuor, sectione parua per latitudinem, in eo quod est inter duos circulos per quantitatem, quod sit sectio in sifac, non in cartilagine: et iste quidem locus est conueniens sectioni, quoniam est priuatus carne, et uasa sanguinis ab eo sunt longinqua.	It is necessary therefore when we wish to do it, that we cut into the epiglottis under three or four circles of the epiglottis, with a small incision through breadth, in what is between two circles by quantity, so that the incision may be in the mucous membrane, not in the cartilage: and this indeed place is fitting for an incision, because it is private from flesh, and the vessels of blood are far from it.
Quod si medicator est timidus, tunc oportet ut extendat cutem gutturis cum uncino.	If the surgeon is timid, then it is necessary that he extends the skin of the throat with a hook.
Deinde findat cutem, donec quando peruenit ad cannalem: deuitet uas sanguinis, si uidet ex eis aliquid.	Then he cuts the skin, until it reaches the canal; pus or blood flows out, if he sees anything from them.
Deinde secet sifac quod narrauimus: et significatur super sectionem cannalis ex phlegmate quod egreditur ex ea, cum eo quod disrumpitur, et abscisione uocis.	Then he sutures the incision that we have described; and it is indicated over the cut of the canal because of the pus that comes out from it, with it being torn and the cutting of the voice.
Et dimitte uulnus apertum tempore aliquo.	And leave the wound open for some time.
Cum ergo remouetur hora in qua timetur praefocatio, aggrega duo labia uulneris cutis, et sue ipsam solam absque cartilagine.	So when however the hour is reached in which a closure is feared, gather together the two lips of the wound of the skin, and sew them up by themselves alone without cartilage.
Deinde administra medicinas quae faciunt nasci carnem, usquequo sanetur.	Then administer medicines that make flesh grow, until it heals.
Inquit Albucasis.	It is said by Albucasis.
Summa huius sermonis quem narrauimus, expositio non est, nisi quando uident, quod aliquod horum apostematum iam opilauit guttur infirmi: et sublimatus est infirmus super mortem, et uult intersecari anhelitus eius: uadunt ad secandum Epiglotim, ut respiret infirmus super locum uulneris quadam respiratione, et saluetur a morte: et propter hoc praeceperunt dimittere uulnus apertum, donec consumatur malicia aegritudinis, et est malicia eius tribus diebus, et quasi ipsa: tunc ergo praecaeperunt suere uulnus, et curare ipsum, donec sanetur.	The sum of what we have narrated in this speech is that the explanation is not given unless it is seen that one of these abscesses has already obstructed the throat of the infirm person: and the infirm person is raised up to the point of death, and wants his breathing cut off: they go to cutting the Epiglottis so that the infirm person breathes over the place of the wound with some respiration and is saved from death: and for this reason they have commanded to leave the wound open until the evil of the illness is consumed, and it is an evil of three days, and as if itself: then therefore they have commanded to sew up the wound and cure it until it heals.
Et illud quod uidi per me ipsum est, quod una ancilla accaepit cultellum, et misit cum in guttur suum, et incidit cum eo partem cannalis pulmonis.	And that which I saw by myself is that one slave girl took a knife and sent it into her throat and cut with it the part of the lung's canal.
Et uocatus sum ad curationem eius, et inueni eam mugire, sicut est mugitus mortui.	And I was called to heal her, and I found her bellowing like a mooing of the dead.
Detexi ergo a uulnere, et inueni sanguinem qui egressus fuerat ex uulnere paruum.	I therefore drew out from the wound and found the blood that had flowed out from the wound to be small.
Confisus ergo sum, quod ipsa non absciderat uenam, neque guidegi: et uentus egrediebatur ex uulnere.	So I was assured that the very thing had not been cut off nor cauterized; and air was escaping from the wound.
Properaui ergo, et sui uulnus, et curaui ipsum, donec sanum est: et non accidit ancillae aliquid, nisi raucedo in uoce: et rediit post dies ad meliorem dispositionum suarum.	I immediately sewed up and cared for the wound itself until it was healed; and nothing happened to the maid servant except that her voice became hoarse, and she returned after a few days to better condition.
Hinc ergo dico: quod in sectione Epiglotis non est timor.	Therefore I say, there is no fear in cutting into the epiglottis.
¶ De sectione Herniae gutturis.	On the cutting of a hernia of the throat.
Caput XLIIII.	Chapter 44.
Hoc Apostema nominatum Hernia gutturis, est apostema magnum, secundum colorem corporis: et est in mulieribus multum.	This hernia called apostema of the throat is a great swelling, according to the color of the body, and it occurs frequently in women.
Et est secundum duos modos: aut enim est naturale: aut est accidentale.	And it is in two modes: either it is natural, or it is accidental.
In naturali certe non est ingenium.	Certainly there is no art in the natural kind.
Accidentale uero est secundum duos modos: quorum unus est similis nodis pinguibus.	The accidental kind, however, is in two modes: one of which is similar to a swelling with pustules.
Et modus alter, est similis apostemati quod fit ex nodatione arteriae.	And the other mode is similar to an apostema that forms from the blockage of an artery.
Et in ipso est timor, et non oportet ut praesumptio fiat ad ipsum cum ferro, nisi in eo quod est paruum: et tu proba ipsum, et inuestiga ipsum cum Intromisso.	And in it there is fear, and one should not make a presumption with iron on it unless it is small; and you will test it, and investigate it with an instrument.
Si ergo inuenis ipsum simile nodo pingui, et non est suspensum cum aliqua uenarum: tunc seca ipsum, sicut secantur nodi: et extrahe ipsum cum eo quod continet ex kisti, si est in kisti: et si non, tunc perscrutare totum eius.	If therefore you find it similar to a swelling with pustules, and it is not hanging from any veins; then cut it out, just as you would cut out a nodule; and extract it along with that which contains it in the sac, if it is in a sac: and if not, then thoroughly investigate all of it.
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod oportet ex curatione, donec sanetur.	Then care for the place with what is necessary from treatment, until it heals.
¶ De sectione super species Nodorum.	On the cutting of above the type of Nodules.
Caput XLV.	Chapter 45.
Nodorum multae sunt species, et ego iam dixi omnes species eorum in diuisione: et oportet ut narrem hic differentiam inter Nodum, et Exituram: cum sit dubitationem faciens.	There are many types of nodules, and I have already mentioned all their kinds in the division; and it is necessary that I narrate here the difference between a nodule and an abscess, since it causes doubt.
Dico ergo, quod cum Exitura est caliditas, et febris, et dolores uehementes, donec sedatur ebullitio superfluitatis, et completur putrefactio: tunc enim quiescunt febris et calor.	I therefore say, that when the operation is warm, and fever, and great pains exist until the inflammation of excessiveness is stilled, and putrefaction is completed; then indeed fever and heat cease.
Cum Nodo uero non est caliditas, neque febris, neque dolores, et continet eos kistis sifachin, qui est eis saccus proprius, et est secundum colorem corporis: et est incaeptio eorum sicut cicer, et fit sicut batecha, et maior et minor.	Since however there is no warmth, nor fever, nor pains, and they are contained by a sac of siplachin, which is their proper sack, and it agrees with the color of the body: and it begins like chickpeas, and becomes like blisters, greater and lesser.
Et sunt secundum duas species: aut pingues: aut continent humiditatem.	And they are according to two kinds: either fatty: or containing moisture.
Et colores humiditatis sunt multi, secundum quod dixi in diuisione.	And the colors of the moisture are many, as I said in the division.
Oportet ergo, quando peruenis ad curationem Nodi, ut experiaris eum, et inquiras ipsum in primis cum instrumento quod nominatur Intromissum, secundum quod ueniet forma eius in capitulo quod est post hoc.	It is therefore necessary, when arriving at the cure of a Nod, that you test him, and inquire into it first with an instrument which is called an Intromissum, according to what its form will be in the chapter that follows this.
Et modus inquisitionis apostematum, et Nodorum omnium est, ut accipias hoc instrumentum, et intromittas ipsum in humidiorem locum, quem inuenis in apostemate: et tu reuolue digitos tuos cum eo paulatim, donec scias quod instrumentum iam penetrauit cutem.	And the method of inquiry for all pustules and Nods is, that you take this instrument, and insert it into a more moist place which you find in the pustule: and you turn your fingers with it slowly, until you know that the instrument has already pierced the skin.
Deinde ultima manum tuam secundum mensuram magnitudinis apostematis.	Then with your last hand according to the measurement of the size of the pustule.
Deinde extrahe Intromissum, et considera illud quod egrediur in uestigio eius.	Then withdraw the Intromissum, and examine that which comes out in its track.
Si ergo egreditur humiditas currens, quicunque color sit: tunc seca ipsum sectione superficiali, secundum quod dixi in reliquis apostematibus.	If therefore moisture running out comes out, whatever the color is: then cut it off with a superficial incision, according to what I said in the other pustules.
Et si non egreditur humiditas in uestigio Intromissi, tunc scias quia est pinguis: seca ergo super ipsum sectione habente formam crucis, secundum formam hanc, sicut docui te: et suspende ipsum cum uncinis, et excoria cutem ab omni parte cum facilitate: et custodi kistin si potes super illud, ut extrahas ipsam sanam cum Nodo.	And if no moisture comes out in the track of the Intromissum, then you will know that it is fatty: therefore cut above it with an incision having the form of a cross, according to this form, as I have taught you: and suspend it with hooks, and strip away the skin from all parts with ease: and protect the sac if you can over it, so that you may draw out the healthy sac along with the Nod.
Si autem disrumpitur kistis apud operationem, et non est possibile extrahere ipsam sanam, multotiens enim accidit illud, tunc extrahe ipsam frustatim, donec non remaneat ex ea aliquid.	If however the cyst bursts during the operation, and it is not possible to remove the healthy part of it, this happens often enough, then remove it piece by piece until nothing remains.
Nam si remanet ex ea aliquid parum, aut multum, redit Nodus secundum plurimum.	For if anything remains from it little or much, the Nodus most often returns.
Quod si uincit te, et remanet ex eo parum: tunc imple uulnus apud completionem tuam, quibusdam pulueribus corrosiuis acutis: et stringe uulnus, et pone supra ipsum quod sedet apostema calidum, et cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	But if it overpowers you and something remains from it little: then fill the wound with your completion, with certain sharp corrosive powders, and bind the wound, and place above it what sits a warm poultice, and cure it with the rest of the treatment, until it heals.
Si ergo est Nodus magnus, tunc sue duo labia eius, et cura ipsum cum eo quod incarnat.	Therefore if the Nodus is great, then close its two lips over it, and cure it with that which becomes fleshed.
Si autem est tibi contraria uena pulsatilis, aut non pulsatilis: tunc propera, et imple locum zegi trito, et dimitte ipsum strictum duobus diebus, aut tribus, donec putrefiat uulnus, et quiescat ebullitio sanguinis: deinde redi ad incidendum illud quod remansit ex Nodo.	But if there is contrary pulsating or non-pulsating vein: then hasten and fill the place with crushed zegi, and leave it tightened for two days, or three, until the wound puttrefies and the boiling of blood subsides: then return to cutting what remains from the Nodus.
¶ De foris instrumentorum pro sectione et perforatione.	About the outer instruments for cutting and perforating.
Caput XLVI.	Chapter 46.
EX Eis sunt formae Intromissorum, et sunt trium specierum.	These are the forms of Intromissories, and they are of three kinds.
Ex eis enim est magnum, et ex eis est medium, et ex eis est paruum.	From them there is a great one, and from them there is a middle one, and from them there is a small one.
Fiant ex ferro alfulud quadratarum extremitatum decenter, ut festinent introitum in apostemate.	They are made of iron with the four-angled ends smoothed out, so that they may hurry into the inflamed part.
Et istae sunt formae Experientium, et no, id est, perforantia: et unum eorum nominatur beris, idest, peforans: et sunt trium specierum.	And these are the forms of Perforators, and indeed they are, that is, piercing ones, and one of them is called Beris, that is, piercer, and they are of three kinds.
Ex eis enim est magnum, et medium, et paruum.	From them there is a great one, and a middle one, and a small one.
Conueniunt, ut inuestigentur per ea apostemata, et exiturae, et fistulae, et bubones ab eo quod inter ea est ex ossibus.	They are suitable for investigating through them abscesses, and ulcers, and fistulas, and boils from the bone that is between them.
Et aliis fiunt rotunda, tersa, lenia, sicut acus magnae quibus subsellia suuntur, ex citrino scilicet, aut ex aere, aut ferro, aut argento.	And others are made round, smooth, soft, like large needles with which they upholster seats, namely from citron wood, or iron, or steel, or silver.
Et meliora eorum sunt quae fiunt ex citrino.	And those that are made of citron are the better ones.
Et fiunt Experientia etiam de plumbo nigro, quae conueniunt ut per ea experiantur fistulae, quarum concauitate sunt reflexiones, ut reflectantur cum lenitate sua cum illis reflexionibus.	And they are also made by experience from black lead, which is suitable for testing fistulas, the concavity of whose reflections cause them to be reflected with their own softness when reflected against these reflections.
Et sunt iterum trium specierum.	And again there are three kinds.
Quoniam ex eis sunt longa, ex eis media, et ex eis breuia, secundum quantitatem amplitudinis fistulae et stricturae eius.	Because they are of a length, of an intermediate length, and of a short length, according to the magnitude of the fistula and its constriction.
Forma Vncinorum, et sunt multarum specierum.	The form of ligatures, and there are many kinds.
Quoniam ex eis sunt simplices, scilicet quibus est curuitas una: et sunt trium specierum sicut uides, Magni, Medii, et Parui.	Because they are simple, that is to say those with one curvature; and there are three kinds as you see, Great, Middle, and Small.
Et ex eis sunt Vncini caeci: et sunt trium specierum.	And from them are blind ligatures: and there are three kinds.
Et ex eis sunt uncini habentes duas curuaturas, et sunt trium specierum: et ex eis sunt uncini habentes tres curuaturas, et sunt trium specierum: et omnes isti sunt necessarii in loco suo.	And from them are ligatures having two curvatures, and there are three kinds: and from them are ligatures having three curvatures, and there are three kinds: and all these are necessary in their place.
Et istae sunt formae Scalpellorum, quibus secantur et excoriantur Nodi, et apostemata: et sunt trium specierum: quoniam ex eis est magnum, medium, et paruum.	And these are the forms of scalpels with which knots and apostemes are cut out and scraped away: and there are three kinds: because from them is great, middle, and small.
Eorum extremitates quibus fit sectio sunt acutae, extremitates aliae sunt non acutae: et non ponuntur taliter, nisi ut cum eis fiat iuuamentum in excoriatione Nodorum apud timorem incisionis uenae, aut nerui: et ut sanetur per ea infirmus, et inueniat tranquillitatem parumper ex adustione quam inuenit apud excoriationem apostematis.	Their extremities with which a section is made are sharp, the other extremities are not sharp; and they should not be placed thus, unless it happens that with them relief is made in the scraping away of knots near fear of incision of a vein or nerve: and so an infirm person may be healed through them, and find tranquility for a little while from burning which he finds at the scraping away of an aposteme.
Istae sunt Magda, et sunt specierum trium.	These are Madga, and there are three kinds.
Fiunt ex aere, et sunt similia Radio, cum quo fit alcohol: et in extremitate lata est puncta Spatumilis occultata: et in ea currit ad interiora, et ad exteriora quando uis, sicut uides.	They are made of iron, and are similar to a Radium with which an injection is made: and at their broad extremity there are hidden points of spatula: and within them it flows inward and outward when you wish, as you see.
Forma Spatumilium quae absconduntur inter digitos apud perforationem apostematum: et non percipiunt ea infirmi: et sunt trium specierum, magnum, medium, et paruum.	The form of bandages which are hidden among the fingers for piercing abscesses: and the sick do not perceive them; and there are three kinds, great, medium, and small.
Fomae Ventosarum cum quibus abscinditur fluxus sanguinis: et sunt trium specierum, magnae, mediae, et paruae.	The forms of astringent plasters with which bleeding is stopped: and there are three kinds, great, medium, and small.
Fiant ex aere, aut citrino, rotundae, ad longitudinem parumper, sicut uides: et sint ad subtilitatem.	They should be made from air or saffron, round, to a length somewhat, as you see them: and they should be thin.
Et oportet ut sint istae species Ventosarum apud te magnae, et paruae: ut abscindas per eas sanguinem cum uelocitate apud necessitatem, et tunc quando non est tibi praesens medicina.	And it is necessary that these kinds of astringent plasters be present to you, great and small: so that with them you can stop blood flow quickly in necessity, and then when medicine is not available.
Verumtamen non utaris eis in abscisione sanguinis in omni loco corporis, et non utaris nisi in locis carnosis: sicut lacertis cruris, et coxae, et lacertis brachiorum, et mammillarum, et uentris, et inguinum, et similibus eis, ex lacertis carnosis, humidis.	However you should not use them in the stopping of blood everywhere in the body, and you should not use them except in fleshy places: such as the calves, thighs, arms, nipples, belly, groin, and similar ones, from fleshy moist limbs.
Et quandoque fiunt ex eis instrumenta parua alia similia corticibus fisticorum, secundum suam formam: quibus abscinditur sanguis quando fluit ex loco phlebotomiae, aut apud incisionem uenae, aut arteriae: et quandoque fiunt ex eis rotundae secundum hanc formam.	And sometimes they make from them small instruments similar to the rinds of figs, according to their shape: with which blood is stopped when it flows from a place of phlebotomy, or at an incision of a vein, or artery: and sometimes they are made round in this form.
¶ De cura Mammillarum hominum quae mammillis mulierum assimilantur.	About the care of the nipples of men which resemble those of women.
Caput XLVII.	Chapter 47.
Quandoque inflantur Mammillae quorundam hominum apud complementum somni (id est, cum incipiunt pollui in somno) donec similantur mammillis mulierum: et remanent apostemosae foede.	Sometimes the nipples of some men become inflamed at the completion of sleep (that is, when they start to urinate while sleeping) until they resemble those of women: and remain inflamed with bad swelling.
Qui ergo abhorret illud, oportet ut secet super mammillas sectione lunari, secundum hanc formam ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. Deinde excoria pinguedinem totam.	Therefore he who is afraid of that, should shave over the nipples with a lunar incision, according to this shape from the line, b, to the line, g. Then scrape away all the fatness.
Postea imple uulnus ex medicamine incarnatiuo.	Then fill the wound with flesh medicine.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then gather together the two lips of the wound with a suture, and care for it, until it heals.
Si autem declinat mammilla ad inferiora, et mollificatur propter magnitudinem suam, sicut accidit mulieribus: tunc oportet ut findatur in duobus lateribus suis superioribus duabus sectionibus similibus figurae lunari, quarum unaquaeque continetur cum altera apud fines utriusque, donec sit linea maior continens minorem, secundum hanc formam ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. Postea excoria cutem quae est inter duo labia, et aufer pinguedinem, et administra quod diximus de sutura et pulueribus, quod est necessarium ex curatione, donec sanetur.	But if the nipple inclines towards the lower parts and becomes softened because of its size, as happens to women: then it must be cut into two upper sides with two cuts similar in shape to a crescent moon, each one being contained with the other at their ends until there is a longer line containing a shorter one, according to this form from line b. to line g. Then remove the skin that is between the two lips and take away the fat, and administer what we said about suturing and powders, which are necessary for healing, until it heals.
Si autem non comples incisionem eius quod oportet te incidere, propter inquietudinem infirmi, aut propter fluxum sanguinis: tunc oportet ut impleas uulnus coto submerso unguento corrosiuo, et dimitte ipsum, donec corrodat illud quod remansit ex pinguedine.	But if you do not complete the incision that is necessary for you to make, because of the disturbance of the patient or because of a flow of blood: then it must be filled with ointment immersed in a caustic, and leave it alone until it corrodes what remains of fat.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for it, until it heals.
¶ De perforatione apostematis, quod accidit sub Titillico.	About the piercing of an abscess, which occurs under the titillate (tittillus).
Caput XLVIII.	Chapter 48.
Ista apostemata quae accidunt sub Titillico, sunt ex speciebus Strophularum dura, quae continet kistis, et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditates.	These abscesses which occur under the titillate are of a hard type like sponges that contain pus, and also those that contain moisture.
Quae ergo sunt ex eis quae continent humiditates, oportet ut secentur sectione lunari, secundum hanc formam, ex linea b. ad lineam, g. cum ergo euacuatur totum quod est in apostemate ex sanie, tunc imple ipsum coto ueteri, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	Therefore those that are of the type which contain moisture must be incised with a crescent-shaped cut, according to this form, from line b. to line g. And when all that is in the abscess has been evacuated by means of pus, then fill it with old dressing and leave it until another day.
Deinde auferatur cotum, et curetur cum unguento conueniente ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then the dressing is to be removed, and it is to be cared for with a suitable ointment, until it heals.
Quod si apostema fuerit ex specie nodorum Strophularum, tunc scinde super ipsum, sicut diximus in sectione super Strophulas aequaliter.	And if the abscess is of the type of solid nodules like sponges, then cut over it, as we said in cutting over equal sponges.
Si autem extenditur uulnus in hoc ut emittat pus, tunc administra in eo cauterium, secundum quod diximus in eo quod praemissum est.	If however the wound extends so that it emits pus, then apply a caustic to it, as we said in what was said before.
¶ De sectione apostematis quod accidit propter Arteriam et Venam.	On the cutting of an abscess which occurs on account of an artery and a vein.
Caput XLIX.	Chapter Forty-nine.
Quando disrumpitur Arteria, et consolidatur cutis quae est supra eam, tuno multotiens accidit inde apostema: et similiter accidit Venae etiam, ut accidat in ea apostema et inflatio.	When an artery is ruptured and the skin which is above it becomes hardened, then many times an abscess occurs therefrom; and similarly with veins, that an abscess and swelling occur in them.
Et signa quibus cognoscitur, quod apostema et inflatio sint propter Arteriam et Venam, sunt: quoniam, quando apostema est propter arteriam, est longum, aggregatum in profundo corporis: et quando impellis apostema digits tuis, sentis quasi sit ei stridor.	And the signs by which it is known that an abscess and swelling are on account of an artery and a vein, are: because when an abscess is from an artery, it is long, accumulated in deep within the body; and when you press upon the abscess with your fingers, you feel as if there were a hissing sound.
Et illud quod est propter Venam, est rotundum in manifesto corporis.	And that which is from a vein is rounded in the body's surface.
Et sectio super hoc apostema est error, et praecipue quod est sub ascellis, et inguinibus, et collo, et in locis multis corporis: et est magnum ualde.	And cutting into this abscess is a mistake, and especially when it is under the armpits, and groins, and neck, and in many places of the body; and it is very great.
Oportet ergo ut deuitetur eius cura cum ferro, et quod ex eis etiam est in extremitatibus, aut in capite, oportet ut deuitetur.	Therefore care must be taken to avoid cutting into it with iron, and what is from them even in the extremities, or on the head, must also be avoided.
Super illud ergo quod ex eis est ex inflatione orificii Arteriae, finde in cute sectione in longitudine.	Therefore into that which comes from it by reason of the expansion of the artery's opening, cut into the skin in length.
Deinde aperi sectionem cum uncinis, postea Arteriam: et libera eam ex tunicis, donec detegatur.	Then open up the incision with a hook, afterwards the artery; and free it from its sheaths until it is revealed.
Deinde intromitte sub ea acum, et fac eam penetrare usque ad latus aliud, et stringe Arteriam cum filo duplo in duobus locis, secundum quod docui te in extractione duarum Arteriarum quae sunt in timporibus.	Then insert an awl under it and make it penetrate as far as the other side; and tie the artery with a double thread in two places, just as I taught you in the extraction of the two arteries which are in the temporal regions.
Deinde punge locum, qui est inter duo ligamenta cum spatumili, donec egrediatur sanguis qui est in eo totus, et soluatur apostema.	Then prick the place between the two ligatures with a small spatula, until the blood that is in it all comes out and the abscess is resolved.
Deinde administra curationem quae generat pus, donec cadant ligamenta: postea cura illud cum unguentis conuenientibus ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then administer a treatment that produces pus until the bonds fall apart. Afterwards treat it with ointments suitable for that until it heals.
Quod si fuerit apostema propter sectionem Venae, tunc oportet ut teneas manu tua quod tibi possibile est ex apostemate cum cute.	If there is an abscess due to the cutting of a vein, then you must take from the abscess with your hand as much as possible along with the skin.
Deinde intromitte acum sub loco quem tenuisti manu tua, et fac eam penetrare: et sit in ea filum duplum, donec extrahas ipsum ex latere altero.	Then insert a needle into the place which you took with your hand and make it penetrate, and let there be in it a thread twice its length, until you draw it out from the other side.
Deinde liga cum ipso apostema ligamento bono: secundum quod dixi tibi in ligamento uuae, a duabus partibus cum duabus extremitatibus fili.	Then tie it with the same abscess with a good bandage: as I told you to do with the grape, from two parts with two ends of thread.
Si autem times quod extrahatur filum, tunc intromitte acum aliam cum filo alio sub apostemate toto apud incisionem acus: preme, et stringe fila tua in quatuor locis.	But if you fear that the thread will be pulled out, then insert another needle with another thread under the entire abscess near the incision of the needle; press and draw your threads together in four places.
Deinde seca apostema in medio sui, donec quando egreditur quod in eo est: tunc incide superfluitatem cutis, et dimitte quod ligatum est ex ea.	Then cut the abscess in its middle until what is inside it comes out; then cut away the superfluity of skin and let go that which was tied to it.
Deinde pone super ipsum puluillum quem submersisti in uino, et oleo.	Then place over it a poultice which you immersed in wine and oil.
Deinde administra curationem, quae fit cum liciniis et unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then administer the treatment that is made with liniments and ointments until it heals.
¶ De apostemate quod accidit ex torsione Neruorum.	Regarding an abscess that occurs from twisting of nerves.
Caput L.	Chapter L.
Sicut accidit apostema in Arteria et Vena, similiter accidit apostema in Neruis: quod accidit in eis percussio, aut accidit a labore superfluo, et similibus: et fit plurimum illis in locis adiutoriorum, aut calcanei, et in omni loco in quo mouentur iuncturae: et est apostema graue.	Just as an abscess occurs in the artery and vein, similarly an abscess occurs in nerves: which comes from a blow or excessive labor and similar things: and it occurs very much in places of joints, or heel, and in every place where joints are moved: and it is a grave abscess.
Similatur color eius reliquo corpori, et est in pluribus dispositionibus absque dolore: et quando stringitur cum uehementia, sentit in eo infirmus simile stupori.	It resembles the color of its surrounding body, and it is found in many dispositions without pain: and when it becomes inflamed with fever, one feels a weakness similar to lethargy in it.
Et non est apostema aggregatum in profundo corporis, imo est sub cute, et ipsum mouetur ad omnem partem, et non uadit ad anteriora, uel ante, neque retro ad posteriora.	And it is not a deep abscess, but rather under the skin, and itself moves to every part, and does not extend forward or in front, nor backward to the back.
Quod ergo ex eis est in iuncturis, non oportet ut inuadatur cum ferro.	Therefore what is connected in them should not be invaded with iron.
Fortasse enim accidet contractio.	Perhaps indeed a contraction will occur.
In illo autem quod ex eis est in capite, aut in fronte, finde cutem cum spatumili.	But in that which is connected to the head or forehead, find the skin with a spatula.
Si ergo est apostema paruum, tunc tene ipsum cum forficibus, et abscinde ipsum a radice.	Therefore if it is a small abscess, then hold it fast with forceps and cut it off from its root.
Et si est magnum, tunc suspende ipsum eum uncino, et excoria ipsum: deinde aufer ipsum, et aggrega uulnus cum sutura: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	And if it is large, then hang it with a hook and lance it; then remove it, and sew up the wound with a suture; and take care of it until it heals.
¶ De sectione apostematis, quod accidit in uentre.	On the cutting of an abscess that occurs in the abdomen.
Caput LI.	Chapter 51.
Accidunt quibusdam hominibus multotiens in uentribus eorum, et in reliquis corporibus ipsorum, thelil, quae nominantur Fungalia, per similitudinem ipsorum cum fungis.	There occur in some people, many times in their intestines and in other parts of their bodies, swellings which are called "Fungalia", by resemblance to mushrooms.
Quorum radix est subtilis, et ipsorum caput est grossum, et conuersa sunt labia eorum.	Whose root is slender, and the head is large, and the lips of them are turned back.
Et est ex eis paruum: et est ex eis quod magnificatur ualde.	And there is a small one among them, and there is also one that greatly grows.
Et ego quidem iam uidi uirum, et in uentre eius erant duo thelil, quae erant magis quam rebus aliis similia fungis: non erat differentia inter ea, alba, minutae radicis, et inuersabantur labia eorum, et findebantur, et humiditas currebat ex eis semper.	And I myself have already seen a man, and in his abdomen were two thelils which were more like mushrooms than other things: there was no difference between them, white, with slender roots, and their lips were turned inward, and they were found, and moisture flowed from them always.
Incidi ergo ea, et inueni in pondere unius quasi X et VIII uncia et in altero quasi VI uncia Et operatio in incisione eorum est, ut consideres tunc, si infirmus est humidus, et color thelil est albus, humidum, subtilis radicis: tunc incide ipsum cum spatumili lato, et sint in praesentia tua cauteria in igne.	I therefore cut them and found that one weighed as much as nine ounces and eight, and the other as much as six; and the operation of cutting them is, that you consider then if the sick person is moist, and the color of the thelil is white, moist, slender root: then cut it with a wide spatula, and be present yourself, with cauterizing instruments in fire.
Multotiens enim expellitur apud sectionem eius sanguis multus: propera ergo si te uincit sanguis, tunc cauteriza ipsum.	For often indeed much blood is expelled during the cutting of it; therefore hurry if blood overpowers you, then cauterize it.
Quod si uides infirmum pauidum et timidum ab incisione cum ferro, tunc accipe filum ex plumbo decenter factum, et stringe cum eo athelul: cuius modus est quem diximus, et dimitte ipsum duobus diebus.	If you see a fearful and timid patient afraid of cutting with iron, then take a thread made from decently formed lead, and bind it with him to the atthel which we mentioned earlier, and leave it for two days.
Deinde adde in strictura plumbi.	Then add some lead to the stricture.
Non ergo cesses stringere plumbum, quotiens imprimit in thelil, donec abscindatur, et cadat per se absque labore.	Therefore do not cease from binding the lead as often as it becomes loose, until it is cut off and falls away without effort.
Si autem thelil grossae fuerit radicis, tunc in incisione eius est quiddam timoris et pauoris: praecipue quod est in uentre.	But if the atthel is of thick root, then there is something to fear and dread in its cutting, especially within the belly.
Verumtamen possibile est, ut incidas medietatem eius.	However it is possible for you to cut half of it.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum, ut non redeat.	Then cauterize it so that it does not recur.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur uulnus.	Then care for him until the wound is healed.
Et caue ne praesumas incidere thelil quod est fusci coloris, pauci sensus, foedi aspectus: ipsum enim est apostema cancerosum: et ego ueniam cum rememoratione Cancri post hoc.	And beware lest you presume to cut the atthel that is of foul colour, little sensation, and bad appearance: for it is a cancerous ulcer: and I come with reminder of Cancer after this.
¶ De cura eminentiae Vmbilici.	¶ On the care for protrusion of the Navel.
Caput LII.	Chapter 52.
Fit eminentia Vmbilici ex caussis multis.	There is a protrusion of the navel from many causes.
Aut ex fissuris sifac, quod super uentrem est: et exit ex eo althub, aut intestinum, secundum quod accidit in reliquis rupturis.	Or from fissures of the sphincter which is over the belly: and an intestine comes out through it, or a part of the intestines, according to what happens in other ruptures.
Aut ex sanguine qui fluit ex Vena, aut ex Arteria, secundum quod praemissum est.	Or from blood that flows from the Vein, or from the Artery, as was previously mentioned.
Aut ex uentositate coartata in eo.	Or from a constricted and swollen vein in it.
Si autem est propter fissuram sifac, et exitum thirbi: tunc est color apostematis similis colori corporis: et est lene, absque dolore: et apparet diuersi situs.	If however it is because of a fissure of the sphincter and a protrusion of the intestines, then its colour is similar to the colour of the body: and it is smooth, without pain: and it has a different appearance.
Et si est propter egressionem intestini, tunc est situs eius, cum eo quod narrauimus, uehementioris diuersitatis.	And if it is because of the protrusion of an intestine, then its condition with it is of a more vehement and greater difference.
Cum ergo tu premis ipsum digitis tuis, occultatur: deinde redit, et fortasse est cum eo sonitus: et magnificatur multum apud introitum balnei, et laborem uehaementum.	When therefore you press it with your fingers, it conceals itself; then it returns and perhaps a sound comes with it: and much glory is made about the entrance of the bath, and great effort.
Si uero est propter humiditatem, est lene, tunc non occultatur quando premis ipsum manu tua, neque constringium, neque additur.	If it is however because of humidity, it is soft: then it does not conceal itself when you press it with your hand, nor does it constrict or swell.
Quod si est propter sanguinem, tunc cum istis signis apparet apostema ad nigredinem de cliue.	Which if it is because of blood, then with these signs an abscess appears to blackness from the swelling.
Si autem est propter carnem natam: tunc est apostema graue, grossum, durum, et figitur secundum quantitatem unam.	If however it is because of born flesh: then it is a severe abscess, large, hard, and remains according to its size.
Si uero est propter uentositatem, tunc tactus eius est lenis.	If it is however because of inflammation, then the touch of it is soft.
Et operatio in illo est, ut consideres tunc, si eminentia umbilici est propter sanguinem Arteriae, aut Venae, aut uentositatem: tunc oportet ut prohibearis a curatione eius.	And the operation on it is, that you will then consider, if the swelling of the navel is because of blood from an artery or vein, or inflammation: then it should be forbidden to cure it.
Nam in illo est timor et pauor, sicut docui te in capitulo, in quo dixi apostemata propter arteriam et uenam.	For on that there is fear and dread, as I taught you in the chapter where I said abscesses because of an artery and vein.
Quod si eminentia umbilici est propter intestinum, aut zirbum: tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmo, quatenus teneat anhelitum suum, et stet stans extensus.	Which if the swelling of the navel is because of the intestine or bladder: then it should be ordered to the patient, as much as possible, to hold his breath and stand standing upright.
Deinde signa cum encaustro in circumitu umbilici totius.	Then make signs with encaustum around the entire navel.
Postea praecipe ei, ut resupinetur inter manus tuas super dorsum suum.	Afterwards order him to be placed on his back between your hands.
Deinde circunda cum spatumili lato in circumitu umbilici super locum quem signasti cum encaustro.	Then encircle with a spatula, wide and flat, around the navel area over the place you marked with encaustum.
Postea extende medium apostematis ad superiora, cum uncino magno.	Afterwards stretch out the middle of the abscess upwards, with a large needle.
Deinde liga eum in circumitu forti cum filo, aut cum chorda de serico ligamento firmo: et sit nodus ligamenti alenxotati.	Then bind it tightly around with strong thread, or with a cord of silk and firm sinew: and let the knot of the ligature be loose.
Deinde aperi medium apostematis extensum supra ligamentum.	Then open the middle part of the abscess stretched out above the ligature.
Si ergo inueneris ipsum iam captum a ligamento: tunc extrahe alenxotati, et intromitte in ipsum digitum indicem, et impelle intestinum ad interiora uentris: et si inueneris zirbum, tunc accipe ipsum cum uncino, et incide superfluitatem eius.	If therefore you have found it already captured by the ligament: then pull out the instrument and insert your index finger into it, and push the intestine to the inside of the abdomen. And if you find a tumour, then take it with a forceps and cut off its superfluity.
Si autem contraria est tibi arteria, aut uena: tunc circunda ipsum multum.	But if the artery or vein is against you: then encircle it much.
Deinde redi ad operationem tuam.	Then return to your operation.
Et accipe duas acus, et intromitte in eis duo fila fortia: et intromitte duas acus in circumitu quem fecisti circa apostema in modum crucis, quas facis penetrare.	And take two needles, and insert into them two strong threads; and insert the two needles into the ligature which you made around the tumour in the form of a cross, so that they penetrate.
Deinde stringe apostema in quatuor locis super acus: et si uis, aufer acus, et dimitte locum, donec putrefiat caro extensa: et cadat per se: aut incide ipsam quando subtiliatur et putrefit.	Then bind the tumour in four places over the needles; and if you wish, remove the needles and leave the place, until the stretched flesh rots and falls by itself; or cut it when it becomes thin and rotten.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod oportet ex unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then take care of it with what is necessary from ointments, until it heals.
Quod si eminentia umbilici est ex carne nara in eo, aut ex humiditate: tunc oportet ut concaues apostema, sicut diximus.	But if the prominence of the navel is from raw flesh within it, or from moisture: then it should be concaved, as we said.
Et extrahas sanguinem, aut humiditatem, quam inuenis in eo.	And draw out the blood, or moisture, which you find in it.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod solidat locum.	Then take care of it with what consolidates the place.
¶ De cura CANCRI.	Note on the treatment of a cancer.
Caput LIII.	Chapter 53.
Iam diximus in diuisione species Cancri, et qualiter est uia ad curationem eius cum medicinis: et cauendum ab eo cum curatione eius cum ferro, ut non ulceretur: et diximus Cancrum generatum in matrice, et cautelam a curatione eius.	We have already spoken in the division of the kinds of cancer, and how it is the way to its cure with medicines; and beware of it with its cure with iron, lest it ulcerate; and we said that the cancer generated in the womb, and the caution against its cure.
Et dixerunt antiqui, quod quandoque Cancer est in loco, ubi possibilis est eius eradicatio: sicut Cancer qui est in mammillis, aut in coxa, et eis similibus, ex membris locatis ad extrahendum totum eius: praecipue quando est incipiens paruus.	And the ancients said that sometimes cancer is in a place where its eradication is possible; such as cancer which is in the breasts, or in the hip, and those similar to them, located in parts from which it can be wholly extracted: especially when it is beginning and small.
Quando uero antiquatur, et est magnus, non oportet ut appropinques ei.	When it is old and large, you must not approach it.
Ego enim non potui sanare ex eo aliquem: neque uidi alium ante me qui peruenerit ad illud.	For I was unable to cure anyone from it, nor did I see another before me who had reached out to it.
Et operatio in eo, quando est locatus sicut diximus, est, ut praecedas, et soluas infirmum ex cholera nigra aliquotiens.	And the operation for it, when it is located as we said, is, as mentioned before, to precede and dissolve the sickness from black bile sometimes.
Deinde phlebotoma ipsum si inuenis cum repletione manifesta.	Then if you find it with a clear filling, bleed it.
Deinde praepara infirmum praeparatione, in qua locetur cum operatione.	Then prepare the sick person for preparation, in which it will be located during the operation.
Deinde proiice in Cancrum uncinos qui conueniunt ei.	Then place on it the thorns that fit it.
Postea concaua ipsum ab omni parte cum cute, secundum perscrutationem, donec non remaneat aliquid ex radicibus eius: et dimitte sanguinem currere, et non abscindas ipsum uelociter, imo exprime loca, et absterge sanguinem grossum totum manu tua, aut cum quo possibile est ibi ex instrumentis.	Then hollow it out from every part with the skin, according to examination, until nothing remains of its roots: and let the blood flow, and do not cut it quickly, but rather press on the places and wipe away all the thick blood with your hand, or as best you can there with instruments.
Si autem contrarietatem facit tibi fluxus sanguinis grossi ex incisione arteriae, aut uenae: tunc cauteriza uenam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	But if a counterflow of thick blood from the artery or vein causes you trouble at the incision: then cauterize the vein until the bleeding stops.
Deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with the remaining treatment, until it heals.
¶ De cura Hydropisis.	¶ On the cure of Hydropepsis.
Caput LIIII.	Chapter LIII.
Iam narrauimus in diuisione species Hydropisis, et qualiter fit aggregatio aquae: et signa omnis speciei, et curationem eius cum medicinis.	Now we have discussed in the division the kinds of Hydropepsis, and how water gathers together, and the signs of every kind, and its cure with medicines.
Et illa quae curatur cum ferro, non est nisi species asclitis sola: et non approximatur cum ferro speciei timpanitis: neque speciei hyposarcae penitus: nam illud mortale est.	And that which is cured with iron is not but one kind of ascites alone, and does not approach cure with iron the kinds of tympanitis nor of hypochondriac disease, for it is mortal.
Quando tu iam medicatus es hanc speciem Hydropisis timpanitis cum medicinis, et non contulit medicatio tua: tunc considera.	When you are already cured of this kind of Hydropepsis which causes tympanitis with medicines, and your treatment has not helped: then consider.
Nam si infirmo iam consecuta est debilitas, aut est cum eo infirmitas alia praeter Hydropisim: sicut si sit cum eo tussis, aut uentris solutio, et similia illis: tunc caue ne mediceris ei cum ferro: quoniam est timor illud.	For if the sick person has already been weakened by a weakness, or is suffering from another illness besides Hydropepsis, such as coughing, or the dissolution of the intestines, and similar things to those, then beware of treating him with iron, for it is feared.
