Si autem uides infirmum exuberantis uirtutis, neque est cum eo aegritudo praeter Hydropisim solam: et non est puer, neque senex: tunc modus operationis in eo est, ut tu eleues infirmum stantem inter manus tuas, et minister post ipsum exprimat uentrem eius manu sua impellendo aquam ad inferiorem partem pectinis.	If however you see a sick person of robust virtue, and he is not suffering from any disease other than simple dropsy: and he is neither a boy nor an old man: then the manner of operating on him is, that you lift up the sick person standing between your hands, and have another attend after him express his belly with his hand forcing water down to the lower part of his navel.
Deinde accipe spatumile spinosum, secundum hanc formam.	Then take a thorned spatula, in this shape.
Sit duarum partium acutarum, longum, acutae extremitatis sicut Spatumile.	There should be two sharp parts, long, with a sharp point like the spatula.
Verumtamen in eo sit quiddam breuitatis paulatim, ut non pertranseas cum eo apud operationem usque ad intestinum, et laedas ipsum.	However in it should be something of shortness gradually, so that you do not pass through with it up to the intestine during the operation and harm it.
Deinde considera.	Then examine.
Nam si est generatio Hydropisis ex parte intestinorum, tunc oportet ut elongeris cum sectione ab umbilico quantitate trium digitorum, ad inferiora in directo eius supra pectinem.	For if there is a generation of dropsy from the part of the intestines, then you must extend with a cut from the navel three finger lengths downwards straight over his navel.
Si uero generatio Hydropisis est propter aegritudinem epatis: tunc sit sectio tua sinistra ab umbilico tribus digitis.	If however the generation of dropsy is on account of liver disease, then let your cut be on the left from the navel three fingers.
Et si generatio eius est propter splenem, tunc sit sectio in latere dextro: et non oportet etiam ut sit sectio in latere super quod uult iacere infirmus, ut non currant superfluitates ad illum locum debilem.	And if his generation is on account of the spleen, then let the cut be on the right side: and it should not also be that the cut is on the side over which the sick person wants to lie, lest there flow to that weak place.
Deinde perfora cum instrumento cutem totam.	Then pierce through with an instrument the whole cut.
Deinde intromitte in illam sectionem, et eleua manum tuam cum Spatumili inter cutem, et sifac, quasi tu excories ipsum: et sit quantitas quae excoriatur quantitas unguis, aut circiter ilud.	Then insert into that cut and lift up your hand with the spatula between the cuts, and scrape, as if you were removing it: and let be the quantity that is scraped off the quantity of a nail, or nearly so.
Deinde perfora sifac, donec perueniat Spatumile ad locum uacuum: et est locus aquae.	Then pierce through with the spatula until it reaches the empty space, and that is the place of water.
Deinde extrahe ipsum, et intromitte in foramen instrumentum, cuius haec est forma.	Then extract it and insert into the opening the instrument which has this shape.
Et est simile cannulae: fit ex argento, aut aere, aut aurichalco, lene, tersum: cui in inferiori parte sui est foramen paruum, et in lateribus eius sunt tria foramina, duo ab una parte, et unum a parte altera: et facia est extremitas eius incisa, secundum modum incisionis calami, sicut uides: in extremitate eius superiore est armilla.	And it is similar to a cannula: it is made of silver, or bronze, or tin, smooth and polished: with a small hole at the lower part of itself, and on its sides are three holes, two from one side, and one from the other: and the tip of it is cut off, according to the shape of a reed pen, as you see: and there is an armlet at the upper end of it.
Nam quando instrumentum peruenit ad aquam, tunc ipsa descendit statim super instrumentum, ergo euacua ex aqua in hora quantitatem mediam.	For when the instrument reaches water, then it itself sinks at once upon the instrument, therefore it drains out of the water by a quantity middle.
Quoniam si tu euacuas ex ea plus quam oportet, in hora fortasse moritur infirmus per resolutionem spiritus sui animalis: aut accidit ei syncopis quae appropinquat morti.	Because if you drain out from it more than is necessary, perhaps the patient will die in an hour by the resolution of his vital spirits: or a suffocation will come upon him that approaches death.
Verum euacua ex ea secundum quantitatem uirtutis eius, et secundum quod significant tibi dispositiones infirmi ex uirtute pulsus eius, et ex bonitate eius.	But drain out from it according to the quantity of its virtue, and according to what the patient's arrangements signify to you through his pulse, and through his condition.
Deinde extrahe instrumentum, et retine aquam.	Then draw out the instrument, and retain the water.
Quod est, quia retinetur statim propter cutem quae retinet foramen quod est super sifac: de quo narraui, ut perfores ipsum secundum illum modum.	Which is because it is retained at once on account of the skin which retains the hole that is over the abscess: of which I spoke, as to perforate it in this manner.
Deinde itera instrumentum die altero, si uides infirmum tolerare illud: et extrahe etiam ex aqua quantitatem paruam.	Then introduce the instrument on another day, if you see that the patient is able to tolerate it; and also draw out a small quantity from the water.
Fac illud diebus aliquot sine timore, et custodi te ab errore: donec non remaneat ex aqua nisi parum.	Do this for several days without fear, and guard yourself against error, until only a little remains in the water.
Si autem times super infirmum, et dimittis ex aqua rem multam: tunc cura ipsum cum sepultura in harena calida, et sudore multo in balneo et sole, et expectet super sitim: et cura ipsum cum medicinis exiccatiuis, donec sanetur: et cauteriza super stomachum, et epar, et splenem, post extractionem aquae: secundum quod narraui in eo quod praecessit.	But if you fear for the patient, and leave much out of the water: then treat him with burial in warm sand, and great sweat in a bath and sun, and let him wait for thirst: and treat him with dried medicines, until he is healed; and cauterize over his stomach, liver, and spleen, after the extraction of the water: according to what I said previously.
¶ De cura infantium qui nascuntur locis urinae eorum non perforatis.	Concerning the care of infants born with unperforated places in their urinary organs.
Caput LV.	Chapter 55.
Quando egreditur aliquis infantium ex uentre matris suae, et caput mutonis eius est non perforatum, aut est foramen strictum, aut in non suo loco.	When someone is brought out of the womb of his mother and the infant's head has not perforated, or it has a narrow opening, or in an unnatural place.
Oportet ergo succurrere cum perforatione eius statim cum nascitur cum Spatumili subtili ualde, secundum hanc formam.	Therefore assistance must be provided with the perforation of it at once with a very fine spatula as it is born.
Deinde pone in foramine clauum subtilem ex plumbo, et liga ipsum: et tene ipsum tribus diebus, aut quatuor.	Then place a thin metal splinter into the hole, and tie it fast; and keep it thus for three or four days.
Quando ergo uult urinam emittere, remoueatur, et mingat.	When, however, he wishes to urinate, let it be removed, and let him urinate.
Deinde reduc ipsum.	Then put it back in.
Et si tu non ponis plumbum, iam possibile est, ut urina quae incedit super locum, non permittat ipsum claudi.	And if you do not place the metal, it is possible that the urine which flows over the place will prevent it from closing.
Ille autem cuius foramen est strictum, medicatur cum plumbo, sicut diximus, diebus multis, donec amplificetur.	But he whose hole is tight is cured with metal, as we said, over many days, until it becomes enlarged.
Illi autem in quibus est foramen in non suo loco, laeduntur.	But those in whom the hole is in a different place are hurt.
Quod est, quia ex eis qui nascitur, foramen est apud finem capitis uirgae: quare non potest mingere ad anteriora, donec eleuat uirgam manu sua ad superiora.	Which is because the hole is at the end of the head of the penis; so he cannot urinate towards the front until he raises his penis with his hand to the top.
Neque est ei generatio, propterea, quod sperma non potest peruenire ad matricem secundum rectitudinem: et est aegritudo foeda ualde.	Nor is he able to generate because the semen cannot reach the matrix according to its straightness; and it is very great suffering.
Et modus operationis in illo est, ut resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum.	And the manner of operating on him is, that he be placed supine over his back.
Deinde extende caput uirgae eius manu tua sinistra extensione uehementi, et incide caput capitis uirgae ex loco priapi, cum acumine, aut spatumili acuto: sicut est incisio calami, aut sicut tu radis aliquid, ut medium eius ueniat simile capiti uirgae: et ut cadat foramen in medio secundum quod oportet.	Then extend the head of his penis with your left hand in a strong extension, and cut off the head of the penis from the place of the priapus, with a sharp point or spatula tip; just as is the cutting of a reed, or as you sharpen something, so that its middle comes out like the head of the penis: and so that the hole falls in the middle as it should.
Et caue tibi apud operationem tuam a fluxu sanguinis.	And beware for yourself at your operation lest there be bleeding.
Multotiens enim accidit illud.	For indeed that often happens.
Oppone ergo ei cum eo quod abscindit sanguinem, et cura uulnus, donec sanetur.	Therefore apply to him the thing with which you staunch blood, and cure the wound until it heals.
¶ De Albather quae accidunt in praeputio et capite uigae, et corruptione, nigredine, et adhaerentia.	Concerning Albuter (possibly a reference to a medical condition or instrument) which happens in the foreskin and head of the penis, and corruption, blackening, and sticking.
Caput LVI.	Chapter 56.
Multotiens accidunt istae Albather in uirga, et est eminentia carnis foedae.	These kinds of boils often occur on the leg, and there is a foul swelling of the flesh.
Et ex ea alia est maligna, et alia non maligna.	And from it another is malignant, and another is not malignant.
Non malignam ergo oportet ut suspendas cum uncino subtili, et abscindas eam, donec mundes eam totam.	Therefore a non-malignant one ought to be suspended with a thin needle, and cut out from it until it is clean throughout.
Deinde pone super eam cotum submersum in unguento aegyptio.	Then place over it a compress immersed in Egyptian ointment.
Deinde cura ipsum post illud cum unguento dyafinicon, donec sanetur.	Then take care of the other one afterwards with Diaphanicon ointment until it heals.
Quod si Albather est maligna, foedi coloris, tunc oportet ut administres in ea cauterium post incisionem eius et ipsius rasionem.	Which if the boil is malignant and of foul colour, then one must apply a caustic after cutting it open and removing its reason.
Si autem Albather est in praeputio captiui, non circumcisi, et est pars Albather inter praeputium, et pars eius extra: tunc oportet ut auferas Albather, quae est intus in primis, donec quando consolidatur, tunc cura ipsum exterius: quoniam quando tu curas eam simul, non securatur praeputium quin preforetur.	But if the boil is on the foreskin of an uncircumcised captive and is a part within, and another part outside, then one must remove the boil that is inside first until it consolidates, then take care of the other one outside: for when you treat them at the same time, the foreskin does not heal but rather becomes inflamed.
Et iam accidunt etiam in testiculis, et praeputio nigredo et corruptio.	And now they also occur on the testicles and foreskin, with blackness and corruption.
Oportet ergo, ut tu concaues totum quod iam denigratum est, et quod uult corrumpi, aut iam corruptum est.	Therefore you must hollow out all that is already blackened and what wants to rot or has already rotted.
Deinde line super ipsum post illud cum melle quod iam concussum est cum farina corticum granatorum, et herbi tritorum cribellatorum.	Then apply a poultice on it afterwards with honey that has already been mixed with flour of ground grains and pounded herbs.
Deinde cura illud cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then take care of it with the remaining treatment until it heals.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis, tunc administra cauterium cum cauterio lunari, secundum hanc formam.	If however there is a flow of blood, then apply caustic with lunar cautery, according to this method.
Cauterium enim est iuuatiuum ad duas dispositiones simul, scilicet ad fluxum sanguinis, et uulnus quando corrumpitur.	For the caustic is useful for two kinds of afflictions at once, namely for a flow of blood and a wound when it becomes corrupted.
Quod si corroditur caput uirgae, et destruitur totum in hora: tunc oportet ut intromittas in meatum priapi cannulam ex plumbo, ut mingat infirmus super eam.	And if the head of the leg is corrupted and is destroyed entirely in an hour: then one must insert into the urethra a tube made from lead, so that the sick man may urinate over it.
In adhaerentia uero praeputii cum capite uirgae, et haec quidem adhaerentia non accidit, nisi in eo cuius praeputium est sanum, et non exigitur super ipsum circumcisio: et quandoque accidit adhaerentia propter uulnus, aut apostema: oportet ergo ut excories eam cum Spatumili obtuso, donec soluatur ligamentum, et liberetur caput uirgae ab omni parte.	Adhesions of the foreskin to the head of the penis actually occur in a man whose foreskin is healthy, and circumcision is not required over him. And sometimes adhesions occur due to a wound or an abscess. Therefore, it should be cut with a blunt spatula until the ligament is loosened, and the head of the penis freed from all parts.
Quod si est difficile discernere ea exquisite, tunc oportet ut excories aliquid ex capite uirgae, et ex praeputio.	If it is difficult to distinguish them finely, then it should be cut away a little of the head of the penis and a little from the foreskin.
Quod est, quia praeputium quando est subtile, fortasse perforatur propter subtilitatem suam uelociter.	For when the foreskin is fine, it may be pierced quickly on account of its fineness.
Deinde separa inter praeputium, et caput uirgae cum panno lini subtili, qui iam madefactus est in aqua frigida, ut non adhereant iterum.	Then separate the foreskin from the head of the penis with a linen cloth fine and already wetted in cold water, so that they do not stick together again.
Deinde curetur cum uino stiptico, donec consolidetur.	Then it should be treated with wine vinegar until it is consolidated.
¶ De mundificatione infantium, et curatione ex errore eis accidente.	Of the cleansing of infants and the cure of errors that occur to them.
Caput LVII.	Chapter 57.
Circumcisio non est solutio continuitatis, sicut reliqua uulnera: uerumtamen cum sit ex operatione nostra, uoluntate nostra, et usus eius sit in pueris proprie, est necesse ut signemus in ea operationem meliorem, et uiam leuiorem perducentem ad salutem.	Circumcision is not a solution of continuity, as are other wounds: however since it is from our operation, by our will, and its use is properly in boys, it is necessary that we mark in it the better operation and the easier way leading to salvation.
Dico ergo, quod antiqui non dixerunt circumcisionem in aliquo suorum librorum: quoniam non utuntur in legibus suis, et non est nisi quod acquisiuimus per experimentum.	I say therefore that the ancients did not mention circumcision in any of their books: because they do not use it in their laws, and it is only what we have acquired by experience.
Quod est, quia ego inueni maiorem partem artificum, et phlebotomatorum uti mundificatione, circumcidendo cum nouacula, et cum forficibus: et utuntur alfecati, et ligaudo cum filo, et incisione cum ungula.	Which is because I have found the majority of surgeons and bloodletters to use a razor and with forceps in circumcision, and they also use stitches and ligatures with thread, and an incision with a nail.
Et ego quidem iam probaui omnes istos modos, et non inueni meliorem mundificatione cum forficibus, et ligamento cum filo.	And I myself have already tried all these methods and did not find that the cleansing with forceps and stitching with thread was better.
Quoniam in mundificatione cum nouacula, multotiens effugit cutis.	Since in cleansing with a scraper, the skin often escapes.
Quoniam cutis praeputii duas habet tunicas: ergo forsitan inciditur cutis superior, et temanet tunica inferior: cogitur ergo ad incisionem ad incidendum alteram, et dolorem futurum.	Since the skin of the foreskin has two coats: therefore perhaps the upper skin is struck, and the lower coat remains; it is therefore forced to an incision in order to hit the other, and future pain.
Et cum mundificatione quae fit per alfecati, id est, digitalis, quo utuntur sutores, non securatur incisio extremitatis uirilis membri: quoniam fortasse ingreditur in foramen eius.	And since cleansing which is done by means of a lancet, that is, with the fingers, as surgeons use them, does not secure an incision of the extremity of the male member: because it perhaps enters into its opening.
In mundificatione autem cum ungula, fortasse euadit ferrum, et corrumpit operationem tuam: et cutis quidem pueri est breuis natura, et multotiens nascuntur taliter, quod non indigent mundificatione: et iam uidi illud.	But in cleansing with a nail, perhaps the iron will escape and corrupt your operation; and indeed the skin of a boy is short-lived by nature, and many times they are born such that they do not need cleansing: and I have already seen this.
Mundificationis autem cum forficibus, et ligamento cum filo, bonum experimentum detexit mihi: quoniam forfices sunt proportionalis incisionis: propterea, quod acuitas quae est superius, est sicut acuitas quae est inferius.	But the cleansing with forceps, and bandaging with a thread, has shown me a good example: because the forceps are of proportional cutting: therefore, what is sharp above, is as sharp as what is below.
Cum ergo premis manum tuam, proportionantur duae acuitates, et incidunt secundum operationem unam in tempore uno: et fit compressio simili figura, continens cutem uirgae ab omni parte, cum qua non cadit error omnino.	Therefore when you press your hand, the two sharp edges are proportioned and cut simultaneously according to the operation: and a compression is made similar in shape, containing the skin of the foreskin from all parts, with which there does not entirely fall an error.
Et modus operationis propriae est, ut facias extimare, puerum praecipue, si est ex eis qui intelligunt parumper, quod tu non facis, nisi quod ligas filum in uirga sua tantum: et dimittas ipsum usque ad diem alium.	And the mode of the proper operation is, that you should cause him to suppose, especially a boy if he is one of those who understand somewhat, that you are not doing anything unless you tie a thread on his penis alone and send him until another day.
Deinde fac eum gaudere et laetari omnimodo quo possibile est tibi illud, ex eo quod recipit intelligentia sua.	Then make him rejoice and be glad in every way as much as you can, because of the recovery of his understanding.
Deinde fac eum stare inter manus tuas praeparatae staturae, et non sit sedens: et occulta forfices in manica tua, aut sub pede tuo, ne uideat eos puer omnino, neque aliquid ex instrumentis.	Then make him stand between your hands prepared and standing, and not be sitting; and conceal the forceps in your sleeve or under your foot, so that the boy may see them entirely, nor may he see anything from the instruments.
Deinde intromitte manum tuam ad uirgam eius, et suffla in cutem, et trahe eam sursum, donec egrediatur caput uirgae.	Then insert your hand into his penis and puff air into the skin, and pull it up until the head of the foreskin comes out.
Deinde mundifica ipsam ex eo quod aggregatur in ea sordicie.	Then cleanse it thoroughly from what accumulates within it as dirt.
Deinde liga locum signatum cum filo duplo.	Then bind the marked place with a doubled thread.
Postea liga inferius eo parumper ligamentum secundum.	Afterward bind below it, for a little while, another thread secondarily.
Deinde tene cum indice tuo, et pollice locum ligamenti inferioris retentione bona, et incide inter duo ligamenta.	Then grasp with your index finger and thumb the place of the lower ligature holding tight, and cut between the two threads.
Deinde eleua cutem sursum uelociter, et extrahe caput uirgae.	Then lift up the wound quickly, and pull out the head of the thread.
Deinde dimitte sanguinem currere paulatim (est enim melius) et pone puluerem desuper: et super puluerem pannum in quo expansus est uitellus oui decocti in aqua rosata, concussum cum oleo ros. Recenti bono: et dimitte eum super ipsum usque ad diem alium: et cura ipsum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then let the blood run slowly (for it is better) and put powder on top; and over the powder a cloth in which an egg boiled in rosate water has been crushed with rose oil. A recent good wound: and let him be above it until another day; and take care of him with the rest of the cure, until he heals.
Forma autem forficis ad mundificationem haec est.	However, the shape of the forceps for cleansing is this.
Sint hebetes duae extremitates, et sint incidentes: ne egrediatur in eis ramus claui: et sit longitudo duarum acuitatum, sicut longitudo duorum manubriorum aequaliter.	Let the two ends be blunt and let them meet: so that a branch of a nail cannot issue forth from them; and let the length of the two sharp edges be as the length of two equal hands.
Error uero cadens in mundificatione est: quoniam fortasse effugit cutis intrinseca tota, aut pars eius apud incisionem.	But an error occurs in cleansing because perhaps the inner skin escapes entirely or a part of it at the incision.
Ergo oportet, ut extendas eam ex hora tua cum ungue tuo ante apostemationem loci: et incidas eam secundum aequalitatem.	Therefore you should stretch it forward from your thumb with your fingernail before the place becomes inflamed; and cut it according to equality.
Quod si non potes tenere eam cum ungue tuo, tunc extrahe eam cum uncino, et incide eam.	And if you are not able to hold it with your fingernail, then pull it out with forceps and cut it.
Si autem praeterierint ei tres dies, et remanet quod est sub uirga inflatum, apostematum: tunc dimitte illud, donec sedetur apostema calidum, et excoria illud cum facilitate, et incide illud secundum quod praeparatur tibi: et caue tibi a capite uirgae.	But if it has passed three days and the part that is under the thread remains inflamed with an apostema: then let it be, until the warm apostema settles; and strip off the scab easily, and cut it according to how it prepares itself for you: and beware of the head of the thread.
Non enim nocebit ei illud.	For indeed it will not harm him.
Cura ergo illud cum eo quod consolidat uulnus ex pulueribus, quos narrauimus in tractatu de pulueribus: et si inciditur ex cute supra mensuram, et euadit ad superiora, non nocet ei illud etiam.	Then therefore take care of it with him that consolidates the wound from powders, which we have narrated in the treatise on powders; and if it cuts out of the skin above measure, and escapes to the upper part, it will not harm him either.
Cura ergo illud cum eo quod diximus, donec sanetur.	Therefore treat it with that which we said, until it heals.
¶ De extractione Vrinae retentae in uesica.	On the extraction of a retained splinter in the scrotum.
Caput LVIII.	Chapter 58.
Urinae retentio in uesica, fit ab opilatione facta ex lapide, aut sanguine congelato, aut pus, aut carne nata, et similibus illis ex eis quae diximus ex modis curationis in diuisione.	Retention of urine in the scrotum occurs from a swelling made by stone, or frozen blood, or pus, or flesh that has formed, and similar things from those which we said on modes of cure in division.
Et si non soluitur Vrina, et uides retentionem eius esse propter Lapidem, qui iam est in collo uesicae: tunc oportet ut sit infirmus super genua sua curuatus.	And if the swelling does not subside and you see retention of it to be because of a stone already in the neck of the scrotum: then it is necessary that he lie ill on his knees bent.
Deinde componantur pedes eius super dorsum eius, et extendat uentrem suum ex superiori parte dorsi eius, et stringat infirmus anhelitum suum quantum possibile est ei.	Then his feet are to be placed over his back and he is to stretch out his belly from the upper part of his back, and the invalid is to take a breath as much as possible for him.
Cogitur ergo cum collo uesicae ad expulsionem Lapidis ad posteriora: quare absoluitur Vrina.	Therefore with the scrotum drawn out in front, the stone is forced to come out behind, whereupon the swelling is released.
Quod si non soluitur cum eo quod diximus, et uehemens sit res super infirmum: tunc oportet ut administres extractionem eius cum instrumento, quod nominatur siringa, cuius haec est forma Sit ex argento, et sit subtile, lene, concauum sicut cannula pennae auis in subtilitate radii, longum in similitudine palmi unius et medii: cui sit cannula subtilis in capite eius.	And if it does not subside with what we said and the matter is severe on the invalid: then it is necessary that you perform its extraction with an instrument which is called a syringe, of which this is the form. It should be made of silver, and should be subtle, soft, concave like the tube of a bird's feather in subtlety of radius, long in similarity to the palm of one hand and middle: and the tube should be thin at its head.
Et modus exitus Vrinae per ipsum est, ut accipias filum duplicatum, et liges in extremitate eius lanam, aut cotum, ligatura bona: et intromittas extremitatem fili in inferiori parte Siringae: et incide cum forficibus si superfluit aliquid ex lana, uerum intromitte in cannulam cum uehementia, sicut alzer.	And the method of exit of the swelling through it is, that you take a doubled thread and bind a good knot at its end with wool or cotton: and insert the end of the thread into the lower part of the syringe: and cut with scissors if anything superfluous comes out from the wool, but insert into the tube with vehemence as an alembic.
Deinde inunge siringam cum oleo, aut cum butyro, et albugine oui: et fac sedere infirmum super sedem, et embroca uesicam, et ipsius uirgam cum oleis humidis, et oleo oliuae, et aqua tepida.	Then anoint the syringe with oil, or with butter, and with egg yolk: and have the invalid sit on a seat, and apply ointment to the scrotum, and to his rod with moist oils and olive oil, and warm water.
Deinde intromitte siringam in uirgam cum facilitate, donec perueniat ad radicem uirgae.	Then insert a syringe into the penis with ease, until it reaches the root of the penis.
Deinde dupla ipsam superius a parte umbilici.	Then double it back from the part above the navel.
Deinde impelle siringam intra ipsam, donec perueniat ad Vesicam, et sentiat eam infirmus iam peruenisse ad rem uacuam: et non fit hoc secundum hunc ordinem, nisi quoniam meatus, in quo uadit, est in quo est tortuositas.	Then push the syringe inside it until it reaches the bladder and let the sick person feel that it has reached the empty place; and this is not done in this order unless the passage through which it goes is twisted.
Deinde extende filum cum lana paulatim.	Then extend the thread with wool gradually.
Vrina enim sequetur lanam.	For the hernia will follow the wool.
Deinde extrahe eam, et fac currere Vrinam per uiam urinae: et itera siringam, et non cesses facere illud, donec euacuetur uesica, et inueniat infirmus alleuiationem.	Then pull her out and make the hernia run through the way of urine: and put the syringe back and do not stop doing that until the bladder is evacuated and the sick person finds relief.
¶ De qualitate clisterizationis uesicae cum Clepshydra.	Concerning the quality of cathartizing the bladder with a siphon.
Caput LIX.	Chapter 59.
Quando accidit in uesica ulcus, aut sanguis in ea congelatur, aut coartatur in ea pus, et uis distillare in eam aquas et medicinas: tunc fiat cum instrumento quod nominatur Clepshydra, et haec est forma eius.	When an ulcer occurs in the bladder or blood freezes in it or pus is compressed within it and urine wishes to be distilled into it with waters and medicines: then make use of the instrument which is called a siphon, and this is its shape.
Est enim surda, id est, clausa.	For it is deaf, that is closed.
Et in eo sunt tria foramina, duo ex parte una, et unum ex parte altera, sicut uides.	And in it are three holes, two from one side and one from the other side, as you see.
Et locus concauus, in quo est illud quod impellit, sit secundum quantitatem quod opilet ipsum sine additione, donec quando trahitur cum eo aliquid, ex humiditatibus attrahatur: et quando impellitur, cum eo expellatur ad longinquum: secundum quod facit clepshydra, qua proiicitur naphta, id est, ignis graecus in praeliis martis.	And the concave place where is that which drives it, should be according to the quantity that suffices for it without addition, until when something is drawn with it from moistures is attracted: and when it is driven, with it is expelled to a distance: according to what the siphon does, in which naphtha, that is Greek fire, is thrown into the lists of Mars.
Cum ergo uis proiicere humiditates in uesicam, intromitte extremitatem clepshydrae in humiditatem, et trahe cum eo quod impellit ad superiora, humiditas enim trahitur in concauitatem clepshydrae.	So when you wish to throw moistures into the bladder, insert the extremity of the siphon into the moisture and draw with it that which drives it upwards; for the moisture is drawn into the concavity of the siphon.
Deinde intromitte extremitatem eius in uirgam, secundum quod narrauimus in siringa.	Then insert his extremity into a reed, as we have narrated concerning a syringe.
Deinde impelle humiditatem cum eo quod impellit illa namque humiditas peruenit ad uesicam statim, ita quod sentit eam infirmus.	Then urge moisture with him as that which urges it reaches the blister immediately, so that a sick person feels it.
Forma clisteris subtilis quo clisterizatur uesica.	The shape of a delicate suppository by means of which the blister is cleansed.
Fiat ex argento, aut auricalco: cuius caput altius sit simile alcama paruo, et sub eo sinus inter quem cadat ligamentum.	It shall be made from silver or gold: whose head be higher like the tip of a small alkam (reeds used for medicinal purposes) and under it a concavity in which a cord falls.
Deinde accipe uesicam arietis, et pone in ea humiditatem, qua uis clisterizare uesicam.	Then take the blister of a goat, and put into it the moisture with which you wish to cleanse the blister.
Deinde liga eam inter duos sinus ligatura forti cum filo duplo: et calefac illam humiditatem parumper super ignem.	Then bind it between two concavities with a strong thread doubled as a ligature, and warm the moisture slightly over the fire.
Deinde intromitte extremitatem clisteris in uirgam, postea stringe manum tuam super uesicam cum humiditate strictura decenti, donec sentiat infirmus, quod illa humiditas iam peruenit ad uesicam.	Then insert the extremity of the suppository into a reed, afterwards tighten your hand over the blister with a binding string suitable to it, until the sick person feels that the moisture has already reached the blister.
Si autem non est tibi praesens uesica, tunc accipe frustum pergameni, et fac ex eo circulum, et perfora ipsum ab omni rotunditate sua.	But if there is no blister present to you, then take a piece of parchment and make out of it a circle, and pierce the same through all its roundness.
Deinde intromitte filum forte in illis foraminibus, sicut reuoluuntur.	Then insert a strong thread into those holes as they unfold.
Deinde aggrega circulum, sicut aggregatur alsofratu: postquam tu ponis in eo illud quod uis ex humiditatibus, et oleis, et aquis.	Then gather the circle together like one gathers aloeswood: after which you put into it that which you wish from moist things, and oils, and waters.
Deinde liga ipsum in instrumento: et fac cum eo sicut fecisti cum uesica ex expressione cum manu tua, donec perueniat humiditas ad uesicam.	Then bind it into the instrument and make with it as you made with the blister from the expression with your hand, until the moisture reaches the blister.
¶ De extractione Lapidis.	Of the extraction of a Stone.
Caput LX.	Chapter Sixty.
Iam diximus in diuisione species Lapidis, et curationem eius cum medicinis: et dixi differentiam inter Lapidem generatum in renibus, et uesica, et signa illius totius: et dixi Lapidem in quo cadit operatio cum manu et sectio: et est Lapis generatus in uesica proprie: et ille qui figitur in uirga: et ego sum narrans illud cum expositione manifesta et abbreuiatione.	Now we have spoken in the division of the kinds of the Stone, and its cure with medicines: and I said the difference between the Stone generated in the kidneys, and the blister, and the signs of the whole thing: and I said the Stone on which the operation is done by hand and cutting: and it is the Stone generated properly in the blister: and that which is fixed in a reed: and I am telling you about that one with clear and concise explanation.
Dico ergo, quod Lapis generatus in uesica, plurimum accidit pueris.	I say therefore that a stone generated in the bladder occurs most frequently in boys.
Et ex signis eius est, quod urina egreditur ex uesica similis aquae in subtilitate sua: et apparet in ea harena alba, et fricat infirmus uirgam suam, et laborat cum ea, et multotiens pendet.	And a sign of it is that the urine comes out from the bladder very fine like water: and there appears to be white sand in it: and the sufferer scratches his private part with it: and labors with it: and often hangs.
Deinde erigitur, et egreditur cum eo anus in multis eorum.	Then he is raised up, and the anus comes out with him in many of them.
Et est facilis sanatio puerorum, ex eo usquequo consequuntur quatuordecim annos.	And there is easy healing for boys, as long as they reach fourteen years.
Et est difficilis in senibus.	And it is difficult in the elderly.
In iuuenibus autem est media, in eo quod est inter illud: et eius cuius Lapis est maior, curatio facilior: et si paruus, est econuerso illius cura.	But in young people it is of a medium sort, in that which is between the two and its cure is easier if the stone is greater, but on the contrary if small.
Cum ergo peruenimus ad curationem, oportet in primis, ut mundificemus infirmum cum clisteri, quod extrahat totum stercus quod est in intestinis suis: ipsum enim quandoque prohibet inuentionem Lapidis apud inquisitionem.	When therefore we come to the cure, it is necessary first that we cleanse the patient with a clyster, which takes out all the dung that is in his intestines: for it sometimes prevents the finding of the stone in the examination.
Deinde accipiatur infirmus cum pedibus suis, et concutiatur, et moueatur ad inferiora: ut descendat Lapis ad profundum uesicae, aut saliat de loco alto aliquotiens.	Then let the patient be taken with his feet and shaken and moved towards the lower parts, so that the stone may go down to the depth of the bladder, or sometimes come out from a high place.
Deinde fac eum sedere inter manus tuas praeparatum, et manus eius sint sub coxis ipsius, ut fiat uesica tota decliuis ad inferiora.	Then make him sit between your hands prepared, and his hands be under the base of his own body, so that the bladder may slope completely to the lower parts.
Deinde perquire eum, et tange eum extrinsecus.	Then examine him and touch him externally.
Si ergo sentis Lapidem in spacio, tunc propera statim cum sectione super ipsum.	If therefore you feel the stone in place, then hasten immediately with a knife over it.
Quod si non cadat sub tactu tuo omnino, tunc oportet ut abstergas digitum indicem cum oleo manus sinistrae, si infirmus est puer: aut digitum medium si est iuuenis completus: et intromittas ipsum in anum suum, et perquire de Lapide, donec stat sub digito tuo: et conuerte eum paulatim ad collum uesicae.	But if it does not fall under your touch entirely, then you must wipe the index finger of your left hand with oil from your hand, if the patient is a boy; or the middle finger, if he is a young man who has completed his growth: and insert it into his anus, and seek out the stone until it stands steady under your finger: and turn him slowly around to the neck of the bladder.
Deinde preme super ipsum cum digito tuo, et impelle ipsum ad exteriora aduersus locus, cuius sectionem uis: et praecipe ministro, ut premat uesicam manu sua, et praecipe alii ministro, ut extendat testiculos manu sua dextra ad superiora: et alia manu sua, ut remoueat cutem, quae est sub testiculis in parte a loco in quo est sectio.	Then press upon it with your finger and push it out against the external place of the wound, where you want the section to be. And command one of the attendants to press the swelling (vesica) with his hand, and command another attendant to stretch the testicles upward with his right hand: and with the other hand, remove the skin that is under the testicles in the part opposite to the place of the wound.
Deinde intromitte Spatumile incidens, cuius forma haec est.	Then insert a spatula cut into shape, whose form is this.
Et finde in eo quod est inter anum et testiculos, et non in medio, ad latus natis sinistrae: et sit sectio super ipsum lapidem, et digitus tuus sit in ano: et fiat sectio transuersa, ut sit sectio exterius ampla, et interius stricta, secundum quantitatem quod sit possibile egressio Lapidis ex ea non maior.	And find it in that which is between the anus and testicles, not in the middle but to the left side of the navel: and let the section be over the stone, and your finger be in the anus: and let the section be transverse, so that the outer part may be wide and the inner part narrow, according as it may be possible for the stone to come out without being larger.
Fortasse enim comprimit digitus, qui est in ano Lapidem apud sectionem, et egreditur absque difficultate.	Perhaps indeed the finger which is in the anus compresses the stone at the section and it comes out without difficulty.
Et scias, quod ex Lapide est cui sunt anguli et margines, quare fit difficilis exitus eius propter illud.	And know that from the stone which has angles and edges, its exit is difficult because of that.
Et ex eo est lenis, similis glandulae, et rotundus: et fit facilis egressus eius.	And it is easy to come out, similar to a gland, and round: and its exit is easy.
Ei ergo cui sunt anguli, et margines, adde in fissura.	Therefore to the one who has angles and edges, add something into the fissure.
Quod si non egreditur ita, tunc oportet ut ingenies super ipsum: aut stringas super eum cum gesti decenter, cuius extremitas sit sicut Luna, quae stringat super Lapidem, et non euadat ab ea: aut ut intromittas sub eo instrumentum subtile, curuatae extremitatis.	But if it does not come out that way, then you must think of something else to do over it: or string something over it with a decent gesture, whose end is like the Moon which strings itself over the stone and does not escape from it: or insert a subtle instrument with a curved end underneath it.
Si autem non potes super cum, tunc amplifica foramen parumper.	But if you cannot do that, then widen the hole a little bit.
Quod si uincit te aliquid ex sanguine, abscinde ipsum cum zegi.	But if something from blood overcomes you, cut it off with a razor.
Si uero lapis est plus quam unus, tunc impelle in primis magnum ad os uesicae.	If the stone is more than one, then push the larger one into the opening of the swelling first.
Deinde incide super ipsum.	Then cut over it.
Postea impelle paruum post illud: et similiter fac si sunt plures duobus.	Then push a small instrument after it: and similarly do this if there are more in pairs.
Quod si magnus est ualde, tunc ignorantia est ut seces super ipsum sectione magna.	But if it is very large, then ignorance lies in cutting upon itself with a great cut.
Quoniam accidit infirmo una duarum rerum, aut ut moriatur, aut accidit ei distillatio urinae assidua: proptera, quia non consolidatur locus omnino.	Because an injury happens to the patient either that he may die or a frequent and persistent dripping of urine occurs to him: therefore, because the place is not completely consolidated.
Verum administra expulsionem eius, donec egrediatur: aut ingenia in fractura eius cum forficibus, donec extrahas eum frustatim.	However administer a purging of it, until it goes out: or take hold of its pieces with forceps, until you extract them bit by bit.
Cum ergo compleueris operationem tuam, tunc imple uulnus thure, et aloe, et sanguine draconis: et stringe ipsum, et pone super ipsum pannum infusum oleo et uino, aut oleo rosato, et aqua frigida: ut sedetur apostema calidum.	Therefore when you have completed your operation, then fill the wound with gall, and aloes, and dragon's blood: and bind it up, and place over it a cloth infused with oil and wine, or rose oil, and cold water: so that the hot swelling may be alleviated.
Deinde resupina infirmum super collum suum, et non soluas ligamentum, usque ad diem tertium.	Then place the patient on his back over a pillow or his own neck, and do not loosen the bandage until the third day.
Cum ergo solueris ipsum, embroca locum cum aqua, et oleo multo.	When therefore you have loosened it, anoint the place with much water and oil.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento dyafinicon, et unguento basilicon, donec sanetur.	Then care for him with Diaphnetikon ointment and Basilicon ointment, until he heals.
Si autem accidit in uulnere apostema calidum additum, et corrosi, et illi similia: sicut si congeletur sanguis in uesica, et prohibeatur ex eo urina: et cognoscitur illud ex egressione sanguinis cum urina.	But if an added and festering swelling, and ulceration, and similar things occur in the wound, such as if blood congeals in a vein, and urine is prevented from flowing from it: and you recognize this by the discharge of blood with urine.
Intromitte ergo digitum tuum in uulnus, et extrahe illum sanguinem.	Therefore insert your finger into the wound and extract that blood.
Nam si remanet, prouocat ad corruptionem uesicae, et putrefactionem eius.	For if it remains, it provokes the vein to corruption, and its putrefaction.
Deinde ablue uulnus cum aceto, et aqua, et sale: et oppone omni speciei cum eo quod conuenit ex curatione, usquequo sanetur.	Then cleanse the wound with vinegar and water, and salt: and apply to it of every kind what is suitable for its cure, until it heals.
Et oportet in horis curationis totius, ut liges duas coxas, et aggreges, caussa medicinarum quae ponuntur super locum.	And it behooves you during the entire period of cure to bind together the two thighs and join them, because of the medicines which are placed over the place.
Quod si lapis est paruus, et sit in meatu uirgae, et figitur in eo, et prohibetur urinae exitus: tunc cura ipsum cum eo quod narro antequam peruenias ad sectionem.	If a stone is small, and it is situated in the urethra, and it is stuck there, and its exit is prevented by urine: then cure it with what I narrate before you come to the incision.
Multotiens enim a sectione excusaris per hanc curationem, iam enim probaui illud.	For often are you excused from an incision through this treatment, for indeed I have already tried it.
Et est, ut accipias Perforatorium ex ferro alferico, cuius haec est forma, triangulatae extremitatis, acutum, fixum in ligno.	And take a perforator of iron soldering rod, whose shape is triangular at the end, sharp, fixed in wood.
Deinde accipe filum, et liga cum eo uirgam sub lapide ut non redeat ad uesicam.	Then take a thread and bind with it the twig under the stone so that it does not return to the bladder.
Deinde intromitte ferrum perforans in uirgam cum facilitate, donec perueniat Perforatorium ad ipsum lapidem: et reuolue Perforatorium manu tua in ipso lapide paulatim: et coneris perforationem eius, donec facias ipsum penetrare a parte altera.	Then insert the piercing iron into the twig with ease, until it reaches the stone: and turn the perforator with your hand in the stone little by little: and you will make a perforation in it, until you make it penetrate from the other side.
Urina namque absoluitur statim.	For urine is immediately released.
Deinde preme manum tuam super illud quod remansit ex lapide ab exteriori parte uirgae.	Then press your hand over what remains of the stone from the outside part of the urethra.
Ipse enim frangitur, et egreditur cum urina, et sanatur infirmus.	For it breaks and is expelled with the urine, and the sick one is healed.
Si autem non praeparatur tibi haec curatio, propter aliquid quod prohibet ab illo: tunc liga filum sub lapide, et filum aliud supra lapidem.	But if this cure is not prepared for you because something prevents it from being done: then bind a thread under the stone and another thread above the stone.
Deinde seca super lapidem in ipsa uirga inter duas ligaturas.	Then cut above the stone on the urethra between the two bindings.
Deinde extrahe ipsum.	Then extract it.
Postea solue ligamentum, et mundifica sanguinem congelatum, qui fit in uulnere.	Later untie the bandage and clean out the frozen blood that forms in the wound.
Et non est necessarium ligamentum fili sub lapide, nisi ut non redeat ad uesicam: et ligamentum aliud desuper, nisi ut quando soluitur filum post egressionem lapidis, redeat cutis ad locum suum, et cooperiat uulnus: et propter illud necesse est tibi illud quando ligas filum superius, ut eleues cutem ad superiora, ut redeat apud complementum tuum, et cooperiat uulnus, sicut diximus.	And it is not necessary to bind a thread under the stone except so that it does not return to the bladder: and another bandage above except so that when you untie the thread after the stone's exit, the skin returns to its place and covers the wound: and because of this you must do this when binding the thread above, that you lift up the skin upwards, that it may return into your body and cover the wound, as we said.
¶ De extractione Lapidis mulierum.	On the Extraction of the Stone from Women.
Caput LXI.	Chapter 61.
Parum generatur Lapis in mulieribus.	The stone is formed to a small size in women.
Si autem accidat alicui earum lapis, tunc difficilis est curatio, et prohibetur propter modos multos.	But if it happens to any of them that she has a stone, then the cure is difficult and is prohibited because of many rules.
Vnus eorum est: quod mulier fortasse est uirgo.	One of these is: that perhaps the woman is a virgin.
Et secundus est, quia tu non inuenis mulierem quae detegat seipsam medico, quando est casta, aut ex habentibus maritos.	And the second one is, because you do not find a woman who will uncover herself to a physician when she is chaste, or from women with husbands.
Tertius est, quia tu non inuenis mulierem bene scientem hanc artem, praecipue operationem cum manu.	The third one is, because you do not find a woman who is well-versed in this art, especially the operation with the hand.
Et quartus est longinquitas a loco lapidis: quare indiget sectione profunda, et in illo est timor.	And the fourth one is, the distance from the place of the stone; wherefore it requires deep incision, and there is fear.
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad illud, tunc oportet ut accipias mulierem medicam, bene scientem: et parum inuenitur.	For if necessity provokes to that, then it is necessary that you take a woman physician, well-versed; and there are few found.
Si uero priuaris ea, tunc quaere medicum castum, subtilem, et praesenta mulierem obstetricem bene doctam in re mulierum, aut mulierem quae in hac arte innuit partem artis: fac ergo eam praesentem, et praecipue ei, ut faciat totum quod praecipis ei ex inquisitione super lapidem.	If however you privatize them [the women patients], then seek a chaste physician, subtle, and present a well-learned woman obstetrician knowledgeable in the affairs of women, or a woman who has some part in this art. Then make her present, and above all command her to do everything that you prescribe to her on investigation concerning the stone.
In primis quod est, ut aspiciat si mulier est uirgo: tunc oportet ut intromittat digitum in anum eius, et quaerat lapidem.	First of all that which is, to see if the woman is a virgin; then it is necessary that she insert her finger into her anus and seek out the stone.
Si ergo inuenit ipsum, coartet eum sub digito suo, et tunc praecipe obstetrici, ut intromittat digitum suum in uuluam infirmae, et inquirat super lapidem, postquam ponit manum suam sinistram super uesicam, et comprimit eam compressione bona.	If therefore she finds it [the stone], let her cover it under her finger, and then command the obstetrician to insert her finger into the vulva of the infirm woman and inquire about the stone, after placing her hand left over the vesica and compressing it with good pressure.
Si ergo inuenit lapidem, tunc oportet ut gradatim moueat eum ab orificio uesicae ad inferiora cum summa uirtutis suae, donec perueniat cum eo ad radicem coxae.	If therefore she finds the stone, then it is necessary that she gradually move it from the opening of the vagina to the lower parts with all her strength, until she comes to the root of the hip.
Deinde secet super eum apud oppositionem medietatis uuluae apud radicem coxae, ex quacunque parte praeparatur ei, et sentit lapidem in illa parte: et digitus eius non remoueatur a lapide, coartans sub eo: et sit sectio parua in primis.	Then he cuts on him above the opposition of the middle of the jaw at the root of the hip, from whatever part it is prepared for him, and he feels a stone in that part; and his finger does not move away from the stone, constricting under it: and let the cut be small at first.
Deinde intromittat radium super illam sectionem.	Then he introduces a reed over that incision.
Si ergo sentit lapidem, tunc addat in sectionem secundum quantitatem proportionatam quod lapis egreditur ab ea.	If therefore he feels the stone, then let him add to the incision as much as is proportional to what stone issues from it.
Et scias, quod species lapidis sunt multae.	And know that there are many kinds of stones.
Ex his enim est paruus, et magnus, lenis et asper, longus, et rotundus habens ramos.	From these is the small and the large, soft and rough, long and round with branches.
Scias ergo species eius, ut significetur tibi per hoc super illud quod uis.	Know therefore its kinds, so that it may be signified to you through this over what you wish.
Si ergo uincit te sanguis, tunc adde in loco zegi tritum, et tene ipsum hora una, donec abscindatur sanguis.	If therefore blood holds sway over you, then add to the place crushed myrrh and hold it for one hour until the blood is cut off.
Deinde redi ad operationem tuam, donec egrediatur lapis: et fac, ut praepares tecum ex instrumentis, quae dixi in extractione lapidis in uiris, ut adiuueris per ea in operatione tua.	Then return to your operation until the stone goes out; and do as you have prepared with instruments which I said for the extraction of a stone in the bladder, so that they may aid you through them in your operation.
Quod si uincit te fluxus sanguinis, et scis quod expulsio sanguinis est ex arteria quae incisa est: tunc pone puluerem super locum, et stringe eum cum puluillis strictura decenti: et non mutes illud: et dimitte lapidem, et non extrahas ipsum.	But if bleeding holds sway over you, and you know that the expulsion of blood is from the artery which was cut: then put dust over the place, and bind him with a decent compressing bandage: and do not change it; and let the stone go, and do not extract it.
Fortasse enim morietur mulier infirma.	Perhaps indeed the weak woman will die.
Deinde cura uulnus.	Then care for the wound.
Cum ergo sedatur acuitas sanguinis post dies, et putrefit locus, tune redi ad operationem tuam, donec egrediatur lapis.	When therefore the sharpness of the blood is stilled after days and the place becomes putrid, then return to your operation until the stone comes out.
¶ De sectione suiper Herniam aquosam.	A section above the Hydrorach (Hydroureter)
Caput LXII.	Chapter LXII.
Ramex aquosa non est, nisi aggregatio humiditatis in sifac albo, quod est sub cute testiculi continente ouum: et nominatur sifac.	The hydrorach is not a stone, unless it is an aggregation of moisture in the scrotal sac white part, which is under the skin containing the seed; and it is called the scrotal sac.
Et quandoque est in panniculo proprio sibi, quem praeparauit ei natura in parte oui, donec putetur: quod est ouum aliud, et est cutis testiculi inter sifac album, quod diximus: et non fit illud nisi raro.	And at times it is found in its own sheath, which nature prepared for itself on the scrotum, until it becomes putrid; which is another kind of sac and skin of the testicle between its two layers of fat. And that does not happen often.
Et generatio quidem huius ramicis, est ex debilitate quae accidit testiculis: quare effunditur ad eos haec materia.	And the generation indeed of this cord is from the weakness that happens to the testicles: wherefore this matter flows towards them.
Et quandoque accidit ex percussione super testiculos.	And at times it occurs due to a blow against the testicles.
Et haec humiditas est habens colores multos.	And this moisture is having many colors.
Aut enim est color eius decliuis ad citrinitatem, aut est sanguineus rubeus, aut faeculentus, niger, aut est aquosus albus, et est illud quod est plus.	For indeed its colour is inclined to yellowishness, or it is reddish bloody, or it is fecal and black, or it is watery white, and that is most often.
Et signa quibus scitur ubi sit aggregatio aquae, sunt ista.	And the signs by which one knows where the aggregation of water is, are these.
Nam si est in sifac albo quod diximus, tunc apostema est rotundum ad longitudinem parumper sicut figura oui: et non apparet testiculus, quoniam humiditas continet eum ab omni parte.	For if it is in the white layer that we mentioned, then the abscess is round in length for a little while like the figure of an egg: and the testicle does not appear, since the moisture contains it from all parts.
Et si est humiditas in panniculo proprio sibi, tunc apostema est rotundum cum parte oui, et propter hoc extimat homo quia est ouum aliud.	And if there is moisture in its own sheath, then the abscess is round with an egg-like part, and for this reason man supposes that it is another kind of egg.
Et si humiditas est inter cutem testiculorum et sifac album, tunc cadit sub sensu.	And if the moisture is between the skin of the testicles and the white layer, then it will fall under sense.
Quando ergo uis cognitionem coloris humiditatis, tunc experire colorem humiditatis in apostemate cum Intromisso quadrato, cuius forma praecessit.	When therefore you wish to have knowledge of the colour of the moisture, then try out the colour of the moisture in the abscess with a square instrument which has preceded in shape.
Secundum illud ergo quod egreditur in uestigio Intromissi, iudica de illo quod est inter ipsum.	According to what comes out therefore in the track of the inserted thing, judge about that which is between it.
Cum ergo uenimus ad curationem cum ferro, tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmo, ut phlebotometur si possibile est ei illud, et uides corpus eius plenum.	When therefore we come to the treatment with iron, then it is necessary that you order the patient to be bled if it is possible for him, and you see his body full.
Deinde resupinetur super dorsum suum super rem altam parum, et pone sub eo pannos multos.	Then he will be placed on his back over a high thing somewhat, and place many cloths under him.
Deinde sede tu super sinistram eius, et praecipe ministro, ut sedeat a dextra eius, qui extendat uirgam eius ad unum duorum laterum cutis testiculorum, et ad partem mirach uentris.	Then sit yourself over the left side of him, and command your attendant to sit on his right side, who should extend his rod across one or two sides of the scrotum, and into the region of the navel.
Deinde accipe spatumile latum, et seca cutem testiculorum ex medio per longitudinem, usque prope pectinem: et fiat sectio secundum rectitudinem aequedistantis lineae quae diuidit cutem testiculorum, donec perueniat ad sifac album comprehendens: et excoria ipsum et obserua, uel caue ex hoc, ut seces ipsum: et sit excoriatio tua qua ipsum excorias, ex parte quae suspenditur cum ouo plus: et subtiliter scrutare cum excoriatione secundum quantitatem quod tibi possibile est.	Then take a broad spatula and cut the skin of the testicles in half along its length as far as possible towards the navel: and let the incision be made according to straightness on an equal line which divides the skin of the testicles until it reaches the white ligament: and clean him out and observe, or beware lest you cut into himself: and let your cleaning be that by which you cleanse him from the part that hangs down like an egg more: and carefully search with cleansing according to as much as is possible for you.
Deinde perfora sifac plenum aqua perforatione ampla, et extrahe totam aquam.	Then pierce the white ligament full of water with a wide piercing, and draw out all the water.
Deinde separa inter duo labia sectionis cum uncinis, et extende sifac ad superiora, et non tangas cutem testiculorum comprehendentem: et incide sifac qualitercunque est possibile tibi incidere ipsum, aut cum totalitate sua, aut frustatim, praecipue latus eius subtile.	Then separate the two lips of the section with a hook, and stretch out the white ligament upwards, and do not touch the skin of the testicles that surrounds it: and cut the white ligament in such a way as is possible for you to cut it, either entirely or piecemeal, especially its thin side.
Nam si tu non exquisite perscrutaris, in incisione eius non fit securitas, quin aqua redeat.	For if you do not carefully search into it, there will be no security in the cut of it, lest the water return.
Si autem procedit ouum exterius a cute sua in hora operationis tuae: tunc quando compleueris sectionem sifac, reduc ipsum.	But if the egg proceeds externally from its wound during your operation hour: then when you have completed the section of the ligament, return it.
Deinde aggrega duo labia cutis testiculorum cum sutura.	Then gather together the two lips of the skin of the testicles with a suture.
Deinde cura ipsum sicut reliqua uulnera, donec sanetur.	Then take care of it as you do other wounds, until it heals.
Quod si inuenis ouum corruptum ex nigredine alia, tunc oportet ut liges uasa, quae sunt suspensorium, timens fluxum sanguinis.	But if you find the egg corrupted by blackness, then it is necessary to tie up the vessels, which are the suspenders, fearing a flow of blood.
Deinde abscinde testiculum cum suspensorio, et extrahe ouum: postea cura illud cum eo quod diximus.	Then cut off the testicle with its suspender, and draw out the egg; afterwards take care of it as we said.
Si uero aqua est aggregata in duabus partibus, tunc scias quia sunt duae ramices: seca ergo partem aliam secundum quod fecisti in altera aequaliter.	If indeed water is accumulated in two parts, then know that there are two branches: therefore cut the other part equally as you did to the one.
Et si aequatur tibi, ut sit operatio una, tunc fac: deinde absterge sanguinem.	And if it is equal to you, so that it should be one operation, then do this: then wipe away the blood.
Et intromitte in sectiones lanam submersam in oleo, aut in oleo rosato: et pone deforis lanam aliam quam submersisti in uino et oleo, et expande eam super duos testiculos, et mirach uentris: et pone desuper pannos duplicatos, et sunt puluilli: et liga eos desuper cum ligamento, quod est habens sex secundum hanc formam.	And insert a thread soaked in oil or rose oil into the sections, and put another thread which you dipped in wine and oil outside it, and spread it over the two testicles and the entrails, and put folded cloths above them, and they are small sacs: and bind them above with a suture that has six threads according to this form.
Deinde sumantur duo panni, et suantur, et impleantur la na carminata, secundum hanc similitudinem: et fiant extremitates quibus premitur ex coto, aut lana humida: et aggregentur cum strictura in lumbari bracharum: et una extremitatum accipiat super anum usque ad dorsum, et secunda accipiat ad partem pectinis: et duae extremitates super duas coxas inferius, et duae extremitates aliae super duo inguina, et aggregetur strictura tota in lumbari bracharum.	Then two cloths are taken and are sewn together, and they are filled with the crimsoned linen according to this likeness: and they make the extremities by which it is pressed from the belly or moist wool: and they gather them along with the suture in the loin of the arms: and one extremity takes hold from the anus up to the back, and the second takes hold at the part of the breast: and two other extremities above the lower thighs, and two other extremities above the inguinals, and the whole suture is gathered together in the loin of the arms.
Et, quandoque artificialiter medicatur haec ramex cum cauterio loco sectionis cum ferro: et est, ut accipias cauterium cultellare subtile, et seces cum eo cutem testiculorum: et est ignitum, secundum quod narrauimus: donec quando detegitur sifac album continens aquam: tunc accipe cauterium, secundum hanc formam.	And sometimes artificially this branch is treated with a cautery in the place of the section by iron: and it is as if you take a sharp-edged knife-like cautery, and cut with it the skin of the testicles: and it is ignited, according to what we have narrated: until when a white pus containing water is shown: then take the cautery, according to this form.
Assimilatur literae graecae.	It is assimilated to Greek letters.
Deinde perfora cum eo illud sifac, et est ignitum, donec egrediatur humiditas tota.	Then pierce with it the pus and it is ignited, until all moisture comes out.
Deinde extende sifac cum uncinis, et excoria cum cauterio subtili ignito, et incide ipsum secundum quod possibile est tibi, donec eradices totum eius.	Then extend the pus with a hook and peel it off with a sharp-edged ignited cautery, and cut into itself as much as is possible for you, until all its roots are eradicated.
Et caue ex ouo, ne tangat ipsum ignis.	And beware that it not touch fire with itself.
Et scias, quod haec operatio est saluior, et longinquior a fluxu sanguinis, et melior quam operatio cum sectione.	And know that this operation is more safe and farther from the flowing of blood, and better than the operation with incision.
Si uero contrarietatem tibi facit in hora sectionis, aut in hora cauterii apostema calidum, aut fluxus sanguinis, aut aliquid aliud: tunc oportet ut cures quod contrarietatem tibi facit ex illo cum curatione quae conuenit ei, secundum quod praemissum est.	But if a contrariety happens to you in the hour of incision, or in the hour of cauterizing an aposteme warm, or flux of blood, or something else: then it behoves that you cure what contrariety is happening to you from it with a treatment that suits it, according as has been aforementioned.
Si autem infirmus est timidus, et non expectat super hanc operationem, propter horribilitatem suam: tunc administra perforationem secundum quod ego narro illud: et est.	But if the ailing person is timid and does not await this operation because of his frightfulness: then administer a perforation according to what I tell you, and it is.
Quando certificatur tibi apud te per illud quod diximus de significationibus, quod ramex est aquosa: tunc oportet quod facias sedere infirmum super sedem eleuatam.	When you have been assured with yourself by what we said about the signs, that the ramex is watery: then it behoves that you make the ailing person sit on an elevated chair.
Deinde perfora apostema in inferiori parte sui cum spatumili lato: et pone perforationem secundum longitudinem corporis, et sit apertio ampla, donec currat aqua tota.	Then pierce the aposteme in its lower part with a broad spatulum and place the perforation according to the length of the body, and let the opening be wide until all the water runs out.
Deinde pone super locum cotum, et liga ipsum, et dimitte ipsum ut currat residuum aquae: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur uulnus.	Then place over the cleansed area a bandage and bind it, and let it be until the remaining water runs out: then take care of it, until the wound is healed.
Si autem contrarietas sit egressioni aquae in hora qua perforas ipsam: et non sit illud nisi propterea, quia panniculus albus contrarietatem facit in orificio uulneris, et prohibet exitum aquae: tunc oportet ut intromittas pennam in uulnus, aut instrumentum cum quo extrahitur aqua hydropicorum, cuius forma praecessit: aut adde in operatione uulneris parumper.	But if the contrariety is of the flowing out of water at the hour when you pierce it, and it is not for this reason alone, because a white membrane makes contrariety in the wound orifice and prevents the exit of water: then it behoves that you insert a feather into the wound, or an instrument with which water from abscesses is drawn out, whose shape has been mentioned before: or add a little bit to the operation of the wound.
Et scias, quod aqua redit, et aggregatur post sex menses, aut circiter eos.	And know that the water returns and gathers after six months, or thereabouts.
Cum ergo aggregatur, tunc pertoretur secundum eundem modum, et pertransibit infirmus dies suos.	When therefore it is gathered, then it should be perforated in the same manner, and the ailing person will pass through his days.
¶ De cura Ramicis carnosae.	Of the care for wounds of the flesh.
Caput LXIII.	Chapter Sixty-Three.
Scias, quod in sectione super hanc Ramicem, est ex timore perducente ad perniciem in pluribus dispositionibus.	You should know that in the incision above this wound, there is from fear leading to harm in many dispositions.
Quapropter uidetur mihi eius dimissio saluari ex ea.	Therefore it seems to me that its dismissal would save from it.
Et ego sum rememorans operationem in ea, et species apostematis.	And I am recalling the treatment of it, and the appearance of the aposteme.
Dico ergo, quod accidunt apostemata multa in corporibus, ex quibus componuntur testiculi: et fit illud ex caussis multis, scilicet.	Therefore I say, that many apostemes occur in the bodies, from which carbuncles are formed: and this is done for many causes, namely.
Aut ex superfluitate acuta, uel acri, quae effunditur ad testiculos.	Or from an excess of sharp or acute fluid that flows to the testicles.
Aut ex percussione.	Or from a blow.
Et est color apostematis secundum colorem corporis, et non inuenitur ei dolor: et est apostema graue.	And the color of the aposteme is according to the color of the body, and no pain is found in it, and it is a grave aposteme.
Et fortasse est apostema lapideum, cuius color est fuscus, et non est sensus ei.	And perhaps it is a stony aposteme, whose color is darkish, and there is no sense in it.
Et quandoque fit ex nodatione arteriarum, et inflatione earum: sicut iam praecessit eius rememoratio: aut ex inflatione uenarum.	And sometimes it occurs from the clotting of arteries and their inflation: as I have already recalled its mention; or from the inflation of the veins.
Quod ergo est ex eis ex inflatione arteriarum, cognoscitur per dispositionem apostematis, quando comprimis ipsum digitis tuis.	Which therefore is from them from the inflation of the arteries, is recognized by the arrangement of the aposteme, when you compress it with your fingers.
Et non oportet ut tangas ipsum prorsus.	And it should not be touched at all.
Illud uero quod fit ex inflatione uenarum, non dispergitur ex eo aliquid apud compressionem cum digitis.	But that which occurs from the inflation of the veins, does not dissipate anything under a pressing with fingers.
Et iam possibile est, quod super hanc speciem fiat sectio, et super reliquas carnes: et est, ut seces cutem testiculorum.	And now it is possible that an incision be made over this kind and over the remaining flesh, and that one cuts the skin of the testicles.
Deinde extende ouum ad sursum, et extrahe ipsum cum sifach albo: et libera suspensorium ex uasis, et liga uasa: et incide suspensorium postquam tu liberas ipsum ab omni parte ex partibus oui.	Then stretch the scrotum upwards and draw out the testicle with a white cord, and free the suspensory ligament from the veins, and bind the veins; and make an incision in the suspensory ligament after you have freed it from all parts of the scrotum.
Si ergo ouum consolidatum est cum illis carnibus natis, tunc oportet ut attrahas ouum, et incidas ipsum.	So if the scrotum is consolidated with those born flesh tissues, then you should grasp the testicle and make an incision in it.
Et si adhaerentia est inter aliquid ex siphaket, aut in eo quod est inter uasa: tunc oportet ut liberes totam illam adhaerentiam, et incidas eam incisione rotunda.	And if the adhesion is between something from a spleen or in what is between the vesicles: then it is necessary that you free the entire adhesion and cut it with a round incision.
Si autem est natiuitas carnis in loco adhaerentiae quae est retro: tunc oportet ut incidas totum eius, et extrahas ouum, sicut diximus.	But if it is the birth of flesh at the place of adhesion which is behind: then it is necessary that you cut all of it and take out the placenta, as we said.
Cum ergo completur operatio tua, tnnc imple uulnus in lana infusa in oleo rosato, et uino: deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Therefore when your operation is completed, then fill the wound with wool steeped in rose oil and wine: thereafter care for it with the remaining treatment, until it heals.
¶ De cura Ramicis, quae est cum Vite.	On the cure of Wounds which are with Vinegar.
Caput LXIIII.	Chapter 64.
Uitis est apostema inuolutum quadam inuolutione, simile botro, cum mollificatione testiculorum: et fit difficilis super infirmum motus et exercitium, et deambulatio.	Vine is a swelling wrapped around with some kind of wrapping, similar to an abscess, with the softening of the testicles: and it makes movement and exercise difficult over a weak person, and walking.
Et in curatione huius aegritudinis est ex timore, propter illud cuius praecessit rememoratio.	And in the cure of this illness is from fear, because of the thing that came before its remembering.
Verum oportet, ut dicamus operationem in ea secundum quod fecerunt primi.	But it is necessary to say that the operation for it is done according to what the first ones did.
Dico ergo, quod oportet ut facias sedere infirmum super sedem eleuatam.	I therefore say, that you should have the sick person sit on a high elevated seat.
Deinde impelle suspensorium testiculorum ad inferiora.	Then push the supporter of the testicles downwards.
Deinde tene cutem testiculorum cum digitis tuis, cum uasis quae sunt propinqua uirgae: et teneat ea minister alius, et extendat ea extensione uehementi.	Then take the skin of the testicles with your fingers, along with the vessels that are near the root: and have another servant hold it, and stretch it with a strong stretching.
Deinde incide cum spatumili lato acuto sectione transuersa in directo uasorum, donec detegantur uasa.	Then cut with a sharp bistoury having a broad blade, a transverse incision directly on the vessels, until the vessels are revealed.
Deinde excoria ab omni parte, sicut diximus tibi in extractione Arteriarum quae sunt in timporibus.	Then scrape away from all parts, as we said to you in the removal of arteries which are in the scalp.
Postea fige in eis acum in qua sit filum duplum, et liga ipsum in primo locorum quibus accidunt Vites: et liga ipsum iterum in ultimo eorum.	Then insert a needle into them with a thread which is double the size of the filament, and tie it first at the places where the Vine occurs: and then tie it again at their last ones.
Deinde seca ea in media sectione recta secundum longitudinem corporis, et extrahe quod aggregatur ex humiditatibus faeculentis corruptis.	Then cut them in the middle straight according to the length of the body, and draw out what is accumulated from corrupted putrid humors.
Deinde cura uulnus cum curatione reliquorum uulnerum, in quibus uis generari saniem, ut cadant uasa quae nutriunt unum testiculorum.	Then care for the wound with the treatment of other wounds, from which a discharge of pus is to be generated, so that the vessels nourishing one of the testicles may fall.
Non est enim malum per illud.	For it is not bad through it.
Si autem accidat Vitis omnibus uasis, tunc oportet ut extrahantur propter hoc testiculi cum uasis: ut non priuetur ouum nutrimento, propter incisionem, et tabescat, uel arescat, et non sit iuuamentum cum eis.	But if the vein is cut with all the vessels, then it is necessary that the testicles themselves are drawn out because of this, along with their vessels: so that the sperm may not be deprived of nourishment on account of the incision, and wither away or perish, and there would be no benefit with them.
¶ De cura Ramicis intestinalis.	About the care for ruptured intestines.
Caput LXV.	Chapter 65.
Euentus huius Ramicis est ex sectione, quae accidit in sifach extenso super uentrem in parte inguinum ex mirach uentris.	The outcome of this rupture is from an incision which occurs in the navel extended over the belly in the part of the groin from the inside of the abdomen.
Quare descendunt intestina ex illa Ruptura ad unum testiculorum.	Why do the intestines descend from that rupture to one of the testicles.
Et haec Ruptura est aut ex sifach, aut extensione eius.	And this rupture is either from a hernia, or its extension.
Et accidunt istae duae species ex caussis multis. Aut ex percussione. Aut saltu. Aut clamore. Aut eleuatione rei grauis, et similibus.	And these two kinds occur from many causes. Or from a blow. Or a jump. Or shouting. Or the lifting of something heavy, and similar things.
Et signum, quando est ex extensione sifach.	And a sign is shown when it is from an extension of the hernia.
Est quod accidit paulatim in tempore longo, et non accidit subito: et est apostema aequale uersus profundum: propterea, quod sifach comprimit intestinum.	It is that which happens gradually over a long period of time and does not happen suddenly: and it is an ecchymosis equal in size against the depth: therefore, because the hernia compresses the intestine.
Et signum eius quando est ex sectione sifach, quia facit accidere ex principio sui dolorem uehementem subito: et est apostema diuersum, apparens sub cute propinque: et illud est propter exitum intestini, et cursus eius ad exteriora sifach.	And a sign of it when it is from the cutting of the hernia, because it makes a severe pain suddenly occur from its beginning: and there is an ecchymosis different, appearing near the skin: and that is because of the exit of the intestine, and its course to the exterior of the hernia.
Et quandoque egreditur cum intestino zirbum: et nominatur haec Ramex intestinalis, et zirbia: et quandoque fit cum uentositate.	And sometimes it emerges with the intestine a tumor-like growth: and this is called the intestinal reed, and the zirbia: and sometimes it occurs with inflammation.
Et quandoque currit in intestinum stercus, et retinetur illic: et est cum eo pernicies infirmi: quoniam facit accidere dolorem prauum, et praecipue quando premitur.	And sometimes it runs into the intestine feces, and is retained there: and with it is the harm of the sick man: because it causes to occur evil pain, and especially when it is pressed.
Et in curatione specierum aegritudinis huius cum ferro est timor: quare oportet ut caueatur casus in ea.	And in the cure of this disease species with iron there is fear: wherefore it behooves that a case be guarded against in it.
Et modus operationis est, ut praecipias infirmo, ut reducat intestinum manu sua ad interiora concauitatis suae, si obedit reditui.	And the method of the operation is, that you command the sick man to reduce his intestine by hand to the inner parts of his own concavity, if he obeys the return.
Deinde resupinetur super collum suum inter manus tuas: et eleua crura eius.	Then it is raised up over his neck between your hands: and lift up his legs.
Deinde extende cutem quae sequitur cutem ad superiora, et seca cutem testiculorum totam per longitudinem.	Then extend the skin which follows the skin upwards, and cut the skin of the testicles entirely along its length.
Deinde fige in duobus labiis sectionis uncinos, secundum quod indiges ad aperiendum sectionem cum eis: et sectio sit secundum quantitatem, quod sit possibile, ut egrediatur ex ea ouum.	Then fix in the two lips of the incision needles, according as you are able to open the incision with them: and let the incision be of such size, that it may be possible for an egg to come out of it.
Deinde excoria siphak, et quae sunt sub cute testiculorum, donec quando detegitur sifach album, durum ab omni parte: tunc intromitte digitum tuum indicem in eo quod sequitur testiculum, in eo quod est inter siphach album, quod est sub cute oui, et inter sifach secundum, et absolue cum eo adhaerentiam quae est in posteriori parte oui.	Then peel the siphac, and what is under the skin of the testicles, until when it is uncovered the white, hard siphac from every part: then insert your index finger into that which follows the testicle, in that which is between the white siphac, which is under the shell of the egg, and the second siphac, and separate entirely with it the adhesion that is in the posterior part of the egg.
Deinde moue cum manu dextra ad interiora cutem testiculorum: et cum hoc extende sifach album ad sursum, cum manu sinistra: et eleua ouum cum sifach ad partem sectionis: et praecipe ministro, ut extendat ouum ad sursum: et tu solue adhaerentiam, quae est retro solutione completa.	Then move it with the right hand to the inner skin of the testicles: and when this extends the white siphac upwards with the left hand: and lift up the egg with the siphac to the part of the incision: and command the servant, that he extend the egg upwards: and you loosen the adhesion, which is behind the completed operation.
Et quaere digitis tuis, ut non sit aliquid illic ex intestino inuoluto in sifach albo duro.	And inquire with your fingers, that there be nothing at all there of the intestine wrapped up in the hard white siphac.
Si autem inuenis ex eo aliquid: tunc impelle ipsum ad uentrem inferius.	If however something is found inside him from it: then push it downwards into his belly.
Deinde accipe acum, in qua sit filum grossum, factum licinium ex decem filis: et intromitte ipsam apud postremum sifach, id est, tunicae, quod est sub cute testiculorum quae sequitur sectionem: deinde incide extremitates quae eminent ex filo, donec sint quatuor fila.	Then take the needle in which is a thick thread, made from ten threads: and insert it near the back part of the sifach, that is, the pouch, under the skin of the testicles which follows the incision: then cut off the ends which project from the thread, until there are four threads.
