Si ergo est penetrans in margine ani interius prope, tunc extrahe filum ex illo foramine: ita ut intromittas digitum tuum in anum, et extrahas extremitatem fili, et aggreges duas extremitates simul: et stringe utramque, et dimitte illud die uno, aut duobus diebus: et quanto plus incidit filum in carne, stringe ipsum bene, donec incidantur illae carnes quae sunt inter duas extremitates fili, et cadant: deinde cura uulnus, donec consolidetur, et sanetur.	If therefore it is penetrating into the edge of the anus on the inside nearby, then draw out the thread from that opening: thus inserting your finger into the anus and drawing out the end of the thread and gathering both ends together: and tighten both, and leave it for one or two days: and as much as the thread inclines in the flesh, tighten it well until the flesh between the two ends of the thread becomes incised and drops: then cure the wound until it consolidates and heals.
Si autem orificium Fistulae non est penetrans: tunc fac ipsum penetrare quocunque modo praeparatur tibi, nisi sit in profundo multum.	But if the opening of the fistula is not penetrating: then make it penetrate however you prepare for yourself, unless it be very deep.
Non enim inest tibi, ut facias illud propter lacertum, ut non incidas ipsum.	For indeed it is not for you to do that because of the tendon, lest you cut it.
Deinde fac cum ea sicut diximus, donec sanetur.	Then do with it as we said, until it heals.
Forma Spatumilis spinosi quo finditur Fistula, cuius curuitas est acuta ualde, et pars altera est non acuta, ut non incidat illud quod non est necesse, sicut uides.	The shape of the splint for a spiny fistula in which it is cut, whose curvature is very sharp and the other part is not sharp so that what is not necessary does not cut into it, as you see.
¶ De sutura Hemorroidarum, ex quibus currit sanguis ex incisione earum: et cura fissurarum.	Concerning the stitching of hemorrhoids from which blood flows out through an incision into them: and the cure of their cracks.
Caput LXXXI.	Chapter 81.
Sunt Hemorroides secundum duos modos.	There are hemorrhoids in two ways.
Aut enim sunt intra anum, similes uesicis carbonum, uel prunarum: aut quasi ipsae sint grana uuae.	For either they are inside the anus, resembling carbuncles or blisters, or else like themselves are like clusters of grapes.
Et ex eis sunt paruae, et magnae: et sanguis currit ex eis semper, et est una, et sunt multae.	And there are small and large ones: and blood flows from them always, and it is one, and they are many.
Et sunt extra anum, et in extremitatibus eius.	And they are outside the anus, and at its extremities.
Verumtamen istae quae sunt extra anum, sunt secundum plurimum paucae humiditatis, ex quibus currit aqua citrina, aut parum sanguinis cursu assiduo: et sunt secundum colorem corporis.	However those which are outside the anus are for the most part few in moisture, from which clear water or a little blood flows with steady course: and they are according to the color of the body.
Et curatio eius quae est intra anum, est, ut praecipias infirmo ut assellet: et exprimatur, donec egrediatur anus, et appareant athelil tibi.	And its cure which is inside the anus is, that you should command the patient to sit down and be pressed: and it should be squeezed until the anus comes out and they appear to you.
Propterea ergo et suspende cum uncinis: aut tene eos cum ungue tuo.	Therefore also hang them with a hook: or hold them with your finger.
Deinde incide eos apud radices suas.	Then cut into them at their roots.
Si autem non retinentur in eis uncini, propter humiditatem eorum et ipsorum mollificationem: tunc cape eos cum panno aspero, aut cum coto ex diploide lanea, et extrahe eos cum digitis tuis.	But if the hooks do not hold in them because of their moisture and softening: then take them with a rough cloth, or with a strip from double woolen cloth, and pull them out with your fingers.
Deinde incide eos, et pulueriza super eos post incisionem quosdam pulueres calidos, ut stent eis loco cauterii.	Then cut into them, and sprinkle over them after the cutting some hot powders to make a cauterizing.
Aut cauteriza eos secundum quod praecessit in capitulo cauterizandi.	Or cauterize them according to what preceded in the chapter on cauterization.
Deinde cura eos cum reliqua curatione, donec sanentur.	Then cure them with the rest of the treatment until they are healed.
Quod si non obedit anus egressioni, tunc clisteriza infirmum clisteri in quo sit mordicatio parua, ut lauetur cum eo quod est in ano, et obediat egressioni uelociter, quando exprimit se infirmus.	But if the anus does not obey evacuation, then purge the patient with a purgative in which is a little bitterness, so that he may be cleansed with it what is in his rectum and quickly obey evacuation when he presses out.
Si autem athelil sunt extrinseci ab ano, tunc res eorum est leuis, facilis: et est ut capias eos cum ungue tuo, aut capias eos cum uncino, et incidas eos.	But if the growths are external to the anus, then their treatment is easy and simple: and it is as if you take them with your finger, or take them with a hook, and cut into them.
Deinde cura eos cum eo quod diximus, donec sanentur.	Then treat them with that which we said, until they are healed.
Et qui abhorret incisionem cum ferro, tunc oportet ut administres suturam eorum secundum hunc modum.	And he who despairs of a cut with iron, then it is necessary to sew them up in this manner.
Accipe filum inuolutum, et intromitte ipsum in acum.	Take up the thread which has been wound and insert it into the needle.
Deinde extrahe athelil ad superiora, et fac ipsum penetrare cum acu in radice eius ex parte altera: et inuolue duas extremitates fili, in inferiori parte acus, et sint latitudinaliter: et stringe athelil strictura forti.	Then draw out the needle to the upper part and make it pierce with the needle into its root from the other side: and wind both ends of the thread around the lower part of the needle and be placed laterally: and draw tight the needle strongly.
Deinde noda filum, et extrahe acum.	Then tie the thread and draw out the needle.
Fac illud cum omnibus athelil, et dimitte ex eis unum: nec suas ipsum, ut currat ex eo superfluitas sanguinis.	Do this with all of them and let one [suture] go loose: do not make it so that the surplus of blood runs from it.
Deinde pone super anum pannum infusum in oleo rosato, aut caeroto, et pone ipsum super anum: et praecipe infirmo, ut quiescat.	Then place a cloth dipped in rose oil or ceruse on the anus and place it over the anus: and command the patient to rest.
Deinde dimitte ipsum, donec cadat.	Then let him go until he falls.
Cum ergo cadunt athelil, cura eos cum unguentis, et reliqua curatione, donec sanentur.	Therefore when the sutures fall out, treat them with ointments and the rest of the treatment, until they are healed.
¶ De cura Fissurarum.	¶ On the care of Fissures.
Multotiens enim accidunt ex exiccatione stercoris, et constrictione naturae.	For many times they happen from drying up of feces and constriction of nature.
Cum ergo antiquantur, et non ualet in eis medicina: tunc oportet ut radas cum puncta Spatumilis, aut cum ungue tuo, donec fiant humidae, et auferatur ab eis cortex superior qui prohibet eas a consolidatione.	So when they become old and medicine does not help in them: then it is necessary to scrape with the points of a sponge or with your own nail until they are moist and remove from them the top crust which prevents them from consolidating.
Deinde cura eas, donec consolidentur secundum quod oportet.	Then treat them, until they consolidate as is necessary.
Si autem non consolidantur: tunc itera eas cum rasione uehementiori quam prima, donec sanguinentur multum, et excorientur deinde cura eas, donec sanentur.	But if they do not consolidate: then repeat them with a sharper scraping than the first, until they are bloody and then scrape again treat them, until they are healed.
¶ De curatione Almirmar inuersorum, et non inuersorum: et Athelil siccorum, et Formicae.	¶ On the cure of ulcers which turn inward, and not inward: and of dry sutures and of ants.
Caput LXXXII.	Chapter 82.
Scias quod Almirmar non est nisi nodus rotundus secundum colorem corporis, similis capiti claui: et fit in toto corpore, praecipue in inferioribus partibus pedum, et digitis: et accidit ex eis dolor apud ambulationem.	Know that Almirmar is nothing but a rounded knot according to the color of the body, similar to a key's handle: and it forms throughout the entire body, especially in the lower parts of the feet and fingers: and pain occurs at walking.
Oportet ergo ut secetur quod est in circumitu claui, et teneatur cum forficibus, aut cum uncino, et eradicetur ex radice sua.	Therefore it is necessary to cut out that which is in the surrounding area of the key's handle, and hold it with forceps or a hook, and be rooted out from its root.
Deinde cura illud: et si uis cauteriza illud secundum quod praecessit in capitulo suo.	Then cure that; and if you wish, cauterize it according to what preceded in its chapter.
Ex athelil autem siccis unus est eminentia parua, aspera, filtrata, rotunda supra superficiem corporis.	From the armpit however dry there is a small, rough, hardened, rounded elevation above the surface of the body.
Et multotiens accidunt in manibus puerorum.	And many times it occurs on the hands of boys.
Et curatio eius est, ut extendas athelil, et incidas ipsum: aut stringas ipsum cum filo de serico: aut cum pilo, donec cadat.	And its cure is to stretch out the armpit, and cut it: or bind it with a thread of silk: or with a thorn until it falls.
Et si uis, cauteriza ipsum secundum quod praemissum est cum igne, aut cum medicina acuta: et iam eradicantur athelil inuersi, et non inuersi cum instrumento quod ego dicam.	And if you wish, cauterize it with fire or with sharp medicine: and now the armpits which were inverted are eradicated, and not those that I shall call by an instrument.
Formica autem est etiam eminentia parua filtrata, grossa, super superficiem corporis, uadens in profundum ualde: et quando inuenit eam frigus, sentitur in ea simile mordicationi formicae, et fit in corpore toto: et plurimum eius fit in manibus.	However a Formica is also a small, hardened, thick elevation above the surface of the body, running deep into it: and when cold weather finds it, one senses something similar to an ant's bite in it, and it occurs throughout the entire body: and most of all it occurs in the hands.
Et curatio eius est, ut accipias cannulam ex penna anseris, aut penna uulturis forti: et pone illam cannulam super Formicam, donec contineat circulus cannulae ex partibus eius.	And its cure is to take a reed from the pen of a goose or a strong vulture: and place that reed over the Formica, until it holds the circle of the reed on its parts.
Deinde reuolue manum tuam cum cannula, donec seces quod est in circumitu Formicae: et ponas eam in profundo carnis, et eradices Formicam ex radice eius.	Then turn your hand with the reed, until you cut out what is in the surrounding area of the Formica: and place it deep into the flesh, and root out the Formica from its root.
Et si uis, fac illud cum cannula aeris, aut ferri, secundum hanc formam.	And if you wish, do that with a reed of air or iron, in this form.
Sit superius cannulae ad sublimitatem trahens surdum inuolutum, ut alleuietur super digitum apprehensio eius et ipsius reuolutio.	The cannula should be stretched upwards as high as possible while drawing out the swelling, that it may be eased over the finger and its own reversal.
Et si uis cauteriza Formicam secundum quod praemissum est in cauterizatione Athelil in capitulo de cauterio.	And if you wish to cauterize a scorpion according to what has been previously said in the chapter on cauterizing a burn.
¶ De formis Instrumentorum quae administrantur ad Clisteria in aegritudinibus Ani, et solutionis uentris, et colicae.	On forms of instruments which are administered for cleansing of the intestines and solutions of the stomach and the bowels.
Caput LXXXIII.	Chapter 83.
Quandoque Clistere fit ex argento, aut ex aurichalco, aut ex aere fuso, aut malleato.	Sometimes a clister is made of silver or of tinned brass or melted bronze, or hammered iron.
Et quandoque fit ex istis Instrumentis paruum, et magnum, secundum illos in quibus administrantur.	And sometimes it is made from these instruments small and large, according to those in which they are administered.
Illud ergo quod administratur in curatione puerorum paruorum, sit paruum: et quorum ani sunt debiles, aut dolorosi, sic et clisteria eorum.	Therefore that which is administered for the care of small children should be small; and that which is given to those whose intestines are weak or painful should also be similar.
Clistere magnum.	The large clister.
Cistere paruum.	Small catheter.
Canna eius, id est, caput superius in quo ligatur uter, sit amplum secundum hunc modum: et sit ei distinctio ut ligetur uter sicut uides, et extremitas eius inferior quae intromittitur in anum, sit surda, id est, non aperta, lenis, ualde, trahens ad subtilitatem: et in uno laterum eius sint duo foramina, et in latere altero foramen unum.	Its tube, that is the upper part in which the uterus is tied, should be wide according to this manner; and there should be a distinction so that the uterus may be tied as you see it, and its lower extremity which is inserted into the anus, should be mute, that is not open, soft, very, drawing to subtlety: and on one side of it are two holes, and on the other side a single hole.
Et sit amplitudo foraminis secundum grossitudinem radiorum, et grossius parum, et sit uter in quo ponuntur medicinae ex uesica animalis: aut ex charta ouis, quae sit secundum formam asofrati paruae: cuius radix sit palmus unus.	And the width of the hole should be according to the size of the stitches, a little larger or smaller, and it should be an uterus in which medicines are placed from animal bladder: or from ox parchment, which is shaped like a small dried sponge, whose root is one palm.
Et perforetur foraminibus multis sicut reuoluitur, et sit spacium quod est inter omne foramen grossitudo digiti.	And it should be perforated with many holes as it revolves, and the space that is between every hole should be the width of a finger.
Deinde intromitte in illa foramina filum forte ex filo crudo, quod sit ex decem filis, aut circiter ea, et aggrega cum eo utrem sicut asofrati.	Then insert into those holes a strong thread from raw thread, which is of ten threads, or about that many, and tie it with the uterus like a sponge.
Cum ergo ponitur in eo uter, stringatur in capite clisteris inter duo distinguentia constrictione forti.	When therefore the uterus is placed on it, a string should be tied around the head with a strong constriction between two distinct divisions by means of a clister.
Deinde clisteriza cum eo.	Then tie a ligature with him.
Et haec est forma circuli utris hic depicta, et foraminum.	And this is the shape of the circle and the openings depicted here.
Qualitas autem clisterizandi cum eo, est: ut impleas utrem, aut uesicam ex medicina, quae sit calefacta secundum quantitatem tolerantiae infirmi: et caue ne sit calida ualde, aut frigida ualde.	But the quality of tying a ligature with him is: that you fill the uterus or bladder with medicine which is warmed according to the tolerance of the sick person: and beware lest it be very hot or very cold.
Deinde resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum, et eleuet crura sua ad superiora: et pone sub eo inthaan, id est, corium super quod iacent homines, aut linteamen.	Then the sick person is laid back on his back and lifts up his legs to the upper parts: and place under him an heapan, that is, a skin on which men lie, or a cloth.
Deinde inunge extremitatem Clisteris cum oleo, aut cum albugine oui, aut cum mucillagine foenugraeci, aut similium.	Then anoint the extremity of the clister with oil, or with lamb's fat, or with fenugreek paste, or similar things.
Deinde intromitte ipsum in anum cum facilitate.	Then insert it into the anus with ease.
Deinde accipiat minister utrem cum duabus manibus suis simul, et exprimat ipsum cum uehementia, donec euacuet totum quod est in Clisteri in intestinum.	Then the servant should take hold of the uterus with both hands at once, and squeeze it out vigorously until all that is in the clister is evacuated into the intestine.
Deinde extrahe Clistere, et eleuet infirmus crura sua ad parietem.	Then draw out the clister, and let the sick person lift up his legs to the wall.
Quod si medicina cogit eum ad exitum, tunc teneat quantum potest.	But if the medicine causes him to evacuate, then he should hold on for as long as possible.
Et si dormit cum ea nocte tota, est magis ultimum in iuuamento.	And if he sleeps with it all through the night, it is a greater relief.
Si autem clisterizas eum in aegritudinibus solutionis uentris, et festinat exitus eius: tunc itera clistere, donec sanetur.	But if you tie him with the clister for diseases of the digestive tract and he hastens to evacuate it: then repeat the clistering until he is cured.
Quod si in ano sunt hemorroides, aut apostemata laedentia, tunc sit clistere subtile ualde, lene, ex clisteribus quibus clisterizantur pueri.	But if there are hemorrhoids or painful swellings in the anus: then let the clister be very fine and soft, like those used to tie up children.
Et haec sit forma clisteris subtilis super quod sit stricta cutis.	And this should be the shape of a thin clister over which tight skin lies.
¶ De curatione Vulnerum capitis sine fractura ossis.	About the cure of wounds of the head without a fractured bone.
Caput LXXXIIII.	I don't see any text to translate. The notation "Caput LXXXIIII" appears to be a medieval heading, possibly from an index or table of contents. If you provide the actual text for Caput LXXXIIII, I'll be happy to assist with its translation into English.
Iam dixi in diuisione de curatione uulnerum quod conueniebat libro, et ego dicam hic curationem eorum cum manu, et cum medicinis secundum complementum.	I have said in the division concerning the cure of wounds what suited this book, and I will say here their cure with hand, and with medicines according to completeness.
Dico ergo, quod uulnera diuersificantur secundum illud quo fiunt uulnera, et secundum locum super quem cadit uulnus.	I say therefore that wounds are divided according to the thing by which they are made, and according to the place on which the wound falls.
Res ergo quibus fiunt uulnera multotiens, sunt sicut iactus lapidis: aut incisio ensis, aut cultelli: aut percussio cum lancea, aut ligno, aut sagitta: et similibus illis ex rebus multis.	Therefore, the things by which wounds are made often are such as a stone thrown: or cutting with a sword, or a knife: or striking with a spear, or wood, or an arrow: and similar to those many things.
Vulnera autem quae fiunt secundum loca corporis sunt, sicut uulnus quod cadit super caput, aut collum, aut pectus, aut uentrem, aut epar: et similia ex eis membris.	But the wounds that are made according to places of the body are such as a wound that falls on the head, or neck, or chest, or belly, or side: and similar to those members.
Et ego sum narrans curationes quorundam uulnerum, ut ponam eam ratiocinationem et regulam super reliqua uulnera.	And I am relating the cures of some wounds, so that I may place this reasoning and rule over the remaining wounds.
Et ego incipiam a uulneribus capitis simplicibus: quoniam rememoratio compositorum ueniet in principio capituli tertii.	And I will begin with simple head wounds, because the treatment of compound wounds will come at the end of the third chapter.
Dico ergo.	I say therefore.
Quando accidit in capite uulnus simplex, et non est fractura ossis: considera tunc, si est ex iactu lapidis, aut ei similibus, et iam fregit cutem tantum: et est uulnus magnum, et times super infirmum euentum apostematis calidi: tunc propera, et phlebotoma cephalicam statim: et non tardes illud: et extrahe ei ex sanguine secundum quantitatem uirtutis eius: si non fuerit prohibens aliquid a phlebotomia, praecipue si fuerit sanguis qui egreditur ex uulnere paucus.	I say therefore. When a simple wound occurs in the head and there is no break of bone: then consider whether it was caused by a stone or something similar and already broke only the skin: and if the wound is large and you fear an evil outcome from a hot apostema: then hurry and apply immediately the cephalic phlebotomy: and do not delay it: and draw out from him blood according to the quantity of its virtue: if nothing prohibits bleeding, especially if the blood coming out of the wound is little.
Et sit phlebotomia ex contrario partis uulneratae.	And let the phlebotomy be on the opposite side of the wounded part.
Et caueat infirmus sibi a repletione, et uino, et cibis grossis.	And let the patient beware for himself to avoid filling, and wine, and coarse foods.
Si autem minutionem prohibet aliquid, tunc minoretur ex cibo, et non appropinquet carnibus, neque uinis.	If something prevents a cutting, then it will be lessened from food, and it will not approach meats nor wines.
Et pone super uulnus si accidit ei apostema calidum, cotum infusum in oleo rosato solo, aut cum uino in quo est stipticitas.	And place over the wound if it happens to have a hot apostume, a poultice infused in rose oil alone, or with wine in which there is sharpness.
Si autem securus fueris ab apostemate calido, tunc pone super uulnus, si est recens cum sanguine suo, et non mutauit ipsum aer, puluerem quem ego narrabo post paululum: et si iam mutauit ipsum aer, tunc pone super ipsum quaedam unguenta, donec sanetur.	And if you are free from a hot aposteme, then place over the wound, if it is recent with its own blood and has not changed air, powder which I will tell later: and if already it has changed air, then place over it certain ointments, until it heals.
Si autem uulnus est magnum, aut est ex incisione ensis, et similium: et non aggregantur labia eius per puluillos, tunc aggrega ipsa cum sutura, secundum quod ego narrabo in uulneribus uentris de sutura eorum.	And if the wound is great or is from a cut of a sword, and similar things: and its lips do not come together by themselves, then gather it with a suture, according to what I will say about the wounds of the belly regarding their sutures.
Si autem uulnus iam detectum est ab osse, et pendet, et non est retentio eius, nisi in suspensorio paruo: tunc incide ipsum.	And if the wound has already been exposed by a bone and hangs, and there is no holding of it except with a small bandage: then cut it.
Deinde cura uulnus cum medicinis, et restaura in eo carnem duram loco cutis, et praecipe infirmo, ut alatur cibis in quibus est grossitudo, sicut sunt capita, et triticum coctum, donec sit ut puls: et eis similia.	Then cure the wound with medicines and restore hard flesh to it in place of skin, and command the sick person to nourish himself with foods in which there is thickness, such as heads and cooked barley until he be like a pulse: and things similar.
Quod si inuenis in cute putrefactionem, et non adhaeret ossi: tunc incide putrefactum totum, et proiice ipsum: deinde cura illud.	But if you find a putrefaction in the skin and it does not adhere to the bone: then cut out the whole putrefaction and throw it away: afterwards cure that.
Si autem in his uulneribus est arteria, aut uena ex qua fluit sanguis: et non abscinditur per medicinas, tunc inquire super arteriam.	And if there is an artery or a vein from which blood flows in these wounds and it cannot be cut off by remedies, then search above the artery.
Si ergo inuenis eam non sectam, tunc seca eam cum Spatumili, aut liga eam.	So if you find it not to be cut with a razor, then cut it with cauterization or bind it.
Quod si necessitas prouocat quando non confert illud quod diximus, tunc cauteriza eam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	And if necessity prompts and does not provide what we said, then cauterize it until the blood is cut off.
Si autem uulnera ista sunt parua, simplicia, tunc res eorum est facilis, leuis: ita ut puluerizes super ea hunc puluerem: quoniam consolidat ea antequam mutet ea aer.	If however these wounds are small, simple, then the treatment of them is easy, light: thus powder them with this powder, for it solidifies them before air alters them.
¶ Modus Pulueris incarnatiui.	The method of powdered flesh.
Recipe olibani partem unam, et sanguinis draconis partes duas, et calcis non extinctae partes tres: teratur totum multum, et cribelletur: et impleatur ex eo uulnus, et constringatur constrictione bona, donec adhaereat super ipsum bene, et coaguletur cum sanguine.	Recipe one part of olibanum, and two parts of dragon's blood, and three parts of unextinguished ashes: it should be ground well and sifted through a sieve. The wound should be filled with this and constricted tightly until it adheres well on top and coagulates with the blood.
Deinde stringe ipsum desuper cum puluillis, et dimitte ipsum, neque soluas ipsum dum permanet, ita quod non apostemetur.	Then bind it tightly from above with bandages, and let it alone, nor loosen it until it remains in that way so that it does not become inflamed.
Nam non eradicatur ab eo medicina, donec sanatur.	For the medicine is not removed from it until it heals.
Et quandoque facit illud calx sola, quando non sunt tibi in praesenti olibanum, et sanguis draconis etiam facit eandem operationem in multis ex uulneribus magnis, quando conuenit ut ponatur super ea et stringantur, et sunt uulnera recentia cum sanguine suo, quae non alterauit aer.	And sometimes it makes the same thing from ashes alone when you do not have olibanum and dragon's blood. And this also performs the same operation in many great wounds when it is placed on them and bound up, and they are fresh wounds with their own blood which air has not altered.
Quod si iam alterauit ea aer quadam alteratione, praecipue quando est in tempore aestatis, tunc non est in positione huius pulueris intentio: cura ergo ipsum cum eo quod diximus, ita ut ponas super ea quaedam unguenta digestiua: aut ponas super ea pultes ex farina hordei, factas cum aqua et melle, donec emittant pus.	But if air has altered them in some way, especially when it is in the time of summer, then this powder is not in position for that: so treat it therefore with what we said, and place on it some digested ointment: or place on it cakes made from barley flour, made with water and honey, until they discharge pus.
Deinde cura ea reliqua curatione, donec sanentur.	Then cure the rest of them with the remaining treatment, until they are healed.
Si uero accidat cum uulnere fractura in osse, et est parua, tunc extrahe illud cum Gesti: et ego iam dicam curationem fracturarum capitis in eo quod futurum est.	But if a fracture happens with the wound in bones and it is small, then extract that thing with Galena. And I will now say the treatment of fractures of the head, as for what will be later.
¶ De uulneribus Colli.	On wounds of the neck.
Caput LXXXV.	Chapter 85.
SI Autem uulnus accidat in Collo, tunc non est inter ipsum differentia in medicatione, et inter uulnus capitis quando est simplex.	But if a wound occurs on the neck then there is no difference in treatment between it and a simple head wound.
Si autem iam incisus est neruus Colli, aut arteria: tunc si est neruus, non est in eo ingenium, nisi ut deuitetur curatio eius cum eo quod facit stipticitatem uehementem, sicut ziniar, et zegi, et eis similia.	If however the nerve of the neck has already been incised, or the artery: then if it is a nerve, there is no treatment for it except that its care be abandoned with it just as it causes intense numbness, such as tinidrosis, and zegi, and similar things.
Quoniam nocent neruis, et contrahunt eos.	Because the nerves injure them and contract them.
Et non ponas super uulnus aliquid frigidum omnino: quoniam substantia neruorum est frigida, et continuatio eius est cum cerebro, quod est sublimius membrorum: et sit illud quo curatur ex medicinis lene, sicut calx lota cum aqua dulci aliquotiens infusa cum oleo, aut cum oleo rosato, et tuthia, quando abluitur etiam cum aqua dulci: et reliqui lapides minerales, secundum hunc modum, et unguenta humida.	And do not place anything cold whatever on the wound: because the substance of the nerves is cold and its continuation is with the brain, which is a more elevated part of the limbs: and that with which it is treated should be gentle medicines such as slaked lime mixed sometimes with clear water and oil or rose oil, and tuthia when washed even with clear water: and the rest of the mineral stones in this manner, and humid unguents.
Si autem uulnus est magnum, tunc administra suturam: aut coarta labia eius cum puluillis.	If however the wound is large, then administer a suture or bind its edges with lint.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it heals.
Si uero uulneri est profunditas, aut accidit in eo sinus in inferiori parte eius, in quo iam aggregatur pus, tunc perfora ipsum in magis depresso loco in eo.	If the wound has depth or occurs in a cavity on its lower part where pus has already accumulated, then puncture it in a more depressed place.
Quod si iam incisa est in uulnere arteria, et consecutus est sanguinem eius fluxus: tunc separa, uel seca eam, et liga ipsam: aut cauteriza eam, si prouocat necessitas ad illud.	Which if it has already been incised in the wound and blood flow from it has followed: then separate or cut it, and bind it itself: or cautery it, if necessity prompts to that.
Si autem iam incidit spondiles gutturis, aut totum, et saluatae sunt alhaudegi: tunc aggrega labia cutis cum sutura super cannam gutturis, et non tangas guttur, imo aequa ipsum, et reduc ipsum super figuram naturalem.	If however the vertebra of the throat has already been incised, or all of it, and other things have been saved: then bring together the edges of the skin with a suture over the cane of the throat, and do not touch the throat, indeed leave it alone, and return it to its natural shape.
Deinde stringe ipsum strictura decenti, et dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot.	Then bind it tightly with a suitable bandage, and let it go for several days.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguentis in quibus est stipticitas et exiccatio, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with ointments in which is numbness and dryness, until it heals.
Si autem uulnus iam fecit impressionem in osse, tunc perquire ipsum: tunc si in ipso sunt fragmenta ossis, extrahe ea omnia, aut quae potes ex eis: et quod non praeparatur, dimitte illud, donec putrescat uulnus, et separetur et alleuietur egressio eius.	If however the wound has already made an impression in the bone, then probe it: then if there are fragments of bone within it, extract all of them or as many as you can, and that which is not prepared, leave it until the wound becomes foul, separates, and its discharge eases.
Quod si uulnus fuerit recens, tunc pulueriza super ipsum puluerem quem narraui.	If the wound is fresh, then sprinkle on it the powder which I have mentioned.
Si autem uidetur in uulnere os, et fit Fistula: tunc cura ipsam cum eo cuius rememoratio uenit in capitulo suo.	But if a bone seems to be in the wound and an abscess forms: then treat it with that whose description comes in its own chapter.
¶ De uulnere in Spatulis.	On a cut on the soles.
Caput LXXXVI.	Chapter 86.
SI Est percussio lanceae, aut cultelli: et uides eius profunditatem, tunc considera.	If it is a blow from a lance or knife and you see its depth, then consider [the treatment].
Si ergo ex uulnere egreditur uentositas, quando anhelat ex eo infirmus, tunc scias, quia uulnus est mortale.	So if from the wound there issues a swelling and when the sick person breathes with difficulty from it, then know that the wound is mortal.
Quod si non fuerit ei profunditas, et est recens cum sanguine suo: tunc non ponas in eo a prima hora puluerem, neque stringas ipsum, ut non retineatur sanguis in profunditate eius, et reuertatur ad cor, et interficiat infirmum: sed pone in ipso unguentum attractiuum, et solue ipsum in die bis.	But if it is not deep and is fresh with its own blood, then do not put powder on it from the first hour nor bind it so that the blood does not remain in its depth and return to the heart and kill the sick person: but put a drawing ointment on it and dissolve it twice a day.
Si uero unguentum non est tibi praesens, tunc pone in orificio uulneris cotum uetustum, ut sugat illud quod egreditur de eo ex humiditatibus: et fac ut dormiat infirmus super uulnus, ut currat quod aggregatur in eo.	But if the ointment is not present to you, then put old cotton in the wound's opening so that it sucks up what comes out of it from moistures: and have the sick person sleep over the wound, so that what gathers in it heals.
Si uero iam praeterierint uulneri tres dies, aut plures, et non accidit infirmo spasmus, neque tremor cordis malus, neque strictura in anhelitu, et uides reliquas dispositiones eius bonas: tunc scias, quia uulnus est saluum.	But if already three days or more have passed over the wound and there has not befallen the sick person a spasms nor bad trembling of the heart nor constriction in breathing, and you see its remaining conditions good: then know that the wound is sound.
Cura ergo ipsum et cum liciniis, et reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	So therefore cure it with liniments and the rest of the treatment until it heals.
Si uero excusatur sanatio eius, et iam aperitur semper, tunc scias, quia iam factum est Fistula.	But if its healing is delayed and it always opens up, then know that an abscess has already been formed.
Cura ergo ipsam ex capitulo suo.	So therefore cure it from its own chapter.
Et si uulnus est ex incisione ensis, aut cultelli, et est simplex in superficie pectoris, aut dorsi: tunc cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit ex sutura, si est magnum: aut cum puluere, si est paruum.	And if the wound is from a cut with a knife or sword and is simple on the surface of the chest or back: then cure it with that which preceded for suture, if it is great: or with powder, if it is small.
Si autem iam fecit impressionem in osse, et incidit ex eo frusta: tunc inquire uulnus, et propera ad extrahendum illa frusta, si sunt separata.	If, however, he has already made an imprint on the bone and it is splintered off from it; then examine the wound, and hasten to extract those splinters if they are separated.
Si uero non sunt separata, tunc dimitte ea, donec putrefiat uulnus, alleuiatur enim extractio eorum.	If, however, they are not separated, then leave them alone, until the wound puttrefies; for extraction of them is eased.
Reliquorum autem uulnerum accidentium in reliquis membris iudicium in curatione, est iudicium eius quod diximus.	But as for other wounds that occur in other parts of the body, the judgment in their cure is the same as that which we said.
¶ De uulneribus Ventris, et exitu intestini, et exitura eorum.	Concerning wounds of the belly, and the outlet of the intestine, and the outlets thereof.
Caput LXXXVII.	Chapter 87.
Disruptio quae accidit uentri, est magna, et media, et parua.	A rupture which occurs in the belly is great, medium, and small.
Ex magna igitur quandoque egreditur intestinum, aut numerus intestinorum.	From a great rupture, therefore, sometimes an intestine or the number of intestines are protruding.
Quare fit intromissio eorum, et eorum sutura uehementior et difficilior.	Why there is intrusion of them, and their stitching more violent and more difficult.
Et disruptio parua etiam fit difficilis ex modo alio.	And a small rupture also becomes difficult from another mode.
Sequitur ergo, ut sit reductio eorum difficilior, si non properas in intromissione sua ad locum suum statim: quoniam inflatur, aperitur, et ingrossatur: quare fit difficilis introitus eius.	Therefore it follows that their reduction is more difficult, if you do not hasten to their intrusion into its place at once, because it swells, opens up, and becomes enlarged: why their entrance becomes difficult.
Propter hoc ergo fit melior disruptionum disruptio media: quoniam cum ea non fit difficilis reductio intestini, sicut fit dissicilis in his duabus speciebus.	On account of this therefore the middle rupture is a better kind of rupture: because with it the reduction of the intestine does not become difficult, as becomes difficult in these two kinds.
Scias, quod sutura uenris est secundum quatuor modos.	Know that the stitching of the belly is according to four modes.
Duae suturae communes conueniunt in sutura uentris, et in sutura reliquorum uulnerum corporis: et duae suturae aliae proprie communicant reliquis uulneribus.	Two common stitches are suitable for the stitching of the belly, and also for the stitching of other wounds of the body; and two other stitches properly communicate with the other wounds.
Verumtamen sunt magis propriae cum sutura uentris: et ego narro tibi unamquamque cum expositione, et declaratione.	However they are more proper for the stitching of the belly: and I will tell you each one with an explanation and a declaration.
Dico ergo, quia quando uulnus est paruum, et egreditur ex eo aliquid ex intestino, et fit difficile reducere ipsum: tunc illud est propter unum duorum modorum.	I say therefore, that when the wound is small and something protrudes from it out of the intestine, and it becomes difficult to reduce it; then that is due to one of two modes.
Aut propter paruitatem disruptionis, sicut diximus: Aut quoniam in intestino est inflatio propter frigus aeris.	Or because of the fragility of the tear, as we have said: Or since there is inflation within the intestine due to the coldness of air.
Quando ergo illud est ita, tunc oportet ut calefacias ipsum, ita ut submergas spongiam, aut pannum humidum in aqua tepida sola.	When therefore it is so, then you should heat the thing itself, just as you would soak a sponge or a damp cloth in lukewarm water.
Aut decoquas in aqua squinantum, et cyperum, et spicam, et embroces cum ea intestinum, donec resoluatur inflatio.	Or you should boil the sap of the squill, and the root of the cypress, and the spike of the asafoetida, and apply them to the intestine with it until the inflation is resolved.
Quandoque facit illud uinum in quo est stipticitas: et est melius quam aqua sola in resolutione inflationis.	And sometimes he makes that wine in which there is astringency, and it is better than water alone for the resolution of inflammation.
Cum ergo uides inflationem iam resolui, tunc humecta intestinum cum aqua in qua decocta est altea, aut malua.	And when you see the inflation already resolved, then moisten the intestine with water in which aloes or mallow have been cooked.
Nam per illud alleuiatur introitus eius cum re parua.	For by that it is eased into him and a small thing is allowed to enter.
Si autem excusatur reditus eius post hanc curationem, tunc finde in disruptione parum, cum instrumento quo secantur hemorrhoides.	But if there is failure of return after this cure, then search for a little disruption with the instrument by which hemorrhoids are cut.
Et curatio prima est melior quando praeparatur, quam sectio: et non fit coactio ad secandum post necessitatem et defectum instrumenti.	And the first cure is better when prepared than a cutting, and there is no need to be forced to cut afterwards because of necessity and deficiency of the instrument.
Sit pars eius una quae est torta, acuta, et pars eius altera non acuta, et extremitas subtilis non sit cum subtilitate Spatumilis, imo sit obtusior parumper: et est illa quae similatur caiada, sicut uides.	Let one part of it be twisted, sharp, and the other part not sharp, and the extremity subtle is not with subtlety so fine as to be like a Scampi, but rather slightly obtuse, and that which resembles a hook, just as you see.
Cum ergo amplificatur uulnus, et ingreditur intestinum, tunc oportet, ut sit reductio eius secundum formam suam naturalem in loco suo sibi proprio, si possibile est super illud: quoniam est melius.	And when the wound is therefore enlarged and enters the intestine, then it should be reduced back according to its natural form to its proper place for itself, if possible over it, since that is better.
Quando uero disruptio est ampla in inferiori parte uentris: tunc oportet ut facias iacere infirmum super dorsum suum, et pone crura sua altiora capite suo.	And when the disruption is wide in the lower part of the belly, then it is necessary to have the sick person lie on his back and place their legs higher than their head.
Et si est in superiore parte uentris, tunc pone caput eius, et pectus ipsius altiora quam eius inferiora.	And if it is in the upper part of the belly, then place his head and chest higher than his lower parts.
Et similiter si est disruptio in una duarum partium uentris, tunc pone intentionem tuam, et tuam considerationem semper in hoc, ut pars in qua est uulnus sit altior parte altera.	And similarly if there is a disruption in one of the two parts of the stomach, then place your intention and your thought always on this, that the part where the wound is should be the higher part of the other.
Et ita oportet, ut admimistres illud in uulneribus magnis, et in uulneribus mediis.	And so it should be, that you take care of it in great wounds, and in middle-sized wounds.
In uulneribus autem paruis, pone illud secundum quod praeparatur tibi.	But in small wounds, place it according to what is prepared for you.
Deinde fac ut sit praesens inter manus tuas minister pius, qui teneat disruptionem totam manu sua: et aggrega labia eius.	Then have a pious attendant present between your hands, who holds the disruption with his hand and closes his lips.
Deinde detege ex ea ei qui sequitur suturam aliquid post aliquid: et iste est modus suturae communis unius.	Then pull out from it a thread to one who follows to sew, bit by bit: and this is the common method of sewing in one.
Et est, ut accipias acum, aut numerum acuum secundum quantitatem amplitudinis uulneris.	And you should take needles, or a number of needles according to the size of the width of the wound.
Deinde dimitte ab extremitate disruptionis quantitatem digiti anularis, id est, medici: et fige acum unam praeter quod intromittas in eam filum in duabus extremitatibuis cutis, cum duabus extremitatibus sifac quod est sub cute ab interioribus, donec facias eam penetrare ab alia parte, et tu iam aggregasti duas extremitates cutis, et duas extremitates sifac: et fiunt quatuor ordines.	Then release from the end of the disruption a length of a finger's breadth, that is, of a doctor: and fix one needle on one side so that you insert thread into it in two ends of skin, with two ends of sifac as if what is under skin from the inside, until you make it pass through the other part, and you have already brought together two ends of skin, and two ends of sifac: and four orders are made.
Deinde stringe cum filo duplo in circumitu acus aliquotiens a duabus partibus simul, quousque sint aggregata duo labia uulneris aggregatione decenti.	Then tie with double thread around the circumference of the needle several times from both parts at once, until the two lips of the wound are properly brought together.
Deinde dimitte grossitudinem digiti etiam, et fige in eis acum aliam: postea reta eam cum filo, sicut fecisti cum acu prima.	Then release the thickness of a finger and fix another needle into them: afterwards draw it back with thread, just as you did with the first needle.
Non ergo cesses facere illud cum eo quo indiges ex acubus, donec compleas constrictionem uulneris totius.	Therefore do not cease to do that with him from whom you need needles until you complete the closure of the wound altogether.
Et sint acus mediae inter grossitudinem et subtilitatem: quoniam acus subtiles ualde uelociter incidunt carnem: et grossae sunt difficilis introitus in cutem: propter illud oportet ut sint mediae in subtilitate, et grossitudine.	And let the needles be of medium size between thickness and fineness: because very fine needles quickly pierce the flesh: and coarse ones are difficult to enter into the skin: on account of this it is necessary that they be of medium size in fineness and thickness.
Et non oportet, ut figatur acus in duabus extremitatibus cutis propinquae multum: ut non incidatur caro uelociter, et aperiatur uulnus ante consolidationem sui, et non elongentur etiam cum sutura, ut non prohibeatur uulnus a consolidatione.	And it is not necessary that the needle be inserted into the two extreme parts of the skin near together much: so that the flesh does not cut quickly, and the wound is opened before its own consolidation, and the edges are not lengthened even with suturing, lest the wound be prevented from consolidating.
Deinde incide extremitatem acuum, ut non laedant infirmum apud somnum suum: et pone eis puluillos ex pannis ab omni parte, qui teneant extremitates acuum: et dimitte eos, donec scias quod uulnus iam consolidatum est.	Then cut off the tip of the needle, lest it hurt the patient in his sleep: and place cloths around them on all sides that hold the ends of the needles: and leave them until you know that the wound is already consolidated.
Et haec quidem species suturae cum acubus taliter est conuenientior in uulneribus paruis.	And indeed this type of suture with needles is more suitable for small wounds.
Quoniam sufficit in sutura eorum acus una, aut duae, aut circiter eas.	Because one or two needles suffice for their stitches, or roughly that many.
Sutura autem secunda communis est, ut aggreges cum sutura extremitates quatuor: extremitates, duas cutis, et extremitates duas sifac in uice una, cum acu in qua sit filum inuolutum aequale in subtilitate, et grossitudine.	However the second stitch is common, that gathers with the stitch four edges: two of skin, and two edges of silk in place one with another, with a needle where there is thread wrapped around it equal in fineness and thickness.
Deinde quando penetraueris cum acu has extremitates quatuor, reduc acum a parte a qua incaepisti eadem, ut cadat filum retatum a superiori parte uulneris: ut sit sutura, sicut sutura panni quo stringuntur panni, et pone inter omnem suturam quantitatem grossitudinis digiti minoris.	Then when you have pierced with the needle these four edges, draw back the needle from the part where you started it again, so that the thread which is left above will fall, that it may be a stitch, like the stitching of cloth by which cloths are sewn together: and place between all the stitches the quantity of thickness of a small finger.
Hanc autem suturam sciunt homines.	Men know this stitch.
Et cum hac sutura ego sui uulnus quod acciderat uiro in uentre suo, qui fuerat uulneratus cum cultello, et erat disruptio uulneris maior palmo uno: et exierat ex intestinis circiter duos palmos ex intestino medio, et erat disruptio in medio uentris.	And with this stitch I closed the wound which happened to a man in his belly, who had been wounded with a knife, and there was a greater disruption of the wound than the breadth of one hand: and he had come out from the intestines about two hands from the middle intestine, and there was a disruption in the middle of the abdomen.
Reduxi ergo illud postquam stetit intestinum eius extra uulnus xxiiii horis.	Therefore I returned it after his intestine had stood outside the wound for 24 hours.
Consolidatum est ergo uulnus in spacio quod fuit circiter XV dies: et curaui ipsum, et sanatus est: et uixit post illud annis multis, conuersatus in suis dispositionibus.	Therefore the wound was consolidated in a space of about 15 days: and I cured it, and he was healed: and he lived after that for many years, living in his usual ways.
Et medici iudicauerant, quod non sanaretur.	And the physicians had judged that it would not be healed.
Et ex miraculo fuit, quod non curaui illud cum unguento.	And by a miracle it was, that I did not heal it with ointment.
Quoniam fui in loco in quo non inueniebatur unguentum, neque aliquid ex medicinis.	Because I was in a place where the ointment was not found, nor anything else from medicines.
Posui ergo super uulnus cotum uetustum bis in die, et assiduaui ablutionem eius cum aqua mellis, donec sanatum est.	So I placed therefore on the wound a worn-out linen cloth twice a day, and I made frequent washing of it with honeyed water, until it was healed.
Duas autem species suturae proprias dicam secundum narrationem sermonis.	But two indeed kinds of suturing proper I will say according to the narrative of speech.
Et est, ut incipias cum sutura acuta: et intromittas acum ab exteriori ad interiorem partem.	And it is, that you begin with acute suture: and you insert the needle from the outer to the inner part.
Cum ergo penetrat acus in cutem, et in lacertum euntem secundum longitudinem et latitudinem totius corporis: dimitte extremitatem sifac in latere in quo intromisisti acum, et fac penetrare in extremitatem aliam ab interiori parte ad exteriorem in extremitate altera mirach.	When therefore the needle pierces the skin and into the muscle running according to length and breadth of the entire body: let go the end thereof which is in the side wherein you inserted the needle, and cause it to penetrate into the other end from the inner part to the outer in the other side.
Cum ergo feceris eam penetrare, tunc fac eam penetrare secundum hoc in eadem hac extremitate mirach ab exteriori parte ad interiorem: et dimitte extremitatem sifac, quae est in hoc latere, et fac penetrare acum in extremitatem alteram ab interiori parte ad exteriorem: et fac penetrare cum penetratione tua qua facis eam penetrare in sifac extremitate mirach, quae est in parte eius, donec penetret in ipsum totum.	When therefore you have made it to penetrate, then make it to penetrate thus in the very same end mirach from the outer part to the inner: and let go the end thereof which is in this side, and cause the needle to penetrate into the other end from the inner part to the outer: and cause it to penetrate with your penetration as you make it to penetrate into the end mirach which is in its part, until it penetrates into itself entirely.
Deinde incipe etiam ab hoc eodem latere, et sue ipsum cum extremitate, quae est ex sifac in latere alio, et extrahe acum ex cute quam penetrauit.	Then begin also from this very same side, and sew it to itself with the end which is from the sifac in the other side, and draw out the needle from the skin wherein it pierced.
Deinde reduc eam in illam cutem, et sue extremitatem sifac, quae est in latere alio, cum hac extremitate mirach: et extrahe eam ex cute quae est ex parte eius, et fac illud uice una, et alia: et fac illud uice post uicem, usquequo suas extrinsecum totum secundum illud exemplum.	Then return it to that skin and sew the end of the sifac which is in the other side with this end mirach; and draw out it from the skin which is of its part, and make this thing vice versa, and another: and make this thing vice after vice, until you have sewn all its exterior according to that example.
Et summa huius suturae, est ut suas sutura pellipariorum qua suunt pelles: ita ut suas sifac uice una ex parte una extremitate cutis: et ut dimittas eam uice alia ex parte alia, donec compleas.	The sum of this suture is to bind the sutures together like those used for skinning hides. So that you stitch them in one place with one end of the skin and then let it go again on the other side until you have completed.
Secunda species suturae propriae, quam dixit Gale nus.	The second kind of proper suture which Galemus spoke of.
Iste eius sermo narratus est, ut suas eam secundum similitudinem, qua suunt eas quidam medicantium, ita quod aggregant omnem partem ad comparem suam conuenientem per naturam: et applicant extremitatem sifac ad eius aliam extremitatem, et extremitatem mirach ad extremitatem eius aliam.	This is his word said that you should do it in a way similar to what certain physicians do. They gather all parts together so they match each other by nature: and apply the end of one suture to the end of another, and the end of one thread to the end of another.
Et illud fit secundum quod narro tibi.	And that is done according to what I am telling you.
Oportet ut figas acum in extremitatem mirach propinquam tibi ab exteriori parte, et facias eam penetrare ad interiorem in eo solo: et dimittas duas extremitates sifac.	You should fix the needle so that it is in the end of one thread close to you from the outer part, and make it penetrate to the inner part alone in it. And let go the two ends of the thread.
Deinde reuolue acum, et fac eam penetrare ab exteriori parte ad interiorem in duas extremitates sifac, scilicet utrinque.	Then turn the needle around and make it penetrate from the outer part to the inner part in the two ends of the thread, that is on both sides.
Deinde reuolue utrasque, etiam fac penetrare utrasque ab interiori usque ad exteriorem, in duas extremitates mirach alias, quae sunt in latere opposito.	Then turn the two [threads] around again and also make them penetrate from the inner to the outer part, in the other two ends of the suture which are on the opposite side.
Et iste modus suturae est melior sutura communi facili, et est sutura cuius praecessit rememoratio.	And this method of suture is a better and easier common suture, and it is the suture which was previously mentioned.
Iste est ergo sermo Galeni etiam.	This then is also the word of Galen as well.
Et dixerunt quidam.	And some have said.
Retificatur sutura uentris cum duabus acubus.	The suture of the belly is corrected with two needles.
Quod est, ut intromittas in eis utrisque filum unum: et incipe cum intromissione acus, ex eo quod est apud te, et fac eam penetrare usque ad latus aliud, secundum suturam eorum qui suunt coria aequaliter.	That is, to insert one thread into both and start with the insertion of the needle from what is at your hand, and make it penetrate as far as to the other side, according to the suture of those who sew skins equally.
Et scias, quod quando disruptio est in medio uentris: tunc sutura eius est difficilior quam reliquorum locorum uentris.	And know that when there is a disruption in the middle of the belly: then its suture is more difficult than other places of the belly.
Iudicium uero medicationis uulneris, est iudicium reliquorum uulnerum.	The judgment of a wound's treatment is the judgment of other wounds.
Quod est, quia quando tu consequeris uulnus recens cum sanguine suo, antequam alteret ipsum aer: et reducis intestinum, et suis ipsum, et aptas ipsum: tunc pone super puluerem incarnatiuum.	For this is because when you treat a fresh wound with its own blood, before the air alters it, and reduce the intestine, and restore it to itself, and bandage it properly: then lay it on powdered flesh.
Quod si aer iam alterauit uulnus: tunc pone super ipsum quaedam unguenta, quae sunt tibi praesentia, donec faciant pus: et cadant fila, et consolidentur sifac, et mirach.	But if the air has already altered the wound, then lay on it some ointments which are present to you, until they make a discharge and threads fall and become healthy and sound.
Deinde cura illud sicut est curatio reliquorum uulnerum, donec sanetur.	Then cure it as is the care of other wounds, until it heals.
Si autem non sunt tibi praesentes medicinae, tunc pone super ipsum statim, exquo incipit emittere pus, cotum uetus: et permuta ipsum bis in die, sicut docui te, donec sanetur.	But if medicines are not present to you, then lay on it immediately an old linen cloth where a discharge begins to come from, and change it twice a day, as I have taught you, until it heals.
Nam tu non indiges medicatione alia in pluribus dispositionibus, quando uulnera sunt simplicia.	For you do not need another medicine for most dispositions, when the wounds are simple.
Si autem times, quod communicet uulnus membris principalibus in laesione, tunc oportet ut submergas lanam lenem in oleo temperatae caliditatis, aut in oleo rosato: et pone ipsam in circumitu locorum quae sunt inter inguina, et sub ascellas.	But if you fear that the wound will communicate to the principal parts with an inflammation, then it is necessary that you soak a soft cloth in tempered warm oil or rose oil, and put it on the areas between the thighs and under the armpits.
Quod si sentit dolorem, aut punctiones, aut putrefactionem in intestinis suis (nam multotiens accidit illud) tunc clisteriza ipsum cum uino stiptico, nigro, tepido: praecipue si putredo iam peruenit in intestino, et facta est exitura penetrans usque ad concauitatem eius.	But if it feels pain, or punctures, or putrefaction within its own intestines (for this often happens) then cleanse it with a warm, black, bitter wine enema: especially if the putrefaction has already reached the intestine and become an open perforation to its depth.
Et scias, quod illud quod est ex intestino grosso, est facilioris sanationis: et quod ex eis est ex subtili, difficilioris sanationis.	And know that the wound from the thick intestine is easier to heal and the one from the thin intestine is harder to heal.
Intestinum autem quod nominatur Ieiunum, non suscipit sanationem ex uulnere quod accidit in eo omnino: et illud est propter multitudinem eius, quod est ex uenis, et magnitudine earum, et propter subtilitatem corporis eius, et propinquitatem ipsius naturae neruorum.	The intestine however that is called the Jejunum, does not accept healing from a wound which happens in it altogether: and this is because of its multitude, which is formed from veins, and the magnitude of them, and because of the thinness of its body, and because of its proximity to the nature of nerves.
Si autem illud quod procedit ex uulnere est zirbum, et consequeris ipsum recens: reduc ipsum secundum reductionem tuam, qua reducis intestina aequaliter.	If however that which proceeds from the wound is pus, and you follow it up recently: reduce it according to your reduction, by which you reduce entrails equally.
Si uero praeteriit ei spacium, et iam factum est uiride, aut nigrum: tunc oportet ut stringas ipsum cum filo supra locum qui denigratus est ex eo, ut non accidat fluxus sanguinis.	But if it has passed the time and has already become green or black: then you must tie it up with thread above the place that was discolored from it, so that there may not be a flow of blood.
In zirbo enim sunt uenae et arteriae.	For in pus are veins and arteries.
Deinde incide quod est praeter illud ligamentum, et pone duas extremitates fili pendentes ex inferiori parte uulneris extra ipsum: ut alleuietur super te attractio eius, et extractio ipsius apud casum zirbi, et emissionem pus uulneris.	Then cut what is beyond that ligament, and place two ends of the thread hanging from the lower part of the wound outside of it: so that there may be a relief to you from its attraction, and extraction of itself in case of pus formation or discharge from the wound.
¶ Rememoratio uulneris quod accidit in Intestino.	A reminder of the wound which occurs in the intestine.
Quando accidit disruptio in Intestino, et est parua: tunc possibile est, ut restauretur in quibusdam hominibus: propterea, quia ego uidi qui fuit uulneratus in uentre suo cum percussione lanceae, et erat uulnus a dextra stomachi, et antiquatum est uulnus: et factum Fistula, et exiuit ex eo egestio, et uentositas.	When there occurs a disruption in the intestine and it is small: then it is possible that it may be restored in some people: therefore, because I have seen someone who was wounded in his belly with a spear thrust, and the wound was on the right side of the stomach, and the wound was old; and a fistula had formed, and there came out from it an evacuation, and inflammation.
Posui ergo curationem, usque quod ego non fui confisus in sanatione eius: neque cessaui subtiliare ipsum, donec sanatus est, et consolidatus est locus.	I therefore applied a treatment, until I was not confident in his healing: nor did I cease to remove it, until he was healed, and the place consolidated.
Postquam ego uidi locum iam consolidatum, timui super infirmum, quod accideret super infirmum accidens malum in uentre suo: et non accidit ei ex illo accidens malum.	After I saw the place now consolidated, I feared for the sick person, that an accidental evil would happen to him in his belly: and it did not happen to him from that accidental evil.
Et remansit in melioribus dispositionibus suis, comedens et bibens, et futuens, et intrauit balneum, et exercitatus est in dietis suis.	And he remained in better physical dispositions, eating and drinking, copulating, and entered the bath, and was exercised in his usual habits.
Et iam dixerunt quidam experimentatorum, quia quando accidit in Intestino uulnus, et est paruum: tunc oportet ut ligetur secundum hunc modum.	And some of the experimenters have said, that when there occurs a wound in the intestine and it is small: then it is necessary to tie it according to this manner.
Et est, ut accipias formicas magnorum capitum.	And take the large-headed ants.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris, et pone formicam unam ex eis quae habeant os apertum super duo labia uulneris.	Then gather two of the edges of the wound and place one ant with its mouth open over the two edges of the wound.
Cum ergo capit super ea, et stringit os suum, abscinde caput eius, adhaeret enim, et non soluitur.	When therefore it bites and closes its jaws, cut off its head, for it adheres and does not come loose.
Deinde pone formicam aliam prope primam, et non cesses facere illud cum formica post formicam secundum quantitatem uulneris totius.	Then place another ant near the first one, and do not cease to repeat this with an ant after each other according to the size of the wound as a whole.
Deinde reduc ipsum, et sue uulnus.	Then pull it back and sew up the wound.
Illa enim capita remanent annexa in Intestino, donec cibetur Intestinum, et sanetur, et non accidat infirmo nocumentum penitus.	For its heads indeed remain attached to the intestines until they are eaten and the wound heals, and no harm will befall the patient entirely.
Et iam possibile est, ut ligetur Intestinum etiam cum filo subtili: quod abstersum est ex intestino animalis, annexo cum eo postquam intromittitur in acum.	And now it is possible to sew the intestine with a thin thread, which I have tried and tested by attaching it to an animal's intestine after introducing it into the needle.
Et est, ut accipias extremitatem huius fili ex intestino, et excarnetur multum.	And take the end of this thread from the intestine and it will be very thick.
Deinde liga in extremitate eius filum lini subtile inuolutum.	Then bind a thin linen thread wound around its end.
Deinde intromitte illud filum in acum, et sue cum eo intestinum.	Then insert that thread into the needle and sew with it the intestine.
Deinde reduc ipsum in disruptionem.	Then pull it back to its place.
Et iste modus suturae cum formicis et intestino, non est nisi secundum uiam fiduciae et spei.	And this method of stitching with ants and intestine is nothing but through the way of faith and hope.
Scias, uulnus quod est magnum, amplum, praecipue si est in uno intestinorum gracilium: tunc non est ingenium nisi subtiliatio, neque est eius sanatio omnino.	Know that a wound which is great and wide, especially if it is on one of the slender intestines, then there is no skill except for the gentle sewing, nor its cure at all.
¶ De cura Zuchemen, et Fistularum.	Concerning the care of abscesses and fistulas.
Caput LXXXVIII.	Chapter 88
Scias, quod omne uulnus, aut apostema quando ueterascit et antiquatur, et fit ulcus, et non consolidatur, et emittit pus semper, et non abscinditur: tunc nominatur uniuersaliter in quocunque membro fuerit Fistula, et nos nominamus ipsum Zuchemen.	Know that every wound or abscess which becomes old and turns to an ulcer, does not consolidate, and constantly discharges pus, and is not healed: then it is universally called a fistula, wherever it may be in the body, and we call it a Zucheum.
Et Fistula quidem est secundum ueritatem nodatio filtrata, dura, alba: cum qua non est dolor, cui est concauitas pennae auis: et propter illud nominant eam quidam Risati, id est, pennam.	And indeed fistula is a true node that is filtered, hard, white; with which there is no pain, whose concavity resembles the feather of a bird: and because of this some call it risatis, i.e., a feather.
Et est in quibusdam horis humida, quae emittit pus.	And it is in certain hours wet, which emits pus.
Et fortasse scinditur humiditas in quibusdam horis.	And perhaps the moisture is broken up in certain hours.
Et quandoque est haec humiditas multa, et est pauca: et est grossa, et est subtilis.	And sometimes this moisture is abundant and scant; and thick and thin.
Et ego iam praemisi in diuisione, tunc cum dixi uulnera, quod omne ulcus quod non sanatur, neque nascitur in eo caro, non est illud nisi propter unam nouem caussarum.	And I have already warned in division, when I spoke of wounds, that every ulcer which does not heal, nor flesh grows in it, is not that except for one of nine causes.
Quarum una est, aut propter paucitatem sanguinis in corpore: aut propter maliciam eius: aut quoniam inter ipsum, et super labia eius est caro dura, prohibens natiuitatem carnis: aut quia est multae sordis et sordiciei: aut quoniam ulcus in seipso est putridum, et materia quae mittitur ei est malae qualitatis: aut quoniam medicina est inconueniens in curatione eius: aut quoniam corruptio cadens in regione est genus pestilentiae, aut per proprietatem in regione, sicut accidit in Caesaraugusta: in qua fit difficilis digestio aegritudinum, et tardatur in ea sanatio apostematum per naturam: aut quoniam in eo est os unum, aut numerus ossium.	One of which is, or because of the small amount of blood in the body: or because of its badness: or because there is hard flesh between it and its edges, preventing the growth of flesh: or because it is very dirty and foul-smelling: or because the ulcer itself is putrid, and the matter sent to it has bad quality: or because medicine is not suitable for its cure: or because a corruption falling in the region is a kind of plague, or by nature in the region, as happens in Caesaraugusta: in which there is difficulty in digesting sicknesses and healing boils is delayed by nature: or because there is one bone or a number of bones in it.
Et ego iam ostendi omnes istas caussas et signa earum, et curationes ipsarum cum medicinis in diuisione: et oportet hic ut faciam te scire curationem Fistulae et Zuken, quae fit per uiam operationis cum manu.	And I have already shown all those causes and signs of them, and their cures with medicines in division; and it is necessary here that I make you know the cure of fistula and zuken, which occurs by way of operation with the hand.
Scias ergo, quod Fistula accidit in omnibus membris corporis.	Therefore know that a fistula can occur in all parts of the body.
Nam ex eis sunt Fistulae quae perueniunt ad uenas magnas et arterias, aut neruos, aut sifac: aut ad intestinum, aut ad uesicam, aut ad aliquam ex costis: aut ad aliquam ex spondilibus dorsi, aut ad aliquam iuncturarum compositarum compositione: sicut manus, et pedis: et ex eis sunt quae uadunt ad propinquitatem membri principalis, et similium.	For some fistulas reach the large veins and arteries, or nerves, or bladder; or the intestines, or the urinary tract, or to some of the ribs; or to some of the vertebrae of the back, or to some joints: such as hands and feet. And from these there are those that go towards the proximity of the main limb, and similar ones.
Quae ergo ex his Fistulis est secundum hunc modum, est ex aegritudinibus difficilis sanationis, et non recipit curationem, et occupatio cum ea est labor et ignorantia.	What therefore is next to these fistulas in terms of difficulty of healing, is one that does not accept treatment and its management is labor and ignorance.
Quod si est ex Fistulis aliqua cuius profunditas non peruenit ad haec loca quae dixi: et speras, et confidis in curatione eius, et uis peruenire ad cognitionem illius, tunc accipe tentam ex aere, aut ferro, si Fistula tendit secundum rectitudinem, et perquire eam cum ipsa.	But if it is from a fistula whose depth does not reach the places I mentioned: and you hope and trust in its cure, and wish to come to an understanding of it, then take a probe made from air or iron, if the fistula runs straight up and down, and seek out the bottom with it.
Si autem in Fistula est tortuositas, tunc inuestiga eam cum tenta de plumbo subtili.	But if there is a twisting in the fistula, then probe it with a thin lead probe.
Quoniam plumbum cum lenitate sui corporis alleuiatur, et curuatur circa tortuositatem.	Because lead, with its soft body, is alleviated and curved around the twisting.
Quod si Fistula est habens orificia multa, non est tibi possibile ut significes super eam cum tenta.	And if the fistula has many openings, it will be impossible for you to find your way over it with a probe.
Clisteriza ergo ex eis orificium ex orificiis suis.	Therefore cleanse one of its openings from among its openings.
Nam humiditas qua clisterizas ipsum, uadit uersus orificia alia, et currit ex eis.	For the moisture with which you clean it flows towards other openings and runs out through them.
Deinde exquisite inquire secundum quem modum est tibi possibile: ut cognoscas quod illic est os, aut neruus, et est Fistulae concauitas longinqua, aut propinqua: aut est Fistula una cui sunt orificia multa, et sta super totum illud, cum summa fortitudinis tuae: cum interrogatione tua, qua interrogas infirmum, et inuentione doloris apud compressionem cum manu tua super locum, et similibus ex significationibus et caussis accidentibus apostemati.	Then carefully investigate by which means it is possible for you to know that there is an opening or a nerve, and whether the fistula's concavity is far away or near; or if it is one fistula with many openings, and stand over the whole of it with your greatest strength: with your questioning of the patient, and discovery of pain at compression with your hand on the place, and similar signs and causes of accidents that happen in an abscess.
Cum ergo steteris super omnia illa statione uera, tunc uade ad curationem secundum confidentiam: et est, ut consideres tunc, si est Fistula propinqua apparens, aut in loco saluo longinquo a iunctura, aut a neruo, aut arteria, aut uena, aut uno locorum quae dixi tibi: tunc seca Fistulam secundum quod praemissum est ex narratione mea, et aufer quod est in ea ex filtratione, et carnibus corruptis, quod nascitur in orificio eius ex carne, aut thelul, et similibus: et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	So when you have stood over all those places truly, then go to the cure according to your confidence. And it is, as you consider then, if there is a fistula appearing near or in a safe place far from the joint, or from a nerve, or artery, or vein, or one of the places I told you: then cut the fistula according to what has been previously said in my narration, and remove what is in it by filtration, and corrupted flesh that is born in its opening from the flesh or skin, and similar things: and heal it until it is cured.
Si autem Fistula est longinquae profunditatis, et est secundum rectitudinem: tunc oportet ut seces eam in profundo quantum est tibi possibile.	If however a fistula is of great depth and along the straightness: then it is necessary that you cut it as deep as possible.
Deinde mundifica ipsam ex omnibus carnibus eius corruptis.	Then cleanse it from all corrupted flesh around it.
Deinde administra licinia inuoluta in medicinis acutis: et intromitte ea usque ad concauitatem Fistulae quam comprehendisti cum ferro: fac cum ea illud aliquotiens, donec corrodat medicina acuta totum quod remansit in concauitate Fistulae ex corruptione.	Then administer a linen strip wrapped in sharp medicines; and insert it into the hollow of the fistula as far as you can reach with iron; do this several times until the sharp medicine eats away all that remains in the hollow of the fistula from the corruption.
Deinde restaura ipsam cum unguentis quae generant carnem sanam, donec sanetur.	Then restore it with ointments which generate healthy flesh, until it is healed.
Si uero non sanatur per illud, tunc cauteriza ipsam secundum quod narrauimus.	If it does not heal by that, then cauterize it as we have described.
Si ergo caussa Fistulae est os, et certificatur apud te illud: tunc inquire ipsum, et seca ipsum secundum quod narraui tibi: si non prohibet te aliquid ex uena, aut neruo, aut membro principali, sicut diximus.	If therefore the cause of the fistula is a bone, and you are certain about it: then investigate it, and cut it out as I told you to; if nothing from the vein, or nerve, or main member hinders you, as we said.
Si ergo detegitur tibi os, et est in eo quiddam corruptionis, et nigredinis: tunc rade ipsum, donec auferatur corruptio eius tota.	If therefore a bone is revealed to you and there is something of corruption and blackness in it: then rasp it away until the corruption of it is entirely removed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod incarnat ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with that which fleshes it out, until it heals.
Quod si non sanatur, et emittat pus sicut faciebat: tunc scias, quod tu non peruenisti ad totam eradicationem corruptionis.	But if it does not heal and discharges pus as it was doing: then you will know that you did not reach the complete eradication of the corruption.
Detege ergo super illud secundo, et exquisite fac rasionem eius, et mundificationem ipsius cum ultima fortitudine tua.	Therefore scrape again over it and make a careful examination of its cavity and cleansing of it with all your might.
Deinde restaura ipsum.	Then restore it.
Si ergo sanatur, bonum est: et si non, tunc scias quod illa corruptio est in profunditate longinqua corporis, quam non es consecutus.	But if it heals, good; and if not, then you will know that the corruption is in a distant depth of the body which you did not reach.
Non est ergo tibi in ea ingenium, nisi dimittere ipsam naturae.	So there is no ingenuity for you with it, except to leave it to nature.
Quod si corruptum est os paruum, et est possibile tibi, attrahe ipsum cum forficibus subtilibus quae conueniunt ad illud.	But if the corrupted bone is small and you are able, draw it out with fine pincers that suit it.
Si autem sunt ossa multa, tunc exquisite fac attractionem eorum omnium, neque dimittas ex eis aliquid cum tua fortitudine.	If however there are many bones, then make an exact union of them all, and do not leave anything out with your strength.
Si uero contrarietatem facit tibi aliquid ex humiditatibus, et non est in incisione eorum timor, uel error: tunc incide illas humiditates et carnes, si sunt illic, et libera ossa.	If however something makes you oppose it from the moistures, and there is no fear or error in their incision: then cut those moistures and flesh, if they are there, and free the bones.
Si uero non est tibi praeparatio auferendi ossa ex hora tua, tunc pone super uulnus quod putrefaciat ipsum: et dimitte ipsum, donec putrefiat quod est in circumitu illorum ossium ex carnibus et humiditatibus.	If however you do not have preparation for removing the bones from your wound, then place something over it that will make it rot itself: and leave it alone, until what is around those bones from flesh and moistures has rotted.
Et custodi uulnus ut non consolidetur.	And guard the wound so that it does not heal.
Et constringatur sectio quam tu secuisti in operatione tua.	And tighten the incision which you made in your operation.
Imo pone super ipsum, si times, cotum submersum sulfure trito cum oleo: aut cotum submersum in unguento aegyptio, aut aliquo unguentorum uiridium.	Indeed place over it, if you fear, a cloth immersed in crushed sulfur mixed with oil: or a cloth immersed in Egyptian ointment, or some green unguents.
Nam quando putrefient illae scilicet humiditates, et separantur ex eis ossa, alleuiatur ablatio eorum, et ipsorum attractio.	For when those moistures rot, namely they will separate from them bones, the removal of them and their union is eased.
Si autem est os unum magnum, sicut os cruris, aut os coxae, et similia illis, et quod ex eo corruptum est, est pars magna: tunc rade ipsum rasione ultima, donec auferatur illa nigredo et corruptio.	If however there is one large bone, such as the leg bone or hip bone, and similar to those, and what has become corrupted from it is a major part: then shave it with a final scraping, until that blackness and corruption are removed.
Deinde restaura uulnus.	Then restore the wound.
Si uero quod est in eo corruptum, est pars magna, et corruptio iam consecuta est medullam ossis, tunc necesse est serrare ipsum, et incidere ipsum totum usque ad locum, ubi peruenit corruptio: tunc cura ipsum, donec consolidetur.	If however what has become corrupted in it is a major part, and corruption has already reached the marrow of the bone, then it is necessary to saw it and cut it all the way down to where the corruption has come: then care for it until it heals.
Et ego narro tibi zuken, quae accidit uiro in crure suo: ut ponas ipsam exemplum et adiutorium super operationem tuam.	And I tell you Zukan, what happened to a man in his leg: that you may set the example and aid over your own operation.
Fuit uir iuuenis aetate circiter triginta annos, cui accidit dolor in crure suo, a caussa quae mota est super ipsum intra corpus, id est, ab interioribus, donec peruenerunt materiae ad crus, et apostematum est apostemate magno: et non fuit ei caussa extrinseca.	There was a young man about thirty years old, to whom happened pain in his leg, from cause which moved against him within the body, that is, from inside, until it came to the thigh and formed a great apostema: and there was no external cause.
Extensum est ergo cum eo tempus cum errore medicorum, donec apertum est apostema, et concurrerunt cum eo materiae multae.	Therefore it was extended with him at that time with the error of physicians, until an abscess was opened up, and many materials occurred with him.
Et postposita est curatio eius, donec fistulatum est crus, et facta sunt in eo orificia multa: quae omnia emittebant pus, et humiditates corporis.	And after that his care was abandoned until the leg had become a fistula and many openings were made in it: which all emitted pus and bodily humors.
Curauit ergo ipsum multitudo medicorum circiter duos annos, et non fuit in eo sapiens in arte manus, donec uocatus sum, et uidi crus eius, et materias quae currebant ex illis orificiis cursu magno: etiam omne uiri corpus iam tabuerat, et color eius citrinus erat.	Therefore a multitude of physicians treated him for about two years and there was no one skilled in the art of surgery among them until I was called and I saw his leg and the materials that were flowing from those openings in great quantity: even his entire body had grown foul and its color was yellow.
Intromisi ergo tentam in uno locorum orificiorum, et peruenit tenta ad os.	Therefore I inserted my probe into one of the openings, and it reached to the bone.
Deinde perscrutatus sum orificia omnia: et inueni ea peruenire ad se inuicem ex omnibus partibus cruris.	Then I examined all the openings, and I found that they were all communicating with one another from every part of the leg.
