Properaui ergo, et secui super unum illorum orificiorum, donec detexi partem ossis: et inueni ipsum corruptum: quod iam corrosum erat, et denigratum, et putruerat, et perforatum erat, donec penetrauerat usque ad medullam.	I therefore proceeded and cut over one of those openings until I exposed a part of the bone: and I found it to be corrupted: which was already eaten away, and denatured, and had become putrid, and perforated, until it had penetrated all the way to the marrow.
Serraui ergo quod detectum est mihi, et praeparatum ex osse corrupto.	I therefore cut out what was found in me, and prepared from the corrupted bone.
Et deputaui, quod non esset in osse nisi illa corruptio, quam abscidi, et serraui.	And I left what would not be in the bone except that corruption which I cut out and removed.
Et ego iam eradicaueram eam.	And I had already eradicated it.
Deinde posui restaurationem uulneris cum medicinis consolidatiuis spacio longo.	Then I placed the wound's restoration with consolidating medicines over a long period.
Et non est consolidatum.	And it has not consolidated.
Deinde tentaui, et detexi super os secundo supra detectionem primam: et inueni corruptionem continuam cum osse: et serraui quod apparuit mihi etiam ex illa corruptione.	Then I tried again and cut into the bone a second time above the first discovery, and I found continuous corruption with the bone: and I removed what appeared to me from that very corruption.
Deinde conatus sum restaurationem eius.	Then I attempted to restore it.
Et non est restauratum.	And it was not restored.
Detexi ergo super ipsum iterum, et non cessaui incidere os particulatim, et conari restaurationem eius: et non est restauratum, donec incidi ex osse circiter palmum unum, et extraxi illud cum medulla sua.	I therefore cut into it again and did not stop cutting away the bone little by little, and attempting to restore it: and it was not restored, until I cut out from the bone about a hand's width, and extracted that with its marrow.
Deinde restauraui ipsum cum medicinis, et consolidatum est uelociter, et sanatum: et non fuit necessaria haec iteratio in operatione eius, et sectione ipsius, nisi propter dispositionem debilitatis infirmi, et paucitatem tolerantiae eius, et timorem meum super ipsum de morte: quoniam accidebat ei in omnibus horis ex superfluitate euacuationis syncopis mala.	Then I restored him with medicines, and he was quickly consolidated and healed. And this repetition of the operation on him and his section was not necessary, except because of the weakness of the sick man's condition, and the scarcity of his tolerance, and my fear for him from death: since harm befell him at every hour from excessive evacuation of bad humors.
Sanatus est ergo sanatione integra: et nata est in loco ossis caro dura, et bona facta est dispositio in corpore suo, et rediit uirtus eius: et conuersatus est in dispositionibus suis: et non fecit ei contrarietatem in ambulatione nocumentum omnino.	He was therefore completely healed by the healing: and there was formed in place of the bone hard flesh, and a good disposition was made in his body, and his strength returned: and he became converted to his former dispositions: and no harm or injury at all occurred to him on walking.
Si autem os eminens in loco corporis iam fractum est: tunc oportet ut serres ipsum, secundum hunc modum: et est: ut accipias ligamentum, et stringe ipsum in extremitate ossis eminentis: et praecipe alicui, qui extendat ipsum ad sursum: et pone ligamentum aliud ex lana grossius ligamento primo.	But if the prominent bone in place of the body is already broken: then it is necessary that you set it, according to this manner: and thus: take a cord, and bind it at the end of the projecting bone: and order someone to stretch it upwards: and put another cord from thicker wool on top of the first cord.
Deinde liga ipsum super carne, quae est suh osse: et extende extremitatem eius, ut trahas carnem ad inferiora: et tu detegis carnem super locum quem uis serrare, ut non laedat Serra carnem.	Then bind it on top of the flesh which is under the bone: and stretch out its extremity so that you pull the flesh downwards: and you must uncover the flesh over the place which you wish to saw, so that it does not injure the saw.
Pone lignum, aut tabulam sub osse inferius decenter: quoniam quando facis illud, non prohibetur quin secet carnem corruptam.	Place a wooden board or a plate under the lower bone properly: because when you do this, it is not prevented that the corrupted flesh will be cut.
Et oportet ut sit Serratura super locum corruptum parumper, ut non sit in concauitate ossis corruptio: et non appareat in apparitione sua sensui, et cogat ad Serraturam sui uice alia.	And it is necessary that the sawing be a little over the place of corruption, so that there may not be concavity of the corrupted bone: and may not appear in its sensation, and may cause another to come in place of the sawing.
Quod si os est corruptum, et non est eminens, imo continuatur pars eius cum parte: et corruptio est in medio eius, aut in parte ipsius: tunc detege carnem ab omnibus partibus totam.	But if the bone is corrupted and not prominent, indeed its part continues with another part: and corruption is in the middle of it or in one of its parts: then uncover all the flesh from around it completely.
Deinde pone lignum inferius.	Then place a wooden board underneath.
Postea serra illud ex parte prima, ubi est corruptio, donec continuetur Serratura ex parte altera: et sit Serratura secundum longitudinem a corruptione parumper, secundum quod diximus.	Then saw it from the first part where there is corruption, until the sawing continues from the other part: and let the sawing be according to length slightly beyond the corruption, as we have said.
Quod si corruptio est in iunctura, incide ipsam iuncturam corruptam, et serra os ubi continuatur ex parte altera.	If there is corruption in a joint, cut out the corrupted joint itself, and saw off the bone where it continues on the other side.
Si uero corruptio est in continuatione duarum iuncturarum, tunc non est in ea ingenium nisi abrasio.	If indeed corruption is in the joining of two joints, then there is no remedy for it except abrasion.
Quod si corruptio est in pectine manus, aut in pectine pedis: tunc res in eo est difficilis ualde.	But if corruption is in the pelvis of the hand, or in the pelvis of the foot: then the case in that part is very difficult.
Verum oportet, ut inquiras corruptionem qualiter appareat tibi.	However, you must inquire about the corruption and see how it appears to you.
Et abradas eam, et mundes ipsam secundum quamcunque dispositionem tibi possibile est, et cum quocunque ingenio rectificatur tibi: quando non facit tibi contrarietatem Vena, aut Neruus.	And you should scrape it clean and cleanse the area according to what is possible for you, and with whatever device you correct it when it does not cause contradiction in a vein or nerve.
Et scias quod incisoria, et Serrae ad incidendum ista ossa sunt multa, secundum situm ossium, et praparationem eorum, et ipsorum grossitudinem, et subtilitatem eorum, et magnitudinem, et paruitatem ipsorum, et duriciem ipsorum, et eorum raritatem.	And you should know that scalpels and saws for cutting these bones are many, according to the location of the bones, and their preparation, and their thickness, and subtlety, and size, and smallness, and hardness, and rarity.
Quapropter oportet, ut praepares omni speciei operationis instrumentum conueniens ad illam operationem.	Therefore it is necessary that you prepare all sorts of surgical instruments fitting for the surgery.
Et scias, quod operationes istae significant tibi super speciem instrumenti quo indiges, quando tecum est studium longum.	And know that these operations are meant to tell you about the kind of instrument you need, when you have a long study with it.
Et cognitio modorum huius artis, testimonium modorum aegritudinum: tunc enim iam inuenies per teipsum illud quod conuenit ei ex instrumentis ad omnem infirmitatem.	And knowledge of the ways of this art is a witness to the ways of diseases; then indeed you will already find through yourself what suits it from instruments for every weakness.
Et ego sum firmans tibi in ultimo huius capituli numerum instrumentorum, quae pones exempla super quae incides, et probationem qua experiaris super alia.	And I am establishing for you at the end of this chapter a number of instruments that you will put examples on which you will cut, and a proof by which you will try others.
Forma Serrae.	The shape of the saw.
Forma alterius Serrae.	The shape of another saw.
Forma Serrae alterius.	The shape of still another saw.
Forma Serrae alterius.	The shape of another saw.
Haec forma Serrae depicta, sit decenter facta.	This shape of the saw should be drawn decently.
Fiat arcus eius superior, acuitas eius ex ferro: et manubrium eius ex buxo, et sit pyramidale decenter factum.	Let its curve be at the top, with a sharpened edge made of iron; and let its handle be of boxwood, and be neatly done in a pyramidal shape.
Forma Rasorii iuncturarum.	The form of a razor for joining things together.
Sit caput huius Rasorii, secundum formam capitis claui stellati: et puncta eius sint secundum formam punctorum elischetfegi.	Let the head of this razor be in the shape of the head of a star-shaped needle, and its points to be in the shape of the points of a slitting needle.
Et non conuenit, nisi ut fricentur cum eo capita iuncturarum, quando corrumpuntur, aut os amplum, et magnum est.	And it is not suitable unless its heads are rubbed with them when the joining parts corrupt or a large and great bone.
Forma maioris Rasorii.	The form of the greater razor.
Forma medii Rasorii.	The form of the middle razor.
Forma Rasorii lati.	The form of the wide razor.
Forma Rasorii in quo est concauitas.	The form of a curved razor.
Forma Rasorii alterius subtilis.	The form of another fine razor.
Forma Rasorii alterius curuatae extremitatis.	The form of the other curved-end razor.
Forma Rasorii parui, subtilis tentae.	The form of a small, fine and pointed razor.
Forma Rasorii cum quo inciduntur ossa.	The form of the razor with which bones are cut.
Forma etiam Rasorii magni.	The form also of the large razor.
Hoc similatur Radio, et extremitas est sicut Serra: exhibetur in locis multis ex rasione ossium.	It resembles a reamer and its end is like a saw: it is shown in many places for the reason of bones.
Forma Rasorii quod conuenit ad rasionem eius quod perforatum est ex ossibus.	The form of the razor which suits the piercing of bones.
Extremitas eius triangula, acutarum est extremitatum.	Its end is triangular with sharp points.
Fit ex Indi.	It is made from steel.
Et similiter oportet, ut fiant omnia quae diximus ex Rasoriis, et Incisoriis, et Serris.	And similarly all the things that we have said should be made from razors and knives and saws.
¶ De incisione extremitatum, et Serratura ossium.	About the cutting off of extremities and the removal of bones.
Caput LXXXIX.	Chapter 89.
Putrefiunt extremitates, aut ex caussa extrinseca, aut intrinseca.	The extremities putrefy either from an external or internal cause.
Cum ergo medicatus fueris illam corruptionem curatione medicinarum, et non confert curatio: et uides corruptionem incidere in membrum, quam non repercutit aliquid: tunc oportet ut incidas illud membrum usque ubi consequitu corruptio, ut euadat infirmus per illud a morte, aut a malicia quae est maior defectu membri.	When then you have been medicated for that corruption and the cure does not take effect: and you see corruption occurring in a member which is not relieved by anything: then it is necessary to cut off that member as far as the corruption goes, so that the sick person may escape death or greater harm from the defect of the member.
Et signum cui accidit illud est, quod denigratur membrum, donec putetur: quod ignis combussit ipsum, aut putrefit post nigredinem: donec inciditur illa putredo usque ad illud quod sequitur illud membrum, et serpit in totum corpus.	And the sign that it has happened is that the member becomes black until it rots: which when fire burns it or after blackening putsrefies: until the decay is cut out as far as follows that member and spreads throughout the body.
Propera ergo cum incisione eius, et similiter si caussa corruptionis est a percussione quorundam uenenosorum: sicut scorpionis marini, et uiperae, et rutellae, et similium.	Therefore with its wound and similarly if the cause of corruption is from the sting of some venomous things: as of the sea scorpion, and viper, and rattlesnake, and similar ones.
Si ergo corruptio, aut percussio est in extremitate digiti, tunc incide digitum, et non des spacium corruptioni, ut incedat usque ad reliquam manum.	Therefore if the corruption or sting is in the extremity of the finger, then cut off the finger and do not allow the corruption to spread so that it may ascend to the rest of the hand.
Et similiter si accidit in manu, tunc incide eam ex radice focilis, et non des spacium corruptioni, donec capiat in focili brachii.	And similarly if it happens in the arm, then cut it off from the elbow and do not allow the corruption to spread until it reaches into the forearm.
Et si inuadit in eo, tunc incide brachium apud cubitum in iunctura sua.	And if it invades that one, then cut off the arm at the elbow at its joint.
Si autem pertransit corruptio, et uides eum circiter cubitum: tunc in illo est mors infirmi.	But if however corruption passes through and you see him around the elbow: then in that one is the death of the sick person.
Et administrare praeter illud ex curatione, est quantitas uirtus.	And to administer anything beyond that from cure is quantity of power.
Et similiter fac de pede, quando inuadit corruptio in digito, tunc incide ipsum apud unum nodorum: et si capit in pectine pedis, tunc incide pedem totum.	And similarly do this for the foot, when corruption invades the finger, then cut off the same at one of the joints: and if it reaches into the heel of the foot, then cut off the entire foot.
Si autem ascendit ad genu, tunc incide crus apud iuncturam genu.	But if it ascends to the knee, then cut off the leg at the joint of the knee.
Quod si corruptio iam peruenit supra genu, tunc non est in ea ingenium, nisi dimissio, et relinquere infirmum morti.	But if corruption has already reached above the knee, then there is no art in it except for cutting off and leaving the sick person to death.
Et modus incidendi membrum, aut serrandi ipsum est, ut stringas ligamentum in inferiori, quem uis incidere: et stringe ligamentum aliud supra locum.	And the method of cutting off a member or sawing it is, to tie the sinew below at the place you wish to cut: and tie another sinew above the place.
Et extendat minister ligamentum unum ad inferiora: et extendat minister aliud ligamentum superius ad sursum.	And let the attendant stretch one sinew towards the lower part: and let the attendant stretch another sinew upwards to the top.
Et tu separa carnem quae est inter duo ligamenta, cum Spatumili lato, donec detegatur caro tota.	And you separate the flesh that is between the two sinews, with a broad spatula, until the whole flesh is exposed.
Deinde incidatur, aut serretur.	Then it is to be cut or sawed.
Et oportet, ut ponas ab omnibus partibus pannum lini, et non tangat Serra locum sanum: et accidat infirmo laesio addita, et apostema calidum.	And it is necessary that you place a linen cloth over all the parts and the saw should not touch the healthy place: and an added injury occurs to the sick person and a hot abscess.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis interius dum operaris, tunc cauteriza locum uelociter: aut pone super ipsum quosdam pulueres abscindentes sanguinem.	If, however, a bleeding of blood should occur internally while you are operating, then burn the place quickly; or put over it some powdered substances cutting off the blood.
Deinde redi ad medicationem tuam, donec compleatur.	Then return to your treatment until it is completed.
Deinde liga membrum uulneratum cum ligamento conueniente ei, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then bind the wounded limb with a suitable bandage and take care of it until it heals.
Et ego narro tibi quod accidit uiro in pede suo, hoc idem accidens quod narro tibi.	And I tell you what happened to a man on his foot, the same thing that I am telling you.
Quod est, quia accidit in pede suo nigredo, cum adustione quae assimilatur combustioni ignis: et corruptio illa in primis accidit in digito suo, donec coepit pedem totum.	Which is that a blackness occurred on his foot, with a burning like a fire's combustion; and the corruption first occurred in his finger, until it began to spread throughout his foot.
Properauit ergo uir ex seipso, postquam uidit corruptionem incidere in membro cum uehementia eius, quod inuenit ex dolore, et adustione eius: et incidit ipsum apud iuncturam, et sanatus est.	Therefore the man drew out from himself, after he saw the corruption fall on his member with its inflammation, which he found because of pain and burning of it: and it fell at the joint, and he was healed.
Et postquam praeteriit ei tempus longum, accidit ei illa eadem corruptio in digito manus suae indice.	And after a long time had passed over him, that same corruption occurred to him in the finger of his hand on his index.
Venit ergo ad me, et conatus sum recuperare illam superfluitatem cum eo quod posui super manum ex medicinis post mundificationem corporis eius: et non repercussa est superfluitas, et coepit incedere in digitum alium: donec coepit coruptio in manum.	So he came to me, and I tried to recover that excess with him on the hand after putting medicines over his body: and the excess was not stayed, and it began to go into another finger; until corruption occurred in his hand.
Vocauit ergo me, ad incidendum manum eius: et nolui illud, sperans ex me super repercussionem illius superfluitatis: et timui etiam super ipsum apud incisionem manus eius mortem.	So he called on me to cut off his hand: and I did not want it, hoping from me on the recovery of that excess: and I also feared death for him at the cutting of his hand.
Quoniam uirtus uiri erat super casum.	Because the man's virtue was over taking a risk.
Postquam ergo desperauit de me, reuersus est ad terram suam: et peruenit ad me de eo, quia properauit, et incidit manum suam totam: et sanatus est.	Therefore after he had despaired of me, he returned to his land: and it came to me about him, because he hastened, and cut off his hand entirely: and he was healed.
Et non attuli hanc narrationem, nisi ut sit adiutorium super illud quod cadit de genere huius aegritudinis: et ut sit significatio qua significetur, et secundum quam agatur.	And I did not tell this story, unless it was to be an aid in regard to that which falls into the kind of this sickness: and so that there would be indication by means of which it should be indicated, and according to which it should be done.
¶ De cura Sinuum, et qualitate clisterizationis cum medicinis.	On the treatment of sinuses and the quality of the cleansing with medicines.
Caput XC.	Chapter 90.
Quando accidit apostema in quibusdam membris carnosis, et prolongatur spacium apostematis, donec collectionem facit saniei: deinde rumpitur, aut perforatur, et egreditur quod in eo est ex sanie, et remanet locus uacuus quasi sit uas: et cutis quae est super ipsum sicut pannus qui iam subtiliatus est: et non peruenit ad ultimum in corruptione sua, neque imprimit in os, neque in neruum, neque in ligamentum: meretur ut nominetur Sinus: et non nominatur Fistula: uerumtamen si prolongatur spacium eius, donec imprimat corruptio in aliquid horum membrorum, tunc nominatur Fistula, aut zuken.	When an apostema occurs in certain fleshy parts and the space of the apostema is prolonged until it forms a collection of pus: then it bursts or becomes perforated, and what is inside comes out with the pus, and the place remains empty like a pouch: and the skin that covers it is like a cloth that has been worn thin: and it does not reach its ultimate point in corruption, nor presses into the bone, nor into the nerve, nor into the ligament: it deserves to be called a sinus: but if its space is prolonged until it imprints corruption on something of these parts, then it is called a fistula or abscess.
Et cura eius est, ut incidas illam cutem totam sicut reuoluitur: et praecipue quando subtiliata est, et facta sicut pannus: et confidis quia non aaehaeret cum loco, propter corruptionem suam.	And its treatment is to cut the entire skin over it as it peels off: and especially when it has been worn thin and become like a cloth: and you trust that it will not adhere with the place because of its corruption.
Si autem speras quod adhaereat cutis, et non consequitur ex eo corruptio illa ultima consecutione: et si in cute est spissitudo ex carne, tunc cura ipsum cum Clisteri: et est, ut consideres ad Sinum.	But if you hope that the skin will adhere and the corruption does not reach its ultimate outcome: and if there is a thickening of skin on it from flesh: then treat it with a poultice: and it is as if you are considering a sinus.
Tunc si est magnus, et pus quod emittitur ex eo est foetidi odoris: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum medicamine aegyptio, quod est aceti, et olei, et ziniar, partes recipiens aequales, aggregentur in uase: et decoquantur super ignem, donec rubeat medicamen: et ueniat in spissitudinem mellis.	Then if it is large and the pus that comes out of it has a foul odor: then cleanse it with Egyptian medicine, which is made from equal parts of vinegar, oil, and zinar (or gum arabic): they are mixed together in a vessel: and heated over fire until the medicine becomes red: and thickens like honey.
Deinde accipe ex eo quod tibi necesse est: et dissolue ipsum cum aqua et melle, et clisteriza cum eo Sinum: et stringe orificium eius, et dimitte medicinam in eo ad quantitatem duarum horarum.	Then take as much of it as you need and dissolve it with water and honey: and cleanse the sinus with it: and bind shut its opening, and leave the medicine inside for the space of two hours.
Deinde extrahe ipsum cum expressione: fac illud diebus tot, donec mundificetur Sinus, et remoueatur foetor.	Then draw it out with a gentle squeezing: do this daily until the sinus is cleaned and the foul odor is removed.
Et quandoque clisterizatur cum aqua cineris, quando non est tibi praesens hoc medicamen: et est, ut accipias cinerem lignorum uitis, aut cinerem ex lignis ilicis: et proiicias super eam aquam.	And sometimes it is cleansed with a cinder water, when this medicine is not present to you: and thus, take the ashes of vine wood or ashes from ilex trees; and pour water over them.
Deinde cola eam, et clisteriza cum ea, donec confidas quod Sinus iam ablutus est.	Then anoint it with oil and cleanse her with it until you trust that the sinus has been washed clean.
Quod si infirmo non est tolerantia super medicamen aegyptium, neque aquam cineris, tunc clisteriza ipsum cum aqua et melle, cui iam permixtum est aliquid ex ziniar contrito.	But if the sick person is not able to tolerate Egyptian medicine nor cinder water, then cleanse him with water and honey in which something from ground gallnut has been mixed.
Aut clisteriza ipsum cum melle et uino permixtis, quoniam de proprietate mellis est, ut mundificet, et abluat: et uinum facit adhaerere Sinum, praecipue quando in uino est superfluitas stipticitatis et siccitatis.	Or cleanse him with honey and wine mixed together, since the nature of honey is to purify and wash, and wine makes the sinus adhere especially when there is excess dryness and astringency in it.
Cum facis illud aliquotiens, et confidis quod Sinus corruptio iam remota est: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum eo quod facit nasci carnem in eo.	When you have done this several times and trust that the corruption of the sinus has been removed: then cleanse him with what makes flesh grow there.
Et est, ut accipias ex emplastro dyafinicon: et dissoluas ipsum cum oleo rosato, et uino stiptico: aut clisteriza ipsum cum quibusdam medicinis, et unguentis aliis, quorum proprietates scripsi in tractatu unguentorum.	And it is, to take from the diaphrenic ointment and dissolve it with rose oil and astringent wine: or cleanse him with some medicines and other ointments, whose properties I wrote down in the treatise on ointments.
Quod si orificium Sinus est strictum, in quo non capit cannula clisteris: tunc amplifica ipsum cum ferro parumper: aut pone in ipso licinium inuolutum in unguento aegyptio, aut in unguento basilicon, donec amplificetur.	But if the opening of the sinus is narrow, into which the cannula of the cleanser will not enter: then widen it with iron for a little while: or place a linen folded in Egyptian ointment, or in basilicon ointment, within it until it is widened.
Et similiter si est orificium etiam amplum, tunc aggrega labia eius cum sutura: et dimitte ex eo quantitatem in quam ingrediatur clistere sine additione.	And similarly if the opening is also large, then join its lips with a suture and let it be empty of as much quantity as the cleanser will enter without adding anything.
Et similiter si orificium eius ex quo currit pus, est eleuatum ad superiora: tunc seca ipsum in depressiori loco qui est in ipso, ut currat ex eo pus usque inferius: quoniam pus quando coartatur in profunditate Sinus, prohibet carnem generari in eo.	And similarly if the opening from which pus flows is raised upwards: then cut it at a lower place that is within it, so that the pus will flow out of it downwards: because when pus is constricted in the depth of the sinus, it prevents flesh from growing there.
Quod si non est tibi possibile secare Sinum circiter inferius eius secundum quod uis: tunc conare, ut praepares membrum praeparatione qua currat ex eo pus cum facilitate secundum quod praeparatur tibi.	If it is not possible for you to cut the sinus around below it according to your will: then try, as you prepare the member with a preparation by which it runs from it pus easily according to how it is prepared for you.
Conare, ut non retineatur in eo aliquid ex pus omnino: et accipe medicinas consolidatiuas quae ponuntur super signum, conuenientes ad illud quod uis.	Try, that nothing of the pus is retained in it altogether: and take consolidating medicines which are put on a sign, fitting for what you wish.
Et extende eas super pannum lini.	And stretch them out over linen cloth.
Et sit pannus tantae quantitatis, qua fiat communicatio totius Sinus.	And let the cloth be of such a size as to make communication of the whole sinus.
Deinde incide cum forficibus in directo orificii Sinus foramen, amplius orificio Sinus parumper.	Then cut with scissors into the direct opening of the sinus' hole, enlarging the opening of the sinus a little.
Deinde extende ex unguentis lenibus super pannum alium, secundum quantitatem foraminis: et pone eum super ipsum positione longinqua ab orificio Sinus, ut alleuietur exitus pus ex eo: et non auferas pannum magnum, nisi post dies aliquos uice una.	Then stretch out a cloth dipped in gentle ointment over another cloth, according to the size of the hole; and place it on top with a position far from the opening of the sinus, so that it eases the exit of pus from it: and you will not remove the large cloth unless after some days once.
Ille autem qui est super orificium Sinus, est ille quem remoues in omni hora, ut egrediatur quod aggregatur in eo ex pus: et ut scias, an illud quod currit ex eo uirus, est multum, aut parum: aut digestum, aut indigestum.	But that one which is over the opening of the sinus, you remove every hour, so that what gathers in it from pus may go out; and so you will know whether what runs out from it is much or little, or digested or undigested.
Et cum hoc iterum considera locum Sinus ipsius, an in ipso sentiat dominus eius dolorem, aut non sit in eo dolor, et an sit in eo apostema, aut non sit in eo apostema.	And when you have done this again, examine the place of the sinus itself, if its owner feels pain in it, or if there is no pain in it; and if there is an aposteme in it, or if there is not an aposteme in it.
Cum ergo protenditur medicatio tua taliter, et uides materiam quae egreditur super orificium Sinus, tunc scias, quod Sinus iam adhaeret, aut approximat adhaerentiae: tunc ergo solue ipsum in mane, aut in tertio die: et quando soluis uulnus, tunc permuta pannum alium, et renoua unguentum.	When therefore your medication is thus prolonged, and you see the matter which comes out over the opening of the sinus, then you will know that the sinus already adheres, or approaches adhesion: then therefore dissolve it in the morning, or on the third day: and when you have dissolved the wound, then change another cloth, and renew the ointment.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post spacium longum uirus subtile, tunc non desperes de adhaerentia eius, nam sanatio eius appropinquat, quoniam ex hominibus sunt qui tardant generationem carnis in uulneribus suis, et ex eis sunt qui agunt econtrario illius.	But if after a long space there comes out from the sinus a thin and subtle pus, then do not lose hope of its adhesion, for its healing is approaching, because among men are those who retard the formation of flesh in their own wounds, and also those who act against it.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post dies multos pus indigestum, tunc scias quod sinus non adhaeret.	If however unclean discharge issues from a sinew after many days, then you should know that the sinew is not adhering.
Si ergo tardatur adhaerentia Sinus, et prolongatur res eius: tunc adde in exiccatione medicinarum, uerum faciant medici, ut sint medicinae in substantia sua humidae, et in uirtute sua siccae: sicut unguentum dyafinicon, quando additur in eo superfluitas additionis ex zegi.	If therefore the sinew is delayed in adhering and its treatment is prolonged, then add to the drying remedies that true physicians do, so that they be moist in substance and dry in virtue: as balm of Vaseline when excess of the added ingredient from gall is removed.
Et ex magis ultimo quo curatur, est, ut accipias unguentum dyafinicon, et soluatur cum oleo rosato, et roretur super ipsum uinum antiquum aequale in substantia sua.	And from the final most serious treatment, is that you take balm of Vaseline, and dissolve it with rose oil, and pour it over equal wine in substance.
Deinde confice ipsum cum eo, et utere ipso.	Then apply it to him, and use it for him.
Et iam facit simile huic actioni, quando non est tibi praesens unguentum dyafinicon, mel, quando decoquis ipsum, donec ingrossetur, et uteris eo.	And now do the same with this action, when you do not have balm of Vaseline present, honey, when it is cooked and thickened, use it.
Aut accipe myrrham, et aloen, et olibanum: tere totum, et pulueriza illud super mel dum est super ignem.	Or take myrrh, and aloe, and galbanum; rub all together, and sprinkle that over honey when it is still on the fire.
Deinde line super ipsum pannum, et stringe ipsum super Sinum: et line cum melle quod decoquisti, donec ingrossatum est: et pulueriza super ipsum species, et pone super ipsum pannum, et stringe eum.	Then tie it over it with a cloth, and bind it over the sinew; then tie with honey which you cooked until thickened: and sprinkle over it spices, and place on top a cloth, and bind him.
Et quandoque administratur in illo aristolochia longa, et radices lilii coelestis, et est lilium: et farina herbi, et centaurea.	And sometimes it is administered to that Aristolochia longa, and roots of lily of heaven, and the lily itself, and wheat of the herb, and Centaury.
Utere eis simplicibus, aut aggregatis, tere ea, et cribella ipsa: et pulueriza super mel quod narraui, et utere eo.	Use them simple or compound, rub them together, and sift it; and sprinkle over the honey that I have spoken of, and use it with it.
Quod si prolongatur res Sinus, et non sanatur hac curatione: tunc scias, quod in profundo eius est corruptio: aut iam facit impressionem in ossibus, aut in reliquis membris duris, aut ligamentis: tunc cura ipsum curatione Fistularum, secundum quod praemissum est.	But if the treatment of the sinew is prolonged and does not heal with this cure: then know that there is corruption deep within it; or already it makes an impression in the bones, or in the other hard parts, or in the ligaments: then treat it with the cure of Abscesses, as was previously said.
¶ De cura Panaritii et unguis attritae, et incisione digiti additi, et sectione.	About the care of paralysis and worn nails, and the cutting of an added digit, and division.
Caput XCI.	Chapter 91.
Panaritium est apostema quod nascitur sub ungue pollicis manus, aut pedis: et fortasse nascitur in reliquis digitis.	Paralysis is a boil which arises under the nail of the thumb of the hand, or foot, and perhaps it also arises on other fingers.
Cum ergo prolongatur res eius, et negligitur curato eius, et apostematur apostemate calido: aut corrumpitur, et emittit pus, donec corrodit radicem unguis: et fortasse corrumpit eam totam, et fortasse peruenit corruptio ad os, donec est ei odor foetidus: et fit extremitas digiti lata, et fit color eius fuscus.	Therefore when it prolongs and is neglected in its care, and boils up with a warm boil, or becomes corrupted and lets out pus, until it corrodes the root of the nail, and perhaps corrupts it all the way through to the bone, so that there is a foul odor: and the end of the finger becomes swollen, and its color becomes dull.
Quando ergo tu curas ipsum, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut incidas cum ferro totam superfluitatem quae remansit ex ungue.	Therefore when you are treating it, as we said in the division, and your treatment is not effective: then you must cut out with iron all the superfluity that remains from the nail.
Deinde cauteriza uulnus post illud.	Then cauterize the wound after that.
Cauterium enim iuuatiuum est ualde.	For a cauterization is very helpful.
Si uero os est sanum, et est unguis etiam sana, et additiones uacuae unguis iam comprimunt carnem ad interiora, et incipiunt pungere ipsam, et laedunt eam: tunc oportet ut ponas Radium subtilem sub angulo unguis quae pungit carnem, et impelle eam sursum: et incide eam carnem cum facilitate, et pone super illud quod remanet de carne ex medicinis comburentibus, corrosiuis, donec remoueatur totum eius.	But if the bone is sound and the nail is also healthy, and the additions of the nail are now compressing the flesh to the inside, and begin to pierce it, and hurt it: then you must put a thin rod under the angle of the nail which pierces the flesh, and push it upwards: and cut out the flesh with ease, and put over what remains of the flesh medicines that burn and corrode, until all of it is removed.
Deinde cura illud cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with ointments, until it heals.
Si autem corruptio iam imprimit in os, tunc oportet ut incidas illud os, et extrahas ipsum: non enim sanatur unquam dum permanet in eo os corruptum.	But if the corruption has already sunk into the bone, then you must cut it out and remove it: for it will never heal while the corrupted bone remains.
Quod si uides corrosionem et corruptionem incedere in digitum, tunc incide eum in uno nodorum, secundum quod praemissa est eius rememoratio.	And if you see the corrosion and corruption spreading into the finger, then cut it off at a joint, according to what has been said before about its amputation.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then treat it, until it heals.
Si autem accidat ungui attritio, aut percussio: et contingit in ea dolor uehemens, tunc oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	If, however, a nail has been driven into or struck an artery: and there occurs in it a severe pain, then the patient must first be bled.
Deinde seca unguem cum Spatumili acuto sectione transuersa de sursum ad uisum.	Then cut off the nail with a sharp steel saw from top to bottom.
Et custodi, ne sectio perueniat ad carnem quae est sub ungue, nam tu facies accidere per illud super infirmum dolorem uehementem, et erit caussa ad natiuitatem carnis additae in loco.	And be careful that the cutting does not reach the flesh which is under the nail, for through it a severe pain will occur on the patient and there will be a cause for the birth of new flesh in place.
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod sedat dolores.	Then cure the place with what soothes pains.
Digitus uero additus qui nascitur in quibusdam manibus hominum, fortasse est carnosus totus: et fortasse sunt in quibusdam eorum ossa, et fortasse est in eo unguis: et quidam eorum nascitur in radice iuncturae, aut est natiuitas eius in quibusdam nodis digiti.	However, the finger which grows on some people's hands, is perhaps entirely fleshy and perhaps in some of them there are bones and perhaps a nail, and sometimes it grows from the root joint or its birth is in some of the finger's nodes.
Ille ergo qui nascitur in quibusdam nodis digiti, non mouetur: et ille qui nascitur apud iuncturam digiti, fortasse mouetur.	Therefore, that which grows in some of the finger's nodes does not move and that which grows at the joint of the finger perhaps moves.
Eius ergo qui ex eis est carnosus, sectio eius facilis est.	So, therefore, that one which is fleshy is easily cut off.
Quod est, ut incidas ipsum apud radicem suam cum Spatumili lato.	Which is to cut it at its root with a wide-bladed steel.
Eius autem cuius natiuitas est in radice iuncturae curatio, est difficilis.	But the cure of that one whose birth is in the joint of the knuckle is difficult.
Abstine ergo ab incisione eius.	Therefore refrain from cutting it.
In illo uero qui nascitur in digito apud ultimum nodorum, tunc oportet ut incidas in primis carnem eius incisione rotunda usque ad os.	But truly he who grows on the finger at the last joints, then it is necessary to cut into his flesh first with a rounded cut up to the bone.
Deinde serra os cum una illarum Serrarum conuenientium ad illud.	Then saw through the bone with one of those saws fitting for it.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then cure him until he heals.
Consolidatio autem quae accidit digitis adinuicem, multotiens accidit aut ex natiuitate hominis, id est, nascitur cum eo, aut a consolidatione uulneris, aut combustione ignis, et similibus.	But the joining together of fingers which often occurs together, happens sometimes from the birth of man, that is, it grows with him, or from the healing of a wound, or by burning of fire, and similar things.
Oportet ergo ut seces illam consolidationem, donec redeant digiti secundum formam suam naturalem.	Therefore it is necessary to cut off that joining until the fingers return to their natural shape.
Deinde pone inter eos licinia, aut pannos infusos in oleo rosato: ut non consolidentur uelociter, et separa inter eos: aut pone inter eos laminam plumbi subtilem, donec consolidetur locus secundum quod oportet.	Then place between them a ligature, or linen cloths soaked in rose oil, so that they do not heal quickly, and separate between them; or place between them a thin sheet of lead, until the place consolidates as it should.
Et similiter si accidat consolidatio quibusdam digitis cum palma, tunc seca illam consolidationem, secundum quod praeparatur et conuenit figurae membri.	And similarly if there is a consolidation of some fingers with the palm, then cut that consolidation, according to how it is prepared and fits the shape of the member.
¶ De incisione Vitium.	About cutting a wound.
Caput XCII.	Chapter 92.
Uites sunt Venae inuolutae, grossae, plenae superfluitatibus melancholicis quae accidunt in pluribus membris corporis: et plurimum euentus earum est in cruribus, praecipue in cruribus iter agentium et laborantium, et portantium.	Ulcers are veins that are wrapped around, thick, and full of melancholic superfluities which occur in many parts of the body: and most often they occur in legs, especially in the legs of travelers and workers, and those who carry heavy loads.
Oportet ergo ut administres excussionem corporis ex cholera nigra aliquotiens excussione forti.	Therefore you must administer a purging of the body from black bile several times with strong cleansing.
Deinde phlebotoma patientis eas basilicam.	Then apply bloodletting to the patient's Basilica vein.
Curatio uero earum cum ferro, est secundum duos modos.	The treatment of them with iron is according to two modes.
Vnus eorum est, ut secentur, et extrahatur sanguis niger.	One of them is, that they are cut, and the black blood is drawn out.
Et modus alter est, ut eleuetur Vena, et extrahatur tota.	And the other mode is, that the vein be lifted up, and the whole thing drawn out.
Sectio uero eius est secundum hunc modum.	The cutting of it is according to this method.
Embroca crus in primis cum aqua calida multum, donec resoluatur sanguis grossus faeculentus.	Wrap the leg first with hot water very much, until the thick and feculent blood dissolves.
Deinde stringe crus infirmi a superiori parte coxae eius, usque ad inferiorem partem genu cum uitta.	Then bind the weak leg of the patient from the upper part of his hip to the lower part of his knee with a bandage.
Deinde seca uenam in loco uno, aut duobus, aut tribus sectione ampla.	Then cut the vein in one place, or two, or three wide incisions.
Deinde eleua, id est, extrahe sanguinem in manu tua ab inferiori parte cruris, usque ad sursum, et a superiori oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	Then raise it, that is, draw out the blood from the lower part of the leg up to the top, and first let the physician take out the blood from the upper part.
Deinde seca unguem cum usque inferius: donec egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uides sufficere, et quam tolerat uirtus infirmi.	Then cut the nail down to the bottom until the quantity of blood that you see is sufficient and as much as the weakness of the patient can tolerate.
Postea liga eam: et praecipe ei, ut abstineat a cibis generantibus choleram nigram: et itera euacuationem et phlebotomiam, quando implentur Venae, et nocet illud infirmo.	Then bind her up. And order him to abstain from foods producing black bile. And let blood and repeat evacuation and venesection when the veins are filled, and it harms the sick one.
Eleuatio autem eius est secundum hunc modum.	Its evacuation however is in this manner.
Rade crus infirmi, si in ea sunt pili multi.	Shave the legs of the sick person if there are many hairs on them.
Deinde intromitte ipsum in balneum: aut embroca ipsum in crure eius cum aqua calida, donec rubeat, et exuberentur Venae: aut exercitetur exercitio forti, si non est ei praesens balneum, donec calefiat membrum.	Then insert him into the bath or pour hot water on his leg until it reddens and the veins are swollen: or exercise him with strong exercise if there is no bath present, until the member is warmed.
Deinde seca cutem in directo uenae sectione per longitudinem: aut in ultimo eius apud genu, aut in inferiori parte eius apud calcaneum.	Then cut the skin in a straight line along the direction of vein sectioning or at its last part near the knee, or at its lower part near the heel.
Deinde aperi cutem cum uncinis, et excoria uenam ab omni parte, donec appareat sensui: et est apud apparitionem eius, quod uides eam rubeam ad nigredinem decliuem.	Then open the cut with a hook and strip the vein from all sides until it appears to the sense: and at its appearance you see it reddening towards blackness.
Cum ergo uadit ex cute, uides eam albam quasi sit chorda.	When therefore it goes out of the skin, you see it white as if it were a cord.
Deinde intromitte sub ea Radium, donec quando eleuatur et egreditur de cute: suspende eam cum uncino caeco, leni.	Then insert under it some linen until when it is raised and goes out of the skin: suspend it with a blind hook gently.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam prope illam sectionem tribus digitis.	Then cut another section nearby, three fingers from that first cut.
Deinde excoria cutem a superiori parte uenae, donec appareat.	Then strip the skin away from the upper part of the vein until it appears.
Deinde eleua eam cum Radiis sicut fecisti, et suspende eam cum uncino alio, sicut fecisti in primis.	Then raise it with linens as you did, and suspend it with another hook as you first did.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam, aut sectiones plures, si indiges illo.	Then cut another section, or more sections if necessary for that.
Deinde eleua, et incide ipsam ultima sectione apud calcaneum.	Then raise and incise the very last section at the heel.
Deinde extrahe eam ad sectionem quae est supra eam.	Then draw it out to the section which is above it.
Et fac illud, donec extrahas eam ex sectione quae est superior, uel altior sectionibus omnibus, donec quando egreditur tota: tunc incide eam.	And do that until you draw it out from the upper section or all higher sections, until when it goes out entirely; then cut it.
Si autem non obedit tibi ad extrahendum, et eleuandum: tunc intromitte acum cum filo forti duplo, et liga eam, et extrahe ipsam: aut intromitte sub ea Radium: et reuolue manum tuam ad omnem partem, donec egrediatur.	But if it does not obey you to be drawn out and raised: then insert a hook with a strong string doublefold, and bind it, and draw it out; or insert under it some linen: and turn your hand over in all ways until it comes out.
Et caue, ne incidatur.	And beware, lest it be cut.
Nam si incidatur, fit difficile tibi eleuare eam ualde, et ingreditur super infirmum ex ea nocumentum.	For if it is cut, it becomes difficult for you to lift it up greatly, and a hurtful trouble enters into the sick person from it.
Cum ergo extraxeris eam totam: tunc pone super locum uulnerum lanam submersam in uino et oleo rosato, aut oleo: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	So when you have drawn it out entirely, then place over the place of wounds a cloth dipped in wine and rose oil, or in oil, and take care of him until he be healed.
Quod si Vitis est contracta, habens tortuositatem cui sit inuolutio ad partes, et non est sicut diximus secundum rectitudinem: tunc oportet ut findas super eam ad omnem partem tortuositatis eius, et loca inuolutionis ipsius.	But if the vein is contracted, having a twist to which its turning is towards the parts, and it is not as we said according to straightness: then it is necessary that you cut on top of it for all part of its twist, and places of its turning.
Deinde suspende eam cum uncinis, donec eleues eam totam: et caue apud sectionem tuam super eam ne incidas uenam, aut uulneres: nam difficile fiet super te eleuare, uel extrahere eam.	Then suspend it with hooks, until you lift it out entirely: and beware near your cut on top of it lest you cut the vein, or wound it: for it will be difficult for you to lift it, or draw it out.
Conserua ergo prudentiam tuam.	Therefore preserve your prudence.
Forma Incidentis quo sanatur Vitis.	The Form of Cutting by which the Vein is healed.
Forma Vncini caeci.	The Form of a Blind Hook.
Non est ei curuitas sicut reliquis Vncinis, neque est acutae extremitatis, ut non uulneret uenam: et est grossae flectuositatis, lenis: quoniam si esset subtilis, incideret uenam subtilitate sua: imo sit ei superflua grossitudo, sicut diximus.	It does not have the curvature as with the other hooks, nor is it sharp at the end, so that it may not wound the vein: and it has a thick, gentle bending, because if it were slender, it would cut the vein by its slenderness: nay, let its thickness be superfluous, as we said.
De extractione Venae cruris.	On the drawing out of the vein of the thigh.
Caput XCIII.	Chapter 93.
Haec Vena generatur in cruribus in terris calidis, sicut Alizegi, et terra Arabum, et in terris aridis, calidis, paucae teneritatis, id est, in quibus non nascitur herba, neque arbor.	This vein is generated in the thighs on hot lands, such as Egypt and the land of the Arabs, and on dry hot lands, a few in softness, that is, in which grass nor tree does not grow.
Et fortasse generatur in locis aliis corporis praeter crura.	And perhaps it is generated in other parts of the body besides the thighs.
Et generatio quidem eius est a putrefactione quae accidit sub cute, sicut accidunt intra corpora serpentes et uermes ascarides, et uermes generati inter cutem et carnem.	And its generation indeed is from the putrefaction that occurs under the skin, just as it happens in the bodies of snakes and ascarid worms, and the worms generated between the skin and flesh.
Et signum incaeptionis euentus huius Venae est, quod accidit in crure inflammatio uehemens.	And the sign of the beginning of this vein's outcome is, that an inflammation occurs mildly in the leg.
Deinde uesicatur locus.	Then the area becomes watery.
Deinde incipit Vena exire ex loco illius uesicationis, quasi sit radix plantae, aut animal.	Then the vein begins to protrude from that place of swelling, as if it were a root of a plant or an animal.
Cum ergo apparet ex ea extremitas eius, tunc oportet ut inuoluas super ipsam frustum plumbi, cuius pondus sit ex drachma keil, usque ad drachmas II et noda ipsam: et dimitte plumbum suspensum ex crure.	So when its extremity appears from it, then it is necessary to wrap around it a piece of lead whose weight is one and a half drachms, up to two drachms, and tie the thread on it: and let the lead hang from the leg.
Quotiens ergo egreditur ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, inuolue illud in plumbo, et noda illud.	Whenever therefore something protrudes from it to the exterior, wrap that up in lead and tie it.
Quod si prolongatur multum, tunc incide partem eius, et inuolue residuum.	But if it is prolonged much, then cut off a part of it, and wrap the remainder.
Et non incidas eam radicitus antequam egrediatur tota.	And do not cut it from its roots until it has protruded completely.
Quoniam si incidis, contrahitur, et ingreditur in carnem: et facit accidere apostema, et putredinem in loco, et ulcus malum.	For if you cut it, it contracts and enters into the flesh: and causes an abscess to occur, and a foul decay in the place, and a bad ulcer.
Quapropter oportet, ut suauiter tractetur, et extrahatur paulatim, donec egrediatur ex ultimo sui, et non remaneat ex ea aliquid in corpore: et ex hac quidem Vena egreditur in quibusdam hominibus quod est in longitudine sua quinque palmorum et decem.	Therefore it is necessary that it be treated gently, and extracted gradually, until it protrudes completely from its last part, and nothing remains of it in the body: and from this vein a certain thing issues forth in some men which is five palms and ten in length.
Et iam peruenit ad me, quia exiuit uiro ex XX palmis.	And now it has come to me, because it protruded from a man of twenty palms.
Si autem inciditur tibi in hora medicationis tuae: tunc intromitte radium in foramine eius, et perfora eam foramine longo, cum corpore, donec euacuetur totum quod est in ea ex materia: et administra putrefactionem loci cum medicinis diebus aliquot.	But if it is cut into you during your time of treatment: then insert a needle into its hole and perforate it with a long hole, along with the body, until all that is in it is emptied out from matter: and administer corruption to the place with medicines for several days.
Deinde cura ipsum curatione apostematum.	Then treat the place itself with the cure of abscesses.
Et haec quidem Vena quandoque habet ramos multos, praecipue quando apparet in iunctura pedis, aut in pede ipso: et accidunt ei orificia multa, et egreditur ex omni orificio ramus.	And this vein indeed sometimes has many branches, especially when it appears at the joint of the foot, or on the foot itself: and many openings occur to it, and a branch issues out from every opening.
Cura ergo ipsam, sicut diximus in diuisione, et cum eo quod praemissum est.	Therefore, cure it as we said in the division, and with what has been said beforehand.
¶ De sectione super Vermes generatos sub cute, et dicitur Aegritudo bouina.	On the cutting of worms that have been generated under the skin, and it is called a horse affliction.
Caput XCIIII.	Chapter 94.
Haec Aegritudo nominatur in quadam terra apud nos Aegritudo bouina: propterea, quia multotiens accidit bouibus, et est uermis paruus unus, qui nascitur inter cutem et carnem.	This affliction is called among us a horse affliction, on account of the fact that it often occurs in horses, and it is a small worm which is born between the skin and the flesh.
Et uadit in corpore toto, ascendendo et descendendo: et ostenditur sensui apud ambulationem eius de membro ad membrum, donec disrumpit ubicumque disrumpit in cute locum, et egreditur.	And it wanders throughout the body, ascending and descending, and is perceived by sense from member to member, until it bursts wherever it bursts through a place in the skin, and comes out.
Et generatio eius est ex putredine quorundam humorum.	And its generation is from the corruption of some humors.
Sicut accidunt uermes et serpentes, id est, lumbrici, et ascarides in uentre.	Just as worms and serpents, that is, earthworms and tapeworms occur in the belly.
Et timetur ex malicia eius.	And it is feared from its evil.
Quia quando ipse uadit in corpore, et eleuatur ad caput, et peruenit ad locum: tunc fortasse aperit in eo, et egreditur, et destruit oculum: et accidit illud multotiens.	Because when it itself goes into the body, and rises to the head, and reaches a place: then perhaps it opens up in it, and comes out, and destroys an eye: and that happens very often.
Cum ergo uis curare eum, et extrahere ipsum, tunc non fit illud nisi apud ambulationem eius, et apparitionem ipsius sensui.	Therefore when you wish to cure it and extract itself, then it is not done unless during its movement, and appearance of itself to sense.
Oportet ergo, ut stringas quod est supra eum, et quod est sub eo cum ligamento constrictione forti.	Therefore you should bind what is above it and what is below it with a strong binding tie.
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	Then cut above it, and extract it.
Quod si profundatur in carne, et non inuenis ipsum: tunc pone super locum cauterium cum igne, donec moriatur.	But if it has sunk deep into the flesh, and you do not find it: then place a cautery with fire on top of the place, until it dies.
Et maius quod timetur, est corruptio eius, qua corrumpit oculum, sicut diximus.	And more feared is its corruption, whereby it corrupts an eye, as we said.
Si autem uides eum iam peruenisse in capite prope oculum, tunc stringe sub eo supercilium strictura bona.	But if you see it already having arrived at the head near the eye, then bind under it the eyebrow with a good binding.
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	Then cut above it and extract it.
Et oportet ut utatur infirmus mundificatione sui corporis, cum medicinis soluentibus humores putridos malos.	And it is necessary that the sick person should purify his body with medicines dissolving bad and foul humors.
Et caueat sibi a cibis generantibus putrefactionem.	And let him beware of foods that generate putrefaction.
¶ De sectione super aegritudinem Nakir.	Concerning the cutting over an ailment called Nakir.
Caput XCV.	Chapter 95.
Haec aegritudo nominatur in terra nostra Nakir: et est dolor qui accidit in quibusdam membris: deinde permutatur de membro ad membrum.	This ailment is called Nakir in our land, and it is a pain that occurs in some members, then it passes from member to member.
Et ego quidem iam uidi ipsum, secundum quod narro tibi.	And I myself have now seen it, just as I am telling you.
Vocatus sum ad mulierem infirmam in quibusdam uillis.	I was called to a sick woman in certain villages.
Et detexit brachium suum, et uidi inflationem paruam in uena funis brachii.	And she showed me her arm, and I saw a small swelling in the vein of the arm's tendon.
Et postquam remansi hora una, uidi unam inflationem incedere cum focili, sicut incedit uermis, ascendendo ad humerum eius uelocius quam esse potest: ut sit sicut argentum uiuum, quando currit de loco ad locum.	And after I had stayed an hour, I saw one swelling move with the flux, as a worm moves, ascending to her shoulder more quickly than it can be, just like quicksilver when it runs from place to place.
Recessit ergo dolor ex illo loco, et fixus est in humero.	Therefore the pain receded from that place and was fixed in the shoulder.
Deinde sedi hora una, et cucurrit in reliquum corpus, donec perueniret in brachium aliud.	Then I sat for an hour, and it ran to the rest of the body until it reached another arm.
Deinde narrauit mihi, quia reuoluebatur in toto corpore suo, secundum quod uidi.	Then she told me that it was revolving throughout her whole body, just as I had seen.
Miratus sum ergo de uelocitate permutationis eius de membro ad membrum.	I therefore marveled at the swiftness of its change from member to member.
Et ego quidem ante illud non uideram hanc aegritudinem oculis meis taliter secundum hunc modum.	And I myself had not seen this ailment with my own eyes in such a manner before that time.
Verumtamen uidi multos, qui inueniunt dolorem permutari de membro ad membrum: et non uidi ipsum oculis, sicut uidi eum in muliere.	But I had seen many who found the pain to be changed from member to member, and I did not see it myself with my own eyes as I saw it in the woman.
Et ego non cogito illud esse, nisi quod est propterea, quod mulier fuit ex illis qui sunt ex uillis sicci corporis detectarum uenarum: hinc ergo apparet sensui illa uentositas permutata.	And I do not think that it is anything else, because the woman was from those people who have dry bodies and their veins are found to be detected: therefore this wind-like swelling appears to me to be changed.
Et est necesse, ut non appareant secundum hanc rationem in illis qui sunt deliciosi, et corporibus humidis, occultarum uenarum.	And it is necessary that they not be visible according to this reason in those who are delicate and have moist bodies, of hidden veins.
Cum ergo uis curationem eius, et sentit patiens illud dolorem: tunc si est apparens tibi oculo, sicut diximus, tunc stringe supra ipsum, et sub ipso uelociter: et seca supra ipsum, donec egrediatur illa uentositas coartata: et cauteriza locum.	Therefore when you wish to treat it and the patient feels that pain, then if it is visible to your eye as we said, then bind something over it quickly from above and below: and cut off above it until the swelling goes out: and cauterize the place.
Si autem non uides ipsum oculis tuis: tunc cura ipsum cum excussione corporis, et cum eo quod expellit uentositates, et carminat eas cum pillulis foetidis, et pillulis de serapino, et similibus.	But if you do not see it with your eyes: then treat it with purging of the body and with that which expels swellings, and plaster them with pills of stinking things, and pills of asafoetida, and similar things.
¶ De extractione Sagittarum.	On the removal of arrows.
Caput XCVI.	Chapter 96.
Sagittae diuersificantur secundum species suas, et secundum loca in quibus cadunt ex corpore.	Arrows are differentiated according to their kinds, and according to the places in which they fall from the body.
Earum uero diuersitas est: quoniam ex eis sunt quae habent cuspides magnos, et paruos: et concauae, et surdae.	Their diversity is that there are those with large points and small ones: and concave and curved.
Et ex eis sunt quae habent tres angulos.	And among them are those which have three angles.
Et ex eis quibus sunt linguae.	And from them there are tongues.
Et ex eis quibus sunt astellae.	And from them there are stars.
Illae uero quae sunt secundum membra in quibus cadunt, est secundum duos modos.	Those however that fall according to members in which they fall, is according to two modes.
Aut enim membra sunt ex membris principalibus concauis, sicut cerebrum, et cor, et epar, et pulmo, et renes, et intestina, et uesica, et eis similia.	Or else the members are of concave principal members, such as the brain and heart and liver and lung and kidney and intestine and bladder and those similar.
Quando ergo cadit in aliquo horum membrorum, et apparent tibi signa mortis, quae ego narro tibi post, tunc oportet ut deuites extractionem illius sagittae ex eis, nam mors consequitur illum in quo est, in pluribus dispositionibus.	Therefore when it falls into one of these members and signs of death appear to you which I will tell you next, then it is necessary for you to flee from the extraction of that arrow from them, because death follows him in whom it is, in many dispositions.
Et quando non apparent tibi ista signa mala, et sagitta non est absconsa in profunditate membri, tunc extrahe ipsam, et cura uulnus.	And when these bad signs do not appear to you and the arrow is not hidden in the depth of the member, then extract it and treat the wound.
Ex signis enim cerebri quando cadit in eo sagitta, et penetrat os, et egreditur siphac quod est super cerebrum, est: quoniam accidunt ex illo soda uehemens, et scotomia, et uertigo, et rubedo in oculis, et inflatio, et rubedo linguae, et spasmus, et permixtio intellectus, et uomitus cholerae.	When a bullet falls into the brain and penetrates the skull, and exits through the siphac that is above the brain, the symptoms are: because of it there occur numbness, weakness, scotoma, vertigo, redness in the eyes, swelling, redness of the tongue, spasm, and mixture of intellect, and choleric vomiting.
Et fortasse egreditur sanguis ex naribus, aut auribus.	And perhaps blood will issue from the nostrils or ears.
Et fortasse abscinditur sermo, et destruitur uox.	And perhaps speech is cut off and voice is destroyed.
Et egreditur ex loco uulneris humiditas alba similis pulti.	And a white fluid like pus issues from the place of the wound.
Et exit ex eo simile aquositati carnis.	And it comes out similar to meat juice.
Si ergo apparent tibi ista signa, tunc abstine a curatione, et extrahe sagittam si non egreditur.	If therefore these signs appear to you, then abstain from treatment and draw out the arrow if it does not issue.
Signa autem sagittae quando cadit in corde, sunt: quod ipsa est prope mammillam sinistram: et sentit cum ea quasi ipsa sit fixa in re dura, non in re uacua.	The signs of the arrow when it falls into the heart are: that it is near the left nipple: and it feels as though itself is fixed in a hard thing, not in an empty one.
Et fortasse sagittae est motus similis motui pulsus: et currit ex uulnere sanguis niger.	And perhaps the movement of the arrow is similar to the movement of the pulse: and blood flows from the wound that is black.
Et sequitur illud frigus extremitatum, et sudor frigidus, et syncopis.	And it follows that chillness of the extremities, and cold sweat, and syncope.
Scias ergo, quod mors descendit procul dubio.	Know therefore that death comes certainly nearby.
Et signum sagittae quando uulnerat pulmonem, est exitus sanguinis spumosi ex uulnere: et uasa quae sequuntur collum, apostematur, et mutatur color infirmi.	And the sign of the arrow when it wounds the lung is the issuance of frothy blood from the wound: and the vessels that follow the neck become inflamed, and their colour changes to that of an invalid.
Et expirat spiritum magnum, altum: et quaerit attractionem aeris frigidi.	And it breathes out a large, deep spirit: and it seeks the inhalation of cold air.
Quod si cadat sagitta in uelamen, quod est in pectore: tunc est prope costas paruas: et fit anhelitus magnus cum dolore uehementi, cum suspirio: et mouentur omnia membra humerorum.	Which if the arrow falls into the membrane that is in the breast: then it is near to the small ribs: and there is a great panting with severe pain, with sighing: and all the members of the shoulders are moved.
Et si cadat sagitta in stomachum, tunc fortasse egreditur ex uulnere ex cibo aliquid indigestum.	And if the arrow falls into the stomach, then perhaps something undigested comes out from the wound.
Et si cadit sagitta in Ventrem, et figitur in eo: egreditur aliquid stercoris ex uulnere, aut zirbum, aut intestinum quod iam disruptum est.	And if an arrow falls into the abdomen and is stuck there: something exits from the wound, either feces or a intestine that has already ruptured.
Non est ergo spes in curatione eius, neque in extractione sagittae.	So then there is no hope for its cure, nor for the removal of the arrow.
Quod si sagitta cadat in Vesicam, et egrediatur urina: et procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, et fortior sit dolor super infirmum: tunc scias, quia est mortale.	Which if the arrow falls into the bladder and urine exits from it, and something proceeds from it to the outside, and the pain is greater over the patient: then you will know that it is mortal.
Reliqua autem membra, sicut facies, et collum, et guttur, et spatula, et adiutorium, et spondiles dorsi, et furcula, et coxa, et crus, et eis similia ex membris saluantur secundum plures dispositiones: quando non inuenit sagitta arteriam, aut neruum: et non est sagitta uenenosa.	But other members, such as the face, and neck, and throat, and scapula, and ribs, and furcula, and coxa, and leg, and similar ones are cured from their wounds according to many dispositions: when the arrow does not find an artery or a nerve, and the arrow is not poisonous.
Et ego narro tibi quod uidi de esse harum sagittarum, ut significes per illud super curationem tuam.	And I tell you what I have seen regarding these kinds of arrows, so that you may know through it about your own cure.
Quod est, quia cuidam uiro cecidit sagitta in lachrymali oculi eius, in radice nasi.	Which is, because an arrow fell into the tear duct of his eye, at the root of his nose.
Extraxi ergo eam ipsi ex parte altera, sub adipe auris eius: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei in oculo eius nocumentum.	So I extracted it from him on the other side, under the fat of his ear, and he was healed, and there was no damage to his eye.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam Iudaeo, quae cecidit ei in adipe oculi sui sub palpebra inferiori: et sagitta iam occultata erat, et non consecutus sum ex ea nisi extremitatem paruam eius, cum qua adhaeret in ligno suo: et erat sagitta magna ex sagittis arcuum Turcorum, cum ferro leni, in qua non sunt aures.	And I extracted another arrow from a Jew, which had fallen into the fat of his eye under the lower eyelid: and the arrow was already hidden, and I did not manage to extract it except for a small part of it, with which it adhered to its wooden shaft: and the arrow was large among the arrows of Turkish bows, with a light iron point, in which there are no barbs.
Sanatus est ergo Iudaeus, et non accidit in oculo eius accidens malum.	So the Jew was healed, and there did not occur any evil thing in his eye.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam ex gutture Christiani.	And I extracted another arrow from a Christian's throat.
Et erat sagitta arabica, et est illa cui sunt aures.	And the arrow was Arab, and it is that one with barbs.
Secui ergo super ipsam inter duas guidegi: et iam submersa erat in gutture eius.	I therefore attached to it two thread-like filaments, and already they were submerged in his throat.
Subtiliatus sum ergo cum ea, donec extraxi eam: et sanatus est Christianus.	I have therefore managed to extract it from her with difficulty, until I drew it out: and the Christian woman was healed.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam uiro quae ceciderat in uentre eius: et cogitauimus, quia moreretur ex ea.	And I extracted another arrow from a man that had fallen into his belly: and we thought, that he would die from it.
Postquam ergo praeterierunt ei triginta dies, et non mutatum est super eum aliquid ex dispositionibus eius, secui super sagittam: et ingeniaui super eam, et extraxi eam: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei accidens malum.	After therefore thirty days had passed over him, and nothing in his conditions had been changed, I followed after the arrow: and I devised a plan for it, and I extracted it: and he was healed, and no evil thing happened to him.
Et uidi uirum cui cecidit sagitta in dorso eius, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam.	And I saw a man upon whom an arrow had fallen into his back, and the wound over it had been closed.
Postquam ergo fuit post septem annos, exiuit sagitta in radice coxae eius.	After therefore seven years had passed, the arrow had come out at the root of his hip.
Et uidi mulierem cui cecidit in uentre suo sagitta, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam, et remansit sagitta intra ipsam: et non mutata est ex dispositionibus eius aliqua, et mulier non inuenit ei nocumentum in aliqua ex operationibus suis naturalibus.	And I saw a woman upon whom an arrow had fallen into her belly, and the wound over it had been closed, and the arrow remained within her: and there was not changed anything in her conditions, and the woman did not find any harm from any of her natural functions.
Et uidi uirum alium, cui cecidit sagitta in facie sua: et consolidatum est uulnus, et remansit, non inueniens ei multum dolorem: et similia istis multa.	And I saw another man upon whom an arrow had fallen into his face: and the wound was closed, and it remained, not finding much pain for him: and similar things to these many.
Et extraxi sagittam uiro ex principibus Regis, quae ceciderat ei in medio nasi sui, et iam declinauerat ad partem dextram parumper: et occultata erat sagitta tota.	And I extracted an arrow from a man who was one of the king's princes, which had fallen into his middle nose, and it had already turned to the right side a little: and the arrow was completely hidden.
Vocatus sum ergo ad curationem eius post casum sagittae usque ad tres dies.	I was therefore called to his cure after the fall of the arrow for three days.
Inueni ergo uulnus sagittae strictum ualde.	I found then the wound of the arrow very tightly closed.
Inquisiui ergo eam cum tenta subtili, et non sensi eam: et ipse quidem inueniebat punctionem et dolorem sub aure sua ex parte dextra.	I therefore questioned it with a fine probe, and I did not feel it: and he indeed was finding a puncture and pain under his ear on the right side.
Speraui ergo, quod erat illa punctio ex extremitate sagittae.	I therefore hoped that the puncture was from the end of the arrow.
Emplastraui ergo locum cum emplastro in quo erat uirtus attractiua, et digestiua, confidens apud me, quod apostemaretur locus, et appareret mihi signum sagittae, ut secarem super eam: et non accidit in loco accidens significans quod sagitta consecuta sit locum.	I therefore applied a dressing to the place with an ointment which had the virtue of attraction and digestion, trusting within myself that the spot would become inflamed, and I would see a sign of the arrow, so that I could cut over it: and no unfortunate event occurred in the place indicating that the arrow had followed it.
Assiduaui ergo cum emplastro super eum diebus multis: et non accidit accidens, et consolidatum est uulnus interim: et remansit infirmus de extractione eius spacio dierum, donec sensit sagittam die quodam intra nasum suum.	Therefore I applied a plaster on him for many days and an accident did not occur, and the wound was consolidated in the meantime. And he remained ill from the removal of it for a period of days until he felt the arrow one day inside his nose.
Et narrauit mihi illud.	And he told me that.
Posui ergo super illud uulnus medicinam acutam, corrosiuam diebus multis, donec apertum est: et cum tenta tentaui ipsum, et sensi extremitatem sagittae subtilem quae adhaeret in ligno.	I therefore placed on that wound a sharp and corroding medicine for many days until it was opened. And when I had touched it with a probe and felt the tip of the arrow which was adhering to the wood.
Deinde addidi in apertione uulneris per illam medicinam acutam, donec apparuit nobis uisibiliter extremitas sagittae: et praeteriit mihi cum eo spacium temporis circiter quatuor menses.	Then I added through the opening of the wound the sharp medicine until it appeared visibly to us that tip of the arrow, and a period of time passed with him about four months.
Deinde postquam amplificatum est uulnus, et possible fuit mihi intromittere forcipes in ipsam, et mouere ipsam, et non obediuit ad exitum: tunc non cessaui subtiliare, et ingeniare super eam cum modis ingeniorum, donec coepi super eam die quodam cum forcipibus decenter factis, secundum quod ueniet forma eorum in fine capituli, donec extraxi eam.	Then after the wound had been enlarged and it was possible for me to insert forceps into it and move it, but it did not obey going out. Then I did not cease to refine and devise over it with the means of artisans until one day with well-made forceps, in such a way as their shape fits at the end of the handle, until I extracted it.
Deinde restauraui uulnus.	Then I restored the wound.
Et medici quidem iudicant, quod cartilago nasi non restauratur.	And indeed the doctors judge that the cartilage of the nose is not restored.
Restauraui ergo ipsam, et consolidatum est uulnus, et sanatus est infirmas sanitate integra: nec nocuit ei aliquid omnino.	I therefore restored it and the wound was consolidated, and the sick person was healed with complete health, nor did anything bad happen to him at all.
Et ego narro tibi qualitatem extractionis quarundam sagittarum: ut ponas illud regulam et significationem super illud quod non dixi.	And I tell you the quality of extracting some arrows, so that you can place a rule and explanation over what I did not say.
Quoniam partes huius artis et distinctiones earum non comprehenduntur cum narratione: neque comprehendit illud liber, et artifex prudens comparat cum pauco super multum: et cum eo quod est paesens, super illud quod est absens: et inuenit operationem nouam, et instrumentum nouum apud descensus rerum extranearum huius artis quando accidunt.	Since the parts of this art and their distinctions are not comprehended with a narration, nor is it comprehended by that book, and a wise craftsman compares little to much: and what is present over what is absent: and he finds a new operation, and a new instrument among the descending things of foreign matters of this art when they occur.
Dico ergo, quod sagittae non egrediuntur ex membris quibus sunt fixae, nisi secundum duos modos.	Therefore, I say that arrows do not emerge from the limbs in which they are fixed, unless according to two modes.
Aut per attractionem ex loco ex quo intrauit.	Or by means of attraction from the place from which it entered.
Aut contrario partis alterius.	Or from the opposite part of another one.
Et illa quae egreditur unde intrauit, aut est sagitta procedens in loco carnoso: et attrahitur, et egreditur.	And that which emerges from where it entered is either an arrow going into a fleshy place and is attracted and emerges.
Quod si non obedit ad exitum ex hora in qua cadit: tunc oportet ut dimittas ipsam aliquot diebus, donec putrefiat caro quae est in circumitu eius: et alleuietur attractio eius, et eius egressio.	Which if it does not obey exit on the hour when it falls: then it is necessary that you let go of it for a few days, until the flesh around it has putrefied and its attraction has been eased, and its emergence facilitated.
Et similiter si figitur in osse, et non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc dimitte ipsam etiam aliquot diebus: et itera eam cum attractione et motione omni die, donec egreditur.	And similarly if it is fixed in a bone and does not obey you to emerge, then let it go also for a few days; and then try it with attraction and movement every day, until it emerges.
Quod si non obedit tibi ad exitum post dies, tunc oportet ut perfores in circumitu sagittae in ipso osse ab omni parte cum terebro subtili, donec amplificentur sagittae.	Which if it does not obey you to emerge after days, then it is necessary that you make a perforation around the arrow in the bone itself from every part with a fine awl, until the arrowhead is enlarged.
Deinde attrahe eam, et extrahe ipsam.	Then draw it out and extract it.
Si autem sagitta est fixa in capitis osse, et iam processit in uno uentrium cerebri, et apparent ex infirmo quaedam illorum accidentium quae dixi: tunc abstine ab attractione sagittae, et dimitte eam, donec aequetur esse eius post dies.	If however the arrow is fixed in the bone of the head and has already proceeded into one of the ventricles of the brain, and some of those symptoms which I have said appear from the patient: then abstain from drawing out the arrow, and let it be, until its force is equalled after days.
Nam si sagitta peruenit ad sifach, tunc mors non prolongatur ei.	For if the arrow has reached the brain, then death is not prolonged for him.
Et si sagitta non est fixa, nisi in corpore ossis tantum, et non penetrat usque ad sifach: et remanet infirmus aliquot diebus, et non accidit ei ex illis accidentibus aliquid: tunc ingenia in attractione sagittae et extractione eius.	And if the arrow is not fixed, except in a single bone, and does not penetrate as far as to the brain: and the patient remains sick for some days, and nothing of those accidents happens to him: then attempt at drawing out the arrow and extracting it.
Si autem est fixa ualde, et non obedit tibi ad attractionem: tunc administra terebella in circumitu sagittae, sicut narraui tibl: deinde cura locum, donec sanetur.	And if it is fixed very firmly and does not obey you to draw out: then administer cauterization around the arrow, just as I told you; then treat the place, until it heals.
Si autem Sagitta iam absconsa est in loco corporis, et occultatur et absconditur a sensu: tunc inquire eam cum tenta.	If, however, the arrow is already hidden within the body's location and is concealed from sense perception: then seek it out with a probe.
Si autem sentis eam, tunc attrahe eam cum quibusdam instrumentis quae conueniunt attractioni eius.	If, however, you feel it, then pull it out with some instruments which suit its extraction.
Si autem non potes super eam, propter constrictionem uulneris, et propter longitudinem sagittae in profundo: et non est illic os, neque neruus, neque uena: tunc finde super eam, donec amplificetur uulnus, et sit possibile extrahere sagittam.	If, however, you are not able to pull out over it, because of the constriction of the wound and the length of the arrow in depth, and there is no bone, nerve or vein: then dig down over it, until the wound is enlarged and it becomes possible to extract the arrow.
Quod si sunt ei aures quibus teneatur, tunc libera carnem fixam in eis ab omni parte, omni ingenio quo potes illud, et ingenia, si non potest super euasionem carnis in fractura aurium, et contorsione earum, donec euadat.	And if there are ears in which it is stuck, then free the fixed flesh in them from all sides, by whatever means you can, and make use of instruments, if it cannot be pulled out over the evasion of flesh in the fracture of the ears and their twisting, until it comes out.
Et tu quando administras extractionem Sagittae, in quocumque loco est, tunc utere contorsione manus tuae, cum forficibus ad partes omnes, donec facias eam euadere: et subtilia ultima subtilitate, ut non frangatur Sagita, et fiat difficilis tibi attractio eius, et ipsius extractio.	And you when administering the extraction of the arrow, in whatever place it is, then make use of twisting with your hand, with forceps to all parts, until you make it come out: and with subtle subtlety, so that the arrow itself does not break and its extraction becomes difficult for you.
Quod si non potes super eam ex hora una, tunc dimitte eam diebus aliquot, donec putrefiant quae sunt in circumitu eius.	And if you are unable to pull it out from one hour, then leave it for several days, until the things that are around it become putrid.
