Considera ergo tunc, si nodatio est recens: administra in ea medicinas quae stipticitatem habent, sicut aloe, et olibanum, et myrrha, et sarcocolla, et acacia, et similia eis.	Therefore consider then, if the swelling is recent: administer to it medicines which have an astringent quality, such as aloe, and frankincense, and myrrh, and resin of the tree called sarcocolla, and acacia, and similar things.
Ita, ut accipias ex istis quasdam, aut omnes eas: et confice eas cum uino stiptico, aut cum albumine oui, aut cum aceto: et pone eas super nodationem in stuppa, et stringe eas super ipsam strictura bona.	Thus take some of them, or all of them; and prepare them with astringent wine, or with egg white, or with vinegar; and place them on the swelling in a compress, and bind them over it with a good bandage.
Et dimitte stricturam, nec soluas eam diebus multis.	And leave the bandage, nor loosen it for many days.
Deinde solue eam, et itera aliam, donec remoueatur nodatio.	Then loosen it, and apply another one, until the swelling is removed.
Aut stringe super ipsam laminam plumbi decenter.	Or bind over it a thin lead plate.
Plumbo enim est proprietas remouendi omne quod timetur ex membris.	For lead has the property of removing all that is feared from the limbs.
Si autem nodatio iam in lapidem conuersa est, et stricta est, et festine prouocat necessitas ad auferendum eam: tunc finde super eam ex superiori parte eius, et incide superfluitatem eminentem: aut rade eam cum quibusdam rasoriis, donec remoueatur: et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	But if the swelling has already turned to a stone and is hard and presses urgently to be removed: then make an incision over it from above down, and cut out the superfluous part that protrudes; or rasp it with some rasps until it is removed: and care for the limb until it heals.
¶ De curatione quando restauratur, et remanet membrum post illud subtile, non secundum naturam suam.	On the treatment when it is restored, and the member remains after that subtle, not according to its natural form.
Caput XXII.	Chapter Twenty-Two.
Quando restauratur fractura ossis, et remanet membrum post illud subtile, debile: tunc non fit illud nisi propter caussas multas.	When a bone fracture is restored and the member remains after it subtle, weak: then that does not happen unless for many causes.
Quarum una est, multitudo solutionis ligamenti et ligationis eius non secundum quod oportet: aut propter superfluitatem stricturae ligamentorum, donec prohibeatur nutrimentum currere ad membrum: aut propter multitudinem embrocationis superfluae in non sua hora: aut propter paucitatem sanguinis in corpore infirmi, et debilitatem eius.	One of these is the multitude of solutions to ligaments and ligation thereof not according to what is fitting: either on account of excess tightness of the ligaments, until it prohibits nourishment from flowing into the member; or on account of the abundance of superfluous embrocation at an improper time: or on account of the scarcity of blood in the body of the infirm person, and its weakness.
Et curatio illius est, cibare infirmum, et tenerum facere corpus eius, donec multiplicetur sanguis in eo.	And the cure for this is to feed the infirm person, and to make their body tender, until blood multiplies in them.
Et administra balneum.	And administer a warm bath.
Et intromitte gaudium et laeticiam super eum.	And bring joy and gladness over him.
Deinde pone picem super membrum: ut attrahat pix ad ipsum nutrimentum multum.	Then place pitch on the member, so that it draws pitch to itself as a great nourishment.
Et assiduet embrocationem eius cum aqua tepida, donec currat nutrimentum, et redeat ad figuram suam naturalem.	And apply its ointment with warm water, until nourishment flows and returns to its natural shape.
¶ De curatione ossium fractorum quando restaurantur tortuose.	On the cure of broken bones when they are set crookedly.
Caput XXIII.	Chapter 23.
Quando accidit membro iam restaurato post sanationem eius tortuositas, et eminentia ossi fracto, aut nodatio: et foedatur per illud forma membri, uerumtamen membrum non prohibetur ab operatione sua naturali: tunc non oportet ut recipias sermonem eius, qui existimat, ut frangatur membrum denuo.	When it happens that a member already restored after its cure is bent and protrudes with the broken bone, or swells: and becomes disfigured in that form of the member, but the member is not prevented from performing its natural function: then you should not believe his words who thinks that the member must be broken anew.
Et iam fuerunt multi stolidorum medicorum et restauratorum, qui fecerunt illud in terra nostra.	And already there have been many foolish doctors and restorers who did it in our land.
Et haec quidem operatio est uituperabilis ualde, perducens ad mortem, uel timorem magnum, ut scilicet sit mortalis.	And indeed this operation is very reprehensible, leading to death or a great fear, so that it may be mortal.
Verum si claudicatio et nodatio sunt recentes: tunc oportet, ut embrocetur cum aqua tepida, in qua decoctae sint herbae mollificantes, sicut folia alteae, et radix eius, et mellilotum, et illis similia.	But if the stiffness and knotting are recent: then it is necessary that they be fomented with warm water, in which have been decocted softening herbs, such as the leaves and root of hawthorn, and meliloth, and similar things.
Et fiat ei emplastrum cum emplastro mollificatiuo, sicut dyachilon decenter factum.	And make a poultice for him with a softening plaster, such as well-made diachylon.
Aut sumatur mucilago radicis alteae, et concutiatur cum adipe gallinae, aut oleo sisamino: et emplastretur cum eo.	A poultice of the juice or sap of the elder tree root should be taken and pounded with chicken fat or sesame oil, and applied thereto.
Aut sumantur ficus pingues, et terantur cum fimo columbino, et similibus eis quae nominantur ex medicinis diminuentes consolidationem.	Figs should also be taken and rubbed with pigeon dung, and similar things which are called from medicines diminishing consolidation.
Et quandoque soluitur nodatio cum fricatione assidua, antiqua, et leni, quae fit cum manibus humidis.	And sometimes the knot is loosened by frequent, old, and gentle friction made with moist hands.
Et administretur motus membri ad omnem partem in horis omnibus.	And motion should be given to the limb in every direction at all hours.
Si autem tortuositas iam antecessit, et fortis facta est, et conuersa est in lapidem, et prouocata est necessitas ad curatonem eius cum ferro: tunc oportet, ut secetur superius eius, et soluatur continuatio ossis, et incidatur quod superfluit ex nodatione aut osse cum Incisoriis subtilibus: et administretur facilitas in illo cum sollicitudine et studio.	But if the curvature has already proceeded and is strong, and has turned into a stone, and necessity for its cure with iron has been provoked: then it is necessary that what lies above it be sawed off, and the continuity of the bone be loosened, and what superfluously remains from the knot or bone be cut out with delicate scalpels; and ease be given to it with solicitude and effort.
¶ De sermone in Dislocatione.	About the treatment in dislocations.
Caput XXIIII.	Chapter 23.
Dislocatio est exitus alicuius iuncturarum a loco suo.	A dislocation is the removal of some joint from its place.
Quare prohibetur a motu suo, et foedatur figura membri.	Wherefore it is forbidden from its motion and the figure of the member is spoiled.
Et facit accidere super infirmum dolores, et laesiones uehementes.	And it causes great pains and severe injuries to the sick person.
Quando ergo accidit alicui dislocatio, tunc oportet festinare ad restaurationem eius: neque tardet eam omnino.	Therefore when a dislocation occurs in someone, it is necessary to hasten to restore it, nor should delay be made at all.
Nam si tardatur, apostematur locus, et fortasse cum eo reductio dislocationis.	For if it is delayed, the place becomes inflamed and perhaps the reduction of the dislocation as well.
Propter illud ergo non oportet, ut moueatur, neque extendatur in hora apostemationis eius.	On account of this therefore it is not necessary to move or stretch it in the hour of its inflammation.
Quoniam multotiens facit accidere spasmum, et dolores laedentes.	For very often it causes spasms and hurting pains.
Verum quando accidit illud, tunc oportet, ut properes ad phlebotomiam infirmi.	But when that happens, then it is necessary to hasten to bleed the sick person.
Deinde dimittatur, donec quiescat apostema.	Then let him be left until the inflammation subsides.
Deinde embrocetur membrum cum aqua calida et oleo.	Then anoint the limb with warm water and oil.
Deinde reducatur cum facilitate.	Then it should be returned with ease.
Et curetur omne membrum cum eo cuius rememoratio ueniet in loco suo.	And every member should be dressed back with him whose recollection comes to its place.
Ego quidem iam ordinaui capitula dislocationis, etiam secundum quod praecessit in fractura, a superiori parte corporis usque ad inferiorem eius.	I have indeed arranged the chapters on dislocations, even according to what preceded in fractures, from the upper part of the body down to its lower part.
¶ De cura dislocationis Mandibulae inferioris.	On the care for the dislocation of the lower jawbone.
Caput XXV.	Chapter 25.
Parum dislocantur duae Mandibulae nisi raro.	The two jawbones are rarely dislocated unless very slightly.
Et dislocatio ambarum fit secundum unum duoru modorum.	And the dislocation of both occurs in either of two ways.
Aut enim remouentur a locis suis remotione parua, et mollificantur parumper.	For they are either removed from their places with slight removal and become slightly relaxed.
Aut dislocantur dislocatione integra, completa, donec mollificentur ad partem pectoris, donec currat saliua infirmi, et non possit tenere eam, neque possit claudere os suum, et inuoluatur lingua eius cum sermone.	Or they are dislocated with complete, full dislocation until they become relaxed up to the chest, until the patient's saliva runs and he cannot hold it, nor can he close his mouth, and his tongue is rolled back around his speech.
Quando autem dislocatio eius est parua, tunc redit in pluribus dispositionibus per se cum paucitate.	When however its dislocation is slight, then it returns in many positions by itself with ease.
Si uero est dislocatio completa, integra: tunc oportet, ut administretur reductio eius uelociter, et non tardetur penitus: et est, ut teneat minister caput infirmi: et intromittat medicus pollicem manus suae unius in radicem Mandibulae dislocationis inter os eius, si dislocatio est a parte una.	If however the dislocation is complete, then it must be reduced quickly and not delayed at all. And it is necessary for the minister to hold the head of the patient and for the physician to insert his thumb of one hand into the root of the jawbone's dislocation between his teeth, if the dislocation is on one side.
Aut intromittat duos pollices suos simul, si dislocatio est a duabus partibus.	Or he should insert both of his thumbs at once if the dislocation is from two sides.
Et reliqui digiti manuum eius sint extra, quibus aequet.	And the rest of his fingers should be outside to apply pressure.
Et praecipe infirmo, ut mundificet Mandibulas suas, et absoluat eas ad manducandum ad omnem partem.	And command the patient to clean his jawbones and clear them for eating on every side.
Et medicus aequet Mandibulam, et impellat Mandibulam, donec redeat ad locum suum.	And the physician should apply pressure to the jawbone and push it until it returns to its place.
Quod si difficilis sit reductio eius, praecipue si sunt ambae Mandibulae simul: tunc administra uaporationem cum aqua calida, et oleo, donec fiat facilis reductio ambarum: neque tardes reductionem ambarum omnino, sicut diximus.	And if the reduction of it is difficult, especially if both jawbones are together then administer a poultice with warm water and oil until the reduction of both becomes easy: nor delay the reduction of both altogether as we said.
Cum ergo redeunt et aequantur, et clauditur os infirmi, et non mollificantur: tunc pone super eas puluillos pannorum, cum ceroto quod sit factum ex cera: et oleo rosato.	When therefore they return and congeal, and the mouth of the ailing person is closed and does not soften: then place on top of them woolen pads with wax made from wax, and rose oil.
Deinde ligetur cum facilitate cum ligamentis mollibus.	Then it will be bound with ease with soft bandages.
Et sit somnus infirmi super dorsum suum: et caput eius sit stans inter duo puluinaria, ut non moueat ipsum ad dextram et sinistram: neque conetur, uel cogatur masticare aliquid: imo ponatur cibus eius sorbitio lenis, donec quando remouentur dolores, et nodatur Mandibula: tunc comedat quod uult, et administretur illud cum facilitate.	And let the patient lie on his back and his head be placed upright between two pillows, so that he may not move it to the right or left nor try to masticate anything. Nay, let a gentle draught be given him until when the pains are removed and the jaw is loosened: then let him eat what he wills, and it will be administered with ease.
Non laboret super operationem oris sui apud comestionem et potum, et oscitationem, donec nodetur Mandibula, et sanetur.	He should not struggle at the operation of his mouth during eating and drinking and gaping until the jaw is loosened and healed.
Quod si difficilis fiat reductio duarum Mandibuiarum, quando dislocantur in hora aliqua, et non conuertuntur ad loca sua: tunc multotiens accidunt inde febres, et soda assidua: et fortasse soluitur uenter infirmi, et fortasse uomit choleram puram.	But if the reduction of the two jaws is difficult when they are dislocated at some time and do not return to their place: then many times fevers and constant sweating occur, and perhaps the patient's belly will be dissolved, and perhaps he will vomit pure bile.
Cum ergo uides illud: tunc scias, quia est perditio, et multotiens moritur ille cui accidit illud in decem diebus.	When therefore you see that, then know that it is a disaster, and he often dies to whom that occurs within ten days.
¶ De reducione dislocationis Furculae, et extremitatis humeri.	On the reduction of the dislocation of the collarbone and the extremity of the shoulder.
Caput XXVI.	Chapter 26
Furcula quidem non dislocatur ex latere intrinseco, propter continuationem suam cum pectore.	The collarbone indeed is not dislocated from the inner side because of its continuity with the chest.
Et dislocatur quandoque ad exteriora: et declaratur illud sensui.	And it becomes dislocated sometimes to the outside and this is made known by sense.
Et restauratio eius est, ut iaceat infirmus super dorsum suum, et extendat brachia sua.	And its restoration is that the patient lie on his back and stretch out his arms.
Deinde coarta locum cum palma tua coartatione forti, nam ipsa redibit.	Then bind the place with your palm a strong constriction, for it will return.
Deinde pone super ipsam emplastrum, et puluillos, et stringe eam.	Then put on top of it a plaster and woolen pads, and tie it.
Extremitates uero eius quae sequuntur cubitum, et continuantur cum eo, non dislocantur, nisi raro.	But his extremities which follow the elbow and are connected with it, do not become dislocated unless rarely.
Quod s dislocatur die aliquo: tunc oportet, ut reducatur et aequetur secundum quod diximus, et quod praeparatur tibi.	When a joint is dislocated on some day: then it must be reduced and adjusted according to what we said, and what is prepared for you.
Deinde pone super ipsam emplastrum, et puluillos, et stricturam.	Then place over it a poultice, and a stricture.
Et praecipe infirmo, adhaerere tranquillitati et quieti, donec sanetur.	And command the patient to adhere to quietness and rest until they are healed.
Et cum hac eadem curatione reducitur extremitas Humeri, quando separatur etiam a loco suo.	And when this same cure is applied, the arm is reduced when it becomes separated from its place also.
¶ De reductione dislocationis Humeri.	Concerning the reduction of a dislocated shoulder.
Caput XXVII.	Chapter XXVII.
Scias, quod Humerus non dislocatur, nisi secundum tres modos.	Know that the shoulder does not dislocate except in three ways.
Quorum unus est, ut dislocetur ad partem titillici ad inferiora.	One of which is, that it dislocates to the upper part towards the lower.
Secundus est, ut dislocetur ad partem pectoris.	The second is, that it dislocates to the breast side.
Et fortasse dislocatur ad superiorem partem Humeri: et illud fit raro.	And perhaps it dislocates to the upper part of the shoulder, and that happens rarely.
Et non dislocatur ad posteriora, propter spatulam.	And it does not dislocate towards the back because of the blade.
Et non dislocatur ad anteriora, propter neruos.	And it does not dislocate towards the front because of the nerves.
Et plurimum quidem dislocatur et egreditur ad inferiora uersus titillicum: praecipue in illis, quorum carnes sunt paucae.	And indeed it dislocates and comes out towards the lower side towards the armpit: especially in those whose flesh is scarce.
Quoniam egrediur in eis uelociter, et ingreditur uelociter.	For it comes out quickly in them and returns quickly.
In illis autem quorum carnes sunt multae, est econtrario illius, scilicet quia egreditur cum difficultate, et ingreditur cum difficultate.	But in those whose flesh is abundant, it happens contrary to that, namely because it comes out with difficulty and returns with difficulty.
Et fortasse accidit quibusdam hominibus percussio, aut casus, et apostematur Humerus apostemate calido, et putatur propter illud, quia iam dislocatus est.	And perhaps it happens to some people by a blow or a fall, and the shoulder is inflamed with a warm inflammation, and it is thought because of that, that it has already become dislocated.
Oportet ergo, ut experiaris illud, donec stes super certitudinem eius, et tunc procedas in curatione eius.	Therefore you must experience that, until you are sure of it, and then proceed to its cure.
Et cognoscitur dislocatio, quando est ad inferiora uersus titillicum: et distinguas inter Humerum dislocatum, et humerum sanum.	And a dislocation is recognized when it is towards the lower side towards the armpit: and distinguish between a dislocated shoulder and a healthy one.
Nam tu inuenis inter eos diuersitatem manifestam, et inuenis in capite Humeri concauitatem, et sub titillico apud tactum caput humeri quasi ipsum sit ouum: et non potest infirmus reducere manum ad aurem suam, neque mouere eam omnibus motibus.	For you will find among them a manifest difference, and you will find in the head of the arm a concavity, and under the little bony point near the touch of the head of the arm as if it were an egg: and the infirm person cannot reduce his hand to his ear, nor move it with all movements.
Et similiter, si dislocatur uersus pectus, aut ad sursum: tunc inuenis manifestum tactum, neque occultatur.	And similarly, if it is dislocated towards the chest, or upwards: then you will find a manifest touch, nor is it hidden.
Et huius quidem dislocationis fit facilis reductio, quando est recens, aut infirmus est puer.	And indeed an easy reduction of this dislocation occurs when it is recent, or the child is weak.
Et reductio eius est, ut eleuet minister manum suam ad superiora.	And its reduction is, that the assistant lifts his hand up to the upper part.
Deinde pone tu pollices tuos sub titillico eius, et eleua iuncturam cum fortitudine ad sursum ad locum suum: et minister eleuet manum suam, et extendat eam ad sursum.	Then place your thumbs under the bony point of it, and lift the joint with force up to its place: and the assistant lifts his hand and extends it upwards.
Deinde ponat eam inferius, ipse enim redit uelociter.	Then set it back down, for indeed it will quickly return itself.
Si autem non redit per illud quod diximus, et sunt a principio quo accidit dislocatio dies multi: tunc oportet, ut balneetur infirmus in aqua calida, et administretur embrocatio quae mollificat et lenit, sicut si decoquantur radices alteae, et foenugraecum, et mellilotum in aqua, et administretur.	But if it does not return through what we said, and there have been many days since the dislocation occurred: then it is necessary that the infirm person be bathed in hot water, and an embrocation be administered which softens and soothes, as if roots of celery, and fenugreek, and melilot were to be boiled in water, and it should be given.
Deinde resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum: et ponatur sub titillico eius sphera et lana, quae sit aequalis inter lenitatem et stricturam.	Then the infirm person is placed on his back: and a ball of wool or flax is placed under the bony point of him which is equal between softness and tightness.
Deinde ponat medicus calcaneum suum super spheram, et eleuet caput humeri cum uirtute, et attrahat manum infirmi ad inferiora.	Then the doctor places his heel on the ball, and lifts the head of the arm with force, and draws the hand of the infirm person downwards.
Et minister alius teneat caput infirmi, ut non moueatur ad inferiora: ipse namque redit statim.	And another assistant should hold the head of the infirm person, so that it is not moved down: for indeed it will return immediately.
Et si uis, reduc eum secundum modum hunc: et est, ut facias esse praesentem uirum qui sit longior infirmo, et stet a parte lateris, et intromittat humerum suum sub titillico infirmi: et eleuet titillicum eius ad superiora, donec sit infirmus suspensus in aere.	And if you wish, reduce him according to this method: and it is, that you make the man who is taller than the infirm person be present, and stand at his side, and insert his arm under the bony point of the infirm one: and lift the bony point of him upwards, until the infirm one is suspended in the air.
Et minister alius trahat manum infirmi ad inferiora uentris eius.	And another attendant should draw the patient's hand down towards his lower intestines.
Si autem infirmus est leuis: tunc oportet, ut suspendatur cum eo aliquid aliud, ut grauet ipsum: nam redit dislocatio statim.	But if the patient is light, then it is necessary that something else be hung with him to weigh him down, for the dislocation returns immediately.
Et reducitur etiam secundum modum alium: et est, ut figatur in terra lignum longum, cuius caput sit rotundum figura: sicut manica mortarii: quod non sit grossum, neque subtile.	And it is also reduced according to another method, which is that a long wooden beam be placed on the ground, with its top being rounded in shape, like a mortar cover, and not too thick nor too thin.
Deinde ponatur sub infirmo postquam ponuntur super caput ligni panni lenes: et infirmus sit stans secundum longitudinem ligni.	Then cloths are placed under the patient after cloth have been put on top of the wooden beam, and the patient stands upright according to the length of the beam.
Deinde extendatur manus eius ad inferiora a parte altera, et extendatur corpus eius ab altera parte cum fortitudine: nam iunctura redit ad locum suum cum uelocitate.	Then his hand is extended downwards from the opposite side, and his body is extended with force on the other side, for the joint returns to its place quickly.
Quod si difficilis sit eius reductio per omnia quae diximus, tunc utere hac cura: et est, ut accipias lignum cuius longitudo sit quantitas duorum brachiorum, et eius latitudo quantitas quatuor digitorum, et grossitudo eius quantitas duorum digitorum: cui sit caput rotundum, ut alleuietur introitus eius in profundum titillici, secundum hanc formam.	But if its reduction is difficult through all that we have said, then use this cure: which is to take a piece of wood whose length is two arm-lengths, and width four fingers, and thickness two fingers; and whose top is rounded, so that it may facilitate its entrance into the deep crevice, in this shape.
Deinde ligentur super caput rotundum panni lenes, ut non laedat lignum infirmum.	Then soft cloths are tied on top of the rounded wood so that it does not hurt the sick person.
Deinde ponatur sub titillico infirmi, ut extendatur manus, aut brachium super lignum usque ad inferiora: et ligetur lignum super adiutorium et brachium et extremitatem manus.	Then it is placed under the patient's crevice, so that his hand or arm may be extended over the wood down to the lower part; and the wood should be tied above the assistant and the arm and the extremity of the hand.
Deinde ponatur brachium super gradum scalae per latitudinem, et extendatur manus ad inferiora, et dimittatur reliquum corpus suspensum a parte altera.	Then his arm is placed over the step of the ladder in breadth, and his hand is extended downwards, and the rest of his body is left suspended on the other side.
Iunctura enim ingreditur statim.	For the joint enters immediately.
Cum ergo completur introitus eius secundum quemcunque modum possibile est: tunc oportet, ut ponas sub titillico spheram aequalis quantitatis ex lana.	When therefore its entrance is completed in whatever way it may be possible, then it is necessary to place under the crevice a ball of wool equal in size.
Deinde pone emplastrum praeparatum ex puluere molendini cum olibano, et albumine oui super humerum totum, sicut reuoluitur desuper.	Then place an ointment prepared from flour of the mill with frankincense and egg white over his shoulder all around, as it rolls off on top.
Deinde stringe sub titillico strictura decenti: et reuoluatur ligamentum super emplastrum desuper: et annectatur manus eius ad collum ipsius, et dimittatur, neque moueatur manus eius septem diebus.	Then a cord is to be bound under the navel with some decent stricture: and the ligament is to be rolled over the plaster above; and its hand is to be joined to its neck, and it is to be left, not moving its hand for seven days.
Et oportet, ut ponatur cibus infirmipaucus, donec confortetur membrum: quoniam est uelocius ad sanationem eius.	And food should be put before the sick person in small amounts until the limb is comforted; for it will be more quickly on its way to healing.
Deinde ponatur amplior post septem dies, aut quinque, et ex ercitetur cum motu.	Then a larger [one] should be put in place after seven days, or five, and it should be exercised with movement.
Si ergo firmatur et non mollificatur, tunc iam sanatus est.	Therefore if it is strengthened and not softened, then it is already healed.
Si uero iunctura dislocatur multotiens, propter humiditatem quae accidit ei, aut propter caussam aliam: tunc oportet, ut administretur in ea cauterium cum tribus foraminibus, secundum quod praemissum est in capitulo de cauterio.	If the joint is dislocated many times, either because of humidity that happens to it, or for another cause: then it is necessary, that a cautery with three holes be administered into it, according to what was mentioned earlier in the chapter on cautery.
Quod si fiat hoc totum, et soluatur ligamentum post septem dies, et non confirmetur iunctura, et reducatur emplastrum et strictura super ipsum aliquotiens, et non firmetur, et cadat, et non possit eleuare ipsum ad superiora: tunc scias, quod nerui eius qui sunt ad caput humeri, iam incisi sunt, aut extensi, aut mollificati: et scias, quod iunctura nunquam figetur in loco suo.	But if this is done entirely, and the ligament is dissolved after seven days, and the joint does not hold firm, and the plaster and stricture are applied to it many times, and still it does not hold firm and falls, and cannot lift itself up higher: then you should know that its nerves which are at the head of the humerus have already been cut, or stretched, or softened; and you should know that the joint will never be fixed in its proper place.
Dislocationis autem quae fit uersus pectus et mammillam, aut ad posteriora reductio, fit cum impulsione et extensione cum manibus: donec redeat, et administretur in ea reliqua strictura et cura, donec sanetur.	But the dislocation which occurs towards the breast and nipple, or to the backside, is reduced with a push and stretching with hands: until it returns, and there is administered into it the remaining stricture and care, until it heals.
Quod si accidat post sanationem grauitas in membro, et tarditas in motu eius, tunc utatur infirmus balneo multotiens, donec leniatur illa grauitas, et redeat ad naturam eius primam.	And if heaviness occurs in the member and slowness in its movement after healing: then the patient should make use of a bath many times, until that heaviness is alleviated and it returns to its original nature.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Cubiti.	On the cure of the dislocation of the elbow.
Caput XXVIII.	Chapter 28.
Scias, quod iunctura Cubiti dislocatur cum difficultate, et similiter redit cum difficultate etiam: et ipsa quidem dislocatur ad omnes partes, et praecipue ad anteriorem, aut ad posteriorem.	You should know that the joint of the elbow is dislocated with difficulty, and similarly it returns to its place with difficulty also; and this very joint is dislocated in all parts, and especially to the front or back.
Et eius dislocatio non occultatur tibi: quoniam est cadens sub uisu, et sub tactu, secundum quamcunque figuram dislocetur.	And its dislocation is not hidden from you: because it hangs under sight, and under touch, however it may be dislocated in shape.
Et quando coniungis cubitum dislocatum cum sano, declaratur tibi illud manifeste.	And when you join the dislocated arm with the sound one, it is made clear to you.
Concauatur enim iunctura, et non potest duplicare brachium, neque tangere cum eo humerum suum.	For the joint swells and the arm cannot be straightened nor can it touch its own shoulder.
Et oportet, ut properes, et reducas dislocationem statim, antequam accidat ei apostema calidum.	And you must hurry to reduce the dislocation at once, before a hot abscess occurs.
Nam si accidit ei apostema calidum, difficilis fit eius reductio: et fortasse non sanatur omnino, praecipue quando est ad posteriora.	For if a hot abscess occurs, its reduction becomes difficult and it will hardly ever be cured, especially when it is in the back.
Est enim deterior omnibus speciebus dislocationis, et uehementioris doloris eis: et multotiens descendit cum ea mors.	For it is worse than all kinds of dislocations and has a more severe pain, and death often accompanies it.
Et restauratio eius quando est ex eis quae possibile est reducere, est, ut extendatur manus eius cum duabus manibus: et brachium eius sit expansum, et manus medici sint supra cubitum et sub eo, et ipse impellat iuncturam cum pollicibus manuum suarum simul, aut cum radice palmae suae, donec redeat ad locum suum.	And its restoration, when it can be reduced from them, is for his hand to be stretched out with both hands, and his arm to be extended, and the doctor's hands to be above the elbow and below it, and he himself should push the joint with the tips of his fingers together, or with the root of his palm, until it returns to its place.
Aut uero dislocatio est ad anteriora: tunc redit ita, ut duplicet manum cum manu sua, donec percutiat cum radice palmae suae cubitum qui est dislocatus.	Or indeed the dislocation is in the front: then it returns so that he doubles his hand with his own hand until it strikes the elbow which is dislocated with the root of his palm.
Quod si non obedit dislocatio ad reductionem, tunc administra extensionem uehementem, fortem ualde: et est, ut extendant brachium duo ministri: et teneant ipsum duo ministri etiam, ut non remoueatur apud extensionem.	Which if the dislocation does not obey to reduction, then administer a strong and forceful stretching, so that two servants extend his arm, and also hold him, so that he may not be moved during the stretching.
Deinde reuoluatur brachium ad omnem partem postquam inuoluitur super manum eius pannus duplicatus longus, aut ligamentum latum.	Then let his arm be turned back to its original position after a doubled and long cloth or wide bandage has been wrapped over his hand.
Et quando tangit medicus manu sua iuncturam, inungat ipsam cum oleo: ut sit illud ex eis quae adiuuant in lubricitate iuncturae cum facilitate.	And when the doctor touches the joint with his hand, he should anoint it with oil so that it may be among those things which assist in the smoothness of the joint with ease.
Deinde impellat iuncturam impulsione uehementi, donec redeat.	Then let him push the joint with a strong thrust until it returns.
Et post reductionem eius oportet, ut ponatur super ipsam emplastrum, in quo sit stipticitas, et exiccatio cum albugine oui: et stringatur strictura decenti.	And after reducing it, a poultice should be placed on top of it, with astringency and drying with egg white: and it should be tightened with a suitable bandage.
Et suspendatur brachium a collo infirmi: et dimitte diebus aliquot.	And the arm is suspended from the neck of the patient: and let him rest for several days.
Deinde soluatur.	Then it should be dissolved.
Si ergo firmatur iunctura in loco suo, tunc solue ligamentum ab ea, et dimitte ipsam.	Therefore if the joint is strengthened in its place, then loosen the bandage from it and let it go.
Et si uides iuncturam non bene stringi, tunc itera emplastrum, et ligamentum, et dimitte ipsam diebus aliquot, donec stringatur.	And if you see the joint not being well tightened, then reapply the poultice and bandage, and let it be for several days until it is tightened.
Deinde solue ipsam.	Then loosen it.
Si autem accidit ei grauitas post reductionem iuncturae, et dispositio sit in motu: tunc administra humectationem in balneatione, et fricationem subtilem, et compressionem, donec liniatur, aut pone super iuncturam iliati, id est, natem arietis pinguem.	But if heaviness occurs to him after the reduction of the joint and it is disposed in motion: then give an ointment for bathing, and subtle friction, and compression, until it becomes smooth, or place over the inflamed joint the fat of a ram's tail.
Deinde ligetur, et dimitte ipsam super eam die et nocte.	Then it should be bandaged, and let it be on her day and night.
Deinde aufer eam, et intromitte ipsum in balneum.	Then remove it, and introduce him into a bath.
Cum ergo sudat, tunc frica iuncturam fricatione temperata.	When therefore he sweats, then rub the joint with tempered friction.
Deinde itera super ipsam aleliati uice una, et secunda, et tertia cum introitu balnei, donec leniatur.	Then reapply over it a plaster like once, and twice, and third time with the entrance of the bath, until it becomes smooth.
Et si uis, pone super ipsam stercus uaccinum, humidum, calefactum cum butyro, et stringe super ipsum.	And if you wish, place over it cow dung, moist, warmed with butter, and bind tightly on it.
Fac illud aliquotiens.	Do that several times.
Ipsa namque lenitur, et redit ad dispositionem suam.	For indeed it becomes smooth, and returns to its proper condition.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Almahassem.	Chapter on the cure of a dislocation by Almahassem.
Caput XXIX.	Chapter 29.
Mahassem manus multotiens dislocatur, id est, iunctura quae est inter brachium et manum.	The hand of Mahassem is frequently dislocated, that is, the joint which is between the arm and the hand.
Et reductio dislocationis eius est facilis.	And the reduction of his dislocation is easy.
Econtrario reliquarum iuncturarum.	On the contrary, to other joints.
Verumtamen oportet, ut uelocitas sit in reductione dislocationis eius in hora in qua dislocatur, antequam apostemetur locus: aut accidat in eo apostema calidum.	However it is necessary, that there be swiftness in the reduction of its dislocation within an hour when it dislocates, before the place becomes inflamed; or a warm swelling occur in it.
Et reductio dislocationis in eo est, ut ponas Mahassem manus infirmae super tabulam, et extendat minister manum eius: et ponat medicus palmam suam super eminentiam iuncturae, et impellat eam, donec redeat.	And the reduction of its dislocation is, that you place the arm of the infirm on a table, and the attendant stretch out his hand to hold it; and the physician put his palm over the prominence of the joint, and push it until it returns.
Verumtamen oportet, ut consyderetur, si palma iam recessit ad uentrem manus: tunc ponat infirmus dorsum manus suae super tabulam apud extensionem et reductionem: et si dislocatio est procedens ad dorsum manus, tunc sit positio manus eius intrinsece super tabulam, id est, interior pars manus eius super tabulam ponatur, ut cadat manus medici super ipsam eminentiam iuncturae.	However it is necessary to consider if the palm has already receded towards the belly of the hand; then let the infirm person place the back of his hand on the table by extension and reduction: and if the dislocation is proceeding towards the back of the hand, then the position of his hand should be internally on the table, that is, the inner part of his hand should be placed on the table so that the hand of the physician falls upon that very prominence of the joint.
Si ergo redit statim, bonum est: et si non, tunc stringe eam cum emplastro sedante apostema: et dimitte ipsum, neque iteres illud.	So if it returns immediately, that is well; and if not, then bind it with a plaster to soothe the swelling: and let him go, nor do you repeat it.
Nam si non tolerat, neque potes super reductionem eius, postquam praetereunt ei dies, uerumtamen iunctura remanet secundum tortuositatem suam: et non nocet infirmo aliquid, nisi quod mollificatur manus, et non potest stringere aliquid: tunc scias, quod nerui sunt abscissi, aut attriti.	For if it does not tolerate, nor can you effect a reduction after the passing of days, however the joint remains according to its own tortuosity: and no harm comes to the infirm person, except that his hand is softened, and he cannot bind anything: then know that the nerves are severed or bruised.
Non est ergo ingenium in ea, nisi ut stringatur cum cauterio prope casum eius.	It is not therefore a condition in it, except to be bound with a cautery near its case.
Et fortasse non confert illud aliquid.	And perhaps that does nothing good.
Cum ergo non redit Almahassem, tunc pone super ipsum emplastrum, quod narrauimus.	So when Almahasseem does not return, then place over him a plaster as we have narrated.
Deinde stringatur, et dimittatur quinque diebus: postea soluatur et dimittatur, et exercitetur manus.	Then let it be bound and let go for five days: afterwards it shall be loosened and let go, and the hand exercised.
Si autem priuatur motus eius, et accidat in ea aliquid grauitatis: tunc leni eam cum aqua calefacta, et fricatione aliquotiens, donec leniatur.	But if it be deprived of its motion and something serious occurs in it: then temper it with warm water and sometimes friction until it is tempered.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Digitorum.	On the treatment of the dislocation of fingers.
Caput XXX.	Chapter 30.
Quando dislocatur ex eis Digitus ad omnem partem, uel ex eis Digitus ad dorsum palmae, aut uentrem eius: tunc extende Digitum, et impelle dislocationem pollicibus tuis, donec redeat.	When a finger is dislocated in any direction, or towards the back of its palm or belly: then stretch out the finger and push the dislocation with your thumbs until it returns.
Deinde sustenta caput Digiti, et suspende ipsum uersus partem ad quam dislocatur, et dimitte ipsum duobus diebus.	Then support the head of the finger and hang it towards the side to which it is dislocated, and let it go for two days.
Deinde suspende eum, et extende ipsum, donec aequetur rectus in illo die suo.	Then hang him up and stretch him until it is straight on that day itself.
Cum ergo fuerit nox, liga ipsum secundum narrationem ipsam: et non cesses soluere ipsum in die: et exerce eum cum motu: et liga ipsum in nocte.	When therefore night comes, bind it according to its own narrative, and cease not to release it by day, and exercise it with motion, and bind it at night.
Fac illud diebus aliquot, donec stringatur.	Do that for a few days until it is tightened.
Et similiter fac cum eo, si dislocatur ad uentrem manus: et liga eum ad partem ipsam, et fac cum eo operationem tuam primam, donec sanetur.	And do the same with him if he is dislocated to the belly of the hand: and bind him to that side, and perform your first operation with him until it heals.
Et similiter fac cum eo quando dislocatur ad reliquas partes.	And do the same with him when he is dislocated in other parts.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Spondilium dorsi.	On the treatment of the dislocation of the back vertebra.
Caput XXXI.	Chapter 31.
Quando accidit alicui Spondilium dorsi, aut colli dislocatio completa, aut remouentur Spondiles multae a locis suis: tunc non est in ea curatio, quoniam mors properat infirmo.	When any of the vertebrae of the back or neck are completely dislocated, or many of them are removed from their places: then there is no cure for it, because death approaches the sick person.
Et signum illius est, quod egestio infirmi egreditur absque uoluntate, neque potest tenere eam: et multotiens mollificantur ex eo quaedam membra eius, aut duo crura eius, aut duo brachia ipsius, aut unum eorum: aut remouetur Spondilis una de loco suo.	And the sign of it is that the sick person's body issues pus without his will, nor can he hold it back: and many times some of his limbs become soft on him, or both his legs, or both his arms, or one of them: or a vertebra is removed from its place.
Multotiens enim remouetur, quod multotiens fit remotio earum ad quatuor partes.	For often it happens that they are removed, which often takes place in four parts.
Illa ergo quae remouetur ad posteriora, nominatur Gibbositas.	Therefore what is removed to the back is called Humpbackness.
Curatio uero eius est, ut consyderes tunc, si Gibbositas accidit a puericia: tunc non est in ea curatio, neque ex ea est sanatio omnino.	Its cure however is, as you should consider then, if humpbackness happens from childhood: then there is no cure for it, nor is there any healing from it.
In illa autem quae accidit a casu, aut percussione, aut similibus illis, iam dixerunt antiqui modos curationis sermone prolixo.	In those things however which occur by chance or stroke or similar ones, the ancients have already spoken in length about methods of treatment.
Cuius plurimum non redit cum proficuo.	Of which a great many do not yield with a good outcome.
Ego uero iam abbreuiaui ex illo, cuius parum excusat a multo eius ex propinquitate mea ad intentionem: et expositione mea qua exposui illud, et formaui instrumentum eius diuerso modo ab eo quo ostenderunt illud, et exposuerunt ipsum.	Indeed I have now shortened from it because of the little that justifies against its much by my proximity to intention and through my explanation with which I explained it and formed its instrument in a different way than they showed it and presented it.
Dico ergo, quod in gibbositate quae accidit ab anteriori parte, non est ingenium, neque sanatio ex ea.	Therefore, I say that in the swelling which occurs from the front part, there is no cure and no healing from it.
Et similiter in illa quae fit ad duo latera etiam.	And similarly in that which occurs to both sides as well.
Et non curatur ex eis, nisi illa quae accidit in dorso proprie, cum eo quod ego narro: et est, ut extendatur infirmus super faciem suam super podium aequale prope parietem: et expandatur sub eo stramentum humidum, ut non laedatur pectus eius.	And they do not get cured from them, unless that which occurs on the back properly, with this that I say and it is, so that the weak one stretches over his face over a flat surface near the wall: and a wet cloth is spread under him, so that his chest may not be hurt.
Deinde ponatur lignum rectum fixum in fouea in terra, in extremitate podii, circiter caput eius: et lignum aliud circiter pedes eius in extremitate altera podii: et minister teneat lignum, et sit non firmatum in fouea.	Then a straight and fixed piece of wood is put in a hole on the ground at the end of the platform, near his head: and another piece of wood near his feet at the other end of the platform: and the servant holds the stick and it is not fixed in the hole.
Et minister alter teneat alterum.	And another servant hold the other one.
Deinde inuolue super caput infirmi, et sub titillicis eius ligamentum lene, firmum: et extende extremitatem ligamenti ad lignum quod est apud caput eius: et liga ipsum in eo.	Then wrap over the head of the sick one and under his cheek a strong soft bandage: and stretch out the end of the bandage to the wood that is by his head: and bind it to it.
Deinde stringe ligamentum aliud supra anchas eius, et supra genua ipsius, et apud cauillas eius.	Then tie another bandage above his armpits and over his knees, and at the crooks of his elbows.
Deinde aggrega ligamenta omnia, et liga ea in ligno altero quod est apud pedes eius.	Then gather all the bandages together and bind them to the other wood that is by his feet.
Deinde extendat omnis minister ad partem ligni ligamentum, et non remoueantur duo ligna ex locis suis in quibus sunt fixa: uerumtamen non sint firmata, sicut diximus.	Then all the servants stretch out to the part of the wood with the bandage and they should not be removed from their places where they are fixed: but however they should not be fastened, as we said.
Et medicus ponat palmas suas super Spondilem cum fortitudine, donec redeat: aut ponat super eam tabulam.	And the physician should place his palms strongly upon the splint until it returns (to its normal shape): or place a board on top of it.
Deinde annectat super tabulam pedes suos, donec redeat.	Then he attaches his feet to the board until it returns.
Si autem non redit per hanc curationem, tunc accipe tabulam cuius longitudo sit circiter tria brachia.	But if it does not return with this treatment, then take a board whose length is about three arms.
Et caua in pariete de quo diximus quod est prope infirmum, locum in quem ingrediatur extremitas tabulae.	And an opening in the wall which we said is near the sick person, a place into which the end of the board enters.
Deinde pone medium tabulae super Spondilem.	Then place the middle of the board on the splint.
Et ponat pedes suos medicus super extremitatem alteram.	And the physician should place his feet on the other end.
Et stringat bene, donec coartetur Spondilis, et redeat ad locum suum.	And he should bind it well until the splint is constricted and returns to its place.
Deinde si uis, operare cum torno quod inuoluitur cum manu tua: et est, ut figas in terram apud caput infirmi in postremo podii duo ligna, quorum longitudo sit brachii unius: et apud caput eius in postremo podii duo ligna.	Then if you wish to do it with a lathe that is wrapped around your hand: and indeed, you fix into the ground near the head of the sick person at the last step two pieces of wood, whose length is one arm, and under his head in the last step two pieces of wood.
Et sit longitudo quae est inter omne lignum palmus unus: et iam factum est in omni loco foramen, in quo currit tornum: et firmetur lignum omne in terra multum, ne moueatur omnino.	And let the length between all the wood be one palm: and thus it is made at every place a hole through which the lathe runs: and let every piece of wood be firmly fixed to the earth very much, so that it may not move at all.
Et intromittatur lignum rotundum: et est tornum in quo reuoluitur ligamentum in duobus foraminibus duorum lignorum.	And a round piece of wood is inserted: and the lathe is in which the tendon is turned around, in two holes of two pieces of wood.
Et in extremitate eius est foramen, in quo firmatur lignum, cuius longitudo est palmus cum eo quod reuoluitur: et in duobus lignis aliis est similiter illius.	And at its end is a hole in which the wood is fixed, whose length is with that which turns together: and similarly in two other pieces of wood.
Deinde stringe ligamenta quae strinxisti in pectore infirmi torno quod est apud caput eius: et ligamenta quae strinxisti in cruribus eius in torno quod est apud pedes eius.	Then bind the bandages which you bound on the chest of the sick person with the lathe that is at his head: and the bandages which you bound on his legs with the lathe that is at his feet.
Deinde stet apud omne tornum minister, qui torqueat manum suam cum licinio, cum quo reuoluitur tornum: et medicus aequet Spondilem, secundum quod diximus.	Then stand beside every lathe the servant who turns his hand with an iron stick, with which the lathe is turned: and the physician should shape the splint, as we have said.
Haec est forma torni, quae sequitur.	This is the form of a saw which follows.
Deinde postquam redit Spondilis, et aequatur locus, tunc oportet, ut ponas emplastrum exiccatiuum cum albumine oui.	Then after Spondilus has healed and the place has been made level, you must put on a drying plaster with egg white.
Deinde stuppam.	Then dress it.
Postea pone supra emplastrum astellam ex tabula, cuius latitudo sit trium digitorum, aut circiter eos.	Then place above the plaster a splint of wood whose width is three fingers, or about that.
Et longitudo eius quantitas quae capiat locum Gibbositatis, et super partem Spondilis sanae.	And its length shall be as much as covers the gibbous place and above the healthy part of Spondilus.
Deinde ligetur cum ligamento quod diximus.	Then it will be bound with the bandage which we mentioned.
Et utatur infirmus nutrimento subtili, donec sanetur.	And the patient should be nourished with gentle food until he is healed.
Quod si remaneat quiddam eminentiae in loco in fine sanationis: tunc oportet, ut administrentur medicinae quae mollificant, et leniunt, cum administratione tabulae quam narrauimus tempore longo.	But if something remains elevated in the place at the end of healing, then it is necessary to administer medicines that soften and calm, with the application of the board which we mentioned over a long time.
Et iam administratur in illo lamina plumbi.	And now lead is applied to it.
Et quandoque accidit eminentia in postremo Spondilium dorsi: et putatur per eam dislocatio, et est illud os quod iam eminet.	And sometimes a prominence occurs in the last vertebra of the back and it is thought to be a dislocation, and that bone which now protrudes.
Quare non oportet, ut praesumptio fiat ei cum hac medicina: fortasse enim accidere faciet mortem.	Therefore it should not be presumed on with this medicine, lest perhaps death will result.
¶ De curatione Anchae dislocatae.	About the cure of a dislocated Ancah.
Caput XXXII.	Chapter 32.
Scias, quod iuncturae Anchae, et iuncturae humeri, non accidit, nisi dislocatio tantum: neque accidit eis quod accidit reliquis iuncturis ex remotione parua, et concauitate.	Know that the dislocation of Ancah and the dislocation of the shoulder joint does not occur except for a dislocation alone; nor do they suffer what other joints suffer from a small displacement and hollowing.
Et iunctura quidem Anchae dislocatur secundum quatuor partes.	And indeed the Ancah joint is dislocated in four parts.
Quod est, quia dislocatur ad anteriora, et ad posteriora.	Which is because it dislocates both forward and backward.
Et plurimum quidem dislocatur ad interiora: et parum dislocatur ad anteriora, et ad posteriora.	And indeed it dislocates most of all to the inside, and little to the front and back.
Et curatio dislocationis eius ad interiora, est: quia quando tu coniungis crus infirmi sanum cum infirmo, est longius: et est genu eius eminens plus quam sani, et non potest infirmus duplicare pedem suum apud inguen: et est locus qui sequitur inguen apostematus apostemate calido, propterea, quod caput coxae iam peruenit illic.	And the cure of its dislocation to the inside is this: because when you join the sick leg of the infirm with a healthy one, it is longer; and his knee is more prominent than that of the healthy one, and he cannot bend down his foot at the groin: and the place which follows the groin is inflamed, on account of the head of the hip having reached there.
Et signum eius cui accidit dislocatio ad exteriora est, quod sunt accidentia eius contraria istis accidentibus.	And the sign of that in whom a dislocation occurs outward is, that are his accidents contrary to those accidents.
Et signum eius cui accidit dislocatio ad anteriora, est, quia expandit crus sanum secundum complementum: uerumtamen non duplicat ipsum absque dolore qui est in genu: et si conatur ad ambulandum, non potest super illud ad anteriora: et retinetur urina eius, et apostematur inguen eius, et apud ambulationem est calcatio eius super calcaneum.	And the sign of that in whom a dislocation occurs forward is, because he straightens out the healthy leg according to its measure: yet he does not double it without pain that is in the knee; and if he attempts to walk, he cannot put his foot forward over it; and his urine is retained, and his thigh becomes inflamed, and at walking is a bruise on his heel.
Et signum eius cui accidit dislocatio ad posteriora est, ut non expandat genu, neque possit duplicare ipsum antequam duplicet inguen: et est crus eius etiam breuius altero: et inguen est mollificatum, et est caput coxae apud locum ilii.	And the sign of that in whom a dislocation occurs backward is, that he does not straighten out his knee, nor can double it until he doubles his thigh; and his leg is also shorter on one side: and his thigh is softened, and there is a prominence at the head of the hipbone.
Reductio uero huius dislocationis specierum est, ut consyderes tunc, si dislocatio est uetusta, quae iam antiquatur cum habente ipsam.	The reduction, however, of this kind of dislocation is to consider then, if the dislocation is old, which already becomes stale with having it.
Deinde si tu administres reductionem eius, et remanet secundum dispositionem suam: tunc non est in ea curatio omnino.	Then if you administer a reduction to him and he remains according to his condition: then there is no treatment at all for it.
Non ergo oportet, ut praesumptio fiat ei penitus.	Therefore it should not be supposed that it is completely incurable.
In illo autem cuius dislocatio est recens, et est ex una specierum quatuor dislocationis: tunc propera ad hoc, ut uoluas iuncturam, et extendas ipsam ad interiora et ad exteriora, et moueas eam dextra et sinistra: fortasse enim redit, et non indiget alia cura.	But in him whose dislocation is recent, and is of one of the four kinds of dislocations, then hasten to this, that you turn the joint and extend it inward and outward, and move it right and left: perhaps it will return, and he will not need any other treatment.
Si autem non redit hoc modo, tunc oportet, ut praepares ministrum fortem, et extendat crus eius ab inferiori parte: aut cum manibus suis, aut cum ligamento, quod ligetur super crus eius supra genu: et minister alius extendat manum eius desuper, ita ut intromittat manus suas sub titillicis eius.	But if it does not return in this way, then it is necessary that a strong instrument be prepared, and the leg be extended from below; or with his own hands, or with a bandage, which is to be tied over his leg above the knee: and another assistant extend his hand from above, so that he may insert his hands under the prominences of his thigh.
Deinde stringat cum ligamento leni super radicem coxae, et teneat extremitatem ligamenti alterius.	Then let him bind it with a soft bandage over the head of the hipbone, and hold the other end of the bandage.
Et sit extensio eius aut ab anteriori parte inguinis ad partem furculae, aut a posteriori ad partem dorsi.	And let its extension be either from the front of the groin to the furca [or] from the back to the back of the torso.
Et sit extensio eorum omnium uice una, donec eleuetur infirmus cum corpore suo a terra, et remaneat pendens.	And let the extension of all be vice versa one, until the sick person is lifted with his body from the earth, and remains hanging.
Et haec enim species extensionis est species communis specierum quatuor.	For this kind of extension is a common form of the four kinds of forms.
Si ergo redit dislocatio cum eo quod diximus, est bonum: et si non, tunc necesse est omni speciei illud quod dicam de curatione propria.	Therefore if the dislocation returns with him to what I said, it is good; and if not, then it is necessary for all species of that which I will say about proper cure.
In reductione quidem eius propria quando dislocatio est ad interiora, oportet, ut resupinetur infirmus super latus suum sanum.	Indeed in its own reduction when the dislocation is to the innards, it is necessary that the sick person be placed supine over his healthy side.
Deinde ponat ligamentum super radicem coxae, in eo quod est inter caput coxae, et locum qui est sub inguine.	Then he should place a bandage on top of the femur's root, in that which is between the head of the hip and the place that is under the groin.
Deinde extende ligamentum ad sursum a parte inguinis ad altiorem partem corporis, ad partem furculae.	Then extend the bandage upward from the front of the groin to the higher part of the body, to the part of the furca.
Deinde accipiat minister alius fortis brachia eius, et minuat locum grossum coxae infirmae, et extendat ad exteriora extensione uehementi.	Then let another strong assistant take hold of his arms and reduce the swollen place of the sick hip, and extend it to the outside with a violent extension.
Iam enim redit ad locum suum.	For now it is returning to its place.
Et haec species est facilioris reliquis speciebus curationis, qua reducitur hoc membrum.	And this kind of treatment is simpler than the other kinds of cures in which this member is reduced.
Si autem excusatur super te, et non obedit tibi ad introitum cum hac specie curationis omnino: tunc oportet, ut ligentur duo pedes infirmi simul cum ligamento forti, leni, super duos calcaneos, et super duo genua: et sit longitudo cuiusque a compare suo quantitatis quatuor digitorum: et sit crus infirmum extensum plus altero quantitate duorum digitorum.	But if it is lifted above you and does not obey you for entering with this kind of treatment entirely: then it is necessary that the two feet of the sick person be bound together at once with a strong, gentle bandage, over the two heel bones, and over the two knees; and let the length of each one from its own comparison be four finger's breadth in quantity; and let the sick leg be extended more than the other by the quantity of two fingers.
Deinde suspendatur infirmus super caput ligni, quod sit in domo: et sit longitudo eius a terra quantitas duorum brachiorum.	Then the sick person should be suspended over a wooden beam in his house; and let its length from the ground be two arm's breadth.
Deinde praecipe iuueni forti, ut muniat caput coxae: et suspendatur cum infirmo inuenis alius: et impellat iuuenis alius, muniens coxam cum fortitudine, nam iunctura redit ad locum suum cum uelocitate.	Then command a strong youth to protect the head and pelvis of the patient: and let another young man support him; and let another youth push with all his strength, protecting the hip with force, for the joint returns to its place quickly.
In reditione autem eius propria, quando est dislocatio ad exteriora, oportet, ut iaceat infirmus super podium, secundum quod narrauimus in habente gibbositatem.	But if it is his own reduction and there is a dislocation to the outside, it is necessary that the patient lie on a platform, just as we have said about one having a hump.
Et stringatur ligamentum super crus eius, infirmum proprie, et super pectus eius.	And let the youth stretch the ligament over his own weak leg and over his chest.
Deinde ponantur duo ligna, unum apud pedes eius, et alterum apud caput ipsius.	Then two sticks are placed, one by his feet and the other by his head.
Deinde ponatur lignum additum in medio podii, fixum bene: super quod inuoluti sint panni humidi, ut non laedat infirmum: et sit lignum inter coxas eius, ut non attrahatur ad inferiora apud extensionem.	Then a stick is placed in the middle of the platform, firmly fixed: over which damp cloths are wrapped, so that the patient is not hurt; and let the stick be between his hips, so that he does not bend down at extension.
Deinde extendat omnis minister ad partem suam, et medicus aequet reductionem manu sua.	Then the attendants stretch out in their direction, and the doctor adjusts the reduction with his own hand.
Si ergo obedit ad reuersionem, erit bonum.	If then it submits to reduction, it will be good.
Et si non, pone super ipsam tabulam, et preme ipsam, sicut diximus in gibbositate, aequaliter.	And if not, place over it a board, and press down upon it, just as we said about a hump, equally.
Verumtamen oportet, ut iaceat infirmus super latus suum sanum.	However, it is necessary that the patient lie on his healthy side.
Et quando dislocatio est ad anteriora, tunc oportet, ut extendatur crus infirmi uelociter: et est secundum hanc eandem narrationem super podium: et ponat medicus palmam manus suae dextrae super inguen infirmum.	And when the dislocation is to the front, then it is necessary that the weak leg be stretched quickly; and this is according to the same account on a platform: and the doctor places the palm of his right hand over the groin of the patient.
Deinde coartet ipsum cum manu altera, et cum illa coartatione pone ipsum extensum ad inferiora ad partem genu.	Then he compresses it with the other hand, and with that compression place him extended to the lower part towards the knee.
Et si dislocatio est ad posteriora: tunc non oportet, ut extendatur infirmus ad inferiora, et sit eleuatus super terram: imo oportet, ut sit positus super rem duram, sicut oportet, ut fit etiam si dislocatur ancha eius ad exteriora, secundum illud quod diximus de accubitu eius super duas anchas: et est super faciem eius, et ligamenta extensa: secundum quod diximus nuper.	And if the dislocation is to the back: then it is not necessary that the patient be extended downwards, and be lifted up from the earth; nay, it is necessary that he be placed on a hard surface, just as it also has to be done if his thigh bone is dislocated outwards, according to what we said about his lying on two thighs: and it is over his face, and stretched ligaments: just as we said recently.
Et oportet, ut administretur compressio cum tabula etiam super locum ad quem egreditur iunctura, cum completur reductio secundum quod oportet.	And it is necessary that a compression be administered with a board even over the place to which the joint protrudes, when reduction is completed as is fitting.
Et signum reditionis eius non occultatur tibi: et est, ut extendas duo crura infirmi: et quando uides ea aequalia, et infirmus stringit crus suum, et expandit ipsum absque excusatione: tunc scias, quia iam redit membrum, secundum quod oportet: tunc coniunge duas coxas, et pone emplastrum, et stringe cum imemati, id est, rota: ita, ut non moueatur ancha ad aliquam partium: et adhaereat infirmus quieti tribus diebus, aut quatuor.	And the sign of its return is not hidden from you: and it is, that you stretch out the two legs of the weak one: and when you see them equal, and the weak one tightens his leg and expands it without excuse: then know that the limb has already returned as is fitting: then join together the two thighs, and apply a poultice, and bind with a bandage, that is, a spiral: so that the joint does not move to any part: and let the weak one rest quietly for three days, or four.
Deinde solue ligamentum, et emplastrum, et compara crus cum altero: tunc si uides ea aequalia in statu, tunc scias, quod dislocatio iam firmata est: absolue ergo infirmum ad ambulandum.	Then dissolve the bandage and poultice, and compare the leg with the other: then if you see them equal in state, then know that the dislocation is already fixed: so release the weak one to walk.
Et si uides aliquid mollificationis: tunc redi, et emplastra illud, et stringe illud secundum stricturam tuam primam: et dimitte illud etiam tribus diebus.	And if you see something of softening: then return and apply a poultice to it, and bind it according to your first stricture: and leave it even for three days.
Deinde solue illud et fac ipsum tardare in ambulatione super utrumque aliquot diebus, donec confortetur bene.	Then dissolve that and make it delay in walking on both sides for some days, until it is comforted well.
¶ De dislocationis Genu.	¶ On the Dislocation of the Knee.
Caput XXXIII.	Chapter 33.
Genu dislocatur secundum tres modos.	The knee is dislocated in three ways.
Dislocatur ad exteriora, ad interiora, et ad inferiora, scilicet ad posteriora.	It is dislocated towards the outside, towards the inside, and towards the lower part, that is, towards the back.
Et non dislocatur ad anteriora.	And it does not become dislocated towards the front.
Et signum dislocationis eius, est, ut praecipias infirmo, ut applicet crus suum ad coxam suam.	And the sign of its dislocation is that you order the patient to place his leg against his hip.
Si autem non adhaeret cum coxa: tunc scias, quod Genu est dislocatum.	But if it does not adhere with the hip then know that the knee is dislocated.
Et restauratio omnium modorum dislocationis eius est, ut facias sedere infirmum rectum, ita ut iam extendat crus suum si potest super illud, et adhaeret dorsum tuum ad faciem eius: et pone pedem eius inter pedes tuos.	And the restoration of all modes of its dislocation is that you make the patient sit up straight, so that he can already stretch out his leg if he can over it, and attach your back to his face: and place his foot between your feet.
Deinde adhaerere fac Genu eius cum palmis tuis, et recta eas inter digitos tuos super Genu eius.	Then bind his knee with your palms and place them straight between your fingers over his knee.
Deinde applica cum palma tua duo latera Genu eius cum fortitudine.	Then apply both sides of his knee with the flat of your hand with force.
Et minister alius extendat pedem eius, donec redeat Genu ad locum suum.	And let another attend to stretch out his foot until his knee comes back to its place.
Et signum reditionis est, ut adhaereat crus cum coxa in lenitate, non laboriose.	And the sign of recovery is, that the thigh adhere with the hip in calmness, not painfully.
Deinde emplastra ipsum, et adhaerere fac crus cum coxa.	Then apply a poultice to him and bind his thigh with his hip.
Deinde liga ea simul cum uitta tribus diebus, aut quatuor.	Then bind them together with a bandage for three days or four.
Deinde solue ea.	Then loosen them.
Et non utatur infirmus ambulatione aliquot diebus, donec sanetur.	And the sick person should not walk for a few days until he is healed.
Si autem recusatur tibi reductio eius, tunc administra extensionem fortem cum ligamentis, quorum praecessit narratio in curatione anchae, donec redeat.	But if his return to place is refused to you, then apply a strong extension with bands of which the preceding narration was spoken in the cure of the knee, until it returns.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Calcanei.	The treatment for the cure of dislocated calcaneus.
Caput XXXIIII.	Chapter 32.
Calcaneus quandoque remouetur remotione parua, et quandoque dislocatur secundum complementum.	The heel is sometimes removed with a small displacement, and sometimes it becomes dislocated according to its completion.
Et dislocatio eius fit, aut ad interiora, aut ad exteriora.	And its dislocation occurs either towards the inside or towards the outside.
Et signum dislocationis eius est, quod uides Calcaneum inflatum, procedentem ad partem ad quam dislocatur.	And the sign of its dislocation is, that you see the heel swollen, proceeding to the side towards which it is dislocated.
Curatio autem remotionis eius, est facilis reditionis: et est, ut extendatur cum facilitate cum manibus, et aequetur, donec redeat.	But the cure of its removal is easy return: and it is, that he be extended with ease by hand, and adjusted, until it returns.
In curatione autem eius quando dislocatur secundum complementum, oportet, ut facias sedere infirmum rectum: et teneat ipsum minister fortis ualde a posteriori parte dorsi eius, in medio ipsius.	But in its cure when it is dislocated according to completion, it is necessary that you make the sick person sit upright: and have a strong attendant hold him from behind his back, at the midpoint of himself.
Deinde tene tu cum manu tua dextra pedem eius a superiori parte eius, et cum manu tua sinistra ab inferiori parte pedis eius loco cauillae.	Then take hold with your right hand his foot from the upper part of it, and with your left hand from the lower part of his foot at the place of the heel.
Deinde trahe pedem ad tecum manu tua dextra.	Then pull the foot towards you with your right hand.
Deinde cum sinistra duabus uicibus.	Then with the left hand two fingers.
Deinde extende cum sinistra, et impelle pectus pedis cum dextra uersus crus absque labore.	Then stretch out with the left hand and push the foot's chest with the right hand towards the knee without effort.
Fac illud bis, sicut narrauimus.	Do that twice as we have described.
Deinde impelle pectus pedis ad crus in uice tertia, et tu trahis cauillam.	Then push the foot's chest to the knee for a third time, and you draw out the bandage.
Si ergo redit in uice una, aut in duabus secundum hunc modum, et uides pedem aequatum, est bonum: et si non, tunc itera operationem super ipsum: quoniam ipse redit.	If therefore it returns in one way, or in two ways according to this method, and you see the foot equalized, it is good; and if not, then repeat the procedure on it, since it will return.
Si autem prohibetur tibi reductio eius cum eo quod narrauimus: tunc fac iacere infirmum super dorsum suum super terram, et fige paxillum in terra firmatum ualde, ut cadat inter coxas eius: et tu iam inuoluisti super ipsum pannum, ut non laedat infirmum.	But if reduction is prevented from happening as we have described, then make the patient lie on his back on the ground and place a sturdy peg into the earth so that it falls between his thighs: and you meanwhile have wrapped a cloth over him so that the patient will not be hurt.
Deinde accipiat minister coxam eius: postea extendat minister alter pedem, aut cum manibus suis, aut cum ligamento quod liget super collum pedis.	Then let the attendant take hold of his thigh; afterwards let the attendant straighten out another foot, or with his hands, or with a bandage that ties over the ankle of the foot.
Deinde extendat omnis minister contra extensionem comparis sui: et paxillus sit stans inter duas coxas infirmi retinens eum, ut non attrahatur corpus eius ad inferiora apud extensionem.	Then let the attendant stretch himself against the stretching of his own limb; and the peg shall be standing between the two thighs of the sick man holding him so that his body is not pulled towards the lower parts during the stretching.
Deinde aequet medicus dislocationem manibus suis, et minister alter teneat crus sanum ad inferiora.	Then let the doctor equalize the dislocation with his hands and the attendant shall hold the healthy leg at the lower part.
Nam dislocatio redit cum uelocitate.	For the dislocation returns quickly.
Quando ergo redit dislocatio, et declaratur tibi sanitas reditionis eius: tunc pone emplastrum et stuppam, et stringe ipsam cum ligamentis firmiter, et liga pedem cum ligamento ad crus.	For when the dislocation returns and your treatment is declared successful: then apply a plaster and stuffing, and bind it firmly with bandages, and tie the foot with a bandage to the leg.
Et oportet, ut caueas uel timeas de neruis, qui sunt supra calcaneum posterius, ut non sit ligamentum super eos uehemens, et laedat eos.	And you must beware or be afraid of the nerves which are above the posterior calcaneum, so that the bandage is not very tight over them and hurts them.
Deinde dimitte ipsum duobus diebus, aut tribus.	Then let it go for two days, or three.
Quod si mollificatur ligamentum, stringe ipsum: deinde solue ipsum in die tertio, aut quarto: et prohibe infirmum ab ambulatione quadraginta diebus.	And if the bandage becomes loosened, tie it again; afterwards untie it on the third day, or fourth: and forbid the sick person from walking for forty days.
Si uero conatur ambulare ante illud spacium, non fit securitas quin dissoluatur super ipsum dislocatio, et corrumpatur, et non recipiat post illud curationem.	If indeed he is able to walk before that space of time, no security is created lest a dislocation be dissolved over him, and be corrupted, and not receive cure after that.
Quod si accidat ei apostema calidum: tunc oportet, ut administres in sedatione eius illud, in quo praecessit narratio nostra in alio loco ex curatione, et embrocationem, donec remoueatur.	If it happens to him that a hot aposteme forms: then it is necessary for you to administer to him on his seat the thing of which our story went before in another place concerning treatment and anointing until it is removed.
¶ De dislocatione Digitorum pedis, et cura.	On the dislocation of the fingers of the foot, and its cure.
Caput XXXV.	Chapter 35.
Oportet, ut aequetur quod dislocatur ex eis cum extensione pauca absque labore: et illud quidem non est difficile, imo est facile.	It is necessary for him to be aligned with what has been dislocated from them with a few extensions without effort; and indeed that is not difficult, nay rather easy.
Si autem dislocatio est in quibusdam nodis dorsi pedis: tunc oportet, ut faciat sedere infirmus pedem suum super locum aequalem terrae, aut super tabulam: et est stans sicut ambulans.	But if the dislocation is in certain knots of the foot or heel: then it is necessary for the patient to sit down his foot on a place level with the earth, or on a board: and he stands as one walking.
Deinde tu sta, et pone pedem tuum super illud quod eminet ex illis iuncturis.	Then you stand, and put your foot on that which protrudes from those joints.
Deinde calca illud cum pede tuo cum uirtute, donec redeat, et uideas ipsum iam aequatum, et non appareat in loco eminentia.	Then step on it with your foot with force until it returns and you see the joint itself now aligned, and no longer appears to protrude.
Deinde pone sub uentre pedis eius tabulam quae capiat pedem totum, cui sint duo capita.	Then place under his foot a board that takes up the whole foot with two ends.
Deinde stringe ipsum strictura decenti tribus diebus.	Then bind it with a suitable bandage for three days.
Deinde solue ipsum, et fac quiescere eum ab ambulatione diebus multis, donec stringatur et securetur a reductione.	Then loosen it and make him rest from walking for many days until it is bound and secured from slipping back into dislocation.
¶ De speciebus dislocationis cum uulnere uel fractura.	On the kinds of dislocations with a wound or fracture.
Caput XXXVI.	Chapter 36.
Quando accidit aliquid ex illo, et conaris curationem eius, et ipsius restaurationem, multotiens succedit mors: et propter illud non oportet, ut praesumat super curationem eius, quod est huiusmodi, nisi qui est prudens in arte longi usus, misericors, pius, tardus, non audax, neque praesumptuosus: et ut utatur in incaeptionce medicinis quae sedant apostemata calida tantum: et dimittat infirmum diuino iudicio.	When something happens from that and you are attempting its cure and restoration, death often ensues; and on account of this it is not to be presumed over its cure, which is of this kind, except by one who is wise in the art through long practice, merciful, pious, slow, not rash or presumptuous: and that he should make use of medicinal remedies which calm hot apostemes only; and let the patient be released according to divine judgment.
Nisi uideas, aut speras salutem a perditione cum lenitate aegritudinis, et in quo apparet quiddam spei.	Unless you know, or hope for salvation from perdition with gentleness of the affliction, and where something appears that gives hope.
Conare ergo reductionem eius statim in principio rei, antequam accidat apostema calidum.	Therefore be able to reduce it at once in the beginning of the thing, before a warm abscess occurs.
Si ergo redit membrum, secundum quod uolumus, tunc administra regimen quod sedat apostema: et cura uulnus cum eo quod conuenit ei ex unguentis desiccatiuis.	So if the member returns, as we wish, then administer a regimen that will calm the abscess; and care for the wound with it that is suitable to it from dry ointments.
Quod si dislocatio est cum fractura, et accidunt in osse satagiae separatae, tunc conare ablationem earum, et fac in illo quod diximus in aegritudinibus simplicibus ex eo quod praecessit in locis earum.	Which if the dislocation is with fracture, and happens in bones separated from each other, then try to remove them, and do in that what we said about simple afflictions from what preceded in their places.
Et caue secundum tuam uirtutem, et custodi teipsum ab introitu in uiam timoris: secundum quod praecessit praedicatio mea tibi.	And beware according to your power, and guard yourself from entering the way of fear: according to what my preceding warning has been to you.
Nam illud est melius tibi apud Creatorem tuum, et magis permanens ad gloriam tuam, et magis saluum tuo corpori apud illos in tuo tempore.	For it is better for you with your Creator, and more lasting to your glory, and safer to your body among them at your time.
